Wang Chongmin notes that the *Zhuangzi*’s *Renjian Shi* chapter reads *‘kill’* as *‘killers’*—this should be followed. *Thus* here functions as *therefore* (see *Jingzhuan Shici*). This means that though tigers differ from humans, their fawning upon their keepers stems from having their nature obeyed, while their bloodlust arises from having it defied. Wang Shu-min suggests the original text may have read *‘Thus those who kill them do so through defiance.’* The current version omits *‘those’*, while the *Zhuangzi* omits *‘them’*—neither is complete. However, Guo Pu’s commentary already reflects this meaning, so his edition must have been uncorrupted.

Then how could I dare oppose them and provoke their anger? Yet neither do I obey them to elicit their joy. For joy inevitably gives way to anger, and anger to joy—both miss the mark. As the commentary notes: *Deviating from the mean, extremes inevitably reverse—this is the natural order.*

Now, my heart harbors neither opposition nor compliance, so birds and beasts regard me as one of their own. Thus, those that roam my garden do not long for lofty forests or vast marshes. As the *Shiwen* records, *‘vast marshes’* is also written *‘expansive marshes’*. Ren Dachun notes: The *Zuozhuan*’s twenty-eighth year of Duke Zhuang reads *‘guangmo’* (广莫), with the commentary glossing it as *‘a desolate expanse’*. The *Xunzi*’s *Jiebi* chapter reads *‘then how could it be vast enough to overcome it?’*, with Yang Liang noting *‘vast’* may be read as *‘desolate’*. The *Wangba* chapter reads *‘why not make it vast?’*, with Yang Liang again noting *‘vast’* may be read as *‘desolate’*. The *Hanshu*’s *Wu Wuzhi Zhuan* reads *‘how boundless is the art of deception!’*, with Su Lin glossing *‘boundless’* as *‘desolate’*. Thus, *vast* and *desolate* are interchangeable.

Those that rest in my courtyard do not yearn for deep mountains or secluded valleys—this is the principle at work. As the commentary notes: *The sage’s way of nurturing all beings, allowing each to fulfill its nature, is like a trainer’s skill in raising animals without letting them harm one another.*

The *Exegesis* states: *Though forms and substances differ, their spirit and qi are not distinct. Thus, the Zhuangzi says: ‘Viewed in their differences, liver and gallbladder are as distant as Chu and Yue; viewed in their sameness, the myriad things are one body.’ The perfected person unites with them in spirit, so that birds do not scatter in flight and beasts do not disperse in herds—opposition and compliance share the same intent without conflict. Hence, fierce beasts can be tamed, and gulls can be befriended. Birds and beasts retreat to deep mountains and secluded valleys to preserve themselves, far from human harm. But if no threat exists, then what difference is there between gardens and forests?*

Yan Hui asked Confucius: *"I once crossed the Goblet Depths, where the ferryman handled the boat as if by magic."* Sun Yirang notes: The *Shuowen*’s *Water* section defines *jin* (津) as *‘a river crossing’*; *jinren* likely refers to the officials or soldiers in charge of ferries. The *Zuozhuan*’s twenty-fourth year of Duke Zhao records: *"Prince Chao used the treasured jades of Chengzhou to sacrifice to the Yellow River. On the jiayin day, a ferryman retrieved them from the river."* Liu Xiang’s *Lienü Zhuan*’s *Biantong* chapter mentions *"Zhao Jinjuan, the daughter of a ferry official of Zhao."* The *Shiwen* reads *cao* (操) as *qī dāo*; the same below.

*"I asked him, ‘Can one learn to handle a boat?’ He replied, ‘Yes. Those who can swim can be taught. Those skilled in swimming often succeed.’"* As Xiang Xiu comments: *Their skill comes naturally—this means their method ensures they are unafraid of boats.* The *Shiwen* records *‘unafraid of boats’* as *‘seizing boats’*, noting *shu* (数) is read *sè jù*, meaning *‘method’*; the commentary concurs.

"Zhuó (擢) is pronounced *zhí xiào*; in one version, it is written as *jù* (惧), likely a miswriting of the character. Bo Jun notes: Originally, it was *‘zhuó zhōu’* (擢舟); *zhuó* was mistakenly written as *jù* (惧), and some meddler further added the character *bù* (不). Jing Shun’s edition already shows the error of *jù* (惧), though it had not yet added *bù* (不).

As for the diver, one who has never seen a boat yet rises to handle it—"

**[Annotation]**
*Sù* (谡) means *to rise*.
Xiang Xiu says: *This refers to one skilled in diving.*
**[Note]**
The character *wù* (鹜) in the annotation appears as *jīn* (矜) in the Northern Song edition; Wang’s edition follows this, but the present text corrects it according to the *Zang* edition. Additionally, the *Sijie* edition appends the three characters *‘wù yīn mù’* (鹜音木) at the end of the annotation.
Zeng Guangyuan says: In Chu dialect, foolishness is called *sōng tóu sōng nǎo* (倯头倯脑), akin to the Northern term *tóu nǎo* (头脑). In Chu, *sōng* (倯) is also called *sù* (谡). *Liezi* states that one who has never seen a boat yet *sù* (谡) operates it—*sù* here means *to act thus*.
**[Shiwen]**
*Sù* (谡) is pronounced *suǒ liù*; *Zhuangzi* writes it as *biàn* (便). *Wù* (鹜) is pronounced *mù*, meaning *duck*. In one version, it is written as *jīn* (矜), an erroneous character.

"I asked again, but received no answer. May I dare ask what this means?"

[Solution]
One who skillfully steers a boat can learn it; one who skillfully swims and floats has practiced it in sequence. As for the diver who has never seen a boat yet masters it, this is a matter of spiritual communion—others cannot comprehend it.

Confucius said: “Ah! *Yi*!” [Shiwen] *Yi* (□) is pronounced *yī*, identical to *yī* (□), an exclamatory sound. Hu Huaichen says: *Yi* (□) is the same as *yī* (噫). “You and I have long studied its text,” [Shiwen] *Wan* (玩) is pronounced *wǔ guàn*, meaning “to practice.” “yet have not grasped its reality, and thus merely discourse on the Dao.”

[Annotation]
Observing that boat-handling can be learned is merely studying its text; failing to realize that divers inherently possess the ability is not yet attaining its reality. Now I shall explain it to you. Tao Hongqing says: Zhang’s annotation, “boat-handling can be learned,” is entirely mistaken. Confucius’s meaning is that you and I have only practiced the text of principles without ever verifying them in reality, and thus fundamentally cannot comprehend the Dao. The following passage—“Master Huzi said, ‘You and I have not yet exhausted its text and reality, yet fundamentally grasp the Dao’”—with Xiang Xiu’s annotation, “Reality is revealed through text, and the Dao is manifested through affairs,” precisely captures its intent. It is suspected that *qie* (且) here should also be *de* (得); the lower half of the ancient character was damaged, leading to its misreading as *qie*. [Shiwen] *Yu* (与) is pronounced *yú*. *Wei* (为) is pronounced *yú wěi*.

One who can swim may be taught—this is due to their lightness in water. One who excels at swimming does so through technique, for they have forgotten the water. [Annotation] To forget the water is to be free of pride or fear. Lu Wenchang says: The *Zang* edition of the annotation reads, “One who forgets the water is then free of pride or fear.” Tao Hongqing says: After “one who can swim,” there should also be a *zhi* (之).

As for the diver who has never seen a boat yet acts thus in steering it, to him the abyss appears as a mound, and a capsized boat seems no different from a cart rolling backward. The overturning and retreat of the myriad things lie arrayed before him, yet none can enter his dwelling. [Annotation] This is called the dwelling of spirit. Lu Wenchang says: The *Zang* edition of the annotation reads, “This is the dwelling of spirit, thus it is called *she* (舍).” Yu Yue says: *Fang* (方) means “together.” The original meaning of *fang* is two boats side by side, hence it carries the sense of “together.” In the *Xunzi*’s “Zhi Shi” chapter, “None fail to clearly understand and rise together in pursuit of utmost perfection,” Yang’s annotation says: “Fangqi (方起) means to rise together.” In the *Han Shu*’s “Yang Xiong Zhuan,” “Though together they journey with Qiao and Woquan,” Yan Shigu’s annotation says: “Fang means to travel side by side.” Both serve as evidence. *Fang chen hu qian* (方陈乎前) means the myriad things lie arrayed together before him. Xi Diao says: Yu’s interpretation is incorrect. In the *Yi Jing*’s *Heng* hexagram, “The noble person establishes without changing *fang*.” Wang Bi’s annotation says: “*Fang* means the Dao.” *Fuque* (覆却) follows the above analogy of boats and carts; *fuque wan fang* (覆却万方) refers to the many ways in which boats and carts overturn and retreat. The *Liezi*’s “Huangdi” chapter adds the character *wu* (物), but the *Zhuangzi* does not.

Where could he not find leisure? [Annotation] All he encounters is leisure. [Shiwen] *Wu* (恶) is pronounced *wū*. *Jian* (间) is pronounced *xián*.

Those who play with clay tiles are skillful—*Shiwen* notes: "*Kou* (抠) means to probe; using the hand to conceal an object and probe to retrieve it is called *kou*, also termed *cangkou* (藏彄)." *Fengtu Ji* states: "After the sacrificial drinking on the La day, elders and children play the game of *kou*." Xin’s *San Qin Ji* records: "Lady Gouyi of Han had clenched fists, and people of the time imitated her, thus naming it *canggou* (藏钩)." *Kou* (彄) is pronounced *kou* (口侯切), and *Zhuangzi* writes it as *kou* (抠). Qin Enfu says: "In the current edition of *Zhuangzi*, *kou* is written as *zhu* (注)."

Those who play with hooks are cautious—*Shiwen* notes: "Hooks are made of silver or bronze." *Dan* (惮) is pronounced *dàn* (待汗切).

Those who play with gold are confused. [Annotation] The act of mutual concealment is called *kou*. Guo Xiang says: "The heavier the stake, the more the mind clings." The annotation’s "曰" in the *Shide Tang* edition is written as "者," which is incorrect; the present version follows the *Zang* edition. Shen Chiran says: "*Zhuangzi*’s *Das Sheng* chapter borrows this passage but changes *kou* to *zhu* (注)." Note: *Tou* (投) means *kou*; shooting to wager is called *zhu* (注). Bo Jun notes: "My teacher, Master Wu Jianzai, says: *Zhuangzi* writes *zhu* (注), *Lüshi Chunqiu* writes *zhu* (殶), and *Huainanzi* writes *zhu* (鉒), all phonetically similar, likely referring to the name of a winning tally in gambling." *Huainanzi*’s annotation states: "*Zhu* (鉒) means *tima* (提马), the 'horse' set up for the victor in *touhu* (投壶)." Today, local customs call the gambling tally *zhuma* (注马), a vestige of this term. *Liezi* writes *kou* (抠), treating it as the character for *cangkou* (藏彄), with a distinct meaning. *Shiwen* writes *hun* (惛) as *hun* (殙), noting: "*Hun* is pronounced *hūn*." *Fangyan* says: "Confusion is *hun*." *Yao* (要) is pronounced *yáo* (于遥切). *Yu* (愈) is pronounced *yǔ* (庾), meaning "to increase."

Skill is one—Xu Weiyu says: "The character *qi* (其) is likely missing before *qiao* (巧)." *Zhuangzi*’s *Das Sheng* chapter writes, "Their skill is one," and *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Qu You* chapter writes, "Their auspice is one," both including the character *qi* (其) as evidence.

Yet when one clings, it is an attachment to externals. All who cling to externals are clumsy within. [Annotation] Only by forgetting both internal and external, relinquishing light and heavy, can one transcend skill and clumsiness.

[Exegesis] Observing the boatman reveals what may be learned, for one savors the text. But if one grasps its truth, then he regards water as land, and capsizing or drowning does not enter his mind—where could he not find leisure? Those who wager with tiles see only their skill in hitting the mark and do not fear losing the tile; if they wager with hooks, they are no longer solely focused on skill but also dread the clumsiness of losing the hook; if they wager with gold, they dare not hope to hit the mark, only fearing the loss of gold. Thus, one sees that the former marvel forgot external things, while the latter fears and clings to them. People of this age know the dual loss of clinging to externals yet covet things to the point of forfeiting their lives.

"Clumsy" (*zhuo*, 拙) in the Northern Song edition is written as *quan* (撰), which Wang’s edition follows; other editions write *gong* (拱). Lu Wenchang says: "*Gong* (拱) in the *Zang* edition is *zhuo* (拙), which is correct." The present version follows it. *Zhuangzi* also writes *zhuo* (拙). *Gong* (拱) and *zhuo* (拙) are graphically similar, hence the error. *Shiwen* writes *zhuo* (拙) as *gong* (拱), noting: "*Gong* is originally *zhuo*."

Confucius observed at Lüliang—Zhuang Kuiji says: There are two accounts of Lüliang. One places it in the West River. Sima Biao says: "Lüliang is west of Lishi County." *Shui Jing Zhu* states: "The river converges with a stream emerging eighty *li* southwest of the old city of Shanwu County. The water flows west, passing through the Lüliang Mountains, forming the Lüliang Rapids. Before Lüliang was opened, the river emerged above Mengmen. This was likely the passage Yu the Great opened to channel the river. Today, following the river west from Lishi County, there are no passes until reaching this point, where it becomes a great peril—this is Lüliang. It lies over a hundred *li* northeast of Lishi." (Bo Jun’s note: The original text of *Shui Jing Zhu* ends here; as this is an abridged citation, no quotation marks are added. The phrase "over a hundred *li* northeast" originally reads "over two hundred *li* northeast," likely a minor error.)

Another account places it in Pengcheng. Yu Zhengxie says: The *Shuo Fu* chapter states, "Confucius returned from Wei to Lu, rested his carriage at the river bridge, and observed it," which is the same event. *Zhuangzi*’s *Das Sheng* chapter refers to the river bridge as the place Confucius observed. *Shiwen* cites Sima Biao: "Where the river is cut by rocks, now in the west of Lishi in the West River, there is such a precipitous place, commonly called Huangliang." *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Ai Lei* chapter says, "Lüliang was not yet opened," and Gao You’s annotation states: "In Lü County of Pengcheng, a great stone lies in the water, which Yu opened to clear the way." *Huainanzi*’s *Ben Jing* chapter says, "Lüliang was not yet opened," and its annotation also states: "In Pengcheng." Note: The four texts describe two different Lüliangs. The *Zhuangzi* and *Liezi* passages refer to Pengcheng, while *Lüshi Chunqiu* and *Huainanzi* place Lüliang in Lishi. The ancient annotations are thus confused.

*Shui Jing Zhu* cites Confucius’s observation in its account of the Si River and Lü’s text and Sima’s account in its account of the Yellow River, which is truly comprehensive. *Zhuangzi*’s *Shiwen* states: "Northerners call all waters *he* (河)." Thus, the Si River may also be called *he*. *Han Shu*’s *Gou Xu Zhi* states: "Yu split two channels; later, during the Three Dynasties, a canal was dug from the river southeast of Xingyang to form the Honggou, connecting Song, Wei, Chen, Cai, Cao, and Zheng, and meeting the Ji, Ru, Huai, and Si in Chu." The Si River’s bridge is thus rightly called a river bridge. Liu Fengshi of Song, in his collation of *Han Shu*, mistakenly deemed this an error. Some claim the Si River’s Lüliang originated in the Tang. *Dushi Fangyu Jiyao* states it existed in the Jin and Song dynasties, but such claims are imprecise.

*Zhuangzi*’s *Shiwen* states: "Lüliang is in present-day Pengcheng Prefecture." *Erya* says: "Where rocks obstruct the water is called a *liang* (weir)." The suspended water falls thirty *ren*, though *Wen Xuan*’s note to Xie Lingyun’s *Returning to My Old Garden and Seeing Ministers Yan and Fan* quotes this as "forty *ren*." *Shuo Yuan*’s *Za Yan* chapter concurs. The torrent’s foam extends thirty *li*, where soft-shelled turtles, alligators, fish, and turtles cannot swim. Yet I saw a man swimming there. Taking him for one in distress seeking death, I had my disciples follow the current to rescue him. *Shiwen* notes: *bing* (并) is pronounced *pang* (傍). *Records of the Grand Historian* and *Han Shu* write *panghai* (傍海) and *panghe* (傍河) as *binghai* (并海) and *binghe* (并河). *Cheng* (承) is pronounced *zheng* (拯); *Fangyan* defines *cheng* as "to pull one from drowning." Some texts simply write *zheng* (拯), while others use *zheng* (撜).

After several hundred paces, he emerged, hair unbound, singing as he swam through the *tang* (pond). [Note: *Tang* (棠) should be *tang* (塘), and *xing* (行) should be *xia* (下). The *Sijie* edition writes *tangxia* (塘下), likely following the note’s correction.] *Shiwen* states: *tang* (棠) is pronounced *tang* (塘), and the same applies below.

Confucius approached and asked him, "At Lüliang, the water falls thirty *ren*, its foam stretches thirty *li*, where even soft-shelled turtles and alligators cannot swim—yet I saw you tread there. [Note: *Dao* (道) should be *dao* (蹈). The *Sijie* edition writes *dao* (蹈), following Zhang’s note. *Shiwen* reads *dao* (道) as *dao* (导), and the same applies below. Guo Pu’s note to *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* says *dao* (道) means "to follow." Mr. Bo Jun observes: *Dao* (道) should be corrected to *dao* (蹈), as the later phrase *qing wen dao shui you dao hu* (请问蹈水有道乎) uses *dao* (蹈), confirming this. Though *Shiwen*’s reading as *dao* (导) is plausible, Zhang’s note is closer to the mark.] I thought you were in distress, seeking death, so I had my disciples follow the current to rescue you. You emerged, hair unbound, singing—at first, I took you for a ghost. But seeing you are a man, may I ask if there is a Way to treading water?"

The man replied, "No. [Note: *Shiwen* reads *wang* (亡) as *wu* (无); the original text lacks this *wang* (亡).] I have no Way. I begin with what is familiar, grow with my nature, and complete it through fate. I enter with the *qi* and emerge with the *gu*." [Note: *Qi* (赍) and *gu* (汨) describe the water’s swirling entry and surging exit. *Shiwen* writes *qi* (赍) as *qi* (齐), citing Sima: "*Qi* (齐) is the swirling water like a mill’s wheel." *Gu* (汨) is pronounced *gu* (古忽切), meaning "surging waves." Guo Xiang says: "The swirling descent and surging rise are *gu* (汨)." Ren Dachun notes: The note says *qi* (赍) and *gu* (汨) describe the swirling entry and surging exit, matching Sima’s "swirling water like a mill’s wheel." *Shuowen* writes *qi* (□) as *□□*. *Yupian* writes *qi* (脐) as *□*. The current text’s *qi* (赍) is likely a corruption of *□*. Also, *hui shui hui fu* (洄水洄伏) in *Zhuangzi*’s *Da Sheng* chapter is written as *hui shui hui fu* (回水回伏) in *Shiwen*. *Hui* (回) means "to turn," while *hui* (洄) means "to flow against the current." *Shuowen*, *Yupian*, *Guangyun*, and *Leipian* all distinguish these two meanings. *Xunzi*’s *Zhi Shi* chapter says, "When water is deep, it *hui* (回)"; Yang Liang’s note: "*Hui* (回) means swirling flow. Deep water without rapids often swirls." *Huainanzi*’s *Ben Jing* chapter says, "*Xuan liu hui bo* (旋流回波)" and later, "*qu fu zhan hui yi xiang yu yu* (曲拂邅回以象湡语)." All swirling waters use *hui* (回), while *hui* (洄) refers to flowing against the current. *Wen Xuan*’s *Wu Du Fu* says, "*Su hui shun liu* (泝洄顺流)"; *Jiang Fu* says, "*Su hui yan liu* (泝洄沿流)"; Li Shan’s note cites the *Mao Zhuan*: "Flowing against the current is *hui* (洄)." *Shui Jing Zhu* says, "Yang Yi lived at *Shanghui* (上洄), Yang Yong at *Xiahui* (下洄)"; the water’s name *hui* (洄) distinguishes upstream and downstream, implying flowing against the current. *Hou Han Shu*’s *Ren Yan Zhuan* says, "Every ten *li*, a water gate was built to make the flow *hui* (洄)." Li Xian’s note cites *Erya*: "Flowing against the current is *hui* (洄)." Thus, *hui* (洄) and *hui* (回) have distinct meanings. However, *Erya*’s *Shi Shui* and *Shiwen* read *hui* (回) as *hui* (户恢反), also written as *hui* (洄). *Wen Xuan*’s *Qi Fa* says, "*Zhi shi ren hui an qi chuang yan* (直使人洄暗凄怆焉)"; Li Shan’s note: "*Hui* (洄) is the same as *hui* (回)." Thus, *hui* (回) and *hui* (洄) are also interchangeable. Hence, *Zhuangzi*’s *Shiwen* writes *hui* (回), while *Liezi*’s *Shiwen* writes *hui* (洄).] I follow the water’s Way without imposing my will—this is how I tread it."

Confucius asked, "What do you mean by beginning with what is familiar, growing with your nature, and completing it through fate?"

The man replied, "I was born on the hills and am at ease on the hills—this is what is familiar. [Note: *Gu* (故) means "what is inherent." Following one’s true nature means being at ease with whatever one encounters.] I grew up in the water and am at ease in the water—this is my nature. [Note: Following the principles of one’s nature means nothing opposes it.] Not knowing why I am so, yet being so—this is fate." [Note: The principle of spontaneity cannot be known through wisdom; recognizing its unknowability is called fate.]

[Exegesis] Being born on the hills and at ease on the hills, born in the water and at ease in the water—habit makes this natural. Thus, it is said: "beginning with what is familiar" and "growing with one’s nature." Accustomed to what is familiar and at ease with one’s nature, one suddenly attains spiritual accord, completing one’s fate without self-awareness. Hence, the *Yi* says, "Exhausting principle and fully realizing one’s nature leads to fate." Fate is harmony with the spiritual Way.

When Confucius traveled to Chu, he came upon a hunchback catching cicadas in the forest. [Note: The *Shide Tang* edition writes *lou* (偻) as *lou* (慺), or sometimes as *yu* (). Ren Dachun notes: *Shuowen* says, "*Lou* (偻) can mean *beilou* (背偻, hunchbacked)." *Tongsu Wen* says, "A bent spine is called *yulou* (伛偻)." *Huainanzi*’s *Jingshen Xun* says, "Zi Qiu was fifty-four and suffered from *yulou* (伛偻)."]

Yang Liang’s annotation reads, “*Lou* (偻) means a bent spine.” The *Dixing Xun* states, “Those people have faces and *lou* (末偻),” with Yang Liang’s annotation: “*Mo* (末) means the spine.” All glosses for a curved spine use *lou* (偻). The *Yupian* states: “*Lou* (慺) means reverent and respectful, not frivolous, or humble in demeanor—it carries no sense of a bent spine.”

It is said: *Ju* (痀) is pronounced *yu* (于禹切) in modern editions, but *lou* (偻) is mistakenly written as *lou* (慺). Bo Jun notes: Ren Dachun erroneously attributed Gao You’s annotation to Yang Liang.

The *Shiwen* reads “*cheng tiao* (承蜩)” as *cheng* (承), pronounced *zhiyao* (直遥切), and also *sheyin tiao* (涉音条), with an alternate version writing *tiao* (蜩), meaning “cicada.” Ren Dachun states: The *Guangyun* reads *lou* (偻) as *lü* (缕). *Julou* (痀偻) means a hunched-back ailment. Alternate forms include *chao* (晁) and *zhao* (朝).

The *Chuci*’s *Tianwen* asks, “Why did [X] delight in *buzhou* (不周)?” with *yao* (遥) pronounced *qie* (切), and *tiao* (条) as *tuliao* (徒聊切). *Chao* (晁) shares the pronunciation of *zhao* (朝, morning). The *Tianwen* also states, “They met at *chao* (晁),” with the *Maoshi* reading, “They met at dawn (*zhao*, 朝) when the skies were clear.” The *Shiji*’s later sections and the *Hanshu*’s *Zi Cuo Zhuan* read *chao* (晁) as *zhao* (朝), with *zhuyao* (竹遥) as the fanqie. Liu Bozhuang reads it as *chao* (潮).

The *Justice* states: In the *Qin Ji*, “*Shuzhang* (庶长) may correspond to *chao zhao* (晁朝),” with *chao* (潮) as a homophone. The *Shiwen* suggests that in antiquity, *chao* (朝) meant “light.” Based on these sources, the characters *wan* (琬) and *yan* (琰) are adopted.

Yan Shigu states: “*Yan* (匽) is also a cicada, though the reading need not be altered.” Consulting the *Shuowen*, it reads “*tiao* (蜩),” pronounced *tiao* (条), though the origin is unclear. *Zhuangzi* writes *cheng tiao* (承蜩), while here it is written as *cheng* (承), a name for the insect.

Further consulting the *Xia Xiaozheng*: “In the fifth month, the *tangtiao* (唐蜩) sings,” with Lu Bian’s annotation: “The *tangtiao* is *yan* (匽).” It is read like *zhao* (朝). Yang Xiong’s *Fangyan* states: “*Yan* (匽)...” Lu Ji’s *Caomu Chongyu Shu* notes: “The *tang* (螗) is a large, black cicada, also called *yan* (蝘).” The *Piya* states: “The *tang* (螗) is also called *yan* (蝘). The *Xia Xiaozheng*’s *tangtiao* (螗蜩) is the same as *yan* (匽) in the *Xia Xiaozheng*—that is, *yan* (蝘蝘).” Thus, the *Shuowen*’s *yan* (匽) is identical to *cheng* (承), derived from *min* (黾), just as *ying* (蝇) and *□* are derived from *min* (黾). This is *cheng* (承). Generally, creatures of the *min* (黾) family have pointed heads and large abdomens. Cicadas also have pointed heads and large abdomens, so *yan tiao* (匽蜩) need not alter its reading. It is akin to *duo* (掇).

The *Shiwen* states: *Duo* (掇) is pronounced *duokuo* (都括切), meaning “to gather or pluck.”

Confucius said: “How skillful you are! Is there a method to this?”

He replied: "I have my method. In the fifth or sixth month, if I stack two pellets and they do not fall, I lose only a trifling amount. [Note] Xiang Xiu said: Stacking two pellets without their falling demonstrates the steadiness of the hand. Thus, in catching cicadas, what is lost amounts to no more than a *zizhu* (a tiny weight). *Shiwen* writes *lei* (累) as *lei* (累), noting: *Lei* is the ancient form of *lei*. *Wan* is pronounced like *wan* (丸). Sima [Biao] said: It means stacking pellets on the tip of a pole. *Zizhu* is pronounced *zishu* (淄殊). *Tiao* is pronounced *diao* (调). If I stack three pellets and they do not fall, I lose one-tenth. If I stack five pellets and they do not fall, it is as effortless as plucking. [Note] With the hand perfectly steady, nothing is lost.

My stance is like a severed tree stump. [Note] Cui Zhuan said: *Juezhuju* (厥株驹) means a broken tree. *Shiwen* writes *juezhuju* (厥株驹) as *juezhuju* (厥株驹), noting: *Jue* is sometimes written as *jue* (橛), pronounced *qiyue* (其月切). The *Shuowen* writes it as *jue* (厥), meaning the base of a tree. Li Yi said: *Jue* means a stump. *Zhuju* also refers to the base of a withered tree. *Ju* is pronounced *ju* (俱). Cui Zhuan, whose courtesy name was Quan, was a native of Qinghe. He served as Gentleman of Discussion during the Jin dynasty and annotated the twenty-seven inner and outer chapters of the *Nanhua Zhenjing*. Ren Dachun said: Modern texts write it as *jue* (厥), which is interchangeable with *jue* (厥). The *Xunzi Dalu* states: "A harmonious jade disk is like the *jue* (厥) of a wellside." The new collated edition reads *jue* as *jue* (厥), meaning the jade is as cheap as a stump. This corroborates Jing Shun’s *Shiwen*, where *jue* (厥) is written as *jue* (厥). Further evidence comes from the *Lüshi Chunqiu*: "The mechanism of *yijue* (佁蹶)"—the commentary explains: "*Jueji* (蹶机) refers to the position inside a gate. The *Book of Songs* says, 'Not far from you, you see me off at the threshold'—this means no farther than the *jue* (厥)." Thus, *yijue* (佁蹶) is the same as the gate’s *jue* (厥). *Jue* (厥) is interchangeable with *jue* (厥) and also with *jue* (蹶). Additionally, *zhuju* (株驹) appears in the *Zhuangzi Dasheng* as *zhujou* (株拘). The *Shiwen* cites Li [Yi] as saying: "*Jue* (厥) means a stump, like *zhujou* (株拘)." The *Yilin* states: "Meng grows *zhuqu* (株瞿), thorns snag my beard." Since it mentions "Meng grows" and "thorns," these too are types of trees. *Zhuju* (株驹), *zhujou* (株拘), and *zhuqu* (株瞿) are all phonetic variations of the same term. Further evidence comes from the *Shanhai Jing*: "Below are the Nine *Ju* (拘)"—the commentary explains: "Their roots are tangled." The *Huainanzi* says: "Great roots are *jue* (擢)." Pronounced *qu* (劬). Thus, *ju* (驹), *ju* (拘), *qu* (瞿), *ju* (枸), and *□* all carry the meaning of a tree’s tangled base.

My arm is like the branch of a withered tree. Wang Shumin said: There should be a *ye* (也) after "I grasp my arm," to match the structure of the preceding sentence. The *Zhuangzi Dasheng* indeed includes *ye* (也). Though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things are numerous, I am aware only of the cicada’s wings. I do not turn or shift my focus; I do not exchange the cicada’s wings for the myriad things. How could I fail to succeed?"

[Note] Guo Xiang said: By relinquishing that, one attains this.
[Explanation] Initially, when learning to stack pellets, one does not succeed. After half a year of practice, one can stack two without their falling. With continued practice, why can one eventually stack five without their falling? My body is like a stump, my arm like withered wood, my mind single-minded and fixed, free from distracting thoughts. Though the myriad things are many, my awareness rests solely on the cicada’s wings. How could I fail to succeed?

Bo Jun noted: *Ce* (侧), *yi* (翼), and *de* (得) rhyme, all belonging to the ancient *zhide* (职德) rhyme group.

Confucius turned to his disciples and said: "When the mind is undivided, it approaches the divine."
[Note] *Fen* (分) means scattered. When intent is focused, it resembles the divine.
Lu Wenchang said: The *Zang* edition writes *yi* (疑) as *ning* (凝), as does the *Zhuangzi*.
Jiao Xun said: The *Guanzi Neiye* states: "Think and think again, then think once more. If thinking does not lead to understanding, ghosts and spirits will make it clear. It is not the power of ghosts and spirits but the culmination of essence and *qi*." Thinking repeatedly is "using the mind without division." "Ghosts and spirits will make it clear" is "approaching the divine."
Yu Yue said: The *Daozang* edition writes *yi* (疑) as *ning* (凝), as does Lu Chongxuan’s edition and the *Zhuangzi*. However, this character should actually be *yi* (疑), meaning "to astonish like ghosts and spirits." The earlier passage where Confucius says, "I took you for a ghost, but upon closer inspection, you are human," also supports the reading "approaching the divine." The *Guanzi Xingshi* states: "Without breadth, it is *yi* (疑)." The *Shenjie* says: "Using compass and square to make circles and squares brings success; using measuring tools to determine length brings accuracy; governing the people with laws and numbers brings peace. Thus, affairs not broad in principle succeed as if by divine means." This is precisely what "using the mind without division approaches the divine" means. For further discussion, see *Zhuangzi Pingyi*.
Tao Hongqing said: Yu Yue’s argument is sound. Zhang’s commentary states: "When intent is focused, it resembles the divine," indicating that the text he saw originally read *yi* (疑), not *ning* (凝).
Wang Shumin said: The *Yungu Yaji* and *Tianzhong Ji* also write it as *yi* (疑). *Yi* (疑) means "to resemble." The *Zhuangzi Tiandi* states: "You are not one of those broadly learned men who resemble the sages."

The *Huainanzi*'s "Chuzhen" chapter also writes it as *yi* (疑), which is precisely this comparison.

Bo Jun notes: Tao Hongqing used Zhang’s commentary as evidence, supplementing what Yu Yue had not fully addressed. In fact, Yu Yue in his *Zhuangzi Pingyi* had already cited this as corroboration. Moreover, the phrase "resembling" as used by Confucius became a set expression, which is why the various masters all employ this wording. Ancient set expressions often featured rhyme, and here *shen* (神) and *nai* (乃) form a *zhen-wen* rhyme (as in *Laozi* Chapter 15, where *chuan* [川] and *lin* [邻] rhyme; the *Liji*'s "Kongzi Xianju," where *shen* [神] and *xian* [先] rhyme; the *Book of Songs*' "Zhengyue," where *lin* [邻] and *yin* [殷] rhyme; the *Yijing*'s "Song" hexagram, where *ren* [人] and *chuan* [川] rhyme; the *Chuci*'s "Tianwen," where *fen* [分] and *shen* [神] rhyme; the "Yuan You," where *tian* [天] and *wen* [闻] rhyme; and the *Xunzi*'s "Yun Fu," where *sun* [损], *wen* [文], *shen* [神], *men* [门], *cun* [存], and *chen* [陈] rhyme—examples are too numerous to list exhaustively). *Zhen* belongs to Duan Yucai’s twelfth rhyme group, and *wen* to the thirteenth, making their rhyme the closest possible, which is the principle at work here.

Could this be what the hunchbacked elder meant?

**[Explanation]**
To focus the mind without distraction is to *congeal* in spiritual union. The Master, however, referred to the elder’s failure to forget the cicada’s wings, hence "congealing in the divine"—not that he had attained spiritual union.

The elder said: "You are but a disciple in flowing robes."
Sun Yirang notes: *Fengyi* (逢衣) refers to the wide-sleeved robes described in the ritual classics. Zheng Xuan’s commentary on the *Zhouli*’s "Sifu" states: "The sleeves of a *shi*’s robe are two *chi* and two *cun* in length, joined to the garment, with cuffs of one *chi* and two *cun*. For *dafu* and above, the sleeves are made wider. To widen them, one takes half the original measurement and adds one part. Thus, the sleeves become three *chi* and three *cun*, and the cuffs one *chi* and eight *cun*." The *Shiwen* reads *ru* (汝) as *nü* (女), glossing it as *ru* (汝). The *Liji*’s "Ruxing" chapter states: "When I lived in Lu in my youth, I wore robes with wide sleeves. When I lived long in Song, I wore the *Zhangfu* cap." Zheng Xuan’s commentary explains: "*Feng* means 'large,' referring to robes with wide sleeves." Xiang Xiu said: "Confucian robes are broad and long." What do you know of such matters? Cultivate your own means, and only then speak of loftier things.

The annotation states: *Xiu* (修) means "to cultivate." It speaks of cultivating the arts of benevolence and righteousness that you employ, returning to the natural Dao, and only then may you bear these words upon yourself.

The exegesis reads: The disciples of the Master are all scholars of the *fengye* robe, employing benevolence and righteousness to teach and transform the world. Yet they cause the world to clamor after fame and profit, exhausting their wisdom and thoughts, losing their true nature, and wearying their spirit and clarity—what do they know of inquiring into this Dao? You who transmit texts to later generations, do you again wish to employ the eloquence of clever speech to bear this Dao upon written words?

Qin Enfu said: The final character *ran* (然) in the exegesis is likely a scribal error for *yan* (焉).
Yu Yue said: Zhang’s annotation does not grasp the meaning. Reflecting on the old man’s words, his disdain for Confucian arts is extreme—how could he urge one to cultivate such arts? *Xiu* (修) means "to sweep away." The *Zhouli*’s "Dian Si" states: "He leads his subordinates in sweeping away [impurities]," and Zheng’s commentary explains: "*Xiu chu* means to clear and sweep," which is its meaning here. The "Si Zun Yi" further states: "*Xiu zhuo*," and the commentary of the Minister of Agriculture reads: "To wash the ladle with water and then pour." That washing with water is called *xiu* also carries the sense of sweeping away. Thus, this passage’s *xiu ru suo yi* means that what you employ should be swept away, and only then may you bear my words upon yourself.
Wang Shumin said: Master Yu is correct in taking *xiu* as *xiu chu* ("to sweep away"), but he has not grasped the meaning of *zai* (載). *Zai* means "again." It speaks of sweeping away what you formerly employed, and only then may you speak of loftier things again.
Lin Xiyi’s *Kouyi* states: "*Zai yan* means to speak anew," which best captures its meaning. The *Zhuangzi*’s "Rang Wang" chapter reads: "The Master was twice expelled from Lu," and the *Taiping Yulan* (486) cites it as *zai*, providing evidence that *zai* and *zai* ("again") are interchangeable.
Wu Kaisheng also said: It speaks of first cultivating what you practice and only then seeking loftier things—Zhang’s annotation is in error.

There was a man from the seaside who was fond of gulls. (Bo Jun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Jing Yu" chapter reads "fond of dragonflies," and the same below.) The *Shiwen* reads: *Hao* (好) is pronounced *hu bao*. *Ou* is pronounced *ou*. Gulls are water owls; those seen today by rivers and lakes, resembling white pigeons and flying in flocks, are they. Each morning he went to the seashore, following the gulls in their play, and the gulls that came numbered in the hundreds without cease.
The annotation states: When the heart is harmonious and the form compliant, creatures do not shun one. *Zhu* (住) should be written as *shu* (数).

Wang Shumin said: The *Yiwen Leiju* (92), *Taiping Yulan* (925), *Erya Yi* (17), *Rongzhai Sibi* (14), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (56), *Shiwen Leiju Fuxi* (46), *Hebi Shilei Bieji* (69), *Yunfu Qunyu* (8), and *Tianzhong Ji* (59) all quote it as *shu* (数). The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhu* (住) is pronounced *shu* (数).

His father said, "I have heard that all the gulls follow you in play. Bring them here so that I may enjoy them." The *Shiwen* notes: In one version, "bring them here" is written as "you may bring them here."

The next day, when he went to the seashore, the gulls danced in the air but would not descend.
The annotation states: When the heart stirs within, the form changes without; even birds perceive it—how could human principles be feigned?

Bo Jun notes: The *Annotations to the Records of the Three Kingdoms* in the *Biography of Gao Rou* quote Sun Sheng as saying, "When the mind harbors calculation, gulls will not descend." Thus, the story of gulls originally existed, and the forger of the *Liezi* borrowed it. Sun Sheng was nearly contemporary with Zhang Zhan and likely never saw this *Liezi*. Hence it is said: Perfect words transcend speech. The *Shiwen* notes: *Qu* (去) is pronounced *qǔ* (丘吕切). Perfect action is non-action. What is known by the equalization of wisdom is but shallow.
The annotation states: Only when all speech is forgotten do things harbor no suspicion. To be limited by what wisdom knows is to miss the mark by far.

Some have doubted whether the old man feigned his form to catch cicadas, while the seaside boy, trusting in harmony, drew gulls to him—these two cases seem opposed yet equally avoid offending things. The foundation of their words lies in their distinct purposes. Though they appear contradictory, they converge in the same truth: the old man demonstrated that when the mind is single-mindedly focused, one can avoid startling creatures—how much more so when one attains natural oblivion, becoming like wood or stone? As for the seaside boy, his sincere heart filled his inner being, and his openness manifested outwardly. Though he did not forget both benefit and harm or eliminate all suspicion, he lightly regarded the strangeness of other species, finding little to marvel at. These two analogies borrow the near to illustrate the distant, using the branch to clarify the root.

The explanation states: Spiritual union transcends reason, not emotional knowledge. When knowledge arises, even flesh and blood suspect one another; when principle arises, all things are without barrier—only then can one discern the subtlest truths. To unite with all things lies in spiritual union; to unite with living beings lies in the extinction of emotion. To pride oneself on one’s heart and wisdom is to distance oneself from the Dao.

The annotation’s "the old man feigned his form" (*wei*, 为) is written as *wei* (伪, "falsely") in the Northern Song edition and the Zang edition; the version with *wei* (为) has greater meaning. The *Shiwen* notes: *Qi* (齐) is pronounced *zhì* (在诣切). *Wu* (忤) is pronounced *wù* (悟). *Hai* (骇) is pronounced *xié* (谐楷切), the same below.

Viscount Xiang of Zhao led a retinue of one hundred thousand to hunt in Zhongshan.
The annotation states: Hunting with fire is called *shou* (狩).
Wang Chongmin said: The *Taiping Yulan* (51) and *Yiwen Leiju* (80) both quote "Zhongshan" as "in the mountains." Bo Jun notes: Zhongshan was known as Xianyu in the Spring and Autumn period and became the state of Zhongshan during the Warring States period, located in present-day Ding County, Baoding region, Hebei. The *Shiwen* notes: Viscount Xiang of Zhao was named Wuxu and was the son of Jianzi. *Shuai* (率) is pronounced *shuài* (所律切). *Tian* (畋) is pronounced *tián* (田).

The flames spread through the forest on a bed of kindling. The *Shiwen* notes: *jiè* (藉) is pronounced *zài yè qiè* (在夜切). *fén* ( ) is pronounced *ér zhèn qiè* (而振切). When the bedding lies beneath, it is called *jiè* (藉); when the grass is left untrimmed, it is called *fén* ( ). *fán* (燔) is pronounced *fán* (烦) and means "to burn." The blaze fanned out, blazing fiercely for a hundred *li*.

A man emerged from within a stone cliff, rising and falling with the smoke and embers. The *Shiwen* notes: *jìn* (烬) is pronounced *jí rèn qiè* (疾刃切). *shàng* (上) is pronounced *shí zhǎng qiè* (时掌切). The crowd called him a ghostly being. The *Yiwen Leiju* (80) quotes this as "the crowd called him a ghostly being." After the fire passed, he walked out slowly, as if he had never traversed anything at all.

Viscount Xiang of Zhao found him strange and detained him. The *Shiwen* notes: *liú* (留) is pronounced *lì jiù qiè* (力救切), meaning to stay and observe him. Upon closer examination: his form, complexion, and seven orifices were those of a man. The *Shiwen* notes: *qiào* (窍) is pronounced *kǒu diào qiè* (口吊切). His breath and voice were those of a man. He asked, "By what *Dao* do you dwell in stone? By what *Dao* do you enter fire?"

The man replied, "What thing do you call stone? What thing do you call fire?" The annotation states: This shows he was utterly unaware of stone or fire—what thing could obstruct him?

Viscount Xiang said, "That from which you emerged just now was stone; that which you traversed just now was fire." The *Shiwen* notes: *xiàng* (向) is pronounced *xiàng* (向). The man said, "I do not know." The annotation states: His ignorance was so complete that he attained this state.

Marquis Wen of Wei heard of this and asked Zixia, "What sort of man is he?" Zixia said, "From what I have heard of the Master’s words, one who harmonizes attains great unity with things, so that nothing can harm or obstruct him. Roaming through metal and stone, treading water and fire—all are possible."

Marquis Wen said, "Why do you not do this?" Zixia said, "To hollow out the heart and cast off knowledge—" The *Shiwen* notes: *kū* (刳) is pronounced *kū* (枯). *qù* (去) is pronounced *qiū lǚ qiè* (丘吕切). "—I have not yet been able to do so. Nevertheless, I can speak of it when I have leisure." The annotation states: To use the heart to hollow out the heart, to borrow knowledge to cast off knowledge—though the burdens of heart and knowledge may be truly exhausted, the traces of what has been relinquished still remain. This makes clear that the ultimate principle cannot be realized through the use of the heart; speaking of it, however, leaves one with ample leisure.

The commentary states: The previous chapter spoke of roaming through water without obstruction; this chapter clarifies that fire and stone do no harm. It notes that many are accustomed to water, but few tread fire, lest one’s nature become biased. Thus, it speaks again of fire to elucidate this. One who inwardly forgets his own form and outwardly forgets things does not know what obstructs stone or harms fire.

Marquis Wen, not understanding, raised the question, while Zixia, who had long known, answered well. Thus, Marquis Wen pressed further: since you know it, why do you not practice it? Zixia replied, "I can speak of it and have more than enough to say; but as for practicing and realizing it, I have not yet attained the ability." Qin Enfu notes: In the commentary, "has not yet attained the ability," the character *zhī* (知) may be superfluous. The *Shiwen* notes: *xiá* (暇) is also written as *jiǎ* (假), but is also pronounced as *xiá* (暇).

Marquis Wen said, "Why does the Master not do it?" Zixia said, "The Master is capable of it but chooses not to."

Marquis Wen was greatly pleased.

[Annotation] In the world, there are those who are capable of it yet choose not to act, those who are capable of it yet cannot help but act, those who are incapable yet force themselves to act, and those who do not act yet naturally possess the ability. As for the sage—what does he do? What does he not do? What is he capable of? What is he incapable of? He bows and rises with the customs of the world, ascends and descends in accord with things. Extraordinary deeds and wondrous traces are never for a moment displayed; the sublime subtleties within his being are not one in ten thousand perceived.

From the beginning of this scroll to this chapter, the Dao of following one’s nature and destiny is made clear: not to be bound by the five emotions, to concentrate the qi and attain suppleness, to be sincere in heart without duality—thus one may pass through water and fire without scorching or drowning, tread upon wood and stone without snagging or stumbling, touch blades and edges without injury or harm, traverse peril and danger without falling or tumbling. The myriad things do not oppose his heart; entering among beasts, he does not disturb their herds. His spirit may wander alone, his body may rise lightly; his ears may hear with perfect clarity, his eyes may see with penetrating illumination.

These words are not conventional, and in truth they startle the common mind. Therefore, let us discuss it: Yin and Yang transform in alternation, the Five Agents nurture in imbalance. Metal and Earth give birth as mother and child; Water and Fire overcome one another through dryness and moisture. Human nature diverges in stillness and agitation; ascent and descent differ in their capacities and dispositions. Thus there are winged creatures that soar through clouds, scaled creatures that lurk in the depths, rats that move through fire, and insects that dwell in wood. Why is this? Hard and soft, heat and cold—each has its proper place.

Those content with one domain are constrained in all others. As for the perfected person, their mind merges mystically with primordial qi, their body harmonizes darkly with Yin and Yang. Squares and circles do not conform to a single form, warmth and coolness do not settle in a single vessel. With spirit settled and qi harmonized, all they ride submits to them—thus the Five Agents cannot oppose them, cold and heat cannot harm them. This is called the depth of embodied virtue, the perfection of harmony. Therefore, they constantly dwell beyond the realm of death—how could they need to deliberate over approach or withdrawal to preserve wholeness?

Treading water and fire, riding clouds and mist, traversing perilous heights, entering the midst of weapons—these are hardly worth marveling at.

[Annotation] The Master’s abilities that he did not exercise were employed to uphold the Dao of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and the proper order of ruler and minister to rescue a declining age—not merely to cultivate his own person among flocks of birds and beasts.

[Collation Notes] Zhang Hua’s *Bowu Zhi* records this matter in nearly identical terms. Another note: The commentary’s "perfected person" appears as "sage" in the Shide Tang edition. The *Shiwen* renders  as 碍, with the pronunciation *yue*. 强 is read as *qí liǎng*. 着 is read as *zhí lüè*. 挂 is pronounced *guà*. 碍 originally appeared as . 颠 is read as *dū nián*, meaning "to fall." 偏 is pronounced *piān*. A divine shaman from Qi arrived and resided in Zheng. The *Shiwen* states: males are called *xí*, females *wū*. Yan Shigu notes: *wū* and *xí* are also used interchangeably. His name was Ji Xian. [Collation] The *Xunzi*’s "Zhengming" chapter reads, "Only then does one follow and name it," and "If the reality is not understood, then name it; if the name is not understood, then set a time"—Yang’s commentary interprets *ming* as "name" in both cases. The *Zhuangzi*’s "Dazongshi" chapter reads, "There is nothing with which to name it," and the *Shiwen* cites Cui’s commentary: "*Ming* means name." The *Zuozhuan* under Duke Huan’s second year states, "The ruler named the heir *Chou* and his younger brother *Chengshi*," and under the sixth year, "At his birth, he was of the same kind as I, so I named him *Tong*." In all cases, *ming* is glossed as "name." Thus *ming yue Ji Xian* means his name was Ji Xian. Another note: The *Huainanzi*’s "Dixing Xun" states, "Wu Xian is in the north," with Gao’s commentary: "Wu Xian knows the Dao of Heaven and clarifies good and ill fortune." The *Shiwen* states: Ji Xian, with the surname Ji and given name Xian, was a man of Zheng. [Collation] The *Zhuangzi*’s "Ying Diwang" chapter reads, "In Zheng there was a divine shaman named Ji Xian," and the *Huainanzi*’s "Jingshen Xun" reads, "The divine shaman of Zheng, Xiang Huqiuzi Lin, saw his signs"—hence the *Shiwen* identifies Ji Xian as a man of Zheng. He knew the life and death, survival and demise, fortune and misfortune, long life and early death of others, predicting them by year, month, ten-day week, or day with divine accuracy. The *Tianzhong Ji* (vol. 40) and *Jingchuan Baibian* (vol. 65) both insert a "之" after "知人." Wang Xianqian says: Whether by year, month, ten-day week, or day, none failed to prove divinely accurate. [Collation] Wang’s reading of "ten-day week and day" as a single phrase is incorrect. Each of "year," "month," "ten-day week," and "day" stands alone, meaning predictions could be made by any of these. When the people of Zheng saw him, they all fled to avoid him. [Commentary] Xiang Xiu says: They disliked hearing their own death dates. The *Shiwen* notes: One variant reads "abandoned" instead of "avoided." 喜 is pronounced *xǐ jì*. Liezi saw him and was enchanted. [Commentary] Xiang Xiu says: He was bewildered by his Dao. Returning, he told Huqiuzi, [Commentary] The *Shiwen* states: Huzi was Liezi’s teacher. saying, "At first I took the Master’s Dao as ultimate, but now there is something even more ultimate." [Commentary] Guo Xiang says: He meant that Ji Xian’s attainment surpassed even the Master’s. The *Shiwen* notes: 过 is pronounced *gē*. Huqiuzi said: "I have practiced the outward forms with you, but you have not yet grasped their essence—how could you have truly attained the Dao? [Collation] Lu Wenchang says: The "无" in the Zang edition appears as "既"; the commentary suggests "无" may be correct, though the *Zhuangzi* also uses "既." Yu Yue says: "无" should be "", read as *guàn* (to penetrate), as "贯" and "" were originally the same character. The *Erya*’s "Shigu" glosses *guàn* as "to practice." The *Huangdi* chapter reads, "You and I have long played with its outward forms but have not yet reached its essence," with the *Shiwen* glossing *wán* (玩) as *xí guàn* (习贯, to practice). Thus here "" (practice) corresponds to *wán* (玩) there—both are phonetically close and share the same meaning. Due to scribal error, it became "", and later scholars replaced it with "无," rendering the passage unintelligible. Lu Chongxuan’s edition reads "既其文未既其实," following the *Zhuangzi*’s revision, but this is not the original text of the *Liezi*. Wang Shuqin says: "I have practiced the outward forms with you, but you have not yet grasped their essence"—whether "既" or "无," the meaning remains unclear. The earlier passage where Yan Hui asks the ferryman about boat-handling reads, "You and I have long played with its outward forms but have not yet reached its essence"—*wán* (玩) is the superior reading. It is likely that "既" here is a corruption of *wán* (玩), and the second "既" should also be *wán*. The "无" variant arose when *wán* (玩) degraded into *yuán* (元), and scribes altered it to "无." The *Shiwen* notes: "无" appears as "无" in some editions, while others use "既," though the latter is less meaningful. A flock of hens without a rooster—how could they lay eggs?" [Commentary] Xiang Xiu says: Essence is made manifest through form, and the Dao is revealed through affairs. To possess the Dao without engaging in affairs is like having hens without a rooster. Though you and I differ in depth, we both occupy the realm of essence—thus no outward forms emerge to reveal it. Therefore, you have not yet fully grasped the essence of my Dao. This speaks to how the perfected person’s song must await a response before harmonizing. [Collation] The *Huainanzi*’s "Lanming Xun" states: "Thus the utmost Yin is howling, the utmost Yang is blazing—when the two interact and harmonize, the myriad things are born."

"With a flock of roosters but no hen—how could transformation ever arise?"

*Shiwen* notes: "卵 is read *luǎn* (short tone)."
Sima [Biao] says: "You have not yet fully received instruction, so you remain unformed. Just as a flock of hens without a rooster produces no eggs, so too does your state yield nothing."
"Yet to oppose the world with the Dao is surely trustworthy."

*Shiwen* notes: "抗 is read *kàng* (rising tone); some write it as 亢, with the same pronunciation."

"Thus others can perceive and assess you."

[Commentary] Xiang Xiu says: "To rigidly uphold one aspect and insist on its trustworthiness in the world is to make yourself perceptible to others."

[Exegesis] When Liezi met the Zheng shaman, he was intoxicated in heart, for the man could discern life and death, fortune and misfortune, and seemed to exhaust the Dao in this alone. Master Huqiu said: "You and I have merely lost our outward traces—we have not yet fully grasped its true principle. How could you have attained my Dao? To still the spirit and quiet the mind is like the state of hens; to act, employ, and achieve success is like the rooster. You now cease affairs to calm the mind—how can you seek eggs without a rooster? Yet you would pit the utmost Dao against a common shaman, and so your deep conviction makes you known even to spirits."

*Shiwen* notes: "相 is read *xiàng* (falling tone)."

"Come with me tomorrow, and I will show you."

*Shiwen* notes: "示 is written as , read *shì* (falling tone)."

The next day, Liezi brought the shaman to see Master Hu. Upon leaving, the shaman said to Liezi: "Alas!

*Shiwen* notes: "嘻 is read *xī* (rising tone)."

Your master is dead. He cannot be revived—he will not last ten days. I saw something strange in him: I saw damp ashes."

Liezi entered, his tears soaking his lapels as he reported this to Master Hu.

*Shiwen* notes: "司馬云: *qi* like damp ashes."

*Shiwen* notes: "衿 originally written as 衾."
Yu Yue says: "衾 should be 衿, the same as 襟."
The *Yingdiwang* chapter of the *Zhuangzi* indeed reads: "his tears soaked his lapels."
Wang Chongmin says: "The Jifu edition correctly writes 衿."
Bo Jun notes: "Here we follow the Jifu edition."

Master Hu said: "Earlier, I showed him *Earthly Pattern*."

*Annotation*: Xiang Xiu says: "Like a clod of earth."
*Shiwen* notes: "向吾 in one version reads 庸吾, the same below."

"[I was] sprouting yet unmoved, unceasing."

*Annotation*: "罪 in some versions reads 萌."
Xiang Xiu says: "Sprouting yet unmoving, neither halting of itself—like a withered tree sharing its lack of bloom, like dead ashes sharing their stillness of spirit. This is the time when the utmost person is without response. The utmost person’s movement is like Heaven, their stillness like Earth, their action like flowing water, their depth like a silent abyss. The silent abyss and flowing water, Heaven’s movement and Earth’s stillness—all are one in their non-doing and natural spontaneity. Now, Jixian saw him dwelling like a corpse and sitting in oblivion, and so called him near death; he saw his spirit move and Heaven follow, and so called him alive. If one responds to stimuli without intent, then rises and falls with change, taking the world as measure—only then can one master things and follow the timeless without limit. How could a diviner perceive this?"

*Annotation*: "其静也地 in the Northern Song edition reads 土; Wang’s edition follows this. Here we follow the Zang edition to correct it."
"謂之有生: 謂 in all other editions reads 為. Here we also follow the Zang edition to correct it."

Yu Yue says: "罪 should be read as □."
The *Shuowen*, in its *Shan* section, writes □, saying: "The appearance of a mountain." This is correct.
*Shiwen* notes: "罪 originally read 萌. The Lu Chongxuan edition also reads 萌, later altered according to the *Zhuangzi*. 萌 is a corrupted form of 罪. For details, see *Zhuangzi Pingyi*."
Wang Shumin says: "Reading 罪 as □ is forced. Here, 萌 is correct. 萌 has the sense of arising (the *Chu Zhen* chapter of the *Huainanzi*: 'Who knows where it arises?' with the note: '萌 means to arise'). '萌乎不震不止' means 'arising in unmoving unceasing,' directly countering the earlier 'Your master is dead.' The meaning is quite clear. 罪 is an error."

The *Shiwen* states: "罪 originally reads 萌." "震 is pronounced as 振." Cui Zhuan says: "不震不止 means like moving yet unmoving." "量 is pronounced as 亮." "This is nearly seeing my concealed virtue-power."

**Annotation:**
Xiang Xiu says: "Virtue-power does not manifest, hence it is called concealed."

**Explication:**
The numinous spirits of ghosts and gods can know the thoughts of human activity. If one has attachments, ghosts will perceive them. Master Hu’s countenance abided in "damp ashes," his mind fixed on the soil, sprouting without deliberation—hence it is called "earthly pattern." When stirred, it becomes life; when still, it merges into obscurity—thus it is said "unmoving yet unceasing."

Qin Enfu says: "In the explication, '天文' should read '地文.'"

"Come again tomorrow!"

The next day, he again brought him to see Master Hu. Upon leaving, he said to Liezi: "Fortunate indeed is your master to have met me—he is recovering! He is ashen yet sprouting. There is life! I have seen his concealed dynamism."

**Annotation:**
Having function yet no advantage, hence it is called "concealed dynamism."

Liezi entered and reported this to Master Hu. Master Hu said: "Earlier, I showed him heaven-and-earth, where the power of covering and bearing is manifest. Compared to earthly pattern, is this not external?

**Annotation:**
Taohong Qing says: The *Shuowen* states: "壤 means soft soil." The *Book of Documents* (*Yu Gong*) says: "Its soil is white 壤." Ma Rong’s note: "Naturally harmonious and fine." The *Rites of Zhou* (*Da Situ*) says: "Distinguishing the twelve kinds of 壤." Zheng Xuan’s note: "壤 means the appearance of harmony and gentleness." Thus, "heaven-and-earth" takes the meaning of harmony and softness. Stated plainly, it is "heavenly harmony." This and "earthly pattern" are both figurative expressions. Zhang’s annotation, taking "heaven-and-earth" as "heaven and earth," is quite difficult to reconcile.

"—is the abyss." Ji Di says: "*潘* should be *沈*, the character for *shěn*. *沈* is the original form of *湛*. The *Shuowen* states: *湛* means "to submerge." By extension, it carries the sense of depth. *沈* and *湛* are ancient and modern forms; today, *沈* is commonly used for *湛*. *渊*, according to the *Shuowen*, is "revolving water," depicted with water radicals, its shape suggesting banks on either side and water in the center. The *Guanzi*’s *Du Di* chapter states: "Water that emerges from the earth but does not flow is called an abyss." Thus, an abyss is where water pools and deepens. The *Shijing*’s *Wei Feng* commentary glosses *渊* as "deep," and *沈* as an abyss further emphasizes this depth. The *Liji*’s *Tan Gong* reads: "For the *yú* tree’s *shěn*, a dredge was set," where *shěn* is *shěn*. Here, however, *shěn* is *shěn*. *Zhuangzi* writes it as *审*. When *沈* is missing a stroke, it becomes *潘*; when *水* is missing, it becomes *审*. Errors arise easily, but the traces remain discernible.

The *Shiwen* writes "旋" as "桓," pronounced *huán* (胡官切), meaning "to linger." One version writes it as *旋*, meaning "to coil." *潘* is pronounced *pān*; originally *蟠*, referring to the swirling of water. Now written as *蟠*, likely a scribal error. *鲵* is a large fish; *桓* means "to linger"; *蟠* means "to swirl." This describes how a great fish’s lingering and coiling creates a deep spring. The *Nanhua Zhenjing* writes it as *审*. Liang Jianwen states: *蟠* means "to gather." Ren Dachun notes: Mountains and waters named *桓* all carry the sense of coiling. The *Shui Jing Zhu* states: "*桓* is the name of a mountain slope; its path coils and winds upward, hence the name *桓*." Slopes named *桓* and waters named *桓* both derive from the sense of coiling, corroborating the *Shiwen*’s *旋* written as *桓*. The words *盘桓* were often glossed as "to revolve" in ancient times. The *Yi*’s *Zhun* *Shiwen*, citing Ma Rong, states: "*盘桓* means 'to revolve.'" Thus, the *桓* in *盘桓* in the *Liezi* is also written as *旋*. Further, in the *Zhuangzi*’s *Ying Di Wang* *Shiwen*, *鲵桓* is glossed by Sima Biao as "two fish names," while Jianwen states: "*鲵* is the whale; *桓* means 'to linger.'" Cui’s version writes it as *鲵拒*, glossing it as "the square cave where fish dwell." Another note states: "*拒* may be written as *桓*." Thus, *鲵桓*’s *桓* is written as *旋* in the *Liezi* *Shiwen* and as *拒* in the *Zhuangzi* *Shiwen*.

Another note: Lu Jingshun’s *Shiwen* states that *潘* was originally *蟠*, referring to the swirling of water, and that the current *蟠* is likely a scribal error. However, this interpretation is somewhat forced. The *蟠* in "now written as *蟠*" may be a corruption of *潘*. Yet in the *Zhuangzi*’s *Ying Di Wang* *Shiwen*, *鲵桓*’s *审* is glossed by Sima Biao as *蟠*, meaning "to gather," while Cui’s version writes it as *潘*, glossing it as "the domain where swirling water congeals." The *Guanzi*’s *Wu Fu* chapter states: "Guide floodwaters, benefit ponds and ditches, and dredge *潘* islets," with the annotation: "*潘* means 'to overflow.' *渚潘* overflows, so dredge them to allow flow. *潘* is pronounced *pān*." The supplementary annotation states: *潘* refers to swirling overflow. The *Guangya* states: "*潘* is *fúyuán*, meaning 'to surge.'" Thus, *蟠* and *潘* each have their basis and are not incorrect. It remains unclear which character the *蟠* in Lu Jingshun’s *Shiwen* is a corruption of.

Further, the *Yupian* states: "*瀊* means 'to swirl,'" from which Lu Jingshun’s *Shiwen* derives its *瀊洄*. The *Guanzi*’s *Xiao Wen* chapter writes it as *盘桓*.

**Annotation:**
The names and meanings of these nine waters appear in the *Erya*. Water is one, yet depending on whether the terrain is high or low, smooth or rugged, it swirls, rushes, flows, or stills differently—just as the mind of the perfected person, in response to external things’ difficulty or ease, exhibits movement or stillness, advance or retreat. Xiang Xiu says: "Whether water flows or stills, whether the *ní* fish coils or the dragon leaps, the abyss remains ever thus, never losing its quietude."

Guo Xiang says: "The perfected person acts when employing the Way and stills when setting it aside. Though waves surge through nine transformations, and order and chaos swirl in confusion, one who abides in the ultimate remains ever tranquil and self-possessed, drifting in non-action."

**Explication:**
The mind moves with the qi of the Great Thoroughfare, vast and traceless, formless yet ever-shifting—like water assuming myriad names in its transformations, yet never departing from the clarity of the abyss. Thus, its form cannot be grasped or described.

**Annotation:**
"Nine transformations" (*jiǔ biàn*): The Northern Song edition reads "all transformations" (*fán biàn*); Wang’s edition follows this, but the present text adopts the Zang edition’s correction.
**Pronunciations:**

*Yì* (易) is pronounced *yì* (with the *shì* rhyme).

"Come again tomorrow!"

Yu Yue says: The preceding text reads, *"This must be seeing my power of virtue in its subtlety—come again tomorrow,"* and again, *"This must be seeing my goodness in its subtlety—come again tomorrow."* Thus, this passage should read, *"This must be seeing my qi in equilibrium in its subtlety,"* followed immediately by *"Come again tomorrow,"* to maintain consistency. The interpolation of the Nine Abysses here is superfluous. I suspect these fifty-eight characters are a misplaced slip from elsewhere. In the *Zhuangzi*’s *"The Emperor of the World"* chapter, only the first three abysses are listed, and it concludes, *"The abyss has nine names; these are three of them,"* precisely because they are irrelevant to the passage’s meaning. This confirms that the version of the *Zhuangzi* seen by its author already matched the present text—errors in ancient books are long-standing.

**Annotation:**
If you remain silent and do not display yourself, whether in Qi or here, you will have nothing to fear. If you violate this principle, you will be safeguarded wherever you go.

**Exegesis:**
Displaying one’s demeanor to others causes people to risk death in reverence. Fearing that the lord’s weariness in affairs would lead to entrusting him with responsibilities and demanding results, he was startled and anxious about the increased burden of his stipend.

Bohun said: If you can withdraw to preserve your true nature, contain your light to erase your traces, others will safeguard you. Why? The desire to advance goodness resides in all people.

Where land yields abundant profit, all people vie for it. The nature of the common person may rise or fall. Knowing that fame and gain cannot be forced, one advances goodness to cultivate oneself. The *Odes*, *Documents*, ritual, and music—these affairs are not easily mastered. Yet if one retreats to seclusion, stills the heart and extinguishes cleverness, eschewing the lure of ostentation, one gains the reputation of a good person. Thus, at the gate of Dao-learning, whether one’s inclinations are good or bad, the noble person purifies the heart, while the petty person reforms the self. Though they may not fully grasp the Way, they still derive benefit from following goodness. Hence it is said: “Others will safeguard you.”

Wang Lai notes: In the exegesis “risk death in reverence,” *death* should read *prior*. Tao Hongqing says: *Safeguard* means *entrust*; it speaks of others placing trust in one, just as the *Liezi* states, “They will entrust me with affairs and demand results from me.” Zhang’s annotation, glossing it as “safeguarded wherever one goes,” is quite untenable. Wang Chongmin says: In Zhang’s note, “If one violates this principle,” *violates* should read *attains*, an error due to graphic similarity. The *Zhuangzi*’s “Ren Jian Shi” chapter reads, “Timing their hunger and satiety, attaining their angry hearts,” while the *Huainanzi*’s “Zhu Shu” chapter mistakenly writes *violates*—this serves as evidence. Xi Tong says: *Abide* should be glossed as *examine*, as explained in detail in Wang Yinzhi’s *Jingyi Shuwen*. *Abiding in oneself* means examining oneself. The *Shiwen* states: *Safeguard* means *attach*. Before long, he went, and the shoes outside his door were filled. The annotation says: Those who returned to him were indeed many. The *Shiwen* states: *屦* is pronounced *jiu* (nine-meet cut), and in the Guanzhong region, shoes are called *屦*.

Bohun Maoren stood facing north, leaning heavily on his staff, pressing it against his chin. The annotation says: *Dun* means *press*. The *Shiwen* states: *Dun* is pronounced *dun* (tone). *Cù* is pronounced *zi-liu* cut. *Yí* is pronounced *yi* (tone). After standing for a while, the *Shiwen* says: *Interval* means a short time. He departed without speaking. The attendant reported this to Liezi.

The *Shiwen* states: *宾* is written as *傧* in the original text, meaning *to guide*, pronounced *bi-ren* cut. Liezi lifted his shoes and ran barefoot. The *Shiwen* notes: *履* is written as *屦*, with *提* pronounced *ti*. *屦* is also written as *履* in another version. *跣* is pronounced *xian-tian* cut. Upon reaching the gate, the *Shiwen* states: *暨* is pronounced *qi-qi* cut, meaning *to arrive*. He asked: "Since you have come, Master, have you not dispensed with the remedy?" The annotation says: *废* means *to set aside*. He has not once offered good words to serve as medicine or stone. The commentary says: *废* should be *发*. Since you have come, Master, why not utter a few words of remedy as instruction? In the *Zhongni* chapter: "If one *发* ignorance, how can there be true nature? If one *发* incapacity, how can anything be done?" The *Shiwen* cites an alternate version reading "If one *废* ignorance, if one *废* incapacity," which is comparable. The *Shiwen* states: *当* is pronounced *dang-lang* cut. "Indeed, I told you before: others would preserve you, and they have indeed preserved you. Yet it is not that you can make others preserve you. [Annotation: If one interacts with things in accord with the principle, then things will naturally preserve one. Now, turning against the principle to move things, one seeks their preservation—but it cannot be obtained.] The *Lu Chongxuan* edition of the *Qin* carving omits the character *you* after 'make others preserve.' It is likely that the omission is correct." *Shiwen* notes: *bei* is pronounced *pei*.

"But you cannot make others not preserve you. [Annotation: Guo Xiang says: If one acts with equanimity and transforms, then there is no stirring, no seeking. Without stirring or seeking, there is no mutual preservation.] [Exegesis: Your withdrawal, your integrity, your renunciation of learning and wisdom—these are why others preserve you, not because you can summon them. If you could erase your traces and merge with the real, concealing both foolishness and wisdom, others would not know to preserve you. Thus, your conduct merely suffices to make others preserve you, yet you cannot make them cease. Why then do you stir them? [Annotation: What method do you employ to move things so?] *Shiwen* notes: *yan* is pronounced *yu-qian*.

"Stirring them, you produce anomalies. [Annotation: Guo Xiang says: Bestowing favors before things move—such favors do not arise from their prior movement but are anomalous.] The *Qin* edition reads 'responding in advance' instead of 'stirring in advance.' The final *zhe* in the annotation appears as *ye* in the *Northern Song* edition; here, it is corrected according to the *Zang* edition." *Shiwen* notes: *xian* is pronounced *xi-jan*.

"Moreover, there must be stirring, and in shaking, the root of the self. [Annotation: *Shiwen* notes: An alternate version reads 'shaking the root of one’s nature.'] It is also meaningless. [Annotation: If one constantly makes things stir one, then the natures of self and other are set in motion and altered.] Xu Weiyu says: In 'Moreover, there must be stirring,' *bi* ('must') should be *xin* ('heart'), the error arising from graphic similarity. The heart and the root of the self proceed in tandem; if the heart is stirred, it necessarily shakes the root of the self (the root of the self meaning one’s fundamental nature). Thus, the preceding text speaks of externally stabilizing the human heart to □ its affliction. The affliction refers to the heart being moved by things, thereby shaking the root of the self. The *Lie Yukou* chapter of the *Zhuangzi* contains the same error. Wang Chongmin says: *Shen* ('self') has the sense of *xing* ('nature'), for *shen* and *xing* were interchangeable in antiquity. 'Root of the self' is thus equivalent to 'root of one’s nature.' The *Lie Yukou* chapter of the *Zhuangzi* reads 'shaking the root of one’s talent.' *Shiwen* notes: 'An alternate version reads *xing* ('nature') for *cai* ('talent').' Both *cai* characters are errors for *shen*. The *Huainanzi*'s *Yuandao* chapter states, 'Thus one who has attained the Dao does not alter Heaven with man,' with Gao You’s commentary: 'Heavenly nature.' Another gloss says, 'Heavenly self.' 'Heavenly self' is thus equivalent to 'heavenly nature.' The *Sanguozhi*'s commentary on the *Wu Zhi* biography reads: 'The supreme general’s true nature was stout; the central commander-in-chief Zhu Shuo’s nature was lean.' 'Nature stout' and 'nature lean' are thus equivalent to 'self stout' and 'self lean.' The *Zhuangzi* commentary by Guo Xiang says, 'If there must be stirring, then it moves one’s fundamental nature'—this is correct." Bo Jun notes: Wang’s interpretation of 'root of the self' as 'root of one’s nature' is correct. However, the *Zhuangzi*’s 'root of one’s talent' is not an error. *Cai* should be read as in the *Mencius*' *Gaozi I*: 'It is not that Heaven has sent down a talent different from yours.' Talent is thus nature." *Shiwen* notes: *yi* is pronounced *yi-chi*.

"Those who wander with you can tell you nothing. [Annotation: They are all followers who shake the root; they cannot enlighten one another.] The annotation originally read 'not all' in Wang’s edition; here, it is corrected according to the *Northern Song* and *Zang* editions.

"Their petty words are all poison to others. [Annotation: Petty words are subtle and clever, easily stirring others, and thus harmful to them.]

"None awaken, none comprehend—how can they examine one another?" [Annotation: They cannot mutually perfect or aid one another.] [Exegesis: What Dao do you employ to stir them?]

"One must extol words of triumph and ease while expounding strange and extraordinary teachings, flailing one’s tongue to display prowess before all things. Though they may submit to you in droves, what benefit does it bring? Those who dwell with you do not criticize your faults but only praise your strengths—this merely poisons your conduct, inflates your pride, and how can it lead to mutual perfection?

[Variant:] *Mo jue mo wu* appears as *ruo jue ruo wu* in the *Qin* edition.
[Annotation:] *Gao*, *du*, and *shu* rhyme, all belonging to the ancient *-uk* and *-owk* rhyme groups.
[Pronunciation note:] *Jue* is pronounced *jiao*.

When Yang Zhu journeyed south to Pei, Gu Yanwu remarked: *Liezi* reads 'Yang Zhu south to Pei,' while *Zhuangzi* reads 'Yangzi resided south in Pei'—*Ziju* is a homophone for *Zhu*.
[Pronunciation note:] *Pei* is pronounced *bei*.

When Lao Dan traveled west to Qin, he was intercepted at the outskirts. Upon reaching Liang, he encountered Laozi.
[Annotation:] *Zhuangzi* refers to *Yangzi Ju*; *Ziju* may have been Yang Zhu’s courtesy name, and he was not contemporaneous with Laozi. These are all allegorical tales.

Midway, Laozi looked up to the sky and sighed:
[Pronunciation note:] *Zhong dao* means 'midway.' *Yang* was originally written as *ang*, also pronounced *yang*.
'At first, I thought you could be taught,
[Pronunciation note:] *Ru* is written as *nü*, pronounced *ru*.
but now you cannot be taught.'
[Annotation:] Though you associate with the perfected, you have not shed your self-importance and boasting, hence it is said you cannot be taught.
[Pronunciation note:] *Qu* is pronounced *qü*; *kua* is pronounced *kwa*.

Yang Zhu did not respond. Upon reaching their lodging, he presented water for washing, rinsing, towels, and a comb.
[Pronunciation note:] *Guan* is pronounced *guan*; *Zhuangzi* writes it as *guan*. *Shu* is pronounced *shou*. *Zhi* is pronounced *zhi*.

He removed his shoes outside the door, advanced on his knees, and said: 'Earlier, Master looked up to the sky and sighed, saying,
[Pronunciation note:] *Xiang* is written as *shang*, pronounced *xiang*.
"‘At first, I thought you could be taught, but now you cannot be taught.’ Your disciple wished to ask for an explanation, but as you were traveling without pause,
[Pronunciation note:] *Jian* is pronounced *xian*, same below.
I dared not. Now that you have paused, may I inquire as to my fault?'

Laozi said: 'You stare haughtily and gawk arrogantly—
[Pronunciation note:] *Sui* is pronounced *xuwei*. *Xu* is pronounced *xu*.
[Citation:] *Shuowen* states: *Xu* means to look upward. *Cangjie Pian* states: *Xu* is the appearance of wide-open eyes. Gao You’s commentary on *Huainanzi* states: *Sui xu* describes the manner of gazing and listening.
With whom do you dwell?'
[Annotation:] How do you conduct yourself and carry on so pompously as to make others sigh at you?
[Annotation:] *Xu* and *ju* rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *-a* rhyme group in level tone.

'The purest white appears tainted; the greatest virtue seems insufficient.'
[Annotation:] Without competing with things, one remains humble and restrained.
Ma Qichang notes: *Ru* is a loan for *du*.
[Annotation:] *Ru* and *zu* rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *-uk* rhyme group in entering tone. Laozi’s forty-first chapter reads 'vast virtue seems insufficient'; Ma Xulun’s *Laozi Hegu* argues that 'greatest' is the correct reading.

Yang Zhu’s expression changed, and he said with reverence:
[Pronunciation note:] *Cu* is pronounced *zilu*.
'I respectfully receive your instruction.'

When he first arrived, the innkeeper and his family came out to greet him. [Annotation:] The host family of the inn. The *Daozang* editions all include the character *zhe* 者 after *she* 舍, except the *Sijie* edition and Wang’s edition, which correctly omit it. Yu Yue notes: *She* 舍 and *she zhe* 舍者 are not the same. Below, it says “the inn guests rose from their mats” and again “the inn guests now vied with him for mats,” both referring to fellow travelers at the inn. Here, *she* 舍 refers to the innkeeper, just as the one who oversees the market is called *shi* 市, and the one who oversees farming is called *tian* 田. The *Liji*’s “Wangzhi” chapter glosses *shi* 市 as “the one who oversees the market,” and its “Yueling” chapter glosses *tian* 田 as “the official in charge of agriculture.” These are analogous examples.

The master held the mat, and his wife held the comb and mirror. The inn guests rose from their mats, and those warming themselves moved away from the hearth. [Annotation:] When one conceals one’s distinction with excessive modesty, others are daunted by it. Lu Wenchang notes: The character *cang* 藏 in the annotation likely should be *zun* 尊. [Pronunciation note:] *Yang* 炀 is pronounced *yang*. Sima Biao comments: *Yang* 炀 means to face the fire. The *Huainanzi* states: “The rich wear embroidered silks; the poor warm themselves at the hearth’s mouth.”

When he returned, the inn guests now vied with him for mats. [Annotation:] When one makes oneself equal to others, others feel no aversion. [Exegesis:] The true recluse makes no boastful claims and bears no air of self-importance. Thus, when Master Yang first arrived, people welcomed and saw him off; but after hearing good counsel and changing his ways, even the inn’s residents now competed with him for mats. The previous chapter spoke of Liezi’s ability to make others protect you, while this chapter shows how Yang Zhu could make others cease protecting you.

Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (709) includes the character *zao* 灶 before *xi* 席. Comparing this with the earlier phrase “the inn guests rose from their mats, and those warming themselves moved away from the hearth,” it seems the original text likely included *zao* 灶. Wang Shumin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (709) reads *yang zhe* 炀者 instead of *she zhe* 舍者, and includes *zao* 灶 before *xi* 席. It is likely that the original text had *yang zhe* 炀者 after *she zhe* 舍者 (or before it), and *zao* 灶 before *xi* 席. The phrase “the inn guests and those warming themselves now vied with him for hearth and mats” encompasses both “the inn guests rose from their mats” and “those warming themselves moved away from the hearth.” The *Taiping Yulan*’s version likely omits the two characters *she zhe* 舍者. [Pronunciation note:] *Wu* 恶 is pronounced *wulu*.

Yang Zhu passed through Song and stayed at an inn. The innkeeper had two concubines: one beautiful, the other plain. The plain one was honored, while the beautiful one was slighted. Yang Zhu asked the reason. The innkeeper’s young servant replied—[Annotation:] The *Hanfeizi*’s “Shuolin Shang” reads: “The innkeeper’s father answered”—“The beautiful one is beautiful in her own eyes, but I do not see her beauty. The plain one is plain in her own eyes, but I do not see her plainness.”

Yang Zi said: "Disciples, take note! Conduct yourself with worthiness yet discard the conduct of self-regard for worthiness—wherever you go, who would not cherish you?"
