[Annotation:] Arrogance, self-satisfaction, and boasting are what ghosts, spirits, and the human Dao do not favor; emptying the self to follow principle is what the world delights to uphold. Proceeding thus, who could resist you?

[Exegesis:] This further consolidates the meaning of the two preceding sections. Those who can make others preserve regard for me—do those who fail to preserve it do so out of envy? If one does not dare let things preserve regard for oneself, then the world will all forget one’s faults—how much more so the concubines of an inn?

[Annotation by Bo Jun:] The *Hanfeizi*’s “Shuolin Shang” reads: "Wherever you go, who would not find you beautiful?"

There is a Dao of constant victory and a Dao of inconstant victory.

[Tao Hongqing’s note:] "Inconstant victory" should read "constantly not victorious." The following text states, "The Dao of constant victory is softness; the Dao of constantly not being victorious is strength," which follows from this.

These two are also to be known—

[Annotation:] "Also" should read "easy."

[Pronunciation note:] *Yi* 亦 is also written *yi* 易, pronounced *yichi*.

Yet people have not understood this.

Thus the ancients said: "Strength first concerns those not equal to oneself"—
[Annotation:] It refers to those one can overcome who are beneath oneself.
"Softness first concerns what proceeds from oneself"—
[Annotation:] Without contending with things, nothing can impose upon one.

Those who first concern themselves with what is not equal to themselves will, upon reaching equality, be imperiled—
[Annotation:] Encountering an equal opponent must be perilous.
Those who first concern themselves with what proceeds from themselves will know no peril—
[Annotation:] Their principle remains constantly secure.
[Pronunciation note:] *Wang* 亡 is read as *wu* 无.

By this means, one may overcome a single body as if it were nothing, and by this means, one may bear the world as if it were nothing—this is called overcoming without striving to overcome, bearing without striving to bear.
[Annotation:] To embody the Dao of softness and emptiness, to dwell in a place of non-contention, though it be the nobility of a single body or the vastness of the world, to guide without intention is to be as nothing.

Nothing means emptiness and silence.
Guo Xiang said: "Listen only to what the ears hear, see only what the eyes see, know only what one knows, and do only what one can do. Employ what is naturally employed, act as one naturally acts, follow one’s nature without contending with things—this is the Dao of utmost softness. Thus, one lifts what lifts itself, holds what holds itself. Though it bears not even the weight of a fraction, I exert no force."
[Exegesis:] Strength and softness—these two are easy to know. Why, then, do people not understand? It is because the desire to prevail is too great. When one encounters those not equal to oneself, it is not yet true strength; if one encounters an equal, one is constantly in danger. Seeking to prevail over a single body or bear the world in this way is ever like servitude, never at ease.

As for softness, even those beneath oneself are not desired to be overcome—how much less those who proceed from oneself? What others call not overcoming, I call self-overcoming; what others call not bearing, I call self-bearing, and thus there is never failure.

Laozi said: "The soft and weak overcome the hard and strong."

Wu Kaisheng said: "*Ruotu* 若徒 means 'this Dao,' the annotation is mistaken."
Zhouzi said: [Pronunciation note:] *Zhou* 粥 is written *yu* 鬻 in the *Shiwen*, which reads: "鬻 originally written 粥, *yu liu* qie."
Ren Dachun said: "Examining the *Shiwen* of the *Liji* *Quli*, 'please *yu*' is also written *zhou*, *zhi liu* fan; the *Shiwen* of the *Zuozhuan*, 11th year of Duke Yin, 'yu' is also written *zhou*, *zhi liu* fan, and also *yu liu* fan; in the *Xia Xiao Zheng*, 'chicken *fu zhou*,' Lu Bian’s annotation reads, 'some say *zhou* means nourishment'; in the *Huainanzi* *Tianwen Xun*, 'walking *fu yu*,' Gao You’s annotation reads, '*fu yu* is *zhou*'; in the *Wen Xuan* *Pan Yue* *Jianju Fu*, 'irrigating gardens and *zhou* vegetables,' Li Shan’s annotation reads, '*zhou* is the same as *yu*'—thus *yu* and *zhou* are interchangeable."

"To desire hardness, one must guard it with softness;
To desire strength, one must preserve it with weakness."

Guard softness not to seek hardness, yet hardness arises of itself; preserve weakness not to seek strength, yet strength emerges of its own accord. Thus hardness and strength are not attainable through desire.

Yang Bojun notes: *Shou* (守, "guard") and *bao* (保, "preserve") rhyme, both being rising-tone words of the *you* rhyme group.

Accumulate softness, and hardness will inevitably follow; accumulate weakness, and strength will inevitably arise. Observe what is accumulated, and you will know the direction of fortune and misfortune.

[Annotation:] Fortune and misfortune arise from what is accumulated.

Strength that overcomes what is not equal to oneself will, when it reaches what is equal, become brittle.

[Annotation:] It will surely break.

Wu Kaisheng says: *Gang* (刚, "hardness") should be written as □, hence the annotation reads "it will surely break."

Wang Shumin says: The *Huainanzi*’s *Yuandao Xun* includes the word *zhe* (者, "that which") after "not equal to oneself" (文子 *Daoyuan* chapter likewise), making the sentence structure consistent with the following text; this should be followed.

Softness that overcomes what surpasses oneself has a power that cannot be measured.

Yang Bojun notes: The words of *Yuezi* cited here also appear in the *Huainanzi*’s *Yuandao Xun* and the *Wenzi*’s *Daoyuan* chapter, though neither attributes them to *Yuezi*. Additionally, *gang* (刚, "hardness"), *qiang* (强, "strength"), *xiang* (乡, "direction"), and *liang* (量, "measure") rhyme, all being words of the *yang* rhyme group in ancient pronunciation. The *Huainanzi*’s *Quan Yan Xun* reads: "Strength that overcomes what is not equal to oneself will, when it reaches what is equal, be obstructed; softness that overcomes what surpasses oneself has a power that cannot be measured," rhyming *ge* (格, "obstructed") and *du* (度, "measured").

Laozi said: "When weapons are strong, they perish.

[Annotation:] Wang Bi says: That which all things detest cannot endure to the end.

When wood is strong, it breaks.

[Annotation:] When strength reaches its extreme, it is destroyed.

Yang Bojun notes: The *Daodejing* (Chapter 76) reads: "When weapons are strong, they are not victorious; when wood is strong, it is felled." Yu Yue, Yi Shunding, and Ma Xulun all argue that the *Liezi* version should be followed, as detailed in *Laozi Hegu*.

*Mie* (灭, "perish") and *zhe* (折, "break") rhyme, both being words of the *zhi* rhyme group in ancient pronunciation.

The soft and weak are the companions of life; the hard and strong are the companions of death."

[Explanation:] The *Junzi* says: "Those who are overbearing do not meet a natural death; those who love to conquer will surely encounter their match. Accumulating virtue and piling up benevolence is the Way of softness."

Yang Bojun notes: This also appears in the *Daodejing* (Chapter 76). Additionally, in the Northern Song edition and Wang’s edition, "companions of death" (*si zhi tu*, 死之徒) reads "companions of transformation" (*hua zhi tu*, 化之徒); here, the reading follows the Zang edition and the Shidetang edition. Furthermore, the *Hanfeizi*’s *Jie Lao* chapter states: "*Tu* (徒) means *shu* (属, "to belong")." Thus, *tu* here should also be glossed as *shu*.

In appearance, one need not be childlike, yet wisdom may be childlike; in wisdom, one need not be childlike, yet appearance may be childlike. The sage embraces childlike wisdom and discards childlike appearance, while the common people cling to childlike appearance and distance themselves from childlike wisdom. Those whose appearance resembles mine are near and beloved; those whose appearance differs from mine are distant and feared.

[Annotation:] *Tong* (童, "childlike") should be written as *tong* (同, "same").

Wu Kaisheng says: Taking *tong* (童) as *tong* (同).

Though possessing a seven-foot frame, distinct hands and feet, hair on the head and teeth in the mouth, standing and moving—this is called a human. Yet humans are not necessarily without the hearts of beasts. Even with the hearts of beasts, by appearance they are deemed kin.

With wings attached and horns borne, fangs spread and claws arrayed, flying aloft or crouching to run—this is called a bird or beast. Yet birds and beasts are not necessarily without the hearts of humans. Even with the hearts of humans, by appearance they are deemed distant.

Fuxi,

[Annotation:] *Pao* (庖) is pronounced *pao* (匏); *xi* (牺) is pronounced *xi* (许宜切).

Nüwa,

[Annotation:] *Wa* (娲) is pronounced *gua* (瓜).

Fuxi and Nüwa were both ancient emperors.

Shennong, and the Xia Hou clan had the bodies of serpents and human faces, the heads of oxen and the noses of tigers—these possessed non-human appearances yet held the virtue of great sages.

[Annotation:] Human forms naturally include some resembling birds and beasts; many ancient sages had extraordinary appearances. The so-called "bodies of serpents and human faces" does not mean they were scaled and belly-crawling without limbs; "heads of oxen and noses of tigers" does not mean they bore horns, had hanging dewlaps, broad foreheads, or loose jaws—just as physiognomy describes "tortoise backs," "crane strides," "kite shoulders," or "hawk beaks."

[Annotation:] *Yi* (臆) is pronounced *yi* (亿); *man* (曼) is pronounced *wan* (万); *e* (頞) is pronounced *e* (乌葛切, "bridge of the nose"); *han* (颔) is pronounced *han* (胡感切, "jaw"); *xiang* (相) is pronounced *xiang* (息亮切); *hu* (鹄) is pronounced *he* (鹤); *yuan* (鸢) is pronounced *yuan* (缘); *hui* (喙) is pronounced *hui* (许秽切).

Jie of Xia, Zhou of Yin, Huan of Lu, and Mu of Chu had the seven apertures of human appearance yet possessed the hearts of birds and beasts. Yet the common people cling to a single appearance in pursuit of supreme wisdom—this is hardly attainable.

[Explanation:] What makes different beings kin is spirit. When spirit departs, even the bond between father and child becomes estranged. Thus, spending a night of terror under the same roof as living creatures brings no fear, for their spirits are the same. Dwelling in an ordinary house with a corpse in the same room induces terror, for their spirits differ. Though the dead and the living share the same form as before, one feels at ease while the other is afraid—this is because those of the same kind have departed, and the form is no longer kin. Yet humans, unaware that all living things share the same spirit despite differing forms, assume worry and fear. To base kinship and distance on the similarity or difference of appearance is delusion. Thus, Zhuangzi says: "What all things share is spirit; therefore, spirit is the master of nurturing life."

Yang Bojun notes: Duke Huan of Lu killed his elder brother to seize the throne, and Duke Mu of Chu killed his father to seize the throne—hence they are said to have the conduct of birds and beasts. The *Explanation* cites Zhuangzi, but this passage does not appear in the current text. In the Qin dynasty engraving, "spending" (*ju*, 居) is written as "after" (*hou*, 后); here, it follows the *Sijie* edition.

[Annotation:] *Ji* (几) is pronounced *ji* (冀).

The Yellow Emperor and the Flame Emperor battled at the wilds of Banquan,

[Annotation:] *Ban* (阪) is pronounced *ban* (蒲阪切). Banquan is in Shanggu.

leading bears, brown bears, wolves, leopards, lynxes, and tigers as their vanguard.

Yang Bojun notes: *Chu* (貙) refers to a large tiger.

The *Explanation* notes: *Shuai* (帅) is pronounced *shuai* (率). *Pi* (罴) is pronounced *pi* (碑). *Chu* (貙) is pronounced *chu* (丑俱切). Eagles, sparrowhawks, hawks, and kites served as their banners.

Wang Shumin notes: The *Yiwen Leiju* (90, 91), *Chuxue Ji* (22), *Taiping Yulan* (919), and *Yu Hai* (83) all include the character "以" before "雕," which should be followed. The current text omits "以," leaving the meaning incomplete.

The *Explanation* notes: *Diaohe* (雕鹖) is pronounced *diaohe* (雕曷), with one version reading *e* (鹗). *Zhi* (帜) is pronounced *chi* (炽). All creatures from bears to brown bears are fierce beasts and valiant fighters.

Hu Huaichen notes: The version reading *e* (鹗) is correct. The original text refers to fierce beasts and birds of prey; the sparrowhawk is not a bird of prey and does not belong among them. The reading *e* (鹗) is thus appropriate.

This is the use of brute force to command beasts. Yao tasked Kui with overseeing music: striking and tapping stones, the hundred beasts danced in unison; when the *Xiao Shao* was played to its ninth movement, the phoenix came to pay homage—this is the use of sound to summon beasts. If so, how do the hearts of beasts differ from those of humans? Their forms and sounds differ from ours, yet we know not the Way of engaging with them.

The *Explanation* reads: "而人不知接之之道," noting that one version omits the character "人." The sage is all-knowing and all-penetrating, thus able to lead and employ them. The wisdom of beasts includes what comes naturally and what they share with human children. In aligning desires and preserving life, they do not borrow wisdom from humans:

Male and female pair as mates, mother and child share affection; they avoid flatlands and seek high ground, shun cold and pursue warmth;

Hu Junyan notes: Hu Huaiche argued that humans do not inherently detest flatlands or favor perilous terrain, thus interpreting "avoid flatlands and seek high ground" as referring to defense. In truth, all these phrases take beasts as their subject, with humans outside their scope. Hu’s claim is incorrect.

When at rest, they form groups; when moving, they maintain ranks. The *Explanation* reads: "行, pronounced as *hù gāng*." The young stay within, the strong guard without. When drinking, they accompany one another; when feeding, they call to the flock.

In the Great Antiquity, the *Explanation* reads: "太 as *dà*, pronounced *tài*," they dwelled alongside humans and walked abreast with them. The *Annotation* states: "Where virtue is pure, beasts harbor no fear." In the age of emperors and kings, they first grew startled, scattered, and disordered. By the degenerate era, they concealed themselves and fled, evading harm. The *Annotation* states: "When humans harbor intent to harm, creatures too know to avoid them."

Now, in the land of the Jieshi in the east, the *Explanation* reads: "介 pronounced *jiè*," there are those who frequently comprehend the speech of the six domestic animals. The *Explanation* reads: "数 pronounced *shuò*; 畜, pronounced *xiù* or *chù*; 解 pronounced *xiè*, as in the annotation." This is but a partial attainment of knowledge. The *Annotation* states: "The tortoise and dragon are the progenitors of creatures with shells and scales; the qilin and phoenix, the sovereigns of those with fur and feathers. Even down to the flying midges and wriggling insects, all call out to one another, each with its own intent and purpose, mutually restraining and guiding—how do they differ from humans? Yet humans, unable to understand, claim that the sounds of beasts lack structure or pattern. Thus, one who exhausts principle and perfects wisdom may penetrate ten thousand paths; one who grasps a single thread through circumstance may chance upon but one avenue."

The *Zuozhuan* of the *Spring and Autumn Annals* states: "Jie Gelu heard an ox low and said, 'This one will bear four calves, all to be used as sacrificial victims.'" The annotation "鸣呼" in the four *Explanations* edition is mistakenly written as "鸣呼." Lu Wenchang notes: "In other editions, the character 'four' in the annotation is corrected to 'three' following the *Zuozhuan*." Bo Jun observes: "Both 'four' and 'three' in ancient script are composed of stacked strokes, leading to this error. Here, it should be corrected according to the *Zuozhuan*." Examining the end of Lu’s *Explanation*, the edition he consulted also reads "three." Shen Tao, however, emended the *Zuozhuan* based on this text, thereby inverting right and wrong (Shen’s argument is found in *Jiaocuixuan Biji*, juan three). The commentary to the *Shishuo Xinyu*’s "Words and Conversations" chapter also cites the *Zuozhuan* as "This one will bear three calves, all to be used as sacrifices," which aligns with the current edition of the *Zuozhuan*, providing further evidence.

The *Explanation* reads: "长, pronounced *zhàng*; 蜎, *xuān*; 蠕, *rú*."

In the highest antiquity, the spiritually sagacious possessed complete knowledge of the dispositions of all things and fully understood the sounds of different kinds. They assembled and gathered them, instructing and teaching them, making them equal to the people. Thus, they first convened with ghosts, spirits, *chīmèi*, and demons—the annotation notes: "This refers to Yu summoning the multitude of spirits at Mount Kuaiji." The *Explanation* reads: "魑, pronounced *chī*; 魅, *mèi*." Next, they reached the people of the eight directions, and finally assembled birds, beasts, insects, and moths—the annotation notes: "This refers to the hundred beasts leading the dance." The *Explanation* reads: "*Erya* states: 'Those with legs are called *chóng* (insects); those without legs are called *é* (moths).' An alternate version reads *chóngyǐ* (insects and ants)." This shows that the hearts and minds of creatures with blood and *qi* do not differ greatly. The spiritually sagacious, knowing this to be so, left nothing untaught or uninstructed in what they imparted.

The *Explanation* states: In the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, Jie Gelu heard the lowing of an ox and knew it would produce three sacrificial beasts; Yu’s summoning of the multitude of spirits and Shun’s [dance with] the hundred beasts—these are examples of such affairs. Qin Enfu remarked: "Lu’s *Explanation* omits the characters *shuàiwǔ* (‘leading the dance’) after ‘hundred beasts.’" Sun Yirang countered: "The *Explanation* omits a *wǔ* (‘dance’) after ‘Shun.’ ‘Shun danced with the hundred beasts’ parallels the preceding phrase ‘Yu summoned the multitude of spirits.’ Qin’s claim of an omission of *shuàiwǔ* is incorrect."

There was in Song a certain Master Ju,—the annotation notes: "One fond of raising gibbons and monkeys, hence called Master Ju." The *Explanation* reads: "*Jū* is pronounced *qīyú*; Master Ju, the gibbon-raising master." He loved gibbons, kept them in troops, and could comprehend their intentions;—the *Explanation* reads: "*Jiě* is pronounced *xiè*."—the gibbons, in turn, understood the master’s heart. He diminished his household’s provisions to satisfy the gibbons’ desires. Soon, however, he found himself impoverished and sought to limit their food. Fearing the troop of gibbons would not submit to him,—the annotation notes: "*Xùn* is pronounced *chún*." The *Explanation* reads: "*Xùn* is pronounced *chún*."—he first deceived them, saying: "I will give you acorns— the annotation notes: "*Xù*, chestnuts." The *Explanation* reads: "*Xù* is pronounced *yǔ*, oak nuts."—three in the morning and four at dusk. Is that enough?" The troop of gibbons all rose in anger. Presently, he said: "I will give you acorns, four in the morning and three at dusk. Is that enough?" The troop of gibbons all prostrated themselves in delight.

All things that are lured by cunning and baseness are like this. Wu Kaiming remarked: "*Bǐ* should be read as *fǒu*." The *Explanation* reads: "The phrase *néng bǐ xiāng lǒng* (‘lured by cunning and baseness’) appears in one version as *zhì bǐ xiāng lǒng* (‘lured by intelligence and baseness’)." Bo Jun noted: "The version with *zhì* (‘intelligence’) is likely correct, as the following text—‘using intelligence to lure the multitude of fools and the troop of gibbons’—directly follows from this." The sage lures the multitude of fools with intelligence, just as Master Ju lured the troop of gibbons with intelligence. Neither name nor reality suffers loss—"name and reality" appears in the Northern Song edition as "if reality," and Wang’s edition follows this; here, we follow the *Zang* edition, Qin’s engraved edition, and the *Shidetang* edition in emending it. The *Zhuangzi*’s *Qiwulun* reads: "name and reality do not suffer loss." The *Explanation* reads: "‘do not’ appears as ‘have not’; it also appears in one version as ‘if reality has not suffered loss.’"—thereby manipulating their joy and anger.

The *Explanation* states: Though all sentient beings share in spirit, those with rounded heads and square feet—humans—are the most intelligent. The most intelligent among them become sages and worthies; those of greatest talent become kings and lords. The sage assigns tasks according to ability, each receiving what is fitting. Whether small or great, each fulfills its proper role. Thus, no person is discarded, nor is any thing. Luring them with intelligence—is this limited to the troop of gibbons alone?

The *Ji Shengzi* reared fighting cocks for King Xuan of Zhou. The *Zangwai* edition reads *Ji Xiaozi*; the Qin edition concurs. Here, we follow the Northern Song edition, the Jifu edition, the *Taiping Yulan* (918), and the *Yiwen Leiju* (91) for correction. The *Zhuangzi*’s *Dasheng* chapter records the same. Bo Jun notes: In the twenty-fifth year of Duke Zhao’s reign in the *Zuozhuan*, the cocks of the Ji and Hou clans fought, where the Ji clan fitted their cock with spurs, and the Hou clan gilded its spurs. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Qu You* chapter and the *Huainanzi*’s *Renjian Xun* also contain this passage. Cockfighting in antiquity was akin to modern cricket-fighting. The ancient *yuefu* and Tao Qian’s *Returning to Dwell in Gardens and Fields* say, “Cocks crow atop the mulberry trees.” Du Zimei’s *Three Poems from Qiang Village* reads: “The flock of cocks clamors in chaos; guests arrive as the cocks fight. Driving the cocks up the trees, only then do I hear the knocking at the brushwood gate.” In the Tang, cocks could still perch in trees, but today few can. In recent times, cockfighting persists in Guangdong and southern Hunan. The *Explanation* reads *Ji Xiaozi* as *Ji Shengzi*, noting: the surname is Ji, the given name Sheng (or Xiao, pronounced *suǒ jǐng*). *Wei* is pronounced *yú wěi*.

After ten days, the king asked, “Are the cocks ready to fight?”
He replied, “Not yet. They are still hollowly proud and reliant on their qi.”
[Annotation] Those without substance who vaunt themselves.

After another ten days, the king asked again.
He replied, “Not yet. They still respond to shadows and echoes.”
[Annotation] Their reactions are swift.
Lu Wenchang notes: The annotation “swift” in the *Zangwai* edition reads “rapid.”
The *Explanation* reads “swift” as “rapid,” noting: *xiang* is pronounced *xiǎng*. Li Yi says: They answer to cries and turn toward their shadows. *Xun* is pronounced *jùn* or *shēn*; one version reads *su*.

After another ten days, the king asked again.
He replied, “Not yet.”

Still they stare fiercely and bristle with qi.
[Annotation] Ever seeking an opponent and insisting on their own victory.

After another ten days, the king asked again.
He replied, “Nearly so. Though other cocks may crow, this one no longer changes.
[Annotation] Confronted by an opponent, it does not respond—it has forgotten victory and defeat.
Seen from afar, it resembles a wooden cock. Its virtue is complete.
[Annotation] One so perfectly whole no longer resembles creatures of blood and qi.
No other cock dares to challenge it; they turn and flee.”
[Annotation] One whose virtue is complete not only harbors no intent within but also prevents external things from arising in opposition.

Guo Xiang says: To nurture it to completion is to be without rival in the world—how much more so to be complete in oneself?

[Explanation] Relying on qi to vaunt oneself is no sure path to victory. Reacting swiftly to things like an echo or shadow means being turned by them, not yet attaining self-mastery. Fierce stares and bristling qi show the machinations of the mind have not been forgotten. Only by forgetting form and spirit, embracing life and death as one, and remaining unmoved by change can one be without rival among external things.

Hui Ang
[Annotation] Hui Ang was of the same clan as Hui Shi. The *Huainanzi*’s “Dao-ying Xun” writes “Hui Meng” instead; the same below. The *Daozang* annotation reads “grandson of Hui Shi.” Zhang’s commentary on the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s “Shun Shuo” has “grandson” in error.

Pronunciation note: *Ang* is pronounced *ā làng*.

He was received by King Kang of Song.
[Collation] The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s “Shun Shuo” Gao commentary states: “King Kang was the great-grandson of Duke Zhao of Song, son of Duke Pi, named Qin. He reigned eleven years, usurped the title of king, and after forty-five years of great impropriety was called ‘the Song ruler unworthy of benevolence and righteousness.’ King Min of Qi conquered and destroyed him.”
Bi Yuan says: Liang Bozi notes that the annotation “named Qin” should read “Yan.” The “forty-five years” differs from the *Jin Se* commentary’s “forty-seven years,” but in fact it was sixty-one years.

Pronunciation note: *See* is pronounced *xiàn*.

The king stamped his foot and cleared his throat.
Wu Kaisheng says: *Die* should be read as *die* (to stumble).
[Collation] Many Six Dynasties texts mention “stamping the foot,” with varying interpretations. The *Liangshu*’s biography of Crown Prince Zhaoming reads: “The steed stamps its foot with a mournful whinny, the hearse moves slowly with a sorrowful clatter”—here “stamping the foot” means a slow pace. Yan Yanzhi’s *Red and White Horse Rhapsody* reads: “Gazing west with head held high, toward northern clouds it stamps its foot”—here “stamping the foot” means swift movement.

Pronunciation notes: *Die* is pronounced *dié*; *qing* is pronounced *qǐng*.

"Kai" is pronounced *kǎi*.

The king spoke hastily: "What I, the solitary one, delight in—*shuo* is pronounced *yuè* (delight), same below—is courage and strength, not delighting in benevolence and righteousness. What instruction do you have for me?"

Hui Ang replied: "I possess a Dao here that renders a man, though brave, unable to pierce;—*ci* (pierce) is pronounced *qì*—though strong, unable to strike.—*zhong* (strike) is pronounced *zhòng*, same below. Does Your Majesty not wish to hear it?"

The King of Song said: "Excellent; this is what I desire to hear."

Hui Ang said: "Though one cannot pierce and cannot strike, this is still a disgrace. I possess a Dao here that makes a man, though brave, dare not pierce; though strong, dare not strike. That he dares not—is not because he lacks the will. I possess a Dao here that eliminates the will itself. That there is no such will—*Daozang* white-text edition and Lin Xiyi’s edition both read *zhe* (者) for *ye* (也)—is because there is no mind of love and benefit. I possess a Dao here that makes all men and women under heaven joyfully desire to love and benefit one another.—*Huan* (joyfully) is pronounced *huān*. This surpasses courage and strength, standing above the four layers."

[Annotation] It stands above the ranks of ministers, grandees, officers, and commoners, hence "four layers." Guang Congxie says: "The four layers: the first is being unable to pierce or strike; the second, daring not to pierce or strike; the third, having no will to strike; the fourth, making all under heaven desire to benefit one another." Hu Huaichen’s explanation is the same. Tao Hongqing says: "This passage should read the thirteen characters *this surpasses courage and strength, standing above the four layers* as a single phrase. The four layers refer collectively to the four matters above: courage and strength (first); being unable to pierce or strike (second); daring not to pierce or strike (third); and having no will to strike (fourth). What is now spoken of—having no such will and yet possessing a mind of love and benefit—thus stands above the four layers. *Lei* (layers) means cumulative levels, like four tiers above." The *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying Xun* quotes this passage, with Gao You’s commentary: "These four matters are all burdens upon the world, while making men and women joyfully desire to benefit one another is above them"—though the meaning remains unclear. Wu Kaisheng says: "The 'four layers' refer to the four matters above; the annotation is mistaken."

The King of Song said: "This is what I desire to obtain."

[Explanation] Unable to pierce or strike (first); not daring to pierce or strike (second); having no will to strike (third); making men and women joyfully love and benefit one another (fourth). Of these four tiers, to attain the highest—how would that be? Thus the King of Song eagerly desired to hear it.

Hui Ang replied: "Confucius and Mozi are such."

Here the elucidation shows that employing wisdom to harmonize all things and exalting instruction to transform people are but secondary affairs for those who ascend through virtue. Confucius and Mozi, though without land, became rulers; *Shiwen* notes: “翟 is read as *Di*.” Mo Di, a grandee of Song who lived after Confucius, composed seventy-one chapters advocating filial piety, reverence for spirits, strengthening the root and moderating expenditure—also a remedy for the world’s ills; he possessed arts of attack and defense. Though without office, they became leaders; the Qin edition reads “office” as “palace.” *Shiwen* notes: “长 is read as *zhǎng*.” Not a man or woman under Heaven failed to crane their necks and stand on tiptoe, yearning to dwell in peace and benefit under them.

Now Your Majesty is lord of ten thousand chariots; the *Lüshi Chunqiu* reads “ten thousand chariots” as “one thousand chariots.” If you truly hold such aspiration, then within the four borders— the Qin edition reads “竟” as “境.” *Shiwen* notes: “竟 is read as *jìng*.”—all would receive its benefit. Your worth would far surpass that of Confucius and Mozi.

The King of Song had no reply. Hui Ang hastened out. The King of Song said to his attendants: “How persuasive! The guest has convinced me with his argument!” Here the elucidation shows that exalting the Dao to illumine virtue and leaving traces to benefit people—while the multitude of disciples see only the transmission of Confucius and Mozi’s teachings, how would they know the hidden Dao that manifests virtue? Thus the inquiry into the ford does not herd with birds and beasts; this is its great purport.

*Bo Jun’s note*: The elucidation’s “inquiry into the ford does not herd with birds and beasts” alludes to the *Analects’* *Weizi* chapter, where Zilu is sent to ask about the ford, and the Master, dismayed, says one cannot herd with birds and beasts—but this does not accord with the original meaning of the *Analects*. *Shiwen* notes: “说 is read as *shuō*, or alternatively as *shuì*.” “Convince the King” in one edition reads “enlighten the King.” *Liezi Jishi*, Scroll Three, *King Mu of Zhou*, Third.

The *Annotation* states: That which receives existence and is called "form" is born; that which bends and rises in ceaseless alteration is called "transformation." Where the spirit intermingles is called "dream"; where form engages is called "waking." Tracing them to their utmost, they converge in emptiness and artifice. Why? The substance of life is rooted in stagnation, enduring a hundred years before its end; the passions of transformation branch shallowly, vanishing in the blink of an eye. The Dao of spirit is dim and indistinct, now present, now absent; the principles of form are manifest and evident, now real, now solid. Thus one who perceives deeply knows the principle of arising and ceasing is equal, the paths of waking and dreaming are one; though ten thousand changes unfold in profusion, they do not touch the spirit’s contemplation. The deluded, confounding the manifest and the obscure, take the slowness or swiftness of verification as cause for doubt, and so cling to the self, regarding the bodily frame as their true dwelling. Who recognizes that the root and return of life and transformation lie in nothingness?

The *Elucidation* states: Heaven and earth form vessels, encompassing all things. Human beings live within them, yet only preserve their existence; they never realize that spirit governs form, and the insubstantial is not constrained by the substantial. This is why the sage nurtures the root, while the foolish know only to nurture the branch. They constrict form to sustain life, coveting life yet unaware of life’s master; they take the decay of form as death, unaware that spirit and consciousness endure forever. The deluded remain ordinary, while the enlightened attain sagely wisdom. The confused are many, so the text first speaks of the enlightened to clarify the distinction.

Wang Lai notes: In the *Elucidation*, "the insubstantial is not constrained by the substantial" should read "the substantial is constrained by the insubstantial." Qin Enfu notes: In the *Elucidation*, the character "branch" is missing before "constricts form." Bo Jun’s note: In the *Annotation*, after "one who perceives deeply," the character "者" should be added. The *Shiwen* reads "blink of an eye" as "blink of an eye," and "dim and indistinct" as "elusive and indistinct," and notes: *俛* is pronounced *miǎn*. *觉* is pronounced *jiào*. *怳* is pronounced *huǎng*. *惚* is pronounced *hū*. Regarding the time of King Mu of Zhou, the *Shiwen* states: King Mu of Zhou was named Man, son of King Zhao.

In the kingdom of the Western Extremity, there came a *huaren*—a being of transformation and illusion. Bo Jun’s note: The *Shu Chao* (Vol. 129), *Tai Ping Yu Lan* (Vols. 173, 626) quote "Western Extremity" as "Western Regions." The *Yi Wen Lei Ju* (Vol. 62) quotes it as "Western Hu." The *Shiwen* notes: *幻* is pronounced *huàn*. They entered water and fire, pierced metal and stone; they reversed mountains and rivers, relocated cities and towns. Riding the void, they did not fall; encountering the solid, they met no obstruction. Their thousand changes and ten thousand transformations could not be exhausted. Having already altered the forms of things, they further transformed people’s thoughts—temporarily causing them to forget their long-held knowledge and perceptions. King Mu revered them as spirits and served them as lords.

The *Elucidation* states: The concerns of ordinary people extend no further than cravings and aversions, fame and profit, benevolence and righteousness. The *huaren* now returns them to their true nature, hence it is called "transformation." The *huaren* is a body responsive to all things. Exhausting principle and perfecting wisdom, their responses are boundless; their thousand changes and ten thousand transformations have no end. King Mu offered them a secluded chamber to reside in, presented the three sacrificial animals, and selected female musicians to entertain them. The *huaren* deemed the king’s palace crude and unfit for dwelling, his kitchen fare rank and foul and inedible—Hu Huaichen notes: "蝼" should be "偻," with the characters "偻" and "膻" transposed. It should read: "The king’s palace was crude and unfit for dwelling, his kitchen fare rank and foul and inedible, his consorts and attendants deformed and repulsive and unlovable." The *Shiwen* notes: *腥* is pronounced *xīng*. *蝼* is pronounced *lóu*. *飨* is pronounced *xiǎng*. The *Zhou Li*, "Offices of Heaven," "Nei Yong" states: "That which is rank and inedible: horses with black spines and patterned forelegs, and *lóugū*." Zheng Xuan comments: "Patterned forelegs refer to fur with natural markings. *Lóugū* is the stench of mole crickets." Modern readers should follow the *Zhou Li*’s *Yong Shi*. *饔* is pronounced *yōng*. *般* is pronounced *bān*. Bo Jun’s note: The current edition of the *Fang Yan* still reads "蝼蛄," not with the "女" radical. The king’s consorts and attendants were rank and repulsive and unlovable.

The *Elucidation* states: To deem the king’s palace crude, his kitchen fare rank, and his consorts and attendants foul is to show that the *huaren* does not value sensory pleasures, flavors, or dwellings. Yu Yue notes: *膻* should be *膻*, meaning foul and unlovable. The *Guang Ya*, "Explanation of Utensils," states: "膻 means foul." The *Shiwen* notes: *膻* is pronounced *shān*. King Mu then had it rebuilt for them. Wang Shu Min notes: The *Rong Zhai Si Bi* (Vol. 3) includes the characters "palace chambers" after "built." The labor of earth and timber, the *Shiwen* notes: *乃* is written as *乃*, an ancient form of *乃*. *为* is pronounced *wěi*. The colors of ochre and whitewash, the *Shiwen* notes: *赭* is pronounced *zhě*, red. *垩* is pronounced *è*, white earth. No craftsmanship was spared. The five treasuries were emptied, and the terrace was finally completed. A thousand *ren* in height, it overlooked the summit of Mount Zhongnan—the *Shiwen* notes: Zhongnan is a mountain name in Jingzhao—and was named the Terrace of Central Heaven. He selected from among the graceful and supple maidens of Zheng and Wei, those of delicate beauty and lithe elegance—the *Annotation* states: *娥媌* means bewitching beauty; *靡曼* means soft and delicate. The *Shiwen* notes: *媌* is pronounced *máo*. Those lovely and light are called *娥*; east of the Pass, in the regions of He and Qi, they are called *媌*, or sometimes *妖*. *曼* is pronounced *wàn*.

They applied fragrant unguents and perfected their moth-like brows—*"e"* in most editions appears as *"é"* (moth). Wang Chongmin notes: the Jifu edition writes *"é"* as *"e"* (beauty). *"E"* is the proper character, while *"é"* is the vulgar form. *Fangyan* states: *"e"* means "beautiful"; in the regions of Qin and Jin, those lovely and light are called *"e."* This is the original sense of *"e-mei"* (moth-brows). The notion that it resembles the brows of silkworm moths began with Yan Shigu’s *Hanshu* commentary, which, misreading the *Shi Jing*’s *Wei Feng* *"Shi Ren"* ("The Stately Lady")—where *"qin"* (dragonfly) and *"e"* (moth) stand in parallel—mistook *"qin"* for *"qingqing"* (a kind of insect) and thus took *"e"* to mean silkworm moths, unaware that *"qin"* should be *□* and *"e"* should be *"e"* (beauty). The *Chu Ci*’s *Da Zhao* reads: *"E-mei, lithe and graceful."* Mei Cheng’s *Qi Fa* has: *"Radiant teeth, moth-like brows."* Zhang Heng’s *Si Xuan Fu* writes: *"Delicate eyes, moth-like brows."* All use *"e."* Bo Jun notes: Wang’s argument follows Chen Huan’s *Mao Shi Zhuan Shu*, and is correct. Here we follow the Jifu edition. *Shiwen* notes: *"e"* is pronounced *é*. They adorned themselves with hairpins and earrings—the *Annotation* states: *ji* are hair ornaments; *er* are *tian* (earplugs). *Shiwen* notes: *ji* is pronounced *jī*; *er* is pronounced *ěr*; *tian* are jade pendants hanging from the crown to fill the ears. *Tian* is pronounced *tiàn* (with the initial *t* as in *tian*). They wore robes of fine *a*-silk and *xi*-cloth—the *Annotation* states: *a* is fine *hu* (gauze); *xi* is fine linen. Hu Huaichen notes: *xi* is interchangeable with *xi* (fine hemp). *A* refers to Dong’e County in Qi, as cited in Xu Guang’s commentary to the *Li Si Zhuan*. *A-xi* stands in parallel with *Qi-wan* (Qi silk). *A* here clearly refers to Dong’e; Zhang’s annotation is incorrect. *Shiwen* notes: *yi* (to wear) is pronounced *yì*; *hu* is pronounced *hú*. They trailed skirts of Qi silk—the *Annotation* states: Qi is the name of the region where *wan* (silk) is produced. *Shiwen* notes: *ye* (to trail) is pronounced *yì*. *Qi-wan*: Fan Zi states, *"White silk and plain silk come from Qi and Lu."* They powdered their faces white and darkened their brows with *dai*. *Shiwen* notes: *dai* is pronounced *dài*. They wore jade pendants and rings, and adorned themselves with mixed *zhi* and *ruo*—the *Annotation* states: *zhi* and *ruo* are fragrant herbs. *Shiwen* notes: *zhi* is pronounced *zhǐ*. They filled the halls to overflowing, and performed *Cheng Yun*, *Liu Ying*, *Jiu Shao*, and *Chen Lu* to entertain them—the *Annotation* states: *Cheng Yun* is the music of the Yellow Emperor; *Liu Ying*, the music of Emperor Ku; *Jiu Shao*, the music of Shun; *Chen Lu*, the music of Tang. *Shiwen* writes *"Jiu Shao"* as *"Jiu Zhao"*, and notes: *ying* is pronounced *yìng* (with the initial *w* as in *wù*), or *jīng*; *zhao* was originally *shao*, pronounced *shào*. Ren Dachun notes: The *Li Sao* reads, *"They played the* Jiu Ge *and danced the* Shao*,"* with a supplementary note: *"The* Shan Hai Jing *states that Xia Hou Kai began the song* Jiu Zhao. *" Kai is the same as Qi. The* Bamboo Annals *reads, *"Xia Hou Qi danced the* Jiu Shao*,"* showing that* zhao *and* shao *were often used interchangeably in antiquity. Every month they presented jade robes, and every morning they offered jade delicacies—the *Annotation* states: This speaks of their rare treasures. *"Month-month"* in the Shide Tang edition appears as *"sun-moon,"* which is incorrect. Even the *hua-ren* (transformed beings) could not bear to leave, and only with reluctance did he ascend the terrace. *Shiwen* notes: *she* is pronounced *shì*.

**[Exegesis]**
The king failed to grasp its meaning and instead embellished it further. Even the transformed being remained unsettled, for his true heart lay not in this. Qin Enfu notes: The exegesis contains a superfluous "之" character.

After but a short while—*Shiwen* notes: *wáng* is pronounced *wú*; *jǐ* is pronounced *jū qǐ*—he requested the king to journey together. *Shiwen* notes: *yè* means "to request." The king grasped the transformed being’s sleeve—*Annotation*: *qū* refers to the sleeve of a garment. *Shiwen* notes: *qū* is pronounced *qū*—and soared upward until they halted mid-heaven. *Shiwen* notes: *shàng* is pronounced *shí zhǎng*.

They arrived at the transformed being’s palace. Wang Chongmin observes: "暨" and "及" share the same meaning; their pairing here is redundant, likely due to a later hand appending "及" beneath "暨" as a gloss, which was then mistakenly incorporated into the main text. The *Leiju* (62), *Chuxue Ji* (27), and *Yulan* (812) all omit the character "及." Wang Shumin adds: The *Beishan Lu* (1, "Shengren Sheng" chapter), *Wen Xuan* commentary on Zuo Taichong’s *Wei Du Fu*, and *Yulan* (173) likewise omit "及." *Shiwen* notes: *jì* is pronounced *qí qì*.

The transformed being’s palace was constructed of gold and silver, adorned with pearls and jade. It rose above the clouds and rain, its foundations unseen below. Wang Shumin notes: The *Beishan Lu* (1, "Shengren Sheng" chapter) includes the character "所" before "据," rendering the phrasing more complete; this should be followed. From afar, it appeared like a mass of clouds. All that met the eyes and ears, all that entered the nose and mouth, was unlike anything found in the human realm.

King Mu believed this to be the Qingdu, Ziwei, Juntian, and Guangyue—realms where the Thearch dwells.

**[Annotation]** Qingdu and Ziwei are the abodes of the Heavenly Thearch. *Records* state: "When Duke Mu of Qin fell ill and lost consciousness, upon awakening he said: 'I was in the Thearch’s realm, greatly joyed, roaming with the hundred spirits in the Juntian’s vast music. Nine performances and myriad dances—unlike the music of the Three Dynasties, its sounds stirred the heart.'" Another account claims Viscount Jian of Zhao experienced the same.

**[Bo Jun’s note]** The annotation’s content appears in the *Records of the Grand Historian*, *Biographies of Bian Que and Cang Gong*.

**[Shiwen]** "Mu" is written as "Miao." "Guangyue" (*yue*) is pronounced *yuè*; the annotation concurs. "Shenle" (*le*) is pronounced *luò*. "Miao" is pronounced *mù*.

The king lowered his gaze and saw palaces and pavilions stacked like clods of earth and heaps of brushwood.

**[Shiwen]** "Kuai" is pronounced *kòu duì*. "Su" refers to firewood gatherers.

**[Bo Jun’s note]** The *Shiwen*’s "人" is likely a scribal error for "也." The *Shide Tang* edition emends it to "也."

The king, having dwelled there for decades, no longer longed for his own kingdom.

**[Annotation]** This is what is meant by "altering one’s concerns."

**[Exegesis]** The Central Heaven embodies the most numinous of hearts. As King Mu could not instantly forsake his desires, the transformation was wrought through the splendor of palaces, seizing his most cherished attachments.

The transformed being again invited the king to roam together.

**[Shiwen]** "Fu" is pronounced *fú yòu*.

Wherever they went,

**[Shiwen]** "Chu" is pronounced *chǎng jù*.

Above, he saw neither sun nor moon; below, neither rivers nor seas. Wherever light and radiance shone,

**[Wang Shumin’s note]** The *Beishan Lu* (1, "Shengren Sheng" chapter) writes "彩" for "影."

The king’s eyes blurred, unable to see clearly.

**[Shiwen]** "Xuan" is pronounced *xuán*.

Wherever sounds arose, the king’s ears were confounded, unable to hear distinctly. His hundred bones and six viscera quivered, unsettled.

**[Shiwen]** "Ji" is pronounced *qí jì*.

His mind wandered, his essence scattered.

**[Shiwen]** "Sang" is pronounced *xī làng*.

He begged the transformed being to let him return.

**[Annotation]** The realm of the Great Void’s indistinctness is not a place mortals can traverse. Confusion of heart and eyes is the natural consequence.

The transformed being moved him,

**[Annotation]** "Moved" means "pushed."

And the king fell as if into the void.

**[Annotation]** "Yun" means "to plummet."

**[Exegesis]** The ultimate principle is the very place the transformed being reached. All phenomena are utterly exhausted—how could sun, moon, rivers, or seas remain? All delusions are dispelled—how could light or shadows persist? This is a state the vulgar form cannot endure, nor the ordinary heart ever know. Yet clinging to the past lingered, so he begged to return.

**[Note]** "殒" in all editions is also written as "". **Wang Lai’s note:** The exegesis omits "音响" before "光景."

**[Shiwen]** "殒" is written as "", pronounced *yǔn*, meaning "to fall."

Upon awakening, he found himself seated where he had been before,

**[Shiwen]** "Xiang" is pronounced *xiàng*.

And his attendants were the same as before. Looking ahead, the wine had not yet cleared, nor the dishes spoiled.

**[Annotation]** Pronounced *fú guì*.

**[Shiwen]** "Fei" is pronounced *fú guì*.

The local dialect explains: "昲" means "to dry things." It is also pronounced *fèi*.

The king asked where he had come from. His attendants replied, "The king has been in silent meditation." From this, King Mu was lost in self-absorption for three months before recovering.

**[Shiwen]** The phrase reads, "for three months before recovering," with one variant reading "did not recover."

He further inquired about the *Huaren*.

**[Annotation]** He asked about the meaning of the form remaining unmoved.

**[Exegesis]** Free from the cares of clinging, he entered the method of tranquil illumination. In a single thought, he surpassed what ten thousand generations could not attain. How could the realm of the perfected person require another method? Thus, the wine had not yet cleared, nor the dishes dried. His attendants saw the king sitting in silence, with no coming or going, and so for three months, the king sat in forgetfulness, not daring to ask.

**Qin Enfu’s note:** The character "聖" (*shèng*) in the exegesis is an error, possibly a superfluous addition.

**Bo Jun’s note:** In the exegesis, the phrase "肴未昲" (*yáo wèi fèi*)—in the Qin edition, "未" (*wèi*) was written as "夫" (*fū*)—has been corrected here according to the *Sijie* edition.

The *Huaren* said, "I traveled in spirit with Your Majesty—how could the form have moved?

**[Annotation]** That which is called "spirit" moves without haste yet arrives swiftly, goes without walking yet reaches its destination. To illustrate with a common example: in a single night’s slumber, one may dream of a hundred years’ events or see things from the farthest realms. While awake, in the brief span of a bow and a stretch, one may touch what lies beyond the six directions. If even wayward thoughts and wanton fancies can achieve this, how much more so when the spirit moves alone, unconfined by form or vessel, perfectly penetrating and mysteriously illuminating, serene and concentrated in emptiness?"

**[Shiwen]** "覺" is pronounced *jiào*.

"Moreover, the place where I dwelt before—how is it different from Your Majesty’s palace? The places where I wandered before—how are they different from Your Majesty’s gardens? What you are accustomed to remains, and you doubt only its temporary absence.

**[Annotation]** Both that and this are not true things. To grow accustomed to what is always present and doubt its momentary absence—this is the delusion of the heart."

**Qin edition:** "王閒恒疑攓亡" (*Wáng xián héng yí qiān wáng*). In other editions, the character "有" (*yǒu*) is omitted after "恒" (*héng*). Here, it has been added following the *Shidetang* edition.

"閒" (*xián*) means "to be accustomed." "恒有" (*héng yǒu*) corresponds to the annotation’s "常存" (*cháng cún*, "always present"). "閒恒有" (*xián héng yǒu*) and "疑暫亡" (*yí zàn wáng*) form a parallel structure.

**[Shiwen]** "閒" is pronounced *xián*, meaning "to be accustomed to what is always present." One variant omits the character "有" (*yǒu*).

"At the extreme of transformation, in the space between slow and swift, can it be fully grasped?"

**[Annotation]** Transformation cannot be exhausted, and the principle of slow and swift admits no gap. To seek its image or model with the intellect is beyond measure.

**[Exegesis]** The marvel of the spirit’s distinction from form is thus further clarified. The king, accustomed only to what he habitually saw, doubted its temporary absence. But for the person of the utmost Dao, who constantly forgets their form, what doubt could there be? The spirit’s transformations, whether slow or swift, cannot be fully expressed.

**[Shiwen]** "模" is written as "摸" (*mō*), pronounced *mó*.

The king was overjoyed. He neglected state affairs,

**[Shiwen]** "恤" is pronounced *xù*.

Took no delight in his ministers or concubines,

**[Annotation]** Moved by these profound words, he abandoned the governance of worldly affairs and forgot the hierarchy between ruler and subject.

**[Shiwen]** "治" is pronounced *zhì*.

And indulged in distant wanderings.

**[Exegesis]** In Zhuangzi’s discourse, those who value the Dao abandon the world without a backward glance—what concern have they for it? Thus, it is like treating dust, chaff, or husks as the clay from which Yao and Shun were molded. Who would take such things as matters of importance? Moreover, to be drowned in the allure of sounds, colors, and desires—how could this be the way of one who delights in the Dao? The king’s joy in the Dao led him to neglect state affairs and take no pleasure in his ministers or concubines. His "distant wanderings" meant forgetting what was near and familiar.

**In the exegesis, "陶鑄" (*táo zhù*) was originally written as "陶懤" (*táo chóu*), but has been corrected here according to the *Sijie* edition.**

He ordered the harnessing of the eight steeds:

**[Shiwen]** "駿" is pronounced *jùn*. "乘" is pronounced *shèng*, and the same applies below.

The right-hand trace horse was □

**[Annotation]** The ancient character for "驊" (*huá*).

**Lü** (*liú*), and the left-hand trace horse was **Lü’er** (*Lǜ ěr*). In the *Shidetang* edition, "□" is written as "□".

**Sun Yirang’s note:** □ is the seal-script form of "騧" (*guā*) from the *Shuowen*’s "Horse" section. Here, □ has been altered to □, and □ to □, with the left and right reversed, rendering it unrecognizable (originally from Zhang Wenhu’s *Shu Jutang Suibi*). The *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* writes it as □, which is also incorrect.

**[Shiwen]** "□" is pronounced *huá*. "騮" is pronounced *liú*. □騮 (*Huáliú*) and 綠耳 (*Lǜ ěr*) are two of the eight steeds.

**Ren Dachun’s note:** The *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* states, "The right-hand trace horse was □騮," with a note reading, "Possibly the character for 驊騮 (*huáliú*)." The characters □ and □ are graphically similar and can be mutually verified.

The right-hand side horse was **Chiji** (*Chì jì*), and the left-hand side horse was **Bai□** (*Bái □*).

**[Annotation]** The ancient character for "義" (*yì*). In the *Shidetang* edition, "義" is written as "牺" (*xī*).

**Hong Yi’s note:** The *Erya*’s "Explanation of Livestock" states, "A horse with a whorl of hair on the elbow is called *déjiǎn yáng*." □ is the character for "減" (*jiǎn*). The *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* writes it as "左白儀" (*zuǒ bái yí*), with Guo Pu’s note reading, "The ancient character for *yì*." Thus, the annotation explains □ as *xī*, which is a corruption of the character *yí*. □ is not the character *xī*.

**Sun Yirang’s note:** "白□" appears twice in the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*, once written as *yì* and once as *yí*. Guo Pu also states, "The ancient character for *yì*," which matches Zhang’s annotation. The *Guangya*’s "Explanation of Livestock" lists a horse type called *lù*, possibly a loan for this character. The current text writes it as □. While Hong Yi suggests it corresponds to the *Erya*’s *déjiǎn yáng*, the forms are somewhat similar, but this reading does not align with the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* or Zhang and Guo’s pronunciations, and may not be accurate.

**[Shiwen]** "□" is written as "牺" (*xī*), pronounced *yì*. "驂" is pronounced *cān*. "驥" is pronounced *jì*.

The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: "Zaofu obtained for King Mu the horses *Huáliú*, *Lǜ ěr*, *Chì jì*, and *Bái xī*, with which he drove on his travels, visiting the Queen Mother of the West and delighting in her company until he forgot to return." This account is largely consistent with the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*.

Guo Pu’s annotation states, "All are named after their coat colors." Later, there are *Qúhuáng*, *Yúlún*, *Dàolí*, and *Shānzǐ*, making the Eight Steeds. For the main chariot, Zaofu served as charioteer, and □□ as the right-hand attendant.

**[Annotation]** "The upper part resembles *qí* (齊), and the lower part resembles *hé* (合); this is an ancient character, but its exact form remains uncertain."
Sun Yirang notes: "The *Shiwen* writes '□' as '□', stating: '□ is pronounced *tài*, and its seal script form is □.' □ should be written as □, with the upper part resembling *dà* (大) and □, akin to the upper half of *qí* (齊); the lower part, derived from *shuǐ* (水), has become *hé* (合), which is a considerable deviation. Yin Yun’s seal script form □ is also a scribal error. The original Zhang annotation likely matched the *Shiwen*, hence the note 'the upper part resembles *qí*, and the lower part resembles *hé*.' This annotation should originally have been placed under '□,' indicating that the character’s upper part resembles *qí* (in fact, following the *Shiwen*, it is an abbreviated form of *qí*), and the lower part resembles *hé*. Since no ancient character dictionary records this form, and neither its shape nor sound can be explained, it is labeled 'uncertain.' Though Zhang and Yin’s versions erroneously wrote □ as □, the pronunciation *tài* remained correct. The phrase 'the upper part resembles *qí*, and the lower part resembles *hé*' specifically describes the form of □ and is unrelated to its pronunciation, much less to the character □. In other versions, □ was further corrupted into □ (the upper *qí* became □, and the lower *hé* became *jiǒng*), losing its resemblance to *qí* and *hé*, while this annotation was mistakenly moved beneath the character □. Readers, unfamiliar with the original text, could not decipher it and thus split the annotation—originally describing the form of □—into the pronunciations of □ and □. This error was adopted from a variant cited in the *Shiwen* (Yin’s version had not yet corrupted the character □, so it is unlikely there was no correction; perhaps this entry in the *Shiwen* was interpolated by Chen Jingyuan?). Later, Ding Du’s *Jiyun* and Han Daozhao’s *Wuyin Jiyun* followed this interpretation, including □ under the *qí* initial and □ under the *hé* initial—a case of ancient texts being repeatedly miscopied and losing their original form to such an extent.

**[The *Yupian* under the *gōng* (弓) section includes the character □, stating: "Pronounced *húhé* (胡合切), meaning 'to meet.' This is also a corruption of □. This entry was certainly not part of Gu Yewang’s original work but was recklessly added by later Song scholars.]**

The *Shiwen* cites the Stone Classics as writing '□' as '□' (based on the Wei *Three-Script Stone Classics*; this is the ancient form of the character *bǐng* (丙). Neither Guo Zhongshu’s *Hanjian* nor Hong’s *Lixu* includes this character among the surviving fragments of the Stone Classics, and it cannot be verified today). This also does not form a recognizable character. Speculatively, the ancient script in the Stone Classics likely originally wrote it as □ (Ruan Yuan’s *Jigu Zhai Zhongding Kuanshi* records the *Zhōu Hū dǐng*, where the character □ is written as □, and *bǐng* (丙) is written in this form. The *Stone Drums*’ *Yǐ gǔ* simplifies the character □ by omitting □, making its form even more complete). This likely represents a reduplicated form of *bǐng* (古籀文 often employs reduplication, as in *wǔ* (五) written as □, *bèi* (贝) as □, and *chē* (车) as □). In clerical script, it should be written as □, but through scribal corruption, the upper *bǐng* became □, and the lower *bǐng* became *zhǐ* (只), rendering it unrecognizable. The *Zilin* writes it as *xī* (西), which should be *bǐng* (丙); this is the seal script form of *bǐng*, with an extra stroke mistakenly added below. The *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* writes '□□ as the right-hand attendant,' which is also a scribal error.

**Further note:** "For the main chariot, Zaofu served as charioteer"—since Zaofu was the charioteer, he should not also be the one who 'presided over the chariot.' The phrase 'presided over the chariot' should include the character *wáng* (王). The king rode in the chariot, thus the king presided over it; in the next chariot, the king did not ride, so Boyi was designated to preside over it instead. The *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* writes 'the Son of Heaven presided over the chariot,' which serves as definitive evidence. The current text omits the character *wáng*, making it seem as if the one who presided over the chariot was also the charioteer, which does not correspond to the next chariot."

Wang Shumin states: "The current text’s omission of the character *wáng* is correct. However, *wáng* should likely precede 'presided over the chariot,' so that 'the king presided over the chariot' matches the syntax of the following phrase, 'Boyi presided over the chariot.'"

The *Shiwen* writes '□' as '□,' stating: "Zaofu is pronounced *zàofǔ* (七到切). *Fù* is pronounced *fǔ*. The *Records of the Grand Historian* states: 'King Mu of Zhou rode the horses *Huáliú* and *Lǜ ěr*, with Zaofu as his charioteer, traveling a thousand *li* in a day.' □ is pronounced *tài*, and its seal script form is □. □ is pronounced *bǐng*, and the Stone Classics write it as □."

The *Zilin* states that *yǐn* is written as □, originally as □□, with the pronunciation *qí* for the upper character and *hé* for the lower—yet this offers no meaningful interpretation. The *Huainanzi* states: "Qián and Jǔ Tàibǐng were charioteers, who removed the reins and bit, discarding the whip and goad." Gao You comments: "These were ancient masters of the Dao skilled in driving." *Qián* is pronounced *qíyán* (其炎切), and *jǔ* is pronounced *zǐyú* (子余切).

Ren Dachun writes: "□" is written as "□." The preface by Chen Jingyuan of the Song dynasty states that "□□" are the two characters "Tàibǐng," indicating that the text Jingyuan saw wrote "□" rather than "□," matching the current edition. Only the *Shiwen* writes □, preserving the ancient form. Wu Renchen states: "In the *Shilin Yanyu*, Wang Qi of the Tang did not recognize the two characters □□. Now, examining the *Liezi*, □ is pronounced *bǐng*, but the source of the character □ remains unattested. Moreover, Wang Shizhen’s rendition of the two characters as □□ appears to be an error." Wu Renchen knew that the character □ derived from the *Liezi* but claimed that □ had no attested source—this is because he had only seen the current edition of the *Liezi* and not Lu Deming’s *Shiwen*.

The *Tongya* cites Tu Weizhen’s preface, which states: "During the Tang, scholars debated □□, with only Wang Qi, Wang Yuanmei, and Hu Mingrui writing it as □ (a corruption of □) and □ (a corruption of □). Thus, what Wang Qi saw still rendered □□ as □□, hence his claim of not recognizing the two characters □□." Comparing this with Lu Deming’s *Shiwen*, which also writes □□, it is evident that in Tang-era editions, □ was often written as □. Though Wang Yuanmei and Hu Mingrui’s □□ is a scribal corruption of □□, the *Shiwen*’s original form as □□ can still serve as evidence for textual reconstruction.

However, the *Shiwen* further states that beneath the character □, the original text reads "□," with □ pronounced *qí* and □ pronounced *hé*—yet this offers no meaningful interpretation. Lu Deming likely meant that another edition wrote □□ as □□, where the upper □ is pronounced *qí* and the lower □ is pronounced *hé*, differing not only in the variant characters □□ but also in the pronunciation of *qí-hé* for □□ versus *tàibǐng* for □□.

The *Wuyin Jiyun* records: □ is pronounced *cúxī* (徂奚切), sharing the same initial as *qí*; □ is pronounced *húlà* (壶腊切), sharing the same initial as *hé*. This confirms that one edition reads □ as *qí* and □ as *hé*. However, since the *Huainanzi* writes it as *Tàibǐng*, while this edition reads *qí-hé*, which offers no meaningful interpretation, the definitive text writes □ as *tài* and □ as *bǐng*, not following the variant edition.

Further examination of the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* reveals: "□□ served as the right attendant." Since □ resembles □ and □ resembles □, scribal errors arose. Sun Yirang notes: In the *Shiwen*’s citation of the *Zilin*, "云" should be "音." The *Yiqie Jing Yinyi* (Vol. 6) quotes the *Zilin* as *yǐn*, matching this text. All editions mistakenly write "云," and Ren [Dachun] did not correct it.

Regarding the chariots that followed: The right horse of the central pair was *Qúhuáng*, and the left was *Yúlún*; the left outer horse was *Dàolì*, and the right was *Shānzǐ*. Jiang Chaobo states: The *Erya* lists among horses *Xiǎolǐng Dàolì*; the *Guangya* writes it as *Táolì*; the *Yupian* as *Táolì*; and the *Records of the Grand Historian* (*Qin Annals*) as *Wēnlì*—all variant forms of *Dàolì*. The *Shiwen* notes: *Lì* is pronounced *lìyí* (力移切). *Dàolì* is the *Xiānlí* mentioned in the *Xunzi* (*Xiānlí* appears in the "Xing E" chapter).

Boyi presided over the chariot. The *Shiwen* states: *Yāo* is pronounced *yúbiǎo* (于表切). Guo Pu comments: "Boyi is a personal name." Canbai served as charioteer, and Benrong as the right attendant. Jiang Chaobo notes: According to the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*, Benrong was a minister of the Gao clan who commanded the Seven Elite Warriors, though Zhang Zhan’s commentary does not elaborate.

They galloped a thousand *li* and arrived in the land of the Jusou clan. Wang Zhong states: *Jusou* is the *Qusou* mentioned in the *Tribute of Yu*. The *Shiwen* notes: *Jusou* is pronounced *Qusou*, the name of a Western Rong state. The Jusou clan presented the blood of a white swan for the king to drink. The *Shiwen* states: *Yǐn* is pronounced *yújìn* (于禁切). They offered the *dòng* of cattle and horses to wash the king’s feet. (Note: *Dòng* refers to milk.) They presented their most precious treasures to the exalted ruler and the two chariot attendants.

The *Shiwen* states: *dòng* is pronounced *zhúyòng* (竹用切); *xǐ* (wash) is pronounced *xiānlǐ* (先礼切); *chéng* (chariot) is pronounced *shízhèng* (实证切).

Having drunk, they departed and lodged at the slopes of Kunlun, on the northern bank of the Red Water. The *Shan Hai Jing* states: "Kunlun Mountain has waters of five colors." The *Shiwen* notes: *Kunlun* is pronounced *Kūnlún* (昆论). The *Shan Hai Jing* also says: "By the shores of the Flowing Sands, beyond the Red Water and before the Black Water, stands a great mountain called Kunlun’s Mound. There are cave-dwellers, known as the Queen Mother of the West." Another day, they ascended Kunlun’s Mound—some versions omit the character *yú* (于). The *Shiwen* records *qiū* (丘) as *□*, noting: *□* is the ancient form of *qiū* (mound). They beheld the palace of the Yellow Emperor. The *Shiwen* cites the *Xin Yu* by Lu Jia: "The Yellow Emperor toured the four seas, ascended Kunlun Mountain, built a palace, and gazed from its heights, sealing it to bequeath to later generations." The *Shiwen* states: *yí* (诒) is pronounced *yí* (怡), meaning "to transmit."

Thereupon, they paid homage to the Queen Mother of the West. The *Shiwen* cites the *He Tu Yu Ban*: "The Queen Mother of the West dwells on Kunlun Mountain." The *Bamboo Annals* records: "In the seventeenth year of his reign, King Mu journeyed west, met the Queen Mother of the West, and was received as a guest in the Bright Palace." They feasted atop the Jasper Pool. The Queen Mother of the West was a human—tiger-toothed, disheveled-haired, wearing a *shèng* headdress, and skilled in whistling. This is recorded in the *Shan Hai Jing*.

The Queen Mother of the West sang a lay for the king—a *yáo* (徒歌, unaccompanied song). The poem was titled *White Clouds*. The *Shiwen* states: *wèi* (为) is pronounced *yú’é* (于讹切). The king responded—*hé* (和) meaning "to answer." His poem was titled *Returning East*. The *Shiwen* states: *hé* (和) is pronounced *húwò* (胡卧切). Her words were mournful.

They observed the place where the sun sets in the west. The *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* states: "They ascended Yan Mountain in the west." The character *xī* (西) was originally written as *nǎi* (乃). Wang Yinzhi notes: *Yān* (焉) here means "in this place," "then," or "thus." The *Zhao Hun* says: "The shaman Yang then descended to summon." The *Far Roaming* chapter reads: "Then he wandered and lingered." The *Liezi*’s "King Mu of Zhou" chapter states: "Thereupon, they observed where the sun sets." These all attest to the ancient usage of *yān nǎi* (焉乃) as a compound. Wang Chongmin argues: Wang’s interpretation is incorrect. The original text read *xī* (西), a scribal error. The character *yān* (焉) should still conclude the preceding clause. Zhang’s annotation cites the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*: "They ascended Yan Mountain in the west." According to Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan*: "Yanzi Mountain is where the sun sets." Yan Mountain lies west of the Jasper Pool, marking the sun’s setting. Zhang’s citation clarifies the meaning of "observing the west." The *Taiping Yulan* (vol. 3) quotes it as "observed the place where the sun sets in the west," with only minor variations but retaining the character *xī* (西). The Ji edition correctly writes *xī* (西). Bo Jun notes: Wang Chongmin’s argument is sound. *Nǎi* (乃) was a graphic corruption of *xī* (西), and the text is now emended following the Ji edition. The *Shiwen* states: *yǎn* (弇) is pronounced *yǎn* (奄).

Jiang Chaobo observes: The block-printed editions of the *Mu Tianzi Zhuan* are fragmentary and incomplete; only Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Shan Hai Jing* preserves a more coherent version. His citation reads: "On the auspicious day of *jiǎzǐ*, they paid homage to the Queen Mother of the West, presenting a black jade tablet and white jade disk as gifts. They offered a hundred strands of brocade and a hundred *jin* of gold and jade. The Queen Mother of the West bowed twice in acceptance. On *yǐchǒu*, the Son of Heaven feasted with the Queen Mother of the West atop the Jasper Pool. The Queen Mother of the West sang a lay for the Son of Heaven:

*White clouds drift in the sky,*
*The mountains and hills rise on their own.*
*The Way stretches far and distant,*
*Separated by rivers and mountains.*
*May you not die, my lord,*
*And come again.*

The Son of Heaven replied:

*I return to the eastern lands,*
*To harmonize and govern the Central States.*
*When the myriad people are equitable and just,*
*I shall turn to see you once more.*
*Within three years,*
*I shall return to your wilds.*

The Queen Mother of the West then chanted for the Son of Heaven:

*Departing for those western lands,*
*You dwell where you belong.*
*Tigers and leopards gather in packs,*
*Birds and magpies nest beside you.*
*Your noble mandate does not waver,*
*For I am the Emperor’s daughter.*
*What manner of mortal are you,*
*Who would now leave me?*
*Playing the reed pipes and drums,*
*My heart soars within.*
*O child of this mortal world,*
*You are Heaven’s hope.*

Thereupon, the Son of Heaven drove his chariot up Yan Mountain, where he inscribed his tracks upon its stones and planted a locust tree, naming it the Mountain of the Queen Mother of the West." They traveled ten thousand *li* in a single day. The *Shiwen* writes *wàn xíng* (万行), noting: *xíng* (行) is read as *lǐ* (里).

The king sighed and said: "Alas! I alone am deficient in virtue yet harmonious in joy. Later generations will surely recount my transgressions!" *Xié* (谐) here means "to distinguish."

From "Thereupon he commanded his eight steeds to be harnessed" up to this point, the events are recorded in the *Tale of King Mu*. The *Shiwen* notes: *shù* (数) is read as *sèjù*, meaning "to reproach."

How near to a divine being was King Mu! *Here meaning: he was not divine.*

Wu Kaisheng remarks: *jǐ* (几) should be read as *qǐ* (岂, "how could"). The following line, "How could it be empty words?" serves as evidence. The *Shiwen* notes: *jǐ* is pronounced *qǐ*.

He exhausted the joys of his own lifetime—the *Shiwen* notes: *lè* (乐) is pronounced *luò*—yet after a hundred years, he still passed away. *Knowing the impermanence of worldly affairs, he gave free rein to his heart.* Bo Jun observes: The *Book of Jin*’s biography of Shu Xi cites the *Bamboo Annals*, stating, "From the Zhou’s receipt of the Mandate to King Mu’s reign, a hundred years had passed," leading later generations to mistakenly believe King Mu lived a hundred years. The world deemed him to have ascended.

*The character 假 here should be written as 遐, meaning the world believed he had "ascended afar," clarifying that he had in fact died.*

*[Exegesis]*
Selecting swift steeds and discerning worthy talents, he applied them as circumstances demanded. Unbound by the distinction between Chinese and foreign lands, he followed only where the Dao led. Without venturing far from the Palace of the Yellow Emperor, he exhausted all that heaven and earth possess, reaching the utmost of what divine knowledge can convey. He did not exalt virtue to flaunt his power but delighted in the Dao to commune with the divine. After a thousand years, he *transfigured* and ascended—yet the common folk believed he had merely "ascended afar."

Qin Enfu remarks: The character *□* in the exegesis does not appear in dictionaries. The *Jiyun* includes the character *□*, pronounced *qí*, an ancient form of *qì* (跂), though its meaning here is unclear. Sun Yirang notes: The exegesis’s *□化* should read *肢化* (*zhīhuà*), meaning "corpse-transformation" (a form of Daoist liberation). Qin’s citation of *□* as an ancient form of *qì* does not suit this context. The *Shiwen* notes: *jiǎ* (假) is pronounced *xiá*.

Lao Chengzi studied illusion under Master Yin Wen. Wang Chongmin observes: The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (752) cites this as "Kao Chengzi," matching the *Shiwen* version. The *Shiwen* reads *lǎo* (老) as *kǎo* (考), noting: "Kao Chengzi" appears in one version, while another gives "Lao Chengzi," author of eighteen chapters. Ren Dachun adds: The *Xingshi Jijiu Pian* ("Quick Access to Surnames") records, "The Lao Cheng clan: the *Shi Ben* mentions Song minister Lao Cheng Fang. The *Liezi* states Lao Cheng studied illusion under Yin Wen. The *Treatise on Arts and Letters* lists *Lao Chengzi*." Thus, the version Hong Mai saw in the *Liezi* read "Lao Chengzi," matching the current text. After three years, he did not report his progress. Lao Chengzi requested to be corrected and sought leave to depart.

Yin Wen bowed and led him into the chamber. Dismissing his attendants, he spoke to him, saying:

"When the Old Master Lao Dan departed for the West, he turned to me and said: 'The qi of living beings and the forms of corporeal things are all illusion. What the Creator begins and what yin and yang transform are called life and death. Those who exhaust the numbers and comprehend the changes, following form to shift and alter, are called transformation and illusion.'

[Commentary] Those who master the numbers of the Two Modes and grasp the principles of yin and yang shape and move the myriad forms without perceiving the difficulty. The Creator’s craft is subtle, its work profound—inherently difficult to exhaust or bring to an end.

[Commentary] Does the Creator have intent? It is naturally and seemingly subtle.

When qi and substance press and thin, congealing into form, they follow transformation and depart, thus not immediately dissipating.

Tao Hongqing observes: Zhang’s commentary fails to grasp the meaning of *miao* (妙). The original character for *miao* should be *miao* (秒), also written as *miao* (妙). In the first chapter of the *Dao De Jing*, 'Constantly desireless, one observes its subtlety,' Wang Bi’s commentary states: '*Miao* is the utmost of the minute.' Its subtlety refers to its craft being so minute and wondrous as to be unknowable. This contrasts with the following phrase, 'Those who rely on form have craft that is manifest and work that is shallow.'

Bo Jun notes: The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (725) cites this as 'thus difficult to exhaust or bring to an end,' with *gu* (固) as *gu* (故), which better suits the meaning.

[Commentary] *Fen* is pronounced *fèn* (房吻切).

Those who rely on form have craft that is manifest and work that is shallow, thus arising and vanishing in an instant.

[Commentary] Those who borrow things to enact change, or who follow form in its shifts, are but briefly born and briefly extinguished. Their work is evident, their deeds conspicuous, so all things are startled.

Only when one knows that illusion and transformation do not differ from life and death can one begin to study illusion.

[Commentary] The meaning of this has already been detailed in the commentary on the chapter title.

Lu Wenchang notes: In the Zang edition, the commentary includes the character *jian* (见) after *zhu* (注).

Wang Chongmin states: *Yu* (与) here means *yi* (以), as explained in *Shi Ci*.

This means one may then begin to study illusion. The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* (752) cites this as 'one may then begin to study illusion,' with different wording but the same meaning.

You and I are also illusion—why must you study?"

[Commentary] The body itself is illusion; to study illusion further is to have illusion study illusion.

[Exegesis] The transformations of form and qi are ever-renewing and unceasing—how do they differ from illusion? Thus, what the spirit and qi transform endures long and is difficult to know, while what techniques and arts produce is near and easily seen. Yet one does not realize that what is difficult to know is the greater illusion, and what is easily seen is the lesser illusion. If one knows that illusion and transformation do not differ from life and death, why study further?

[Commentary] *Fu* is pronounced *fù* (扶又切).

Lao Chengzi returned home and, applying Yin Wen’s words, meditated deeply for three months.

[Commentary] *Shen* (深) is written as *yin* (淫), pronounced *shēn* (深).

Ren Dachun states: In the *Nine Hymns* of the *Chu Ci*, 'floating without root' is glossed as 'one version reads *chen* (沉), meaning deep and profound.' In the *Stratagems of Yan* from the *Warring States*, 'his wisdom is deep and his plans profound,' the commentary states: '*Chen* means deep.' In the *Records of the Grand Historian*, *Treatise on Music*: 'The sound is excessive and reaches the Shang.' Wang Su comments: 'The sound is deeply excessive and avaricious for Shang.' This confirms that *yin* (淫) is glossed as *shen* (深). Moreover, in this text, *yin* (淫) and *shen* (深) are often interchangeable. In the *Yellow Emperor* chapter, 'He will dwell in a measure that is not *shen* (深),' the commentary states: '*Shen* should be *yin* (淫).' *Yin* is read as *shen*, and *shen* is also read as *yin*—their meanings are interchangeable.

Thereafter, he could freely control life and death, manipulating the four seasons.

Wu Kaisheng notes: *Fan jiao* (□校) means to manipulate or play with.

[Commentary] *Fan* is pronounced *fān* (翻). *Jiao* is pronounced *jiǎo* (绞). Gu Yewang reads it as *fan jiao* (翻交) of the four seasons.

In winter, he summoned thunder; in summer, he created ice. What flew ran, and what ran flew.

[Commentary] If deep contemplation for a time can yield such mastery, how much more so for one who attains it without effort? Life must follow principle, and form must follow life. There has never been life without principle, nor form without life. Life and form, form and principle—though differing in refinement and coarseness—alternate as guest and host. They flow and shift in ceaseless succession, never pausing even briefly. Thus, they are ever-changing and never fixed, now gathering, now dispersing. When governed with order, their work is subtle and their deeds concealed; when cultivation loses measure, their traces become manifest and their transformations evident. Now, if the commands of the four seasons are disrupted, the three luminaries fall into disorder. Thunder and ice reverse their seasons, vessels and objects melt and scorch, so that flying things smelt clouds and sand to form billowing ice. When this occurs as usual, none doubt it. Extending this principle, if one exhausts the subtle numbers of yin and yang and fathoms the nature of the myriad things, one can shape and mold all beings, equaling the work of Creation. As for those who partially grasp techniques and draw upon qi and substance, bending and rising to emerge and submerge, glancing to exchange flight and running for altered forms—these are but the lesser arts.

[Commentary] The phrase *bing hong* (冰澒) in all editions is mistakenly written as *shui qing* (水顷).

[Commentary] *Shuo* is pronounced *shuò* (铄). *Hong* is pronounced *hóng* (洪).

For the rest of his life, he never revealed his arts.

[Commentary] *Zhuo* (箸) is written as *zhuó* (着), pronounced *zhù* (陟虑切).

Thus, the world never transmitted them.

[Commentary] That the Hundred Clans use it without knowing—this is the Way of the Sage."

Revealing marvels to astonish an age—this is the affair of common men.

[Exegesis] One who fathoms the root of spirit and qi and discerns the source of life and death can then transform without limit; this is the necessary principle. It must be realized through personal awakening and embodied verification, and thus cannot be transmitted through words or texts.

Yu Yue notes: "Thus" in Lu Chongxuan’s edition reads "indeed." *Indeed* and *thus* are interchangeable—this is the ancient version. Zhang Zhan’s edition arbitrarily alters it to *thus*, which no longer preserves the antiquity of the original text.

Master Liezi said: "One skilled in transformation follows a Way that is subtle and ordinary, and their achievement is the same as others’.

[Commentary] They merely seek to benefit the world and pacify things, and so their achievement works in hiddenness, unknown to others.
