[Explanation] This is what is meant by “spiritual communion and mutual understanding”—not merely the art of archery. Thus, they cast aside their bows and swore an oath. Only after their spirits had truly connected could the transmission occur, and so they could not impart their art to others.

The teacher of Zaofu was named Taidou.

[Annotation] Taidou appears in various miscellaneous records.

[Collation] *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s “Ting Yan” chapter states: “Zaofu first studied under Da Dou.” Gao You’s commentary: “Da Dou was likely the name of a charioteer.” *Da Dou* is the same as *Taidou*.

[Exegesis] *Zao* is pronounced *qi dao*; *fu* is pronounced *fu*.

When Zaofu first began learning charioteering, he observed the rites with great humility, yet Taidou did not instruct him for three years.

[Collation] *Yiwen Leiju* (746) includes the character *shi* (“Master”) after *Taidou*, and the same below.

Zaofu’s observance of the rites grew even more reverent, until Taidou finally told him: “An ancient poem says: ‘The son of a master bowyer must first learn to make a winnowing basket; the son of a master smith must first learn to make a fur coat.’”

[Annotation] Both winnowing baskets and fur coats require bending and joining materials before they become useful implements. For bowyers and smiths, harmonizing sinew and horn or blending metal and iron follows the same principle. Thus, a student must first master what is easy before achieving what is difficult—this is the analogy.

[Explanation] The winnowing basket is the tool used to craft a bow; the fur coat is the tool used to fan the forge. Laozi likened it to a bellows, which today would be called a bag. The one shapes the bow’s frame, the other fans the fire—though neither is the bow or the forge itself, both are indispensable to their making.

[Collation] *Liji*’s “Xue Ji” states: “The son of a master smith must first learn to make a fur coat; the son of a master bowyer must first learn to make a winnowing basket.” Another note: In the *Shide Tang* edition, the annotation’s *yu* (“analogy”) is written as *lun* (“discourse”).

[Exegesis] *Yi* is pronounced *yi chi*.

“First observe my movements.

[Annotation] *Qu* means “movement.”

[Exegesis] *Qu* is pronounced *qu*; the same below.

When your movements match mine, then you may grasp the six reins,

[Exegesis] *Pei* is pronounced *bi*.

and the six horses may be driven.”

Zaofu replied: “I will follow your command.”

Then Taidou set up wooden planks as a path, just wide enough to hold the feet—

[Annotation] Only enough to steady the soles.

[Exegesis] *Jin* is pronounced *jin*.

—measuring his steps to place them,

[Annotation] Spaced as his strides required.

[Exegesis] *Ji* is pronounced *ji*, meaning "dense."

He trod upon them and walked, running back and forth with speed and agility, never stumbling or faltering.

[Exegesis] *Die* is pronounced *tu*.

Zaofu learned this, and in three days mastered its skill. Taidou sighed and said: "How keen you are! How swiftly you have grasped it!

[Annotation] *Min* means "quick"; *jie* means "swift."

[Exegesis] *Jie* is pronounced *ji ye*.

In all your driving, proceed likewise."

[Exegesis] The planks were shaped like feet, arranged like steps. *Zhuangzi* says: "Beyond the space where one’s feet could tread, the earth was cleared away—yet those who could not walk upon it were unsettled in mind." So too with driving horses: if one guides them as one guides one’s own feet, then mastery is achieved.

[Collation] Lu’s exegesis cites *Zhuangzi*, but no such passage exists in the received text.

"Formerly, in your walking, you gained it through the feet and responded with the heart. Extend this to driving: harmony is achieved in the interplay of reins and bit,

[Exegesis] *Ji* is pronounced *ji*. The *Shuowen* says: *Ji* means "chariot carriage." Here it speaks of Zaofu’s skill in driving—how the alignment of the carriage depends on the reins and bit, just as a ruler who wins the people’s hearts brings peace to the state.

—while urgency and ease reside in the harmony of the lips and mouth, correctness and measure dwell in the center of the chest,

[Collation] The *Shuowen* says: "*Yi* is the breastbone; sometimes written with the *yi* radical." The *Guangya* explains: "*Yi* means 'chest.'" Xu’s commentary on the *Wenxuan*’s "Shelie Fu" says: "*Yi* means 'breast.'"

[Exegesis] *Wen* is pronounced *wu fen*; *yi* is pronounced *yi*.

—and rhythm is held in the grasp of the hands."

Within, harmony is found at the center of the heart, while without, it aligns with the horse’s will—thus one can advance and retreat as if treading a plumb line, and turn in curves as if compass-drawn. Tao Hongqing says: The character *ju* (矩, "square") is superfluous. The original text reads: *"Advance and retreat in accord with the plumb line, and turn in curves in accord with the compass,"* meaning *"straight movements follow the plumb line, curved movements follow the compass."* The *Huainanzi’s* "Treatise on the Dao of Rulership" quotes this passage without the character *ju*. Wang Chongmin says: Tao’s view is correct. The *Zhuangzi’s* "Attaining Life" chapter states: *"Dongye Bi was presented to Duke Zhuang for his driving skill; his advance and retreat followed the plumb line, and his left and right turns followed the compass,"* identical in meaning to this passage from the *Liezi* but without the character *ju*, which serves as proof. For *"treading the plumb line"* and *"following the compass"* form a parallel structure; if *ju* were included, not only would the meaning be disrupted, but the phrasing would become redundant. The *Taiping Yulan* (746) also omits *ju*. Yang Bojun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu’s* "Adapting to Might" chapter likewise states: *"Dongye Ji was presented to Duke Zhuang for his driving skill; his advance and retreat followed the plumb line, and his left and right turns followed the compass,"* and further: *"For advance and retreat to follow the plumb line, and left and right turns to follow the compass—even Zaofu’s driving could not surpass this,"* both omitting *ju*, providing further conclusive evidence.

With the Dao mastered, one travels great distances while qi and strength remain abundant—truly, the art is fully attained. What is received through the bit responds to the reins; what is received through the reins responds to the hands; what is received through the hands responds to the heart. Thus, one need not rely on the eyes to see nor the whip to urge. With the mind at ease and the body aligned, the six reins remain untangled, and the twenty-four hooves land without error. In turning, circling, advancing, or retreating, all moves accord with rhythm.

[Annotation] This corresponds to the harmonious sounds of the *heluan* bells.

Only then can the space beyond the carriage wheels leave no excess tracks, and the space beyond the horse’s hooves leave no wasted ground. One remains unaware of the peril of mountains and valleys or the levelness of plains and lowlands—all appear as one. My art has reached its limit. Remember this well!

[Annotation] The path one treads requires only enough space for the feet. When no excess ground is needed beyond the feet, and others dare not tread there, it is because the mind is not at peace and the body is not at ease. When the mind is at peace and the body at ease, then movement and stillness follow constant measures, and slowness and speed adhere to fixed degrees. If one fully grasps the subtleties, this principle applies not only to the self but can be extended to all things. Even with the complexity of six reins and the multitude of a horse’s hooves, as long as they are regulated by the Dao, disorder is not a concern. Thus, one does not rely on the absence of useless tracks beyond the wheels, nor on the absence of wasted ground beyond the hooves—can this not be affirmed?

[Exegesis] Zhuangzi, in his explanation of butchering an ox, says: *"Between the bones there are gaps, and the blade of the knife has no thickness. When that which has no thickness enters where there is a gap, there is ample room to move."* This speaks of the principle of abundant space. By not regarding the ground beyond the feet, one’s will becomes focused. With focused will, the feet move as the heart directs. If this principle is applied to reins and bits, or exchanged for fine horses, then where tracks align with hooves, what danger could there be? Most people seek only the superficial and do not grasp the root; those who recognize the truth must first seek the root before applying it. Thus, even the minor arts of archery and driving must accord with the Dao.

Yang Bojun notes: The exegesis cites the *Zhuangzi’s* "Nourishing Life" chapter but only summarizes its general meaning, not the original text.

Wei Hei Mao killed Qiu Bingzhang out of personal enmity.

[Annotation] *Nixian* refers to private resentment.

[Exegesis] Those who kill or harm out of personal enmity, or who destroy things out of desire, act according to the common ways of the world—not the conduct of one who embodies the Dao.

Lai Dan, the son of Qiu Bingzhang, plotted to avenge his father’s death. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (344, 386, and 482) all render "avenge" as "repay." Wang Shumin adds: The *Beitang Shuchao* (122), *Shilei Fu* (13), and *Shuwu Yiming Shu* (8) likewise render "avenge" as "repay." Dan’s qi was fierce, but his form was emaciated. Yang Bojun notes: The *Liji* (*Tan Gong*) states, "Gather the limbs and form." Zheng Xuan’s commentary: "Form refers to the body." The *Zuozhuan* (*Zhao* 1) reads, "Do not allow blockages or stagnation that expose the body." Du Yu’s commentary: "Exposed means frail." Thus, "form emaciated" means "body exceedingly frail." The subsequent annotation by Zhang clarifies this as "body frail and weak," precisely capturing its meaning. He measured his food by grains and moved only with the wind. Though enraged, he could not wield weapons to exact vengeance. [Annotation] Though bold in spirit, his body was frail and weak, rendering him unable to lift arms. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (482) renders "enraged" as "resentful." Given the following line—"Lai Dan’s friend Shen Ta said, ‘Your resentment against Hei Mao has reached its limit’"—the variant "resentful" may be more accurate. [Pronunciation] *Cheng* (wield): *chi zheng* cut. *Lei* (frail): *li wei* cut.

He sought aid from others, vowing to slaughter Hei Mao with his bare hands and sword. Hei Mao’s ferocity surpassed all others. [Pronunciation] *Han* (ferocity): *han* sound. His strength equaled that of a hundred men. His sinews, bones, skin, and flesh were not of human kind.

He craned his neck to meet the blade—*Dao* in the *Zangben* and *Shidetang* editions—laid bare his chest to receive the arrows. Though the edges of spears and swords bent and shattered, his body bore no mark nor wound. [Annotation] Wang Chongmin notes: The character *ta* (wound) does not align with the preceding text. The *Taiping Yulan* (386 and 482) omits *ta*, suggesting it may be a superfluous interpolation. Hu Huaichen observes: The characters *hen ta* (mark and wound) may be transposed. [Pronunciation] *Mang e*: *mang e* sound. *Hen*: *hu en* cut. *Ta*: *ta da* cut.

Relying on his strength and prowess, he regarded Lai Dan as but a fledgling chick. [Pronunciation] *Chu* is written as *chu* in the *Shiwen*, pronounced *zhu ju* cut. *Kou*: *kou* sound. A chick that must be fed is called *kou*; one that feeds itself is called *chu*.

Lai Dan’s friend Shen Ta—[Annotation] Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (344 and 482) renders this as *Shen Bao*, consistent below. [Pronunciation] *Ta* is written as *tuo* in the *Shiwen*, pronounced *tuo* or *qian*, with one variant reading *bao*—said, “Your resentment against Hei Mao has reached its limit. Hei Mao’s contempt for you has gone too far. [Pronunciation] *Yi*: *yi chi* cut. What plan shall you devise?” Lai Dan, tears streaming, replied, “I beg you to devise one for me.” [Pronunciation] *Wei*: *yu wei* cut.

Shen Ta said, “I have heard that your ancestor, Kong Zhou of Wei, obtained a treasured sword of the Yin Emperor. When a mere boy wore it—[Annotation] *Fu* (wore) and *pei* (wore at the waist) share an ancient pronunciation, a case of loan characters. [Pronunciation] *Tong* is written as *tong* in the *Shiwen*, pronounced *tong*—he repelled the masses of three armies. Why not seek it?” [Exegesis] The most refined objects of Heaven and Earth restrain the multitudes through awe alone. If their merit lay in cutting and severing, they would not be the most refined.

Lai Dan then journeyed to Wei, where he met Kong Zhou. Assuming the role of a servant-charioteer, he first offered his wife and children, then stated his desire. Kong Zhou said, “I possess three swords, any of which you may choose. None can kill a man—[Annotation] *Sha ren* (kill a man) refers to killing a man outright. Let me first describe their forms. The first is called *Han Guang* (Containing Light): though gazed upon, it cannot be seen; when wielded, its presence is unknown.”

Where it strikes, it leaves no trace—*mijnian* without boundary.

[Variant Notes] The *Jifu* edition, *Daozang* unannotated edition, and Lin Xiyi’s edition all read “其有” (*qí yǒu*) for “其所触也.” Wang Chongmin observes that the two characters are transposed. The *Leiju* (60) omits the character “有,” likely because the inverted text made no sense, and the compiler excised “有” by conjecture. The *Jifu* edition’s “其有” is correct. Wang Shumin argues that omitting “有” or reading “其有” are both incorrect; “有” should belong to the preceding line as a caesura. “运之不知有” (*yùn zhī bù zhī yǒu*) parallels the earlier “视之不可见” (*shì zhī bù kě jiàn*). The phrasing of “其所触也，泯然无际” matches that of “其所触也窃窃然有声” and “其触物也騞然而过.” *Mijnian* without boundary: the *Shiwen* glosses *mǐn* as *wángrěn* (亡忍切); when it passes through things, they remain unaware.

The second is called *Chengying* (Bearing Shadow). At the cusp of dawn’s first light or the threshold of dusk’s dimness, when facing north to observe it, one perceives only a faint presence, as if something lingers—*dàndàn* as though a form exists. The *Shiwen* glosses *dàn* as *yàn* (艳). Yet its shape eludes recognition. Where it strikes, it emits a faint sound—*qièqièrán*.

[Variant Notes] Wang Chongmin notes that the *Jifu* edition reads “焉” (*yān*) for “然” (*rán*). Earlier, the text states, “北面而察之，淡淡焉若有物存” (*dàndànyān ruò yǒu wù cún*), where *yān* and *rán* are synonymous; “淡淡焉” is equivalent to “淡淡然.” He suspects “窃窃然” was originally “窃窃焉,” and the *Jifu* edition preserves the older reading of the *Liezi*. Wang Shumin counters that the *Daozang* unannotated edition and Lin Xiyi’s edition also read “焉,” but the original text likely used “然.” “窃窃然” aligns with the earlier “泯然” and later “騞然.” Wang’s argument is incorrect. When it passes through things, they suffer no harm.

The third is called *Xiaolian*. By day, one sees its shadow but not its light—[note] its color is the same as the sun and moon. By night, one sees its light but not its form—[note] this refers to its illumination. Lu Wenchang notes: The *Daozang* edition reads “夜” (*yè*, night) for “也” (*yě*) in the annotation. When it strikes an object, it passes with a *huōrán* sound—[note] *huō* is pronounced *xiūbì*. Liu Wu states: *Huōrán* describes the swiftness of a blade’s passage. Precisely because the blade passes so swiftly is it a treasured sword. The *Shiwen* reads: *Huō* is pronounced *hūmài*, the sound of breaking. As it passes, the wound closes instantly, so swift is its strike that the blade draws no blood.

These three treasures have been passed down for thirteen generations—[note] *chuán* is pronounced *zhuān*—yet they have never been put to use—[note] they cannot harm things. They are encased and stored away—Lu Wenchang notes: The *Daozang* edition reads “柙” (*xiá*) for “匣” (*xiá*). The *Shiwen* reads “柙,” stating: *xiá* is equivalent to *xiá*. The seals have never been broken.

Lai Dan said: “Even so, I must request the lowest of them.”

Kong Zhou then sent his wife and children away and fasted for seven days. During a moment of partial clarity between clouds—[note] *Yan* signifies brightness. Sun Yirang states: The *Shuowen*’s *ri* section defines *yan* as “sky clear.” The *Hanshu*’s “Tianwen Zhi” reads: “At the hour of *bu*, the sky is *yan*” (i.e., clear). The *Hanfeizi*’s “Wai Chu Shuo Zuo” states: “After rain ceases and the sun emerges, one gazes upon the space between *yan* and *yin*,” which aligns with this meaning. “Between *yan* and *yin*” refers to the state between clear and overcast, not dusk. Zhang’s annotation errs here. Bo Jun notes: The *Huainanzi*’s “Miucheng” chapter reads: “The gleaming sun knows *yan*; the harmonious *yin* knows rain.” The *Wen Xuan*’s “Yang Xiong’s *Yu Lie Fu*” states: “The sky is clear, the sun *yan*.” Its commentary cites Xu Shen’s annotation from the *Huainanzi*: “*Yan* is where there are no clouds.” Thus, *yan-yin* is equivalent to *qing-yin*, concurring with Sun’s interpretation.—he knelt and presented the lowest-grade sword. Lai Dan bowed twice, received it, and departed. [note] As it could be grasped and seen, he accepted the lowest. [Explanation] The more precious the implement, the deeper its harm to things. The utmost Dao and utmost refinement injure nothing. Lai Dan then took the sword and followed Black Egg. At that moment, Black Egg was drunk and reclining beneath the window—Wu Kaisheng states: *Shi* should be read as *zhi* (to encounter). Bo Jun notes: *Shi* ought to be read as in the *Lunyu*’s “Yang Huo”: “Confucius *shi* their absence,” meaning “to wait for.” Further, the *Shu Chao* (122), *Shi Lei Fu* (13), and *Taiping Yulan* (344) all read “reclining beneath the window,” and judging by the earlier phrase “reclining beneath his wife’s loom,” the version with “reclining” is correct.—and struck him three times from neck to waist. The *Shiwen* reads “waist” as *yao*, pronounced *yu xiao*, with the same pronunciation below. Black Egg did not stir. Lai Dan, believing Black Egg dead—Bo Jun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (344) omits the character “之,” which is correct—hastened away. The *Shiwen* reads *qu* as *qu* (to hurry). At the gate, he encountered Black Egg’s son and struck him three times, as if thrusting into emptiness. Black Egg’s son was laughing and said: “Why are you so foolish as to beckon me thrice?” Yu Yue states: The *Shuowen*’s *shou* section defines *zhao* as “to summon with the hand.” Black Egg’s son did not see Lai Dan striking him with the sword but only saw him raising his hand as if beckoning, hence his words: “Why are you so foolish as to beckon me thrice?” The *Shiwen* notes: “One version reads *nian*,” which is a scribal error and should not be forced into interpretation. The *Shiwen* reads: *Zhao* in one version is *nian*, pronounced *nu jian*, meaning “to pick up an object with the fingers,” and also pronounced *dian*. Realizing the sword could not kill, Lai Dan sighed and returned home.

Black Egg, upon waking, angrily rebuked his wife: “You got me drunk and exposed me, causing my throat to seize and my waist to stiffen.” Xu Weiyu states: The *Shuowen*’s *kou* section defines *ai* as “the throat.” The *Fangyan* says: “*Ai* means choking. In Qin and Jin, it may also be called *ai* or *ye*.” The *Shuowen* defines *ye* as “food blocking the passage.” The *Odes*’ “Wang Feng” reads: “My heart is as if choked,” and the Mao commentary explains: “*Ye* means grief that cannot be stilled.” The meaning of *ai* as an ailment is the same. Choking with grief that cannot be stilled refers to the throat constricting and the breath becoming disordered. The *Shiwen* notes: “*Ai* is pronounced *yi*, referring to the upper throat.”

His son said: “Last night, when Lai Dan came, he encountered me at the gate and beckoned me three times, which also caused my body to ail and my limbs to stiffen.” The *Shiwen* reads “*qiang*” as “*qiang*,” noting: “*Qiang* is pronounced *qi liang*.”

“Surely he despises me!”

**[Exegesis]**
The person who has attained the utmost Dao is unharmed by the myriad things, nor can the harm of the myriad things injure them. Thus, venomous creatures do not sting, and fierce beasts do not seize. Even the most refined essences of things cannot cause harm. Laozi said: “Their spirit does not harm others.” For this reason, the sage values knowledge—why? Because it does not harm the myriad things.

The *Shiwen* notes: “*Yan* is pronounced *yu ran*, and the original character is also written as *ya*, pronounced *wu xia*."

King Mu of Zhou launched a great expedition against the Western Rong. The Western Rong presented a *kunwu* sword—the *Shiwen* notes: "*Kunwu* is a dragon sword." The *Hetu* states: "On Yingzhou there are many piled stones, called *kunwu*, which can be forged into swords." The *Shizi* says: "The *kunwu* sword can cut jade." They also presented fire-washed cloth—the *Shiwen* notes: "*Huan* is pronounced *huan*." The *Yiwu Zhi* records: "In the kingdom of Xintiao there is a Fire Continent, where trees and rats grow; their fur and pelts are woven into cloth called fire-washed cloth."

The sword was a *chi* and a *zhi* in length—the *Shiwen* notes: "*Zhi* is pronounced *zhi*, and eight *cun* make one *zhi*." Its blade was tempered steel with a red edge, and when used, it cut jade as easily as slicing mud.

**Bo Jun’s note:** The *Bowu Zhi* cites the *Zhou Shu*: "The Western Regions presented fire-washed cloth, and the Kunwu presented a jade-cutting knife. When the fire-washed cloth is soiled, it is burned, and it becomes clean again. The jade-cutting knife (these two characters are supplied from the *Taiping Yulan*, chapter 345) cuts jade like [missing character].’ In Han times, fire-washed cloth was presented, but the knife was never heard of."

The fire-washed cloth, when washed, must be cast into fire. **Wang Shumin says:** The *Taiping Yulan* (chapter 820) reads "its cloth" instead of "fire-washed cloth," matching the syntax of the earlier phrase "its sword was a *chi* and a *zhi* in length." When the cloth is in fire, it takes on the color of flame; when soiled, it resumes its cloth-like hue. Taken from the fire and shaken, it gleams as if pure snow. **Annotation:** This is as stated in the *Zhou Shu*. The *Shiwen* writes "*hao*" as "*hao*," noting: "Pronounced *gao*, or also written as *hao*, *hu lao* cut."

The Crown Prince believed no such thing existed and that those who transmitted this account were deluded. **Xiao Shu said:** "The Crown Prince was indeed obstinate in his self-assurance and hasty in dismissing reason!"

**Annotation:** This chapter concludes here, and the discussion of the jade-cutting knife and fire-washed cloth serves to demonstrate that all the preceding records are factual, for even these two objects are not fabrications.

**[Exegesis]**
That metal cannot cut jade is not due to the blade’s dullness; that cloth cannot be washed in fire without burning is due to the object’s peculiar nature. Within heaven and earth, among the multitude of the ten thousand things, some can be sought through reason, while others lie beyond reason’s reach. Thus, though jade is hard, it has a grain that can be carved; though a sword is iron, it has an edge that must sever. When an edge that must sever meets a thing with a grain that can be carved, if it does not penetrate, it is merely because the blade is not supremely sharp—not that there is no principle by which it can cut. Since such things already exist, why doubt them?

Moreover, among the categories of animals and plants, their natures differ: some arise through water and fire, while others perish through them. Thus, the mice of Fire Mountain come to life through fire, and the beasts of Wind Birth live through wind; man depends on empty space to stand, just as fish depend on water to exist. Now, the fire-washed cloth is neither ramie nor hemp. Though its name matches that of Chinese cloth, its fire and the fur of fire-mice are one and the same—what here is worthy of wonder? Those who cling stubbornly to their own certainty are simply ignorant!

**[Exegesis]**
After "neither ramie nor hemp" should follow "made from fire-mouse fur" (four characters), here omitted following the *Four Exegeses* edition. Also, after "matches that of Chinese cloth," the character "fire" is absent, and after "and," the three characters "the fur of fire-mice are one" are missing; these have been restored following the *Four Exegeses* edition.

Lu Wench’ao notes: The annotation’s "through" (*yin*) in the *Zang* edition appears as "by" (*you*), which is synonymous.
Guang Congxie observes: This refers to the *Dian Lun* of Emperor Wen of Wei’s discussion of fire-washed cloth. The "royal son" is Emperor Wen of Wei, indicating that this book still saw interpolations as late as the Jian’an era.
Yu Zhengxie states: The *Commentary* to the *Book of Later Han*’s "Account of the Southwest Barbarians" cites the *Shen Yi Jing*: "In the south there is a Fire Mountain, where grows an unburning tree that blazes day and night. Within the fire dwell mice weighing a hundred *jin*, their fur over two *chi* long, fine as silk, and white. Spun into cloth, if soiled, it is cleansed by fire." The *Taiping Guangji* records the *Liang Si Gong Ji*: "A merchant from Nanhai brought three bolts of fire-washed cloth: two were made from the bark of trees, one from the fur of fire-mice. The wood was stiff, the fur soft." The *Justice* to the *Records of the Grand Historian*’s "Account of Dayuan" cites Wan Zhen’s *Nanzhou Zhi*: "On the island of Sidiao in the sea of Da Qin grows a tree whose bark, stripped in winter, is spun into cloth indistinguishable from hemp or burnt cloth, its hue slightly green-black. If soiled, it becomes immaculate when placed in fire—hence the name fire-washed cloth. The people of Qin call it the bark of the *dingzhongshenjian* tree." It also cites the *Kuodi Zhi*: "In the Fire Mountain country, within the fire, are white mouse fur and tree bark, spun into fire-washed cloth." Ren Fang’s *Shu Yi Ji* states: "In the south, the Fire Mountain burns from the fourth to the twelfth month. When the fire dies, grass and trees sprout branches and leaves; when it revives, they shed. The bark is spun into fire-washed cloth." Kuang Lu’s *Chi Ya* notes: "Among the Miao, fire-washed cloth comes in three kinds: *bifang* hemp, *zhurong* wood, and fire-mouse fur." As for its use, the *Commentary* to the *Book of Later Han*’s "Account of the Western Barbarians" cites Fu Zi: "Elders say that during the reign of Emperor Huan of Han, Liang Ji made a robe of fire-washed cloth. When entertaining guests, he poured wine and feigned soiling it. Burning it, the grime vanished, the fire extinguished, and it emerged gleaming white as if washed in water." Cai Tao’s *Tiewei Shan Congtan* records: "Fire-washed cloth resembles cotton cloth, its color dark green. Cast into fire, it turns pure white. After the Xuanhe and Zhenghe eras, it arrived in abundance, and the imperial storehouse stitched it into kerchiefs, bedding, skirts, and robes." Thus, it first reached China in the Eastern Han, becoming common Southern merchandise by the Song. Jiang Shaoshu’s *Yunshi Zhai Bitan* observes: "Fire-washed cloth is slightly white; when brushed by hand, it leaves powder on the fingers, like touching a butterfly’s wings." This, then, is cloth spun from bark, its residual oil still present—a mundane thing. Today, in the borderlands of Yuexi Hall in Sichuan, within the crevices of the Wuman Mountains, grows a grass root called *buxiumu* ("undecaying wood"), its nature purely yin. Woven into cloth, it is washed with fire. The *Sichuan Tongzhi* states: "Only the destitute use it." The *Baopuzi*’s "On Immortals" records: "Emperor Wen of Wei claimed the world had no jade-cutting knives or fire-washed cloth. When he wrote the *Dian Lun* and asserted this, before long both objects arrived. The emperor sighed and promptly destroyed the work." Now, examining the text: "Emperor Wen said that the notion of fire-mouse fur as cloth, cleansed by fire when soiled, was false. Fire has no power to nurture life—how could mice live within it? He had the *Dian Lun* engraved at the Imperial Academy. During Emperor Ming’s reign, one who presented this cloth as tribute caused the stele to be chiseled away."

The *Liezi*’s "Tang Wen" chapter likewise records this. The *Liezi*, a work from the Jin dynasty attributed to Wang Fu and Ge Hong, speaks of sages in its "Zhong Ni" chapter and of fire-washed cloth in its "Tang Wen" chapter. Cen Zhongmian notes: "Fire-washed cloth is asbestos, later called 'undecaying wood' and now known as 'stone floss.' Persians and Arabs were well acquainted with it. The Central Asian variety originates from Badakhshan, once a vassal region of China. This substance possesses fibrous structures resembling hemp, from which cloth, paper, and kerchiefs may be crafted."

Bo Jun observes: The *Erya*’s *Shi Gu* commentary, citing the *Shizi*’s "Guang Ze" chapter with the line *"Huangzi gui zhong"* ("The august son cherishes the inner"), suggests—if credible—that a certain "august son" predated Shi Jiao. Yet this "august son" unmistakably refers to Emperor Wen of Wei. Further, *The Complete Prose of the Jin Dynasty* includes the *"Fu on the Wondrous Cloth of Ban Ju"*, whose preface states that in the second year of Taikang (281 CE), the Da Qin kingdom presented tribute, and the fire-washed cloth was particularly marvelous, prompting the composition of the *fu*—this was the same fire-washed cloth.

Another note: In the phrase *"fu jin zhi bu neng qie yu zhe ji bu zhi bu neng huan yu huo"* ("that metal cannot cut jade and cloth cannot be washed in fire"), the two *"bu"* ("not") characters appear to be superfluous. The *Exegesis* glosses *"duan"* as pronounced *da guan*. *Collected Exegeses of the Liezi*, Volume Six, "Li Ming" ("Force and Fate").

The *Annotation* states: "Fate" refers to the inevitable term, the inherently fixed portion. Though this matter has yet to be verified, this principle is already so. To believe that longevity or early death depends on nurture and care, or that success or failure hinges on wisdom and effort, is to be deluded about the principles of Heaven.

The *Exegesis* states: "Fate" is the fixed portion, which cannot be realized without effort; "effort" is the power of advancement, which cannot be fulfilled without fate. Those endowed with fate must rely on effort; those who exert effort may or may not align with their fate. There are things effort cannot achieve—this is the absence of fate; relying on fate without striving is merely awaiting the right moment. Those who trust fate but not effort err greatly; those who trust effort but not fate are also not correct.

The *Exegesis* notes: *Fen* (portion) is pronounced *fu wen*; *yao* (early death) is pronounced *yu zhao*; *xi* (hinge) is read as *ji*.

Effort said to Fate: "What is your merit compared to mine?"
Fate replied: "What merit do you have over things that you dare compare yourself to me?"
Effort said: "Longevity or early death, success or failure, nobility or baseness, wealth or poverty—these are all within my power."
Fate said: "Peng Zu’s wisdom did not surpass that of Yao and Shun, yet he lived eight hundred years."
Kong Guangsen notes: Peng Zu was the ancestor of the Peng clan. The Peng clan included several states: Da Peng, Shi Wei, and Zhu Ji. Da Peng served the Xia and Yu dynasties and became a lord under the Shang, but was destroyed during the reign of Wu Ding. Thus, "Peng Zu lived eight hundred years" refers to the Peng state lasting eight hundred years before its fall, not that Jian himself was immortal.
Yan Kejun notes: In the *Discourses of Zheng*, Historian Bo said: "Among the eight descendants of Zhu Rong, Da Peng and Shi Wei were lords under the Shang." The Peng clan included Peng Zu, Shi Wei, and Zhu Ji, all of whom were destroyed by the Shang. Wei Zhao explains: "Da Peng was the third son of Lu Zhong, named Jian, who founded the Peng clan and was enfeoffed at Da Peng, hence called Peng Zu." He also explains: "Peng Zu refers to Da Peng." The *Records of the Grand Historian: House of Chu* states: "Lu Zhong had six sons; the third was Peng Zu." The *Collected Explanations* cites Yu Fan: "His name was Jian; he founded the Peng clan, was enfeoffed at Da Peng, and was called Peng Zu." The *Index* cites the *Genealogical Records*: "The third son was Jian Keng, known as Peng Zu." The *Book of Zhou: Explanation of Wheat* states: "August Heaven pitied Yu and granted him the longevity of Peng, to rectify the Xia’s decline." The *Bamboo Annals* records: "In the fifteenth year of Emperor Qi, Wu Guan rebelled in the West River. Peng Bo Shou led troops to suppress the West River and decisively defeated them." Thus, Peng Zu was a state name, namely Da Peng, which served as a regional lord under the Xia and Shang, one of the Five Hegemons of antiquity. It was enfeoffed during the Tang and Yu dynasties, passed through dozens of generations, lasted eight hundred years, and was destroyed by the Shang—this is the historical fact. "Peng Zu lived eight hundred years" is akin to saying the Xia lasted four hundred years, the Shang six hundred, and the Zhou eight hundred.
Ma Xulun notes: Kong and Yan’s explanations are correct. The *Zhuangzi: Free and Easy Wandering* states: "Yet Peng Zu is still renowned for his longevity." It seems Zhuangzi also mistakenly believed Peng Zu lived seven or eight hundred years. This was a common saying of the time, which Zhuangzi followed, as did Xunzi.
Yan Yuan’s talent did not surpass that of ordinary people, yet he died at eighteen.
The character "eighteen" follows the Northern Song edition and the Shide Hall edition; the Zang, Sijie, Jifu, and Qin engravings of Lu’s commentary read "forty-eight."
Hong Yi notes: The *Huainanzi: Spirit and Vitality* commentary by Gao You states: "Yan Hui died at eighteen." The *Book of Later Han: Biography of Lang Yi* states: "In the past, when Yanzi was eighteen, the world embraced benevolence." The *Baopuzi: Recluses* states: "When Yan Hui died, Duke Ding of Lu was about to personally offer condolences and sent someone to ask Confucius." The *Baopuzi* also takes Yan Yuan as having died at eighteen, hence his death occurring during Duke Ding’s reign.
Bo Jun notes: The lifespan of Yan Yuan varies in ancient traditions. Though he was said to have died young, if we examine reliable records such as the *Zuozhuan* and *Records of the Grand Historian*, we can confidently assert that he did not die at eighteen. However, since this text is allegorical, it may adopt the shortest lifespan.
Confucius’s virtue did not surpass that of the feudal lords, yet he was besieged in Chen and Cai.

The conduct of King Zhou of Yin did not surpass that of the Three Benevolent Ones, yet he occupied the throne. Bo Jun notes: The *Analects: Weizi* states: "Weizi departed, Jizi became his slave, and Bigan remonstrated unto death. Confucius said: ‘Yin had three benevolent ones.’" The *Exegesis* reads: *xing* (conduct), pronounced as in *xiameng*. Jizha held no rank in Wu. The *Exegesis* states: Jizha, a descendant of Taibo of Wu, was virtuous and yielded his position, abandoning his household to till the land. Later, he was enfeoffed at Yanling, hence styled Yanling Jizi. Tian Heng monopolized the state of Qi. Boyi and Shuqi starved at Shouyang, while the Ji clan grew wealthier than Zhan Qin. If these are within the power of your strength, why then do some live long while others die young, why are the sagely impoverished while the perverse prosper, why are the worthy debased while the foolish exalted, why are the good impoverished while the wicked enriched?"

Li replied: "If it is as you say, then I have certainly no merit in relation to things, yet why do things fare thus? Is this then within your control?" The *Daozang* unannotated edition and Lin Xiyi’s edition read "若言" (*ruo yan*, "as you say") as "是言" (*shi yan*, "these words"). Tao Hongqing said: The first "邪" (*ye*) should be read as "也" (*ye*, "then"). "Yet why do things fare thus then?" connects in meaning to the following sentence, saying: "That things fare thus—is this within your control?" For he first concedes his lack of merit and then counters with a question. Note that *ye* and *xie* were interchangeable in ancient usage.

Ming replied: "Since it is called *ming* (fate/destiny), how can there be one who controls it? I simply push forth what is straight and entrust what is crooked. Some live long, some die young; some are impoverished, some prosper; some are exalted, some debased; some grow rich, some remain poor. That which is so without knowing why it is so—this is *ming*. How can it be controlled? How can I comprehend it? How can I comprehend it?"

[Note] This chapter elucidates that all things possess *ming*, rendering wisdom and effort futile. The *Yang Zhu* chapter speaks of people following their desires without restraint, implying that control does not derive from *ming*. The principles differ and appear contradictory. Yet amid the shifts between order and chaos, the clashes of love and hate, the myriad deceptions and complexities—who can fathom the causes of their excesses? Thus the sage preserves both perspectives without debate. This is to broadly uphold the teachings of names and rituals, for the origins of corruption cannot be entirely blocked. Some rely on deceit and force to defy the times and *ming*, as when the Lord of Chu inquired about the Zhou tripods, or when Wu Zhi caused chaos in Qi. Others feign natural integrity to pursue fame, as when Boyi and Shuqi starved on Mount Shouyang, or when Zhong You was minced in Wei. Therefore, Liezi presents these two extremes, allowing all things to seek their own center. If one attains this center, then the cunning and active will not disrupt their inherent allotment with power, nor will those who pride themselves on fame harm their bodily life through artificial restraint. The intent of these words lies precisely here. Alas! Can readers fail to examine this closely?

**[Exegesis]**
*Ming* is Heaven; *li* (force) is man. *Ming* can accomplish, *li* can move—hence it is called "moving *ming*." Zhuangzi said: "When one knows there is nothing to be done, one rests in it as *ming*." This is when *li* cannot move it. Confucius said: "At fifty, I understood the *ming* of Heaven." "He who does not understand *ming* cannot be a noble person." Yet when he traveled through the states on diplomatic missions, he longed to be a groom holding the whip—this was not forgetting *li*.

**Yang Bojun’s note:** The exegesis cites Zhuangzi from the "Human World" chapter, omitting the word *er* (而) after *he* (何). The Shidetang edition mistakenly writes *si* (似) as *yi* (以), *cun* (存) as *qing* (情), and *xun* (殉) as *zhi* (殖). The *Shiwen* (Explanations of Characters) reads: *wu* (恶) as *wulu* (乌路切); *di* (适) as *di* (的); *xun* (殉) originally as *xun* (徇), meaning "to seek"; *hai* (醢) as *hai* (海); *kou* (叩) as *kou* (寇).

Beigongzi said to Ximenzi: "You and I live in the same age, yet people esteem you; we belong to the same clan, yet people respect you; we share the same appearance, yet people love you; we speak the same words, yet people employ yours; we act the same way, yet people trust you; we hold office together, yet you are honored; we farm together, yet you are wealthy; we trade together, yet you profit. I wear coarse hemp, *shuhe*, while you wear patterned brocade; I eat coarse grains, *zili*, while you eat fine millet and meat. I live in a thatched hut, while you dwell in a mansion with towering beams; I walk on foot, while you ride in a carriage drawn by four horses. At home, you are cheerful and seem to scorn me; in court, you are forthright and wear an air of disdain toward me. You do not visit me for favors, nor do we travel together—this has been the case for years. Do you consider your virtue superior to mine?"

Ximenzi replied: "I have no way of knowing the truth of this. You undertake affairs and meet with failure; I undertake affairs and meet with success—is this not proof of the difference in our *houbo* (thickness/thinness)?"

**[Annotation]** It refers to the thickness or thinness of virtue.

**[Exegesis]** All my undertakings succeed, while all yours fail—thus the thickness or thinness of virtue is evident. Yet you claim we are equal. How thick-skinned you are!

Beigongzi had no reply. He left in embarrassment and on the way encountered Master Dongguo. The master said: "Where have you been, that you return with such halting steps and a look of deep shame?"

Beigongzi described what had happened. Master Dongguo said: "I will relieve your shame. Let us go together to Ximen’s house and ask him." He said: "Why do you so humiliate Beigongzi? Speak plainly."

**Yang Bojun’s note:** *Gu* (固) should be read as *gu* (姑), meaning "temporarily."

Ximenzi said: "Beigongzi claims that our clans, ages, appearances, words, and conduct are the same, yet our status, wealth, and poverty differ. I told him: 'I have no way of knowing the truth. You undertake affairs and fail; I undertake affairs and succeed—is this not proof of the difference in our *houbo*? Yet you claim we are equal. How thick-skinned you are!'"

Master Dongguo said: "Your words on *houbo* refer only to differences in talent and virtue. My words on *houbo* differ from this. Beigongzi is thick in virtue but thin in *ming*; you are thick in *ming* but thin in virtue. Your success is not due to wisdom, nor is his failure due to folly. Both are of Heaven, not of man.

**[Annotation]** This is the natural course of things, not due to human skill or clumsiness.

You take pride in your thick *ming*, while Beigongzi feels shame for his thick virtue."

**Hu Huaichen’s note:** Since he knows his virtue is thick, he should not feel shame. Thus, "feeling shame for thick virtue" is textually unsound. It should read, "feeling shame for thin *ming*." This is not a copyist’s error but a minor flaw in the original *Liezi* text.

**Yang Bojun’s note:** Hu’s argument is debatable. Ancient texts often employ reciprocal phrasing—here, "thick *ming*" implies "thin virtue," and "thick virtue" implies "thin *ming*." Both fail to recognize the principle of inevitability.

**Textual note:** The Zang, Jifu, Sijie, and Qin editions omit the word *yi* (矣). It is added here following the Northern Song and Shidetang editions. Also, *guran* (固然) may originally have been *ziran* (自然).

**The *Shiwen* reads:** *fu* (夫) as *fu* (符).

Ximenzi said: "Enough, Master!"

"I dare not speak further."

**[Annotation:]**
Hearing the principle, he submits.

**[Exegesis:]**
That Ximenzi’s pursuit succeeded was *ming*; that Beigongzi’s did not was also *ming*. Unaware of *ming*, one bears an air of self-importance; knowing *ming*, one harbors no anxiety or shame. Attainment or failure—neither hinges on wisdom or folly, talent or virtue. That Ximenzi dared not speak further was because, knowing *ming* had favored him, he dared not presume upon his virtue.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Fu* (復), *fúyòu* cut.

When Beigongzi returned home, he donned his coarse hempen robe, its warmth like that of fox or raccoon-dog fur;
**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Yi* (衣), *yùjì* cut. *Húhè* (狐貉), pronounced *húhè*.

he took his rough beans, their savor like that of fine rice and millet;
**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Róngshū* (茙菽), pronounced *róngshū*. The *Erya* states: *róngshū* are called *rěnshū*, that is, barbarian beans. The *Guanzi* records: Duke Huan of Qi, journeying north to Mount Tai, gathered winter onions and *róngshū*, then spread them throughout the land. Zheng Xuan notes: these are soybeans.

he sheltered beneath his thatched hut as though beneath a vast mansion’s eaves;

he rode his thornwood carriage as though adorned with a patterned chariot.
**[Textual Note:]**
*Bì* (筚) appears in all other editions as *bì* (荜). Here, *bì* (筚) is the correct character; the *Zuozhuan* writes *bì* (筚), and the *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the "Hereditary House of Chu," writes *bì* (荜). The *Phonetic Gloss* writes *bì* (荜), noting: *bì* (荜), *bì* tone; *lù* (辂), *lù* tone. The *Zuozhuan* states: "a firewood cart." **[Yang Bojun’s Note:]**

For the rest of his life, he remained carefree,
**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Yōu* (逌), *yóu* tone. *Yōurán* (逌然) describes a self-contented demeanor. The same pronunciation appears in the later "Yang Zhu" chapter.

unaware of glory or disgrace residing in others or in himself.
**[Annotation:]**
Once the principle is grasped, external things—whether abundant or meager—cannot sway the mind.

**[Exegesis:]**
Knowing *ming*, one feels neither anxiety nor shame, nor does one discern the thickness or thinness of virtue.

**[Phonetic Gloss:]**
*Gài* (概), *gǔdài* cut.

Master Dongguo, hearing this, said: "Beigongzi has slumbered long indeed! A single word awakened him—how easily roused!"
**[Exegesis:]**
"Slumbered" means he had not yet awakened. When he did awaken, it was merely to the ordinary.
**[Textual Note:]**
*Wù* (悟) appears in the Northern Song edition as *wù* (寤); the Zang and Shidetang editions write *dá* (怛). Yu Yue notes: *dá* (怛) should be read as *dàn* (旦). In the *Mang* ode of the *Book of Songs*, "the earnest oath *dàndàn* (旦旦)" is cited in the *Shuowen* under the "heart" radical as *xīnshì* □□. □ is an alternate form of *dá* (怛). Thus, *dá* (怛) and *dàn* (旦) were interchangeable in antiquity.

Those who slumber awaken at the break of dawn. Beigongzi had slumbered long before suddenly awakening—hence the saying, "How easily dawned upon!" The *Shiwen* notes *dàn* (旦) as *dāng gē* cut, though its pronunciation remains uncertain. Some write it as *wù* (悟), a later emendation by those who failed to grasp its meaning.

**Bo Jun’s Note:** According to Lu’s commentary, the *Chongxuan* edition also writes *dá* (怛). The *Shiwen* renders *wù* (悟) as *dá* (怛), stating: "*Dá* (怛), *dāng gē* cut; writing it as *wù* (悟) is incorrect."

Guan Yiwu and Bao Shuya shared a bond of profound kinship. **Bo Jun’s Note:** In the *Mencius* ("Gaozi, Part II"), it is written: "When his elder brother drew the bow to shoot him, he wept and pleaded with him. There was no other reason—it was kinship." The commentary explains: "*Qī* (戚) means 'intimacy.'"

The *Shiwen* states: Guan Yiwu and Bao Shuya were both natives of Yingchuan. Bao Ya was a grandee of Qi, his tomb located in Yingzhou. **Bo Jun’s Note:** The *Shiwen*’s "Bao Ya" should read "Bao Shu."

They both resided in Qi. Guan Yiwu served Prince Jiu. The *Shiwen* notes: *Jiǔ* (纠), *guī yǒu* cut. Bao Shuya served Prince Xiaobai. The Qi royal clan was rife with favoritism, with legitimate and illegitimate lines treated equally. **Note:** Qi Xigong’s younger brother, Yizhong, fathered Prince Wuzhi. Xigong doted on him, granting him rites and rank equal to the crown prince. The *Shiwen* notes: *Dí* (嫡), *dí* sound. *Xī* (僖), *xǔ qí* cut, sometimes written as *lí* (厘). The people of the state feared chaos.

Guan Zhong and Shao Hu escorted Prince Jiu in flight to Lu. **Note:** Jiu was Duke Xiang’s younger brother. The *Shiwen* notes: *Shào* (召) is written as *Shào* (邵) in some editions. Bao Shu escorted Prince Xiaobai in flight to Ju. **Note:** Xiaobai was Jiu’s younger brother. The *Shiwen* notes: *Jǔ* (莒), *jǔ* sound.

Later, Prince Wuzhi staged a rebellion. **Note:** After Duke Xiang ascended, he demoted Wuzhi’s rank and attire, leading Wuzhi to kill the duke and seize the throne. The people of the state soon killed him. The *Shiwen* notes: *Chù* (绌), *chù* sound, also *shì hū* cut. *Zhì* (秩), *zhì* sound. *Shā* (杀), *shì* sound.

With Qi lacking a ruler, the two princes vied to enter. Guan Yiwu clashed with Xiaobai in Ju, shooting him in the belt hook along the way. The *Shiwen* notes: *Shè* (射), *shí yì* cut. *Zhòng* (中), *dīng zhòng* cut. Once Xiaobai ascended the throne—**Note:** Xiaobai was Duke Huan—he coerced Lu into killing Prince Jiu. The *Shiwen* writes *xié* (胁) as *lā* (搚), noting: "Also written as *xié* (胁)." Shao Hu died for him, while Guan Yiwu was imprisoned. **Note:** Qi informed Lu: "Prince Jiu was our brother; we could not bear to execute him ourselves, so we ask you to kill him. Shao Hu and Guan Zhong were our enemies; we wish to savor their flesh as mincemeat. If you refuse, we will destroy Lu." Fearing this, Lu killed Prince Jiu. Shao Hu took his own life, while Guan Zhong requested imprisonment.

Bao Shuya told Duke Huan: "Guan Yiwu is capable—he can govern the state." The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhì* (治), *zhí lì* cut. Duke Huan replied: "He is my enemy; I wish to kill him." Bao Shuya said: "I have heard that a worthy ruler bears no private grudges. Moreover, one who can serve his lord can also serve a ruler. If you seek hegemony, **The *Shiwen* notes:** *Wáng* (王), *yú kuàng* cut. none but Yiwu will suffice. You must pardon him!" The *Shiwen* notes: *Shě* (舍), *shì* sound. Duke Huan then summoned Guan Zhong. Lu returned him to Qi, where Bao Shuya welcomed him beyond the outskirts and freed him from captivity. Duke Huan treated him with ritual propriety—**Note:** Bao Shu personally met Guan Zhong at Tangfu, removing his shackles, and presented him to Duke Huan at Qi’s outskirts. The *Shiwen* notes: *Fù* (阜), *fù* sound. Jia Kui said: "Tangfu lies on Lu’s northern border." Du Yu said: "It is a Qi territory in Dongguan." *Jiàn* (见), *xián biàn* cut. **Bo Jun’s Note:** Tangfu is located northwest of present-day Mengyin County, Linyi Prefecture, Shandong—Qi territory. He was placed above Gao and Guo, while Bao Shuya humbled himself beneath him. **The *Shiwen* notes:** *Xià* (下), *xiá jià* cut. Entrusted with state governance, he was styled "Zhongfu." Guan Zhong once sighed: "In my youth, when I was poor and destitute, I once traded with Bao Shu. The *Shiwen* notes: *Gǔ* (贾), *gǔ* sound. I kept more of the profits for myself, yet Bao Shu did not think me greedy—he knew I was impoverished. I once devised a plan for Bao Shu that led to great hardship. This is why the world praises Guan and Bao’s fine friendship and Xiaobai’s skill in employing talent. Yet in truth, there was no fine friendship, nor was there skill in employing talent. That there was no fine friendship and no skill in employing talent does not mean there exists some other fine friendship or skill in employing talent. **Note:** This clarifies that in principle, there is no fine friendship or skill in employing talent—this is not limited to Guan, Bao, or Duke Huan. **Exegesis:** When one’s fate aligns with its use, one attains success through friendship—this does not imply some other fine friendship or skill in employing talent. Thus, relying on talent to gain office is a matter of fate, while achieving success through friendship is a matter of effort.

Not only does Heaven’s timing play its part, but even those who succeed through human planning and effort ultimately return to fate. When fate arrives, Bao Shu could not but exert all his strength, and Duke Huan could not but employ him—all was fate! Shujun notes: Below "there exists some other skill in employing talent," a "者" should likely be added.

Zhao Hu was not capable of dying, yet could not but die; Bao Shu was not capable of recommending the worthy, yet could not but recommend; Duke Huan was not capable of employing his foe, yet could not but employ him. **Annotation:** All these were driven by unseen forces, not governed by human effort. **Exegesis:** Fate is perfected through effort, and effort is perfected through fate—there is no partiality in this.

The original text read "human principle" (人理) for "human effort" (人力), but the present version follows the *Zang* edition’s correction.

When Guan Yiwu fell ill, Duke Huan visited him and said, "Your illness has become grave—it cannot be concealed. **Annotation:** The severity of the illness leaves no room for concealment. **Exegesis:** When death approaches, it cannot be denied. The *Shide Tang* edition reads "the illness is severe" (病疾矣). Yu Yue argues: The *Lu Chongxuan* edition has "病" instead of "疾," which should be followed. The *Zhuangzi*'s *Xu Wugui* chapter concurs. Shujun notes: The Northern Song edition, *Zang* edition, *Jifu* edition, and *Sijie* edition all read "病," as do the *Yanzi* and *Zhiyou* quotations. The original likely read "疾病." The *Shuowen* states: "疾 means illness; 病 means illness worsening." In ancient texts, severe illness is always termed *jibing* (疾病). For example, the *Lunyu* (*Zihan* chapter) says, "When the Master’s illness worsened, Zilu had his disciples act as retainers" (Zheng Xuan’s note: "病 refers to illness growing more severe"). The *Yili* (*Jixi Ji*) states, "In severe illness, both inner and outer chambers are swept clean" (Zheng Xuan’s note: "Severe illness is called 病"). The *Zuozhuan* (*Xuan* 15th year) records: "When ill, Meng Ke said, 'You must marry her!' When the illness worsened, he said, 'You must bury her with me!' Upon his death, Meng Ke married her, saying, 'When illness worsens, one’s mind is disordered—I follow what is proper.'" The *Zuozhuan* (*Xiang* 19th year) also states: "When the Marquis of Qi fell ill, Cui Zhu secretly welcomed Guang; when the illness worsened, he enthroned him." The *Zuozhuan* (*Huan* 5th year) further notes: "When the Duke’s illness worsened, chaos erupted." All these are examples of *jibing* (疾病) used together. The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Zhijie* chapter) likewise says, "Your illness has become grave—what teachings will you leave me?" This is further confirmation. The *Shide Tang* edition reads "病疾," a reversal of the proper order; later scholars, failing to recognize this, hastily altered it to "病病." Yu Yue’s argument is incorrect. The *Shiwen* notes: *fu* (復) is read as *fuyou*.

"When it comes to a fatal illness, to whom should I entrust the state?" Wang Chongmin argues: Zhang’s annotation states, "The severity of the illness leaves no room for concealment." Based on this, the original text’s "可不" should be transposed. The *Guanzi* (*Jie* and *Xiaochen* chapters) both read "不可讳." Zhang’s interpretation, taking "可不讳云" as a single phrase and explaining it as "cannot be concealed," is also incorrect. The word *yun* (云) should be read as the start of the next clause, meaning "like" or "as if." See the *Shici* for examples. The *Zhiyou* omits these four characters, likely because its compiler did not grasp their meaning.

Shujun notes: Wang’s argument is sound. The *Liji* (*Tangong*) states: "When Cheng Zigao was gravely ill, Qing Yi entered and asked, 'Your illness has become critical—if it reaches a fatal stage, what then?'" Here, "云至于大病" parallels "如至乎大病也." The *Shiwen* notes: *wu* (恶) is read as *wu*; *zhu* (属) is read as *zhu*.

Guan Yiwu asked, "Whom does Your Lordship desire?" The *Shiwen* notes: *yu* (欤) is read as *yu*.

Duke Huan said, "Bao Shuya would be suitable."
Guan Yiwu replied, "He is not. His character is that of a pure and upright gentleman. **Annotation:** He merely keeps himself unsullied. The "也" after "人" is added following the *Zang* edition to match the structure of "其为人也" below. The *Shiwen* reads "洁" as "絜," pronounced *jie*. Toward those who do not match his standards, he does not associate. **Annotation:** He seeks to align all things with his own virtue. If he hears of another’s fault, he never forgets it. **Annotation:** He cannot overlook flaws to record virtues. The *Shiwen* notes: *xia* (瑕) is pronounced *xia*.

If you appoint him to govern the state, above he will constrain his lord, and below he will oppose the people. **Annotation:** He will inevitably invoke the lord’s commands, but his Way is not expansive. If the Way is not expansive, he will oppose the people and fail to guide them. Wang Chongmin argues: The *Zhuangzi* (*Xu Wugui* chapter) reads "治国" instead of "理国"—this should also be "治," altered to avoid taboo. The *Zhiyou* correctly reads "治."

His offense against his lord will not be long in coming." The *Zhiyou* omits the "也."

Duke Huan said, "Then who is suitable?"
Guan Yiwu replied, "If you must choose, then Xi Peng is suitable. **Annotation:** He is not necessarily suitable, but there is no better option. The *Shiwen* notes: *xi* (隰) is pronounced *xi*.

His character is such that above he forgets his rank, and below he does not rebel. **Annotation:** Occupying a high position yet forgetting himself, he need not fear the people’s dispersal. Wang Chongmin argues: Zhang’s explanation is incorrect. The *Zhuangzi* reads "上忘而下畔," with an extra "不." *Pan* (畔) is interchangeable with *pan* (叛), meaning "rebellious slander." *Pan* and *yan* (谚) are rhyming words, a common pairing in ancient speech."

The *Shi* *Dayi* *Huangyi* reads "畔援," while the *Hanshu* *Xuzhuan* annotation cites it as "畔换," and the *Wenxuan* *Weidu Fu* renders it as "叛换." Sometimes it appears as the single word "谚," as in the *Shangshu* *Wu Yi*: "乃逸乃谚." The apocryphal Kong commentary states: "叛谚不恭" ("rebellious slander is irreverent"). In the *Lunyu* *Xianjin* chapter, it says: "由也喭." Zheng Xuan’s annotation explains: "Zilu’s conduct errs in rebellious slander"—this is the meaning. At times, it appears as the single word "畔." In the *Lunyu* *Yongye* chapter: "君子博学于文，约之以礼，亦可以弗畔矣夫" (following Yu Yue’s *Qunjing Pingyi* reading), and in the *Liezi*: "上忘而下叛," this is the usage. The *Shi* *Zheng* commentary states: "畔援 means overbearing." The *Han Shi* reads: "武强也" ("martial and strong"). Liu Yuanlin’s annotation to the *Weidu Fu* explains: "叛换 is like 恣睢" ("arbitrary and unrestrained"). Thus, "上忘而下不叛" means "toward superiors, he forgets his loftiness; toward inferiors, he does not assert dominance." Hence, the following text states: "He who with virtue defers to others has never failed to win them." Guo Xiang’s annotation to the *Zhuangzi*—"high yet not overbearing"—captures its essence.

Bo Jun’s note: The *Lüshi Chunqiu* *Guigong* chapter reads "上志而下求" ("above, he is mindful; below, he seeks").

He feels shame before those not equal to the Yellow Emperor and pities those not equal to himself.
**Annotation:** Ashamed that his Dao does not match the sages, and compassionate toward those whose people fall short of his own, he thus discards no one.
**Explanation:** Forgetting his own loftiness and ashamed of his lack of virtue, his resolve to embrace goodness runs deep. Toward those inferior to himself, he feels pity and compassion, so his subordinates do not rebel or disperse.

Wang Chongmin notes: The *Zhiyao* omits the character "其" after "愧," which is correct. Neither the *Zhuangzi* *Xu Wugui* chapter nor the *Lüshi Chunqiu* *Guigong* chapter includes it, confirming this.

One who shares virtue with others is called a sage.
**Annotation:** He transforms others to align with the Dao without imposing control.

One who shares wealth with others is called a worthy.
**Annotation:** The more he gives, the more he possesses.

To govern others with worthiness never wins their allegiance.
**Annotation:** Demanding perfection from others, things will not comply.
Wang Chongmin notes: The *Zhiyao* includes the character "者" after the first "人," which is correct. This parallels the following sentence: "以贤下人者未有不得人者也." Since the latter includes "者," it is clear the former originally did as well. The *Zhuangzi* omits both "者" characters, a divergence between the *Zhuangzi* and *Liezi*. However, this may serve as indirect evidence that the first sentence should include "者."

He who with worthiness defers to others has never failed to win them.
**Annotation:** One who rises and falls with things will surely be embraced by them.
Wang Chongmin notes: The *Zhiyao* includes the characters "之也" after "归" in the annotation.

In governing the state, there are things he does not hear; in managing the household, there are things he does not see.
**Annotation:** When the Dao prevails, there is no need for excessive hearing or seeing. Thus, it is said: "One who is neither blind nor deaf cannot achieve success."
Wang Chongmin notes: The *Zhiyao* renders "烦" as "赖" in the annotation.
Bo Jun’s note: The *Lüshi Chunqiu* *Guigong* chapter includes the sentence "其于物也有不知也" after "有不闻也."

**Annotation by Guo Xiang:** If he were to hear and see everything, affairs would center on himself, leaving subordinates nowhere to place their hands and feet. Thus, disregarding such matters is acceptable. Since he cannot fully embody the Dao, merely this is permissible.
**Explanation:** Not demanding the ordinary nature of things is "not hearing in the state." Not seeking others’ minor faults is "not seeing in the household."
The *Zhiyao* renders "群下" as "群生" in the annotation.

Thus, the *Shiwen* notes: "仅 is pronounced *jin*."

In this case, Guan Yiwu’s slighting of Bao Shu was not intentional; he could not but slight him. His favoring of Xi Peng was not deliberate; he could not but favor him. Favor at the outset may turn to slight in the end; slight in the end may turn to favor at the outset. Tao Hongqing states: The phrase "薄之于终，或厚之于始" should read "薄之于始，或厚之于终" ("slight at the outset may turn to favor in the end"). The current version redundantly echoes the preceding two sentences. The ebb and flow of favor and slight do not depend on me.
**Annotation:** All is the principle of Heaven.
**Explanation:** Yiwu’s feelings held no inherent favor or slight; this was a public recommendation. Recommending someone was favor; not recommending was slight. All was a matter of effort. Since Duke Huan did not employ Bao Shu, it was Bao Shu’s fate. Employing Xi Peng was Xi Peng’s fate. Had Bao Shu lacked fate, Yiwu’s efforts would have been futile. Had Xi Peng lacked fate, Yiwu’s efforts, though exerted, would have been in vain.

Deng Xi wielded the doctrine of dual possibilities.
**Annotation by the *Shiwen*:** *Xi* is pronounced *xi*.
Deng Xi authored two chapters. A native of Zheng, he was a contemporary of Zichan. Both the *Liezi* and Xunzi state that Zichan killed Deng Xi, but according to the *Zuozhuan*, Zichan died in the twentieth year of Duke Zhao, while in the ninth year of Duke Ding, Si Luan killed Deng Xi and adopted his bamboo penal code. Thus, he was not killed by Zichan.
**Annotation:** *Cao* is pronounced *qi dao*.
Ren Dachun states: The account of Zichan killing Deng Xi appears in various philosophical works, not just Xunzi and Liezi. The *Lüshi Chunqiu* *Liwei* chapter records: "When Zichan governed Zheng, Deng Xi devoted himself to challenging him. Those among the people with lawsuits would offer a robe for major cases or a jacket and scallions for minor ones. The number of people presenting robes, jackets, and scallions to learn litigation became innumerable. He inverted right and wrong, turning wrong into right and right into wrong."

Right and wrong lacked measure, and what was permissible or impermissible shifted daily: what one wished to vindicate was vindicated, and what one wished to condemn was condemned. The state of Zheng fell into great disorder, and the people’s voices clamored in uproar. Zichan, troubled by this, thereupon executed Deng Xi and exposed his corpse, and the people were greatly subdued.

The *Huainanzi*’s *Quan yan xun* states: “Deng Xi was clever in disputation and subverted the law.” Gao You’s commentary notes: “Deng Xi taught the people of Zheng to litigate, and litigation brought no calamity. Zichan executed him for this.”

Yang Liang’s commentary on the *Xunzi*’s *Zheng lun* chapter cites the *Xin xu* as saying: “When Zichan judged cases, Deng Xi taught the people to challenge him. For major lawsuits, they pledged a robe; for minor ones, a jacket and scallions. The number of people presenting robes, jackets, and scallions to study litigation became innumerable. He inverted wrong into right and right into wrong. The state of Zheng fell into great disorder, and the people’s voices clamored in uproar. Zichan, troubled by this, thereupon punished Deng Xi and exposed his corpse, and the people were subdued; right and wrong were thus settled.” This account is of the same kind.

The claim that Deng Xi was not executed by Zichan first appears in Zhang Zhan’s commentary on the *Liezi*, under the phrase “soon after, he was executed.” Zhang Zhan’s note states: “The *Liezi* says Zichan executed Deng Xi, but the *Zuozhuan* records that Si Luan killed Deng Xi and adopted his bamboo penal code—Deng Xi died twenty years after Zichan’s death.” Jing Shun’s *Shiwen* further elaborates on this annotation, stating that Zichan died in the twentieth year of Duke Zhao, and Si Luan killed Deng Xi in the ninth year of Duke Ding—thus, Deng Xi’s death occurred twenty years after Zichan’s.

Yang Liang’s commentary on the *Xunzi*’s *Bu gou* chapter also notes: “The *Zuozhuan* states that Si Luan of Zheng killed Deng Xi and adopted his bamboo penal code, so the claim that Zichan executed him is likely an error.” This annotation, like Jing Shun’s *Shiwen*, is based on Zhang Zhan’s commentary.

He crafted endless arguments while Zichan held office and created the bamboo penal code.
**Annotation:** *Bamboo penal code* refers to laws inscribed on bamboo slips.
Lu Wenchong remarks: The annotation “bamboo penal code, laws on bamboo slips” should perhaps read “bamboo-slip penal code.” Bo Jun notes: Lu’s suggestion does not clarify Zhang’s intent; Zhang’s annotation likely explains *bamboo penal code* as *laws on bamboo slips*.

The state of Zheng adopted it, repeatedly challenging Zichan’s governance.
**Annotation:** *Shuo* is pronounced *shuo*. *Nan* is pronounced *nandan*.

Zichan was confounded by this. Zichan arrested and executed him, soon after putting him to death.
**Annotation:** This tradition states that Zichan executed Deng Xi, but the *Zuozhuan* records that Si Luan killed Deng Xi and adopted his bamboo penal code—Deng Xi died twenty years after Zichan’s death.
Bo Jun notes: The phrase “Zichan arrested and executed him” contains a superfluous repetition of “Zichan,” likely interpolated from the preceding text. “Executed him” and “put him to death” are redundant. It is suspected that *lu* (executed) should instead read *ju* (arrested). The *Taiping Yulan* (626) omits the eight characters “was confounded by this. Zichan arrested and executed him,” having excised them due to their incomprehensibility, which further confirms the error’s long-standing nature.
**Annotation:** *Lu* is pronounced *liu*, or written as [variant character]. *Luan* is pronounced *chuan*. *Zu* is pronounced *zilu*.

Thus, Zichan was not truly able to employ the bamboo penal code—he had no choice but to use it. Deng Xi was not truly able to humble Zichan—he had no choice but to submit. Zichan was not truly able to execute Deng Xi—he had no choice but to put him to death.

**Annotation:** The principle of this passage aligns with that of the preceding one.

**Explication:** To establish laws is a matter of power; to suffer execution is a matter of fate. To enforce those laws is also a matter of power; to put their author to death is also a matter of fate. To wield power in affairs is a matter of talent; for talent to go unrecognized is also a matter of fate. The Northern Song edition, Wang’s edition, and the Shidetang edition all omit the character *zhang* ("passage"); this follows the *Zang* edition’s addition.

Those who may live and do live—some accumulate virtue and practice benevolence, some encounter favorable times and prosper, gaining the world’s favor and fulfilling their own aspirations, as if by retribution, as though through wisdom and effort. The Shidetang edition’s annotation omits the character *ye* ("also") at the end. This is Heaven’s blessing. Some are simply born, simply at peace—this is not necessarily due to benevolence, virtue, or wisdom. Yet to walk the path of trust and compliance, to fulfill one’s aspirations, to live out one’s years without care or peril—what but Heaven’s blessing could account for this?

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Xing* (conduct) is pronounced *xia meng*.

Those who may die and do die—some accumulate evil and commit violence, some suffer hunger, cold, and destitution, thus scorning punishment and execution, forsaking survival, and meeting their end in death, as if self-inflicted, as though responding to circumstance. The *Zang* edition’s annotation reads *yi* ("with") for *yu* ("in"), while the Shidetang edition reads *er* ("and"). This, too, is Heaven’s blessing. Some simply die, simply meet their end—this is not necessarily due to cruelty or folly. Yet to indulge a cruel heart, to dwell in a state where survival is untenable, and to meet one’s end in death—such a death is a fitting death, and thus it, too, is called Heaven’s blessing.

**Explication:** To live when life is possible is Heaven’s blessing; to die when death is fitting is also Heaven’s blessing. For example, Yiwu sought life in the time of Duke Huan of Qi and secured his survival—this was truly Heaven’s blessing. Or consider Chu Ni, who dashed his head against a locust tree to meet his end, preserving his lord’s command and sparing a worthy man from harm, thus securing his death and an undying name—this, too, was Heaven’s blessing. The *Daozang Sijie* edition of the *Zang* reads *yi* ("with") for *yu* ("in") in the annotation “meeting their end in death.”

Those who may live but do not—dwelling in prosperity and ease, wishing for long life yet meeting an early end. This is Heaven’s punishment. To wish for life yet not attain it is called Heaven’s punishment.

Those who may die but do not—dwelling in hardship and humiliation, wishing not to live long yet enduring beyond death. The various editions omit the character *jiu* ("long") before *sheng* ("life"). This, too, is Heaven’s punishment. To scorn death yet not die is also Heaven’s punishment.

**Explication:** Dwelling in prosperity and ease, occupying a lofty position—this is to be able to live yet not live, as with Dong Xian and the like. Dwelling in hardship and humiliation, enduring suffering and adversity—this is to be able to die yet not die, as with the human swine and the like. To seek yet not attain—both are Heaven’s punishment.

There are those who may live or die and do live or die. There are those who may neither live nor die, yet some die and some live. **Annotation:** This refers to those who, in this circumstance, live and do live, or die and do die. The two preceding lines have already encompassed this meaning, and their repetition here is suspect; likely a textual error. Tao Hongqing said: The two *bu* ("not") characters are superfluous; the original text read, “Those who may live or die, some die and some live.” This speaks of those who may live yet die, or may die yet live. Zhang’s annotation states: “This refers to those who, in this circumstance, live yet die, or die yet live.” This suggests that the edition he consulted lacked the two *bu* characters. The preceding passage states, “Those who may live yet do not live suffer Heaven’s punishment; those who may die yet do not die suffer Heaven’s punishment”—its meaning aligns with this, hence Zhang’s annotation also suspects repetition.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Chong* (repetition) is pronounced *zhu yong*.

Yet life and death, life and death—neither due to things nor to the self—are all a matter of fate. There is nothing wisdom can do.

**Annotation:** Since the principle of life and death is unfathomable, death does not arise from things, nor does life reside in the self—how could wisdom avail?

**Explication:** Not due to things, nor due to the self; when knowledge cannot prevail and effort cannot succeed, only then may one submit to fate. The Yuan edition and the Shidetang edition’s annotation read *bi* ("must") for *ru* ("how") at the end.

Thus it is said: Profound and boundless, the Dao of Heaven converges of itself; vast and undifferentiated, the Dao of Heaven moves of itself.

**Annotation:** Boundless and undifferentiated—this is the ultimate of spontaneity. To converge and move of itself—how could it be compelled?

Jiang Yougao said: *Ji* (convergence) and *hui* (meeting) rhyme, both in the ancient *zhi* (*祭*) rhyme group. *Fen* (division) and *yun* (movement) rhyme, both in the ancient *wen* (*文*) rhyme group.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Fen* is pronounced *fu wen*; the annotation is the same.

Heaven and Earth cannot transgress it.

**Annotation:** Though Heaven and Earth are vast, they cannot defy spontaneity.

The sage and the wise cannot interfere with it.

**Annotation:** Though the sagely and the divine are wondrous, they cannot contravene the workings of time.

Ghosts and demons cannot deceive it.

**Annotation:** Though ghosts and demons are uncanny, they cannot falsify what is true and upright.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Mei* is written as *魅*; the annotation states: some write it as *媚*.

That which is spontaneous completes in silence.

**Annotation:** *Mo* means "without."

Levels and pacifies.

**Annotation:** To level and pacify requires no action.

Guides and welcomes.

**Annotation:** Without loss or ruin, it seems as though it guides and welcomes.

If one aligns with the Dao to fulfill destiny, Heaven and Earth cannot transgress it, the sagely and the wise cannot interfere with it; when operations accord with principle, responses to change are divine—even ghosts and demons cannot deceive it; how much less so human affairs?

**Annotation by Bo Jun:** *Cheng*, *ping*, and *ning* rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *geng* group; *jiang* and *ying* rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *yang* group.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Sang* is pronounced *xi lang*.

A friend of Yang Zhu was named Ji Liang.
Ji Liang fell ill, and after seven days, his condition grew critical.
**Annotation:** *Jian* means "severe."
**Variant:** The Northern Song edition has *ji* ("illness") instead of *bing* ("disease").

His sons surrounded him, weeping, and begged for physicians.
**Annotation by Wang Chongmin:** The *Taiping Yulan* (738) includes a *ye* ("petition") after *qing* ("beg"), meaning to request of their father that physicians be summoned. The following line, "in the end, three physicians were petitioned," refers to this. Without *ye*, the meaning is unclear.
**Annotation by Wang Shumin:** The *Wen Xuan* annotation to Sun Zijing’s letter to Shi Zhongrong also includes *ye*.

Ji Liang said to Yang Zhu: "My sons are so unworthy—why do you not sing for me to enlighten them?"
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Wei* is pronounced *yu wei*.

Yang Zhu sang:
"Heaven does not recognize it—
how can man be aware?
Not by blessing from Heaven,
nor by misfortune from man.
Is it I? Is it you?
Do they not know?"

"Physicians or shamans—
do they truly know?"
**Annotation:** This means only you and I understand that life and death are fated; physicians and shamans cannot know this.

His sons did not comprehend and ultimately petitioned three physicians.
**Annotation:** They failed to grasp the meaning of Yang Zhu’s song, believing it aligned with their own views.
**Exegesis:** If even the mandate of Heaven cannot be discerned, how can man perceive it? Heaven does not bestow blessings selectively, nor does man err to invite misfortune—yet one falls ill: this is fate. If even you and I cannot know this, how could physicians or shamans? Furthermore, the song’s intent suggests: if you and I can endure this illness, and I cannot, then perhaps the shaman can.

**Qin Enfu’s note:** Lu’s exegesis under "song’s intent" contains omissions and errors.
**Jiang Chaobo’s note:** *Zhong* means "complete." The *Huainanzi*’s *Chuzhen Xun* states: "Wisdom encompasses Heaven and Earth." *Zhong* means "complete." Thus, "ultimately petitioned three physicians" means "petitioned all three physicians," not "in the end."

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Jie* is pronounced *xie*.
One was surnamed Jiao.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Jiao* is pronounced *jiao* (rising tone).
The second was surnamed Yu, and the third was surnamed Lu. They examined his illness.
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Zhen* is pronounced *zhen* (rising tone), meaning to feel the pulse.

Physician Jiao said to Ji Liang: "Your cold and heat are imbalanced,
**Phonetic Annotation:** *Ru* is written as *nü* (same pronunciation as *ru* below).
your deficiency and excess lack measure, and your illness stems from irregular eating, sexual indulgence, and scattered essence and thought. It is neither Heaven’s doing nor a ghost’s."

The Northern Song edition, Wang edition, and Qin edition write "Heaven" as "premature death." While "premature death" may be borrowed for "portent," though plausible, judging by the subsequent text—"your illness stems neither from Heaven, nor from man, nor from ghosts"—the version with "Heaven" is more appropriate. Thus, we follow the *Zang* edition and Yuan edition as correct.

"Though chronic, it may yet be treated."

Ji Liang said, "A mediocre physician. Quickly dismiss him!"

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Ji* is pronounced *jí*. *Bing* is pronounced with a rising tone, meaning "to remove."

Physician Yu said, "At first, your prenatal *qi* was insufficient, while your postnatal milk was excessive.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Dòng* is pronounced *zhòng*, meaning "milk."

The illness did not arise in a single day or night; its cause has accumulated gradually and cannot be cured."

Ji Liang said, "A fine physician. Let him stay and be fed!"

**[Exegesis]:** The illness described by Physician Jiao stems from human failings, matters within one’s own power. The illness described by Physician Yu, however, arose with the body’s formation—*qi* was insufficient from the start and cannot be remedied.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Shí* is pronounced *sì*.

Physician Lu said, "Your illness stems neither from Heaven, nor from man, nor from ghosts. Upon receiving your form, there was already one who governed it, and one who knew it.

**[Annotation]:** The division of life and death, the span of long and short, are all determined by non-action, by the governance of Heavenly principle. Yet the ignorant are deluded by this, while those of profound insight comprehend it.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Fèn* is pronounced *fèn*.

What can medicine and stone do for you?"

Ji Liang said, "A divine physician! Bestow generous gifts and send him off!"

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Kuàng* is pronounced *kuàng*.

Soon after, Ji Liang’s illness resolved of its own accord.

**[Exegesis]:** The illness described by Physician Lu arose from the spirit. The spirit’s workings may yield merit or fault. The form is the vessel that repays the spirit, and the spirit governs it. Before receiving form, the spirit already knew it. If the spirit is insufficient, the form follows accordingly. Longevity or brevity, beauty or ugliness—one’s physical endowment is already fixed. How could medicine or stone cure this? Ji Liang regarded him as a divine physician. By cultivating the spirit and nurturing virtue, his illness healed itself.

**Phonetic Annotation:** *Chōu* is pronounced *chōu*.

Life is not preserved by what is prized, nor is the body enriched by what is cherished. Life is not cut short by what is despised, nor is the body diminished by what is slighted. Thus, what is prized may not preserve life, and what is despised may not cause death; what is cherished may not enrich the body, and what is slighted may not diminish it. This appears contradictory, yet it is not—life and death, enrichment and diminution, proceed of their own accord. Or, what is prized may preserve life, and what is despised may cause death; what is cherished may enrich the body, and what is slighted may diminish it.
