Zhaomu said: “I have long known this, and long chosen it. The paths of action are manifold—one selects what one prefers and acts accordingly. How could I await your words to recognize it? Life is hard to encounter, death is easy to reach. With life so hard to encounter, to wait for death so easy to reach—how could one not ponder this deeply? Yet you would exalt ritual and righteousness to impress others, feign temperament and nature to seek fame. To me, this is no better than death.

How penetrating are these words! As for those who painstakingly follow convention, violate their nature to comply with things, forfeit the fleeting joy of the present, and harbor lifelong sorrow—though their limbs remain intact, they are already near death. To desire the full enjoyment of life’s delights, to exhaust the year’s pleasures, one need only fear a bloated belly that prevents unrestrained drinking, or weariness that bars indulgence in sensuality. One has no leisure to fret over the disgrace of reputation or the peril of life and fate.

Moreover, do you intend to flaunt your governance skills to impress others, to use specious words to disturb my heart, to delight my mind with rank and emolument? Is this not base and pitiable? I would further distinguish this from your way.

One who excels at governing the external may not bring order to things but will exhaust himself; one who excels at governing the internal may not bring chaos to things but will harmonize his nature. Your way of governing the external may be briefly enforced in one state, yet it does not accord with human hearts. My way of governing the internal may be extended to all under heaven, and the Way of ruler and minister will cease.

I have long wished to explain this method to you, yet you instead instruct me in that method?”

*Note: The text originally read, “I have long wished to explain this method to you, yet you instead instruct me in that method?” The repetition of “you” was indicated by a mark in the original, later miscopied as “之若,” resulting in the present error.*

Zichan was left speechless, unable to respond.

[Exegesis] Those who pursue passion and indulge desire wield cunning words and perverse arguments sufficient to silence the mouths of sages and disrupt the laws of all under heaven. Thus, Jie and Zhou’s intelligence could adorn their wrongdoing, and Shaowu’s rhetoric could bewilder the masses. Though they may not have prevailed in their time, they stirred up their era. Thus, the Master was confounded by the words of Robber Zhi, and Zichan was stymied by Zhaomu’s speech—no great regret. Yet the deluded believe *Liezi* recounts this to express its sentiment, and Zhang Zhan annotates it to elucidate its principle. Such is the common taste of the vulgar—how could it be the refined art of the Dao’s lineage?

Hu Huaichen notes: “忙然” is now commonly written as “茫然.”

*Note: The exegesis originally read, “the Master was confounded by the words of Robber Zhi,” referring to the episode in the *Zhuangzi*, “Robber Zhi.”*

Later, Zichan reported this to Deng Xi.

Deng Xi said: “You lived alongside a true person yet did not recognize him—how can you be called wise? The governance of Zheng was merely coincidental, not your achievement.”

*[Annotation:]*
Not knowing a true person, one cannot govern a state; governance is but a matter of chance.

This entire passage is too blunt and confrontational in its rhetoric, lacking the tone of a gentleman. Yet its intent is to relieve the burdens of those who constrain themselves, hence its excessively unrestrained words.

*[Exegesis:]*
When rewards are given according to ability and appointments made by virtue, the worthy advance day by day while the unworthy retreat. If appointments are made solely by talent, the Way of the good prospers; if the unworthy are inevitably dismissed, the Way of the petty incurs no resentment. Let the worthy and unworthy each settle into their proper place and fulfill their aspirations, and the governance of Zheng will be fitting.

Those two men indulged in wine and sensual pleasures, neglecting ritual and righteousness. They did not rely on the influence of fathers and elder brothers to seize opportunities, but followed their desires without remorse—these were truly true persons. Yet you sought to correct their conduct and feign their intentions, seizing emoluments and rank for private gain. That the state happened to be well-ordered was no credit to your impartiality—how could this be called wisdom?

Here, “true person” does not refer to a truly sagely individual, but to one who is genuinely without talent.

*[Annotation:]*
The character *tai* (太) in the *Shidetang* edition appears as *da* (大).

Lu Wenchang notes: In the *Zhuangzi*, the phrase “jingting” (径挺) appears as “jingting” (径庭) or “jingtin” (俓侹).

Qin Enfu observes: In the exegesis, “wei qi xin” (为其心), *wei* (为) and *wei* (伪) were interchangeable in ancient script. Yang Liang’s commentary on the *Xunzi*’s “Xing’e” chapter states: “‘Wei’ means ‘to do’ or ‘to feign.’ Anything not of innate nature but contrived by humans is called *wei*. Thus, the character *wei* (伪) combines *ren* (人) and *wei* (为), forming a compound ideograph.”

The *Shiwen* renders “jingting” (径挺) as “jingtin” (径廷), with *ting* (廷) pronounced *ting* (听). *Kang* (抗) is pronounced *kang* (苦浪切). *Qu* (去) is pronounced *qǔ* (丘吕切). *Lei* (累) is read in the falling tone.

Wei’s Duanmu Shu was a descendant of Zigong. *[Exegesis by Bo Jun:]* The *Strategies of Qin* states: “Marshlands can be bequeathed to posterity,” with the annotation: “‘Posterity’ refers to later generations.” The *Discourses of Jin* reads: “Without virtue, one does not reach the age,” with the annotation: “‘Age’ means succession.” Thus, “descendant of Zigong” refers to Zigong’s posterity. Below, it says “relying on his ancestral wealth,” meaning he relied on Zigong’s wealth, for Zigong was skilled in commerce. Shallow-minded people, not grasping the meaning of *shi* (世, “posterity”), arbitrarily added the character *fu* (父, “father”). The *Taiping Yulan* (477 and 493) both cite it as “Shifu” (世父), but this is incorrect. However, the citation in volume 830 omits *fu* (父), avoiding the error. Others have mistakenly added *zi* (子), as in the *Bai-Kong Liutie* (19).

“Relying on his ancestral wealth.” *[Exegesis by Bo Jun:]* The *Guanzi*’s “Neiye” chapter states: “That which comes of itself may be relied upon for counsel,” with the annotation: “‘Rely’ means ‘to depend upon.’” The *Shiwen* glosses *zi* (赀) as *zi* (髭).

The household amassed wealth of ten thousand gold. He paid no heed to worldly affairs, indulging whatever he fancied. As the *Shiwen* notes: *hao* (好, “fancy”) is pronounced *hu bao*, and the same applies below. Whatever the people desired to do, whatever the human heart longed to enjoy—nothing was left undone, nothing left unindulged. Walls and houses, terraces and pavilions, gardens and parks, ponds and pools, food and drink, carriages and robes, music and concubines—he rivaled the lords of Qi and Chu. As for what his nature craved, what his ears longed to hear, his eyes to see, his mouth to taste—even if it came from distant lands or remote regions (the commentary notes: *pian*, 偏, means “remote”), or was not native to Qi, he spared no effort to obtain it. Yu Yue observes: The passage below reads, “Though mountains and rivers barred the way, though paths stretched long and far, nothing was left unvisited,” so this passage should read “nothing was left unobtained,” with the extra *zhi* (之) being an erroneous interpolation. Yet to him, such things were as readily at hand as objects within a garden fence. The *Shiwen* writes *fan* (藩) as *fan* (蕃), glossing it *fu yuan*. Ren Dachun notes: The *Zhouli*’s *Da Situ* commentary states, “Du Zichun reads *fan yue* (蕃樂) as *fan yue* (藩樂).” The *Shi*’s “Breaking willows for the garden fence” has the *Shiwen* gloss: “*Fan* (樊) means *fan* (藩), and is also written *fan* (蕃).” The *Han Yi*’s *Shiwen* concurs. The *Zuozhuan*’s twenty-eighth year *Shiwen* reads, “*Fan* (藩) is also written *fan* (蕃).” The *Chu Yu* states, “They made for it gates and bolts, *fan li* (蕃籬),” with Wei Zhao’s commentary: “*Fan li* (蕃籬) means walls and enclosures; *fan li* (蕃籬) is the same as *fan li* (藩籬),” showing that *fan* (藩) and *fan* (蕃) are interchangeable.

When he traveled, though mountains and rivers barred the way (the *Shiwen* writes *zu xian* (阻險) as *ju yan* (岨崄), noting that *ju* (岨) is the same as *zu* (阻), and *yan* (崄) the same as *xian* (險)), though paths stretched long and far, nothing was left unvisited—it was as effortless as taking a single step. The *Shiwen* glosses *zhi* (咫) as *zhi* (紙). Guests filled his courtyard daily by the hundreds. Yu Yue states: *Zhu* (住) should be *shu* (數), a phonetic error. The *Huangdi* chapter reads: “The flocking birds arrived by the hundreds without cease,” with Zhang’s commentary: “*Zhu* (住) should be *shu* (數),” confirming this. This passage in Lu Chongxuan’s edition reads *wang* (往), which is a mistaken character. The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhu* (住) is pronounced *se zhu*, and is also written *wang* (往). Smoke never ceased rising from his kitchens (the *Shiwen* writes *pao* (庖) as *bao* (胞), glossing it *pu jiao*, and noting it is also written *pao* (庖)). Ren Dachun observes: The *Kao Ji Tong* states, “*Bao* (胞) refers to the lowliest of meat-officials,” with the commentary: “*Bao* (胞) means *pao* (庖).” The *Zhuangzi*’s “Gengsang Chu” chapter reads: “Thus Tang used *bao* (胞) and *chu* (厨) to ensnare Yi Yin.” The *Hanshu*’s *Dongfang Shuo Zhuan* reads: “*Bao* (胞) official Yin Yan,” with Yan Shigu’s commentary: “*Bao* (胞) and *pao* (庖) share the same meaning,” showing that *pao* (庖) and *bao* (胞) are interchangeable. Music never ceased playing in his halls and corridors. The *Shiwen* glosses *wu* (庑) as *wu* (武).

What remained after his own provision was first distributed to his clan; what remained after the clan was next distributed to his village; what remained after the village was then distributed throughout the state. At sixty years of age, his *qi* and vigor waning, he abandoned his household affairs, dispersing all his storehouses, treasures, carriages, robes, concubines, and attendants. Within a year, he exhausted it all, leaving no wealth for his descendants. The *Shiwen* glosses *wei* (為) as *yu wei* (于偽). When he fell ill, he had no store of medicines or stones; when he died, he had no resources for burial. The commentary notes: One who grasps the Dao understands the impermanence of all things and the fleeting nature of wealth. Its accumulation is not one’s own achievement, so one fulfills the proper measure of provision; its dispersal is not one’s own gift, so one clarifies that things do not permanently gather. Such a person—how could mere fame or ritual and law restrain him? The *Shiwen* glosses *shi* (施) as *shi chi* (始豉), and the same applies below.

Those in the state who received his gifts—Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (493) omits *ren* (人) after *zhi* (之)—joined together to contribute and bury him. Yu Yue states: *Fu* (賦) means calculating by household to raise funds. The *Zhouli*’s *Da Zai* commentary by Zheng Xuan reads: “*Fu* (賦) means a per-person levy of coin.” The *Hanshu*’s *Shi Huo Zhi*, in Yan Shigu’s commentary, reads: “*Fu* (賦) means calculating by household to raise wealth,” which clarifies its meaning. *Zang* (藏) here means burial, as in the *Liji*’s “Tan Gong” chapter: “Burial is *zang* (藏),” so *zang* (葬) and *zang* (藏) are interchangeable. The *Yi Jing*’s *Xi Ci Zhuan* reads: “Buried in the wilds,” while the *Hanshu*’s *Liu Xiang Zhuan* quotes it as “*Zang* (臧) in the wilds,” with *zang* (臧) being the same as *zang* (藏). Since Duanmu Shu had no resources for burial, those who received his gifts pooled their contributions to bury him, returning his descendants’ wealth to them.

Qin Gu (the commentary notes: also written Qu Li) heard of this and said: “Duanmu Shu was a madman, bringing shame upon his ancestors.” Duangan Sheng heard of it and said: “Duanmu Shu was an enlightened man, his virtue surpassing that of his ancestors. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (493) writes *Duangan Sheng* (段干生) as *Duangan Mu* (段干木), which should be followed. The *Shiwen* glosses *guo* (過) as *ge* (戈). What he did, what he pursued, shocked the common mind, yet was affirmed by true principle. The gentlemen of Wei, who rigidly upheld ritual and teaching, were fundamentally incapable of understanding such a man’s heart.”

Meng Sunyang asked Yang Zhu: “Suppose there were a man here who valued life and cherished his body, seeking immortality—would that be possible?” The *Shiwen* glosses *qi* (蕲) as *qi* (祈), and Yang Zhu replied: “In principle, there is no immortality.”

“If one sought long life, would that be possible?”
Yang Zhu replied: “In principle, there is no long life. Life is not preserved by valuing it, nor is the body enriched by cherishing it. Moreover, what would be the purpose of long life?

[Note] Even if long life were granted, it would not be what one truly desires. The five passions—love and hate—remain the same in ancient times as now; the safety or peril of the four limbs, the same; the bitterness or joy of worldly affairs, the same; the alternations of order and chaos, the same. We have heard of these things, seen them, and experienced them.

[Lu's note] *Geng* (更) means to undergo or experience. The *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the "Biographies of Dayuan," states: "The Han, then intent on destroying the Hu, upon hearing these words, wished to establish communication. The route would necessarily pass through the Xiongnu." The *Suoyin* commentary explains: "*Geng* means to traverse." The word applies equally to the traversal of a journey and the experience of life.

[Shiwen] *Geng* is pronounced *geng* (庚).

A hundred years would still feel too long—how much more the suffering of long life?”

[Note] The experiences of a single lifetime are thus: now love, now hate; now safety, now peril, like an endless cycle. If one were to consider this joy? Then the return of what has already come would bring no renewed delight. If one were to consider this suffering? Then the afflictions of the self cannot be endured again. Thus, the longer one lives, the more sorrows accumulate.

[Shiwen] *Chong* (重) is pronounced *zhong* (柱用切); *fu* (复) is pronounced *fu* (扶又切).

Meng Sunyang said: “If that is so, then swift death is preferable to long life. In that case, to tread upon blades or plunge into boiling water would achieve one’s aim.”

Yangzi said: “Not so. Once born, one should relinquish and entrust all to the natural course, exhausting one’s desires while awaiting death.

[Note] One ought simply to indulge one’s nature until the end.

When death approaches, one should again relinquish and entrust all to the natural course, exhausting whither it leads, and thus release oneself to the end.

[Note] Since control does not lie with me, there is nothing to cling to or long for.

Nothing is not relinquished, nothing is not entrusted—why then hasten or delay between these?”

Yang Zhu said: “Bocheng Zigao did not use even a single hair to benefit others, relinquishing his state to live in reclusion and till the soil.

[Shiwen] *She* (舍) is pronounced *she* (舍).

[Bo Jun’s note] “有” should be an error for “音.”

The Great Yu did not use his own body for self-benefit,

[Shiwen] “不以一身自利” is also written as “不以一身利物.”

his body withered in part.

The ancients would not yield even a single hair to benefit the world, nor would they accept the whole world offering itself to a single person. If each person neither yields a single hair nor seeks to benefit the world, the world would be well-ordered.”

[Note] *Rongzhai Xubi* 14 omits the two characters “人人” before “不利.”

[Shiwen] *Zhi* (治) is pronounced *zhi* (直吏切).

Qinzi asked Yang Zhu: “Would you remove a single hair from your body to save the world?

[Shiwen] *Qu* (去) is pronounced *qu* (丘吕切).

[Note] Doubting that Yangzi valued the body excessively, he posed this question.

[Shiwen] “太” is written as “大,” pronounced *tai* (泰).

Yangzi said: “The world is certainly not saved by a single hair.”

[Note] Finding his question to miss the point of his own intent, he thus answered in kind.

Qinzi said: “Suppose it could be saved—would you do it?”

[Bo Jun’s note] This exchange is likely based on *Mencius*’s *Jinxin I*: “Yangzi took ‘for oneself’ as his principle; if plucking a single hair could benefit the world, he would not do it.”

Yangzi did not respond. Qinzi went out and spoke to Meng Sunyang.

[Shiwen] *Yu* (语) is pronounced *yu* (鱼据切).

Meng Sunyang said: “You do not grasp the Master’s intent. Allow me to explain. If by harming your skin you could gain ten thousand gold, would you do it?” He replied: “I would.”

Meng Sunyang said: “If by severing one of your limbs you could gain a state, would you do it?”

[Shiwen] *Duan* (断) is pronounced *duan* (短).

[Bo Jun’s note] The *Wen Xuan*’s “Letter from Ruan Yu to Cao Gong for Sun Quan” reads: “It is not a matter of encroaching upon one’s skin or inflicting injury,” which may be the source of this spurious remark.

Qinzi was silent for a while. Meng Sunyang said: “A single hair is smaller than skin, and skin is smaller than a limb—this is evident.

[Note] *Sheng* (省) means to examine.

[Shiwen] *Sheng* (省) is pronounced *sheng* (息井切).

Yet skin is accumulated from single hairs, and limbs are accumulated from skin. A single hair is surely one ten-thousandth of the body—how can it be treated lightly?”

Qinzi said: “I cannot answer you on these terms. Yet if your words were put to Lao Dan and Guan Yin, then your words would be correct.

[Note] The teachings of Lao Dan and Guan Yin value the body and deprecate external things.

[Shiwen] *Dang* (当) is pronounced *dang* (丁浪切).

If my words were put to the Great Yu and Mo Di,

[Shiwen] *Di* (翟) is pronounced *di* (狄).

then my words would be correct.”

[Note] The teachings of Yu and Mo forget the self to save others.

Meng Sunyang then turned and spoke of other matters with his disciples.

Yang Zhu said: “The world’s praise gathers upon Shun, Yu, the Zhou, and Confucius; the world’s blame gathers upon Jie and Zhou. Yet Shun tilled the fields at Heyang and made pottery at Leize,

[Shiwen] According to the *Records of the Historian*, Shun tilled at Lishan and made pottery by the river. Today, this refers to Puyang and Leize County.

his limbs never knew a moment’s rest, his mouth and belly never tasted fine fare; his parents did not love him, his brothers and sisters did not treat him with affection.”

At thirty, he married without informing his parents.

[Shiwen] *Gao* (告) is pronounced *gao* (古沃切). To report to superiors is *gao*; to issue proclamations to inferiors is *gao* (诰).

By the time he received Yao’s abdication, he was already advanced in years,

[Shiwen] *Zhang* (长) is pronounced *zhang* (张丈切).

and his wisdom had declined. Shangjun was unworthy,

[Shiwen] *Jun* (钧) is pronounced *jun* (均).

yet he ceded the throne to Yu, living in constant sorrow until his death. This was the utmost suffering of a celestial being.

[Northern Song edition omits the character *zhi* (之).]

Jiang Chaobo remarked: *Zhuangzi*’s *Xu Wugui* chapter echoes this sentiment, altering the phrasing: “The one who curled up in toil was Shun. Shun had a foul reputation, yet the people delighted in him. Yao, hearing of Shun’s worthiness, raised him from the barren lands. Though his years were advanced and his faculties had waned, he could not return to rest—this was the one who curled up in toil.”

Gun, tasked with regulating the waters and lands,

[Shiwen] *Gun* () is pronounced *gun* (古本切). The name of Yu’s father; alternate character: □.

failed in his endeavors and was banished to Feather Mountain. Yu inherited the task and avenged his father’s grievance, devoting himself solely to the wild lands. He did not raise his son, nor did he enter his own home when passing by;

[Shiwen] *Guo* (过) is pronounced *guo* (戈).

his body became emaciated, his hands and feet calloused.

[Shiwen] *Pianzhi* (胼胝) is written as *pianzhi* (跰□). *Pian* (跰) is pronounced *pian* (步千切); *zhi* (□) is pronounced *zhi* (丁湜切).

Upon receiving Shun’s abdication,

[Shiwen] *Shan* (禅) is pronounced *shan* (善).

he lived in humble dwellings,

[Shiwen] *Bei* (卑) is written as *bi* (蔽). Pronounced *bi* (弊) or *bei* (卑).

Ren Dachun noted: *Bei* (卑) and *bi* (蔽) share a phonetic connection, hence *bi* is pronounced both *bi* (敝) and *bei* (卑). The *Shiwen* of the *Artificers’ Record* states: “The wheelwright’s *lunbi* (轮箄) is pronounced *boji* (薄计反).” The *Records of the Historian*, *Biography of the Marquis of Huaiyin*, reads: “He took a hidden path, concealing himself in the mountains.” Ru Chun commented: “*Bi* (萆) is pronounced *bi* (蔽), meaning to conceal oneself behind the mountain.” *Bi* (箄) is derived from *bei* (卑), yet both are read as *bi* (蔽). Thus, *bi* (蔽) may be pronounced *bi* (敝) or *bei* (卑). The rendering of *bei gongshi* (卑宫室) as *bi gongshi* (蔽宫室) arises from the phonetic proximity of *bei* (卑) and *bi* (蔽).

he wore fine robes and crowns, living in constant sorrow until his death. This was the utmost hardship of a celestial being.

After King Wu’s passing, King Cheng was young and weak, and the Duke of Zhou assumed the regency of the Son of Heaven. The Duke of Shao was displeased, and rumors spread among the four states. Exiled to the east for three years, he executed his brother and banished his kin, barely preserving his own life.

[Shiwen] *Jin* (仅) is pronounced *jin* (觐).

He lived in constant fear until his death. This was the utmost peril of a celestial being.

Confucius expounded the Way of the emperors and kings, responding to the summons of contemporary rulers. He was barred from felling a tree in Song, erased from the records in Wei, impoverished in Shang and Zhou, besieged in Chen and Cai.

[The Qin engraving and Lu Jie’s edition read *kun* (困) for *wei* (围).]

Yu Yue remarked: *Wei* (围) is a scribal error for *kun* (困).

He was humiliated by the Ji family and disgraced by Yang Hu, living in constant sorrow until his death. This was the utmost restlessness of a man of the world.

These four sages, in life, knew not a single day of joy; in death, they gained a name for ten thousand generations. Yet a name is not something real that can be grasped. Though praised, they knew it not; though rewarded, they knew it not—no different from a stump or a clod of earth.

[Shiwen] *Zhu* (株) is pronounced *zhu* (诛); *kuai* (块) is pronounced *kui* (口对切).

[Note] Observing their forms and deeds, the traces of their sorrows and perils are manifest. Searching within their hearts, there is none who did not suffer grievances. To elucidate the words of the utmost principle, one must present the extremes of good and evil in parallel.

Jie inherited the resources of generations, occupying the honored seat of the ruler. His wisdom sufficed to resist his ministers, his might sufficed to awe the realm. He indulged his ears and eyes in whatever pleased him, exhausting the depths of his desires, living in carefree abandon until his death. This was the utmost dissipation of a man of the world.

Zhou, too, inherited the resources of generations, occupying the honored seat of the ruler. His authority knew no bounds, his will no opposition. He gave free rein to his passions in the Leaning Palace, indulged his desires in endless nights;

The *Shiwen* notes that "纵" is written as "从", reading *cong* as *zong*, and the same applies below. They did not afflict themselves with ritual and righteousness, living in carefree abandon until their execution: these were the most dissolute of men under Heaven.

Those two tyrants, in life, enjoyed the pleasures of indulging their desires; in death, bore the name of folly and violence. In truth, such men are fundamentally untouched by reputation. Though slandered, they knew it not; though praised, they knew it not. Yu Yue notes: The preceding text speaks of Shun, Yu, the Zhou, and Confucius, saying, "Though praised, they knew it not; though rewarded, they knew it not." Thus, in discussing Jie and Zhou, it should read, "Though slandered, they knew it not; though punished, they knew it not." "Slandered" pairs with "praised," and "punished" with "rewarded," aligning with the later passage: "Those four sages, though the destination of all praise; those two tyrants, though the destination of all blame." "Praised and rewarded" are the destination of praise; "slandered and punished" are the destination of blame. Here, following the earlier text by also using "praised" renders the meaning incoherent. How do they differ from clods of earth?

**[Annotation]** They exhausted the extremes of arrogance and extravagance, indulging their insatiable natures. Though nourished by all under Heaven, they never found contentment in their hearts. This was truly a life of year-long suffering and distress. The *Shiwen* notes: *Jin* (尽) is read as *zǐrěn*; *yàn* (厌) as *yīyán*; *qiè* (惬) as *kǒutiē*.

Those four sages, though the destination of all praise, toiled to the end of their days, and all alike met death. Those two tyrants, though the destination of all blame, reveled to the end of their days—*Shiwen* notes: *lè* (乐) is read as *luò*—and likewise all met death.

Yang Zhu met with the King of Liang. Speaking of governing the realm, he said it was as easy as turning one’s palm. Wang Chongmin notes: *Leiju* 94 cites this as "King Hui of Liang," and the following "the King said" omits the word "Liang." Wang Shumin notes: *Shilei Fu* 22 includes the word "初" before "Yang Zhu." *Wen Xuan* commentary on Dongfang Manqian’s *Response to a Guest’s Objections*, *Shiwen Leiju* (later collection) 39, *Yunfu Qunyu* 6, and *Tianzhong Ji* 54 all include the word "Hui" after "Liang."

The King said: "Sir, you cannot even govern one wife and one concubine, nor tend three *mu* of garden; yet you claim governing the realm is as easy as turning your palm. Why is this?" Yang Zhu replied: "Have you seen those who herd sheep? Wang Chongmin notes: The words "见其" are reversed in error. *Leiju* 94 writes "其" as "夫," which also works (*Shuo Yuan*’s *Zhengli* chapter reads: "Have you not seen the sheep?"). Bo Jun’s note: *Qi* (其) means *bi* (彼). 'Have you seen those who herd sheep?' is akin to 'Have you seen *those* who herd sheep?' The use of *qi* to mean *bi* is explained in Zhongfu’s *Advanced Chinese Grammar* and *Word Explications*. A hundred sheep in a flock, led by a five-*chi* boy carrying a switch and following behind—Wang Chongmin notes: *Leiju* 94 writes the first "而" as "为," which is likely correct. The ancient character for *wei* (为) was written as □, easily confused with *er* (而). This book’s *Yellow Emperor* chapter reads: "Those who attain this and exhaust it—how could they be upright?" *Zhuangzi*’s *Dasheng* chapter reads: "How could things restrain them?" The *Jifu* edition of *Liezi* reads: "How could they be corrected?"—this is evidence. Wang Shumin notes: *Taiping Yulan* 833, *Shiwen Leiju* (later collection) 39, and *Tianzhong Ji* 54 all write "而群" as "为群." Wang’s point is valid. If they wish to go east, they go east; if west, they go west. But if Yao were to lead a single sheep, with Shun carrying the switch and following behind, they could not move forward.

Moreover, I have heard: fish that can swallow a boat do not swim in shallow streams; the great swan soars high and does not alight in filthy ponds. Why? Their aspirations are lofty."

Wang Shumin states: The *Shuo Yuan*’s *Zhengli* chapter and the *Jinlouzi*’s *Liyan Xia* chapter both include the character *zhi* (志) after "其," and this should be followed. The subsequent text reads: "Why? Their tones are sparse." Here, *zhi* (志) and *yin* (音) stand in parallel. The grand harmonies of *huangzhong* and *dalü* cannot accompany frantic, clamorous dances. Why? Their tones are sparse.

The character *zhong* (钟) appears as *zhong* (锺) in Wang’s edition and is identical in the *Jifu* edition; here, it follows the standard versions. Tao Hongqing notes: "奏" should be "凑." *Cou* means convergence. Those who govern the great do not govern the petty; those who achieve great deeds do not fuss over trifles—this is what it means.

Yang Zhu said: "The affairs of the distant past have vanished—who records them? The deeds of the Three Sovereigns exist as if they exist not, the affairs of the Five Emperors seem like waking dreams (as the *Shiwen* notes: *jue* is read as *jiao*). The undertakings of the Three Kings appear now hidden, now manifest—of a hundred million, one is not known. (As the *Shiwen* notes: *shi* is read as in the standard pronunciation, or as *zhi* below, and similarly hereafter.) The events of one’s own lifetime are sometimes heard, sometimes seen—of ten thousand, one is not known. The matters before one’s eyes now exist, now cease—of a thousand, one is not known. From the distant past to the present, the years are indeed beyond counting. Yet since Fuxi’s time, over three hundred thousand years have passed, and all—wisdom and folly, beauty and ugliness, success and failure, right and wrong—have dissolved into nothingness, differing only in the swiftness or slowness of their passing.

[Annotation:] To be bewildered by such swiftness or slowness, to race endlessly in pursuit—is this not contemptible? To pride oneself on fleeting praise or blame, to wear body and spirit raw for it, and to seek a lingering name for a few hundred years after death (as the *Shiwen* notes: *yao* is read as in *yī yáo qiè*)—can this moisten dry bones? Where is the joy in life?"

Yang Zhu said: "Humans resemble the classes of Heaven and Earth, bearing the nature of the Five Constants. [Annotation:] *Xiao* means 'to resemble.' Alike in yin and yang, their nature follows the Five Phases. The *Shiwen* notes: *Xiao* is written as *qiao*, pronounced like *xiao*; some versions use *xiao*. Ren Dachun said: In the *Huainanzi*, 'to immerse in thoughts of *xiao* types,' Gao You annotates: '*Xiao* means things that resemble.' The *Hanshu: Xingfa Zhi* states: 'All people resemble the forms of Heaven and Earth.' Yan Shigu takes *xiao* as *xiao*, thus *xiao*, *qiao*, and *xiao* are interchangeable."

Of all living beings, humans are the most spiritually endowed. Yet their claws and teeth are insufficient for defense, their skin and flesh inadequate for self-protection. The *Shiwen* notes: *Han* is written as *han*, pronounced like *han*. *Yu* is pronounced *yǔ*. Their swift movement is not enough to pursue benefit or flee harm—originally 'flee benefit and harm,' now corrected according to the Dunhuang manuscript S.7776. Bo Jun notes: The *Shuowen* states: '□ means to hasten.' The *Shiming* says: 'Slow walking is called *bu*, swift walking *qu*, and hasty movement *zou*.' The *Lüshi Chunqiu: Quanxun* reads: 'The King of Qi fled to Ju,' with the annotation: '*Zou* means to flee.' The *Shiwen* writes *qu* as *qu*, pronounced *qū*.

Devoid of fur or feathers to shield against cold and heat, humans must rely on external things for sustenance. All versions include 'nature' after 'sustenance,' now deleted following the Dunhuang manuscript S.7776. They employ wisdom rather than brute force. Thus, what wisdom values is preserving the self; what force disdains is encroaching upon others. Yet the body does not belong to oneself—once born, one cannot but preserve it. Things do not belong to oneself—once possessed, one cannot discard them. 'Cannot discard them'—the Northern Song, Wang, Qin block-printed Lu, and Shidetang editions all read 'cannot but discard them.' Yu Yue said: It should read 'cannot discard them,' as the following text states: 'Though one does not discard things, one cannot claim ownership of them.' The version 'cannot but discard' contradicts the subsequent passage, likely influenced by the earlier 'once born, one cannot but preserve it,' mistakenly changing *er* to *bu*. Bo Jun notes: Yu Yue's argument is sound; the Daoist Canon's unannotated text, Lin Xiyi's edition, and the Jifu edition correctly use *er*. Here, the text is amended accordingly. The *Shiwen* writes 'er qu' as 'bu qu,' with *qu* pronounced *qù*.

The body is indeed the master of life, just as things are the master of sustenance. Though one preserves life, all versions include 'body' after 'life,' now deleted following the Dunhuang manuscript S.7776—one cannot claim ownership of the body. Though one does not discard things, one cannot claim ownership of them. To claim ownership of things or the body is to wrongfully appropriate the bodies and things of the world. The *Shiwen* notes: *Heng* is pronounced with the falling tone, as below. Those who neither wrongfully appropriate the bodies nor the things of the world—all versions omit these fourteen characters, now restored from the Dunhuang manuscript—are none other than the sages! [Annotation:] Only the sage understands that the body cannot be privately owned, nor things possessed.

Tao Hongqing said: Zhang's annotation misplaces the punctuation. 'Are none other than the sages' should be read with the following, forming an inverted sentence: 'Are none other than the sages—those who share the bodies of the world, share the things of the world—are none other than the perfected!' This both praises their sagacity and acknowledges their perfection. The *Yi Jing: Qian Gua Wenyan* states: 'Are none other than the sages! Those who know advance and retreat, life and death, yet do not lose their correctness—are none other than the sages!' The syntax is identical. Bo Jun notes: Tao's edition omits the fourteen characters 'neither wrongfully appropriate,' hence his argument. With these characters restored, Tao's interpretation is no longer tenable. The *Shiwen* connects the following passage as a single segment: 'Those who share the bodies of the world, share the things of the world—are none other than the perfected!' This is called the utmost of the utmost. [Annotation:] To regard the bodies of the world as one's own body, the things of the world as one's own things—who but the perfected can achieve this? Having realized the error of selfishness and the rightness of impartiality, this is called the utmost of the utmost.

Yang Zhu said: "The people cannot rest because of four concerns: The *Shiwen* notes: *Wei* is pronounced *wéi*, as below. First, for longevity, [Annotation:] They dare not indulge their desires. Second, for reputation, [Annotation:] They dare not act recklessly. Third, for status, [Annotation:] They compromise to seek advancement. The Shidetang edition mistakenly writes 'emerge' instead of 'compromise.' Fourth, for wealth. [Annotation:] They monopolize profit and hoard expenses."

Those who harbor these four concerns fear ghosts, fear others, fear authority, and fear punishment—such are called the "reclusive people." [Annotation:] Those who violate their natural state. The character *min* ("people") was originally written as *ren* ("person"); the Dunhuang fragmentary scrolls write *min*. Wang Chongmin states: *Ren* should be *min*; Song editions failed to correct the Tang taboo. Bo Jun notes: Wang’s argument is sound, and the text has been amended accordingly. Wang Chongmin further states: The *Yilin* quotes it as "these are called the 'reclusive people'"; this reading should be adopted. The following passage reads, "these are called the 'compliant people,'" with identical sentence structure. Wang Shumin notes: Jiang Yu’s commentary reads, "these are called the 'reclusive people,'" and the version he consulted also preserves the correct order of *zhi wei* ("are called"). [Annotation:] *Dun* is pronounced *dùn*.

Their lives may be taken or spared, for control over their fate lies beyond themselves. [Annotation:] When whole, they are not bound to their own will. Bo Jun notes: *Huó* ("live") and *wài* ("beyond") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *zhi* rhyme group.

If they do not resist fate, why crave longevity? If they do not prize nobility, why crave reputation?

Do not crave power—[Annotation:] *Yào* is pronounced *yáo*. Why covet rank? Do not covet wealth, why covet goods? These are called the "compliant people." [Annotation:] They attain the principle of life.

The world has no equal, for control over fate lies within. [Annotation:] It cannot be controlled by external things. [Annotation:] *Duì* ("equal") and *nèi* ("within") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *zhi* rhyme group.

Thus, the saying goes: "When a man does not seek office, half his desires are lost; when a man does not depend on clothing and food, the Way of ruler and minister ceases." Jiang Yougao notes: *Huàn* ("office") and *bàn* ("half") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *yuan* rhyme group. *Shí* ("food") and *xī* ("cease") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *zhi* rhyme group.

A Zhou proverb says—[Annotation:] *Yàn* is pronounced *yàn*—"A field laborer may be killed by sitting still." [Annotation:] *Fù* is pronounced *fǔ*, the same below. Rising at dawn and retiring at dusk, he takes this as the constant of his nature; sipping bean broth and chewing coarse greens—[Annotation:] The *Jizuan Yuanhai*, chapter 57, cites *shuǐ* ("water") for *shū* ("bean"). [Annotation:] *Chuò* is pronounced *chuǎi*. *Rú* is read in the falling tone. *Huò* is pronounced *huò*.—he takes this as the height of flavor. His flesh is coarse and thick, [Annotation:] *Cū* is pronounced *cāng*, his sinews and joints taut and tense—[Annotation:] *□* is pronounced *qūwèi*. [Annotation:] The *Shiwen* writes *□* as *kuì*, noting: *Jīn* is pronounced *jīn*. It is read *kuì*, meaning "sinews and joints tense." Alternatively written as *□□*, the first character is pronounced *quán*, the second *qūwèi*. *□chǒu* describes the appearance of tense sinews. Qin Enfu notes: The *Shiwen*’s "read *kuì*" refers to the pronunciation of *□*. *□* should be written as *□*. *□* belongs to the *guǐ* phonetic series, hence it is read *qūwèi*. If it were *□*, it would be read *zhīchūn*. The *Yupian* states: "*□□*, an ugly appearance." *□* is written with the *yuè* radical and the *guàn* phonetic; *□* with the *yuè* radical and the *juǎn* phonetic. *Guàn* and *juǎn* are phonetic transformations. The *Huainanzi*’s *Xiumu Xun* writes it as *□*, with Gao You’s commentary: "Read as *quánhéng*’s *quán*, pronounced with a tense tone. *□* is read *kuí*." That *kuí* is a reversal of *qūwèi* is clear proof. The *Erya*’s "*qǔn* is its sprout" is glossed by Guo as *qiǎnquǎn*, which is clear evidence that *kuì* is a corrupted character. [Annotation:] Zhang Zhan’s edition writes *□* as *□*; the *Huainanzi* writes it as *□*. Neither the "mountain" nor the "mouth" radical is correct—it should be the "moon" radical. Ren Dachun states: *□* has no *qūwèi* pronunciation and should be an error for *kuì*. Furthermore, the Shide Tang edition adds after "sinews tense in appearance" the six characters "*yuē kuì yīn qūwèi qiè*," which the Daoist Canon edition omits in error. This is because alternate versions of the *Liezi* may write *□kuì*, and the *Shiwen* thus explains the two characters separately. Where it says "*□* ugly," it glosses the meaning of *□*. The *Yupian*, *Guangya*, and *Guangyun* all state "*□□* ugly in appearance," hence *□* ugly is used to explain the meaning of *□*. Where it says "sinews tense in appearance is called *kuì*, pronounced *qūwèi*," it clarifies the difference in pronunciation and meaning between *kuì* and *□*. The Daoist Canon edition’s omission of the six characters from "*yuē kuì*" onward makes it seem as if *□* ugly is glossed as "sinews tense in appearance," but *□* ugly has no such definition. [Annotation:] Bo Jun notes: Ren’s argument is incorrect. The five characters "*kuì yīn qūwèi qiè*" originally belong to Zhang’s commentary; the Shide Tang edition conflates them with the *Shiwen*, and Ren’s supplementation of the *Shiwen* based on the Shide Tang edition is unreliable. Furthermore, the *Yupian* and *Guangyun*’s "*□□* ugly in appearance" (the *Guangya*’s *Shigu* writes "*□□* ugly") should be read as *□□* together. Wang’s *Guangya Shuzheng* cites the *Huainanzi*’s *Xiumu Xun*: "*kuīduō huī*," which is the *Guangya*’s "*□huī□*," the same as this *□□*. Ren’s reading of *□* ugly is incorrect. However, the *Shiwen* also contains errors and omissions.

If one morning he is placed amidst soft furs and fine silk curtains—[Annotation:] *Tímò* is pronounced *tímò*—and offered fine grains, meats, orchids, and citrus, his heart will be vexed and his body restless, and internal heat will breed illness. [Annotation:] *□* is pronounced *yǎn*. The lords of Shang and Lu, equal in status to the field laborer—[Annotation:] *Móu* is pronounced *móu*—would likewise not endure even a single day before exhaustion. [Annotation:] To speak of what one is accustomed to: none of it can be abruptly changed, let alone what is natural. [Annotation:] *Zú* is pronounced in the falling tone.

Thus, what the rustic finds at ease, what the rustic finds beautiful, is deemed without peer in the world. Long ago, in the state of Song, there was a field laborer who always wore a garment of matted hemp—[Annotation:] Tangled flax. [Annotation:] The Shide Tang edition writes *fén* as *fén*, which is incorrect. [Annotation:] *Yì* is pronounced *yì*. *Yùn* is pronounced *yùn*. *Fén* is pronounced *fén*. *Yùnfén* refers to a garment made from torn hemp fibers. The *Han Shi Waizhuan* calls it "a garment of mixed colors." Alternatively pronounced *fén*.—just enough to survive the winter.

When spring arrived for the eastern labors—[Annotation:] The *Canon of Yao* states: *"Yin welcomes the rising sun, and the eastern labors are arranged in order."* The apocryphal Kong commentary says: *"The year begins in the east, and the commencement of plowing is called 'eastern labors.'"* Zhao Qi’s annotation to the *Mencius* reads: *"The Book says, 'The eastern labors are arranged in order,' referring to the management of agricultural affairs."* The *Book of Han*’s *Biography of Wang Mang* states: *"In every county, plowing was practiced to encourage the eastern labors."* The *Records of Emperor Zhi of the Later Han* and the *Continuation of the Han’s Treatise on Ritual and Ceremonies* both say: *"When spring arrives for the eastern labors,"* providing further clear evidence. [Annotation:] *Jì* is pronounced *jì*.—he would bask in the sun himself—[Annotation:] Wang Shumin notes: *The Anthology of Categorized Matters*, *Imperial Digest*, and *Tianzhong Record* all quote *"basking in the sun"* as *"basking in the sun in the fields,"* with the addition of *"admiring it"* after *"fields."* [Annotation:] *Pù* is pronounced *pù*.—unaware that the world contained spacious halls and secluded chambers, silk floss and fox-fur robes. [Annotation:] *Ào* is pronounced *ào*. [Annotation:] *Hé* is pronounced *hè*.

He turned to his wife and said: *"The warmth of the sun on my back—[Annotation:] *Xuān* may be written as *nuǎn* (warm). [Annotation:] *Xuān* is pronounced *xuān*—no one else knows of it. If I present it to our lord, I shall receive a great reward."* A wealthy man of the village informed him: *"In the past, there was a man who praised fine large beans, sweet *xǐ*-stemmed celery, water-pepper seeds, and *píng* to the village magnate. [Annotation:] The village magnate was the most honored man of the locality. [Annotation:] *Píng* is written as *pín* here. [Annotation:] *Róngshū* (large beans) was explained in the *Lì Mìng* chapter. *Xǐ* is pronounced *xǐlǐ*. *Xǐ* refers to *húxǐ* (cocklebur). The *Cāng Jié Piān* states: *□* is an ear [of grain]. It is also called *cāng’ěr* (cocklebur). *Xǐ* is colloquially pronounced *cǐ*. *□* is pronounced with the rising tone. The *Ěryǎ* states: *Píng* is *fúróng* (water-pepper). Also, *píng* is *lài xiāo* (reed). Guo’s commentary notes: This is today’s *lài hāo* (wormwood), which is edible when young. The magnate took some and tasted it, but it stung his mouth [Annotation:] *Zhé* is pronounced *zhé*—and pained his stomach. [Annotation:] *Cǎn* is pronounced *qiān gǎn*. *Cǎn* and *zhé* both mean *pain*. The crowd laughed at him and resented him. [Annotation:] *Shěn* is pronounced *shì rěn*. The man was deeply ashamed. You, sir, are of this same sort."*

Liu Xiaobiao notes: In the *Wen Xuan*, Ji Kang’s *"Letter Breaking Off Relations with Shan Juyuan"* states, "There was a rustic who, delighted by roasting his back in the sun and finding water-cress delicious, wished to present them to the emperor." This shows the legend already existed, and the compiler of the *Liezi* incorporated it into this chapter.

Yang Zhu said: "Grand mansions, fine robes, rich flavors, and beautiful women—with these four, what more could one seek externally? Yet those who possess them and still seek beyond are of insatiable nature. Such insatiable nature is the moth that gnaws at yin and yang. [Annotation:] It not only burdens the self but also erodes the upright qi."

[Annotation:] The character *其* in the note appears as *正* in the *Shidetang* edition, which is incorrect.

[Annotation:] *Dù* is pronounced *dù*. *Lěi* is read in the falling tone.

"Loyalty is insufficient to secure the ruler’s peace and only endangers the self; righteousness is insufficient to benefit others and only harms one’s life. Peace for superior and subject does not arise from loyalty, yet the name of loyalty is extinguished; benefit to others does not arise from righteousness, yet the name of righteousness is lost. When ruler and subject are at peace and self and others both profit—this was the Way of antiquity. The *Yuzi* states: *'He who abandons fame knows no sorrow.'* Laozi said: *'Fame is but the guest of reality.'* [Liu Xiaobiao notes:] This line does not appear in the current *Laozi* but is found in the *Zhuangzi*’s *Free and Easy Wandering* chapter. Yet the careless multitude ceaselessly pursue fame. If fame cannot be abandoned, can it truly be treated as a mere guest?

Now, to have fame is to gain honor and glory; to lack fame is to suffer lowliness and disgrace. Honor and glory bring ease and joy; lowliness and disgrace bring sorrow and suffering. Sorrow and suffering violate one’s nature; ease and joy accord with it. These are the ties that bind reality. How can fame be abandoned? How can it be treated as a guest? The true evil lies in clinging to fame and thereby burdening reality."

[Annotation:] *Wù* is pronounced *wùlù*. *Fú* is read as *fú*. *Lěi* is in the falling tone.

"Clinging to fame and thereby burdening reality will lead to concerns over peril and ruin that cannot be saved—how could it be merely a matter between ease and joy or sorrow and suffering?"

Qin Enfu notes: From the passage beginning *"Wei, the Viscount Duanmu Shu,"* onward, Lu’s commentary is missing, and there is no way to supplement or correct it.

*Liezi Jishi*, Volume Eight: *Shuofu* (Explaining Symbols)

[Annotation:] Affairs are boundless, with fortune and misfortune mutually propelling one another. When words are spoken and verified, they are grasped within the convergence of change and adaptation.

[Exegesis:] This chapter, departing from the *Mo Ming* edition, approximates form to discern spirit. Establishing affairs reveals the real; pursuing names seeks reality. Only then does one recognize the loss of the Dao in following emotions and the forfeiture of truth in indulging desires. Thus, those who know the Dao do not lose their timely self, and those who employ ability need not distance themselves from harm.

Qin Enfu notes: The character *"zi"* (自) in the exegesis is likely superfluous.

Master Liezi studied under Master Huqiu Zilin.
Master Huqiu Zilin said: "If you understand *holding back*, then we may speak of *holding the self*."
[Annotation:] Laozi said, *"Hold back the self, and the self will advance."*
Liezi said: "I have heard of *holding back*."
Master Huqiu replied: "Look at your shadow, and you will understand."
Liezi turned and observed his shadow: when the body was bent, the shadow was crooked; when the body was straight, the shadow was upright. Thus, crookedness and straightness follow the body and do not reside in the shadow; bending and extending depend on the object and not on the self. This is called *holding back to occupy the forefront*."
[Annotation:] No thing can contend with it, so it always occupies the forefront. These words, though Huzi’s answer, are not clearly expounded. Liezi grasped the meaning of *holding back* and thereby explained it himself, so Huzi did not further respond.
[Exegesis:] The shadow arises from the form, and crookedness or straightness originates in the form’s movement. The form exists through the spirit, and authenticity or falsity lies in the spirit’s function. If one discerns the form by observing the shadow and knows the spirit by understanding the form—without demanding the shadow to rectify the body or clinging to the body to illuminate the Dao—then by observing the branch, one knows the root, and by examining the manifest, one perceives the subtle. Only then can one always occupy the forefront.

The *Daozang* edition and Yuan edition both read *"seems Huzi’s answer"* instead of *"with Huzi’s answer."*
Bo Jun notes: The *Huainanzi*’s *Miu Cheng Xun* states: *"Liezi studied under Huzi and, observing the reflection in a pillar, understood *holding back*."*

[Phonetic Annotations:] *Zheng* (争) is pronounced *zhèng*. *Xie* (解) is pronounced *xiè*. *Fu* (复) is read *fú*.

Guan Yin said to Master Liezi: "Beautiful words produce a beautiful echo; foul words produce a foul echo. A long body casts a long shadow; a short body casts a short shadow. The name is the echo; the self is the shadow."
[Annotation:] The retribution of good and evil is like echoes and shadows—there is no discrepancy in principle.
Tao Hongqing notes: The preceding line, *"The name is the echo,"* follows from *"Beautiful words produce a beautiful echo; foul words produce a foul echo"*—an echo arises from words, but words are not the echo. This line follows from *"A long body casts a long shadow; a short body casts a short shadow"*—a shadow arises from the body, but the body is not the shadow. Now, saying *"the self is the shadow"* is somewhat difficult to reconcile. Here, *"self"* refers to the body that receives retribution, entirely distinct in meaning from *"long body"* or *"short body"* above. The subsequent text—*"Measure lies in the self; verification lies in others. If others love me, I must love them; if others hate me, I must hate them"*—means that by observing others’ love or hatred toward me, one knows my own love or hatred toward others. Loving or hating others is the self; others loving or hating that self is the shadow. Thus, *"the self is the shadow."*
Wang Shumin notes: *"Self"* (身) should be *"conduct"* (行). The following line, *"Be cautious in your conduct, for it will be followed,"* directly continues this idea. The current text’s *"self"* is an error, arising from the preceding *"long body"* and *"short body."* The *Shizi*, as cited in the *Taiping Yulan* (430), reads *"conduct is the shadow,"* providing collateral evidence.
Bo Jun notes: Wang’s proposal is tenable; Tao’s interpretation, though ingenious, is overly circuitous.

Thus it is said: Be cautious in your words, for they will be harmonized; be cautious in your conduct, for it will be followed.
[Annotation:] As the saying goes: *"Speak good words, and a thousand *li* away they will respond; act nearby, and it will be seen afar."*
Jiang Yougao notes: *"He"* (和) and *"sui"* (随) rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *ge* rhyme group.
[Phonetic Annotations:] *Jian* (见) is pronounced *xiàn*.

Therefore, the sage observes the outgoing to know the incoming, examines the past to know the future—this is the principle by which they possess foreknowledge.
[Annotation:] Seeing words go out and echoes return, forms depart and shadows arrive, one understands that the principle of retribution is no different. Yet things have not yet awakened to this, so it is called *"foreknowledge."*
[Exegesis:] The echo follows the sound; if the sound is good, the echo is beautiful. The name follows reality; if reality is good, the name is true. Thus, the name is the echo of the sound, and the self is the shadow of the spirit. Sounds emit and echoes harmonize; conduct is practiced and the spirit follows. Therefore, the sage hears the echo to know the sound and sees conduct to know the Dao.

The measure lies in the self; verification lies in others. If others love me, I must love them; if others hate me, I must hate them.
[Annotation:] Ritual measure lies in the self; verification lies with others. Love and hatred follow accordingly—things do not betray the self.
Tang and Wu loved the world, thus they reigned.

"Wang" is pronounced *yù* (于放切). Jie and Zhou hated the world, thus they perished.
[Annotation:] This is the verification of the principle. This is what is meant by *"verification."*

[Exegesis:] Ritual measure lies in the self; verification lies in others—like the shadow responding to the form, the echo answering the sound. The traces of Tang, Wu, Jie, and Zhou may be examined; their measures may be made clear. One must be cautious in matters of love and hatred. If both verification and measure are clear yet the Dao is not followed, it is like going out without using the door or walking without following the path.
[Annotation:] When the principles of verification and measure are already clear, yet the Dao is still not practiced, it is like exiting without passing through the gate or walking without following the path. (The character *jìng* [径] appears in one version as *qú* [衢], and in another as *shù* [术]. *Fù* [复] is pronounced *fú* [扶又切].) To seek profit by such means—is it not difficult?
[Annotation:] There has never been profit gained by violating principle.

[Exegesis:] If the matters of verification and measure are clear yet the Dao is not followed, it is like walking without using the gate or the thoroughfare. To seek profit for oneself in the world by such means—is it not difficult? (Qin Enfu notes: According to the exegesis, the Lu edition reads *qú* [衢] instead of *jìng* [径].)

I have observed the virtue of Shennong and Yan, examined the books of Yu, Xia, Shang, and Zhou, and measured them against the words of learned scholars and worthies. There has never been a case of survival or ruin, rise or fall that did not proceed from this Dao.
[Annotation:] From ancient times to the present, there has been no instance without verification.

[Exegesis:] By examining their conduct and verifying their traces, the words of ancient sage-kings and worthies remain consistent with those of others. Survival and ruin, rise and fall are all clearly evident. There has never been a case of governance not proceeding from this Dao.

Yan Hui said: "Those who ask about the Dao do so to become wealthy.
[Annotation:] *Ask* here means *to learn.* (*Wèi* [为] is pronounced *wéi* [于伪切].) Now that I have obtained a pearl, I am wealthy—what need is there for the Dao?"
[Annotation:] The Dao is the root of wealth; the pearl is its branch. When the root exists, the branch remains; to preserve the branch is to lose the root. (The Northern Song edition omits the character *yě* [也] after *"wealth’s branch,"* and Wang’s edition follows this. Here, it is restored according to the *Four Exegeses* edition.)

Master Liezi said: "Jie and Zhou valued profit and slighted the Dao, thus they perished.
[Annotation:] They were not without wealth, but by losing the root, they lost themselves. How fortunate that I have not yet spoken to you of this! A person without righteousness eats and nothing more—
[Annotation:] *Righteousness* means *what is fitting.* One who attains the fitting principle of reason cannot be deprived by external things. Such a person is no better than a chicken or a dog. Forcibly seizing food and butting heads—
(Yu Yue says: *Mǐ* [靡] should be read as *mó* [摩]. In the *Mati* chapter of the *Zhuangzi*, it says, *"When pleased, they rub necks together."* The exegesis by Li cites *mó* [摩], showing that *mǐ* [靡] and *mó* [摩] share the same meaning. Thus, *mǐ jiǎo* [靡角] means *rubbing horns together.* Wang Shumin says: Yu’s interpretation is correct. The *Taiping Yulan* [421] quotes it as *mó* [磨]. *Mó* [磨], *mó* [摩], and *mǐ* [靡] were interchangeable in ancient usage. *Mǐ* [靡] is pronounced *wén bǐ* [文彼切]. The *Han Shi Waizhuan* says: *Mǐ* [靡] means *together.* The *Lüshi Chunqiu* says: *Jiǎo* [角] means *to test strength.* This passage describes those who value profit and slight the Dao, eating and nothing more—like birds and beasts that eat their fill and then butt heads together to compete for dominance.) The victor gains control—such are birds and beasts.
[Annotation:] To seek victory by force is not the human Dao. (Wang Chongmin says: The character *zhì* [制] is semantically incoherent here and should be *lì* [利], a scribal error. The *Taiping Yulan* [421] quotes it as *"the victor gains profit,"* which confirms this.) To be no better than chickens, dogs, birds, or beasts yet desire others’ respect—this cannot be attained.
[Annotation:] How could one desire others’ respect? When the Dao is present, one is naturally respected. If others do not respect you, danger and disgrace will befall you.
[Annotation:] To be willingly esteemed without resentment is what it means to be respected. If one violates this principle, ruin will follow.

[Exegesis:] *Wealth* means *without lack*—it does not refer to the wealth of profit-seeking. To value profit and slight the Dao is how Jie and Zhou perished. Chickens, dogs, birds, and beasts know nothing of benevolence and righteousness; they fight over food and rely on strength, unaware of anything else. To act thus is to invite danger and disgrace upon oneself. How could one then expect others’ respect? This is what is meant by *seeking reality through names.*

Liezi had hit the target in archery.
[Annotation:] He had hit it by chance, not through deliberate aim. (*Zhòng* [中] is pronounced *dīng zhòng* [丁仲切] below.)
He asked Master Guan Yin about it. Master Yin said:
(Wang Chongmin says: The *Taiping Yulan* [745] includes an additional *guān* [关] here, which is correct. Ancient texts sometimes refer to him as *Guan Yin* but never as *Yinzi* below. Wang Shumin says: Wang’s interpretation is correct. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Shen Ji* chapter also reads *"Master Guan Yin said"* below.)
"Do you know why you hit the target?"
He replied: "I do not."
Master Guan Yin said: "Not yet."
[Annotation:] Though he had hit the target, he did not know how, so it was said to be "not yet."
He withdrew and practiced. After three years, he returned to report to Master Guan Yin. The Master said: "Do you know why you hit the target?"
Liezi said: "I know now."
Master Guan Yin said: "It is acceptable. Hold to this and do not lose it.
[Annotation:] With a calm mind and upright body, seeking within oneself, one attains the Dao of hitting the target. Then, one may aim at the target in advance, and every shot will strike without fail. This is not only true of archery—governing a state and cultivating the self are the same."

Thus, the sage does not examine whether something endures or perishes but examines the reason it is so.

Though one may hit the target without knowing how, this is not the Dao of hitting the target; though one may endure without knowing why, this is not the principle of endurance. Therefore, in archery, the unskilled and the skilled may both hit the mark, yet those who know *why* they hit it differ. The worthy and the foolish may both endure, yet those who know *why* they endure are distinct.

One who does not know *why* they hit the target is not the most excellent of the excellent. To grasp it with the hand and respond with the heart, to command the shot and strike the mark—this is attainment. To attain and hold to it is called the Dao. One who knows this Dao may apply it not only to archery but also to governing a state and cultivating the self.

The master of archery does not value merely hitting the target but values the reason it *must* be hit. Likewise, the master of ordering a state or cultivating the self does not value mere endurance but values the reason it *must* endure. Thus, whether the worthy or the foolish, order or chaos, may be known—this is the presence of the Dao.

Liezi said: "Those whose appearance is flourishing are arrogant; those whose strength is flourishing are aggressive—they cannot yet be spoken to of the Dao. Only when their hair is streaked with white may one speak to them of it, lest they lose it. How much less can they practice it?

Those who are arrogant and aggressive allow no one to instruct them. With no one to instruct them, they become isolated and lack support. The worthy, however, employ others, and so even in old age they do not decline; even when their wisdom is exhausted, they do not fall into chaos.

Thus, the difficulty in governing a state lies not in being worthy oneself but in recognizing worth in others. One who deems themselves worthy is, as stated above, isolated and without support. But one who recognizes worth allows the wise to counsel them and the capable to serve them. With no talent wasted, the state is easily ordered."

The common people rely on appearance and strength. Those who rely on appearance foster arrogance and indolence; those who rely on strength harbor aggressive and combative intentions—they cannot be spoken to of the Dao. Only when their appearance and strength have faded, when their hair is streaked with white, may one speak to them of it. Yet even then, though they may hear the Dao in old age, they cannot attain it—how much less can they practice it? Thus, those who abide in humility and weakness are embraced by the Dao, while those who are self-assertive and aggressive find no one willing to instruct them. With no one willing to instruct them, how can they have support?

The worthy entrust themselves to others, and so their spirit does not wane with age, nor does their mind fall into chaos when their wisdom is spent. One who governs a state in this way, recognizing worth and employing it, allows worthy talent to serve them. But one who deems themselves worthy and lacks support loses others.

There was once a man of Song who, for his lord, crafted mulberry leaves from jade.

After three years, it was completed. Its edges and stems, whether full or slender, its fine veins and lush sheen—when mixed among real mulberry leaves, none could distinguish them. Thus, this man came to feed himself by his skill throughout the state of Song.

Master Liezi heard of this and said: "If heaven and earth took three years to produce a single leaf, then things with leaves would be few indeed. Therefore, the sage relies on the transformative power of the Dao and not on clever skill."

[Annotation] This shows that relying on skill is insufficient to sustain things; following the Dao in transformation leaves nothing unfulfilled.

[Exegesis] Carving and polishing to return to simplicity is the Way of restoring purity. Thus it is said: the master binder needs no glue or lacquer; the master locker needs no bolt or key. Therefore, great eloquence seems inarticulate, and great skill seems clumsy. If three years’ labor produces a single leaf indistinguishable from a real one, how can this be the skill of governing a state or preserving the Dao? Thus, the sage relies on the transformative power of the Dao—just as harmonious qi spreads and all things come to life—rather than on clever skill. To defy the principles of heaven and produce artificial craft is to fail to understand root and branch.

[Note] "Skill" in some editions reads "merit" or "ability." "Sustain things" in the Northern Song edition appears as "marry things," where "marry" is likely a scribal error.

Master Liezi was poor, his face bearing the pallor of hunger. A guest spoke of this to Zi Yang of Zheng, saying: "Lie Yukou is surely a man of the Dao, yet he dwells in your state and suffers poverty—does this not suggest the lord does not love men of worth?" Zi Yang of Zheng immediately ordered an official to send him grain. Master Liezi went out to meet the messenger, bowed twice, and declined. The messenger departed. When Master Liezi returned inside, his wife struck her breast and said: "I have heard that the wife and children of a man of the Dao all enjoy ease and happiness. Now you bear the look of hunger, and the lord, passing by, sent you food. You refused it—is this not fate?" Master Liezi laughed and said to her: "The lord does not know me himself."

Master Liezi said: "He sent me grain on the words of another; should he blame me, it would likewise be on the words of another—this is why I did not accept it."

Bo Jun notes: The *Xin Xu*’s "Jie Shi" chapter contains the lines: "Moreover, to accept another’s sustenance and not die for their peril is unrighteous; to die for their peril is to die for an unprincipled man—how can that be righteous?"

In the end, the people indeed rose in revolt and killed Zi Yang.

[Commentary] To eat another’s provisions is to share their concerns. The lord did not know me himself but bestowed grain upon me based on another’s words; if he were to blame me, it would likewise be based on another’s words. What I value is the one who truly knows me—a man who has awakened to the Dao. When Zi Yang’s calamity arose, I was not harmed—this is what it truly means not to be burdened or harmed by external things.

Bo Jun notes: The *Records of the Grand Historian*’s "Hereditary House of Zheng" states: "In the twenty-fifth year of Duke Xu, the lord of Zheng killed his minister Zi Yang." The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Shi Wei" chapter says: "Zi Yang favored severity; one who erred and broke his bow feared he would surely die, so he incited mad dogs to assassinate Zi Yang."

The Lu family of the Shi clan had two sons: one fond of learning, the other fond of military arts. The one fond of learning offered his arts to the Marquis of Qi; the Marquis accepted him and made him tutor to the various princes. The one fond of military arts went to Chu and offered his methods to the King of Chu; the King was pleased and made him military commander. Their salaries enriched their household, and their ranks honored their kin.

The neighboring Meng family had two sons as well, who pursued the same studies, yet they were distressed by poverty. Envying the Shi family’s prosperity, they asked for the path to advancement. The two sons told the Meng family the truth. One of the Meng sons went to Qin and offered his arts to the King of Qin. The King of Qin said: "Now the feudal lords contend with force, and what they pursue is nothing but arms and provisions. If I were to govern my state with benevolence and righteousness, it would be the way to ruin."

Thus, the King of Qin imprisoned and exiled the Meng son. The other son went to Wei and offered his methods to the Marquis of Wei. The Marquis said: "My state is weak, hemmed in between great powers. I serve the great states and soothe the small ones—this is the Way to seek security. Were I to rely on military power, destruction would soon follow. If I were to let you return intact and you went to another state, the harm you could bring me would be no small matter." He then had the Meng son’s feet cut off and sent him back to Lu.

Upon their return, the father and son of the Meng family beat their chests and reproached the Shi family. The Shi family said: "In all things, those who seize the moment prosper, while those who miss it perish. Your Way was the same as ours, yet your success differed—this was a matter of missing the moment, not of flawed conduct. Moreover, in the world, principles have no constant right, and affairs no constant wrong. What was used before may now be discarded; what is discarded today may later be employed. In this, use and disuse have no fixed right or wrong. Seizing opportunities and meeting the moment, responding to affairs without fixed method—this depends on wisdom. Though one may possess the arts of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and law, without wisdom suited to the time, one acts and misses the moment. If wisdom is insufficient, even were one as learned as Confucius or as skilled as Lü Shang, where could one go and not meet with failure?" The Meng father and son, their resentment dissolved, said: "We understand. Say no more!"

To study the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, to master the arts of strategy and planning—though civil and martial differ, both converge in the application of talent and conduct, which must rely on wisdom suited to the moment. Wisdom is the application of the Dao; to rely solely on wisdom is to depart from the Dao.

To strike is to hit the gap; to act is to meet the moment. Responding to change without fixed method—all this is wisdom. Thus, one who adapts to the time is never at a loss for talent; one who illuminates the Dao is never lacking in wisdom. If wisdom is insufficient, though one’s civil arts match Confucius or martial skill match Lü Shang, one cannot escape hardship.

The Meng father and son, having awakened, said only, “Say no more.”

When Duke Wen of Jin went forth to meet the lords, intending to attack Wei, Prince Chu looked up to the sky and laughed. The Prime Minister asked, “Why do you laugh?” He replied, “I laugh at my neighbor, who was escorting his wife back to her family when, on the road, he saw a woman gathering mulberry leaves. Enamored, he spoke to her, yet when he turned to look at his wife, another was beckoning to her as well. I laugh at this.”

The Duke grasped his meaning and called off the attack.

Wang Chongmin notes: In the *Leiju* (ch. 88) and *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 305 and 457), the character "寤" is uniformly written as "悟." The *Shiwen* glosses: "寤 is pronounced as 悟." The army was withdrawn, yet before it returned, raiders had already struck its northern border.

**[Annotation]** What I have done, others may also do. To indulge one’s own ambitions while assuming others will not harbor the same intentions is to be deluded by the distinction between self and other.

**[Exegesis]** To covet gain without understanding that gain must be guarded is the common folly of the vulgar. Thus, desires know no bounds, and the true Dao daily wanes. The value of one who knows the Dao lies in inwardly preserving the Dao without loss and outwardly applying it to things without omission. The worldly, however, are not so: outwardly, they lust after other women, enamored of another’s wife; inwardly, they lose the Dao, and their own wife is beckoned by another.

Qin Enfu remarks: In the exegesis, the character "得" in "得有所守" is likely a superfluous interpolation.

The state of Jin suffered from rampant banditry. There was a man named Xi Yong—Lu Jun notes: "郄" should be written as "郤." The *Shuowen* states, "郤 was the fief of Shu Hu, a grandee of Jin." Duan Yucai’s commentary adds: "Shu Hu’s son was named Xi Rui, who took his fief as his surname." The *Qunshu Zhiyao* correctly writes it as "郤," and the same should apply below. Shao Ying’s *Qunjing Zhengzi* observes: "The vulgar further corrupt it to '郄,' a variant of '郤.' In the *Hanxue Shichao* by Song En et al., the character '师' appears as '□□,' with a component resembling '卩,' leading the vulgar to alter it to '郄.' The * Yupian* notes: '郄 is a vulgar form of 卩.'" The *Shiwen* glosses: "郄 is pronounced *qì* (去逆切). 雍 is pronounced *yōng* (邕)." Xi Yong could discern a bandit’s appearance—"貌" originally read "眼," but the present version follows the *Jifu* and *Shidetang* editions, which correct it to "貌." The *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) also writes it as "貌." The *Shiwen* notes: "貌 appears in one edition as 眼."—and examine the space between their brows and lashes to uncover their true nature. The *Shiwen* glosses: "睫 is pronounced *jié* (接)." The Marquis of Jin sent him to identify bandits, and among thousands, not one escaped his detection.

The Marquis of Jin rejoiced greatly and told Zhao Wenzi: "I have found one man, and the bandits of the entire state are as good as eradicated. Lu Jun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) includes a "之" after "为." The *Shiwen* glosses: "为 is pronounced *wěi* (于伪切). Why should I employ many?" Wenzi replied: "My lord relies on surveillance to catch bandits, yet bandits will not be eradicated. Moreover, Xi Yong will surely not meet a natural death." Soon after, the bandits plotted among themselves: "The one who has cornered us is Xi Yong." Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) includes a "以" after "所," which is correct. They then joined forces to murder him.

**[Annotation]** "残" means to kill or destroy. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Qunshu Zhiyao* and *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) write "残" as "戕," and the latter may be closer to the original. The *Shuowen* defines "戕" as "a minister from another state who assassinates a ruler," hence Zhang’s annotation reads "to kill treacherously." The *Shiwen* writes "残" as "戕," glossing: "戕 is pronounced *qiāng* (墙), as in the annotation; one edition writes it as 残."

The Marquis of Jin, upon hearing this, was greatly alarmed. The *Shiwen* writes "骇" as "駴," noting: "It is the same as 骇." He immediately summoned Wenzi and said: "As you predicted, Xi Yong is dead! But what method should we use to capture the bandits?" The *Qinke Lu* edition omits the character "盗." Wenzi replied: "There is a Zhou proverb that says: 'One who sees the fish in the depths is inauspicious; one who predicts hidden things brings calamity.' Jiang Yougao notes: "祥 and 殃 form a rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *yang* rhyme group." Lu Jun notes: The *Hanfeizi* (*Shuo Lin Shang*) states: "An ancient proverb says, 'One who knows the fish in the depths is inauspicious.'" The *Shiwen* glosses: "料 is pronounced in the falling tone (去声). Moreover, if my lord wishes to eliminate banditry, you must elevate the worthy and employ them. Let instruction be clear above, and transformation flow below; if the people have a sense of shame, what banditry will there be?"

**[Annotation]** This answers the method to stop banditry.

Thereupon, they appointed Sui Hui to oversee governance, and the bandits fled to Qin.

**[Annotation]** To employ keen discernment in judging right and wrong is to invite the flight of the deceitful; to use foresight in exposing hidden evils is to incur the hatred of the wicked. Is the peril of wisdom mere empty talk?

**[Exegesis]** Instruction is the outward form, the path by which the multitude walks. Transformation is the Dao, the principle by which the multitude daily lives and inwardly submits. When the heart submits, shame arises; when the outward form is clear, instruction is achieved. Elevate the worthy and employ the capable, and bandits will flee. Someone asked: Zhuangzi said, "When the sage is born, great bandits arise." Yet here it says that elevating the worthy and employing the capable causes bandits to depart. How can this be? The answer: To seek empty fame while losing substance is to give rise to great bandits; to attain substance while forsaking fame is to cause bandits to depart. Thus, elevating the worthy and employing the capable is the pursuit of fame; employing Sui Hui is the attainment of substance. The principles do not contradict each other—what doubt can there be? The *Qunshu Zhiyao* writes "先" as "少" in the annotation "用先识," which is closer to the original. The *Shiwen* glosses: "擿 is pronounced *zhí* (陟革切)."

Confucius, returning from Wei to Lu, halted his carriage at the bridge over the Yellow River and gazed upon it.

A cataract plunges three hundred feet—*Shide Hall*’s edition mistakenly writes "thirty." Its whirling currents span ninety *li*. Fish and soft-shelled turtles cannot swim there; *yuan*-turtles and alligators cannot dwell there. Yet a man was just about to ford it. The *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the word "a." *Shiwen* notes: *厉* means "to wade through water." Confucius sent someone along the bank to stop him—the *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the words "along the bank." *Shiwen* notes: *并* is pronounced *páng*; *涯* sounds like *yá*. "This cataract plunges three hundred feet; its whirling currents span ninety *li*. Fish and soft-shelled turtles cannot swim there; *yuan*-turtles and alligators cannot dwell there. Do you think it can be crossed?" The *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the words "cannot swim." The man did not alter his resolve—the *Qunshu Zhiyao* writes *措* for *错*. *Shiwen* notes: *错* is pronounced *cù*. He then crossed and emerged.

Confucius asked him, "Are you skillful? Do you possess a Daoist technique?" Wang Shumin notes: The *Jia Yu*’s *Zhisi* chapter and the *Shuo Yuan*’s *Zayan* chapter both add the word "you" before "skillful," making the phrasing more complete; this should be followed. This text’s *Huangdi* chapter reads, "Are you skillful? Do you possess the Way?" The *Zhuangzi*’s *Zhi Beiyou* chapter reads, "Are you skillful? Do you possess the Dao?" Both follow the same pattern. "How is it that you were able to enter and emerge?" The man replied, "When I first entered, I relied on loyalty and trust. When I emerged, I again followed loyalty and trust. Loyalty and trust placed my body amidst the waves, and I dared not act on private motives—the *Qunshu Zhiyao* writes *措* for *错*. Yu Yue notes: The phrase "loyalty and trust placed my body amidst the waves" contains a superfluous "loyalty and trust," likely borrowed from the preceding sentence. Wang Shumin notes: Yu Yue’s observation is correct. The *Qunshu Zhiyao* indeed omits the words "loyalty and trust." "Thus I was able to enter and emerge—this is how."

Confucius said to his disciples, "Remember this, all of you!" *Shiwen* notes: *识* is pronounced *zhì*. "If even water can be approached with loyalty, trust, and sincerity, how much more so can people?" The annotation notes: This passage appears in the *Huangdi* chapter with minor differences, but its meaning is not distinct, so its meaning is not re-explained here. The explanation states: Loyalty harmonizes with all things; trust leaves no room for doubt. Harmonizing without doubt and refraining from private motives—this is how one enters and emerges. Thus, to harmonize without doubt and refrain from private motives is to grasp the Dao! This passage also appears in the *Huangdi* chapter. Bo Jun notes: This passage centers on the two words "loyalty" and "trust"; the words "and sincerity" may be superfluous. The *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the words "and sincerity," confirming this. *Shiwen* notes: *复* is pronounced *fù*.

Lord Bai asked Confucius, "Can one speak with you in secret?" Wang Chongmin notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Jingyu* chapter, the *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter, and the *Taiping Yulan* (chapter 58) all include the word "to" after "asked"—the current text is missing it due to a scribal error. Confucius did not respond. The annotation notes: Lord Bai was the grandson of King Ping of Chu and the son of Crown Prince Jian. His father was slandered by Fei Wuji and fled to Zheng, where the Zheng people killed him. Bai wished to have ministers Zixi and Ziqing attack Zheng, but though they agreed, they did not act. When Jin attacked Zheng, Zixi and Ziqing prepared to aid Zheng. Bai grew angry, saying, "The Zheng people are here—our enemies are not far off!" He wished to kill Zixi and Ziqing, so he questioned Confucius. Confucius, knowing his intent, did not respond. *微言* means "secret plans."
