Qin Enfu notes: In the commentary, "breaking limbs" refers to "breaking branches." Mencius says, "To break a branch for an elder." Zhao Qi’s annotation explains: "Breaking branches means massaging the joints to relieve fatigue."

There was a man from Song who, while traveling on the road, found a discarded wooden tally. The note explains: "discarded" means abandoned. Wang Chongmin observes: The *Taiping Yulan* (499) omits the character "traveling." The tally was a notched piece of wood used to record matters. He took it home and hid it, secretly counting its teeth. The note explains: the notches resembled teeth. Wang Zhong comments: According to the note, the "tally" here refers to the carved notches, synonymous with "engraving." Yang Bojun notes: The matching parts of a tally are its teeth, used to verify authenticity. The *Yilin* states: "The left tally matches the right, their teeth aligning." Thus, upon finding the tally, the man secretly counted its teeth. He told his neighbor, "I shall soon be rich!" The note explains: Those who use empty names to seek real gain are like holding a discarded tally to claim wealth.

The commentary states: Ordinary people, deluded by empty names and losing sight of truth, are all like picking up a lost wooden tally, counting its notches to await riches. They are also like those who feel no shame in begging in the marketplace yet feel shame in serving others. How is this different from a runaway slave abandoning his master to serve another? The labor is no different, yet he believes himself no longer bound to anyone. Following deluded emotions while losing true principle—such is the nature of all these cases.

There was a man with a withered parasol tree. His neighbor, an elder, said that withered parasol trees were inauspicious. Yang Bojun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Qu You* chapter) uses "good" instead of "auspicious." The neighbor hastily chopped it down. The note explains: Though his words were fair, he spoke out of place. Yu Yue argues: The character "neighbor" is superfluous. Above, it says "a man had a withered parasol tree," and here it says "his man," referring to this same person. The "neighbor elder" mentioned throughout refers to this man’s neighbor—how could it then refer to the neighbor as "this man"? Below, it says, "The man was displeased, saying..."—also without the character "neighbor," proving that "neighbor" here is extraneous. The neighbor elder then asked to take it as firewood. The note explains: He further treads a dubious path. Wang Shumin observes: The *Liu Tie* (16) omits the character "man," and the current text’s "man" may be an interpolation from the surrounding text. The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Qu You* chapter) also omits "man." The man was displeased, saying, "The neighbor elder merely wanted firewood and thus urged me to cut it down. Living beside me, how treacherous he is—how can this be?" The note explains: In doubtful matters, things cannot be trusted.

The commentary states: Urging him to cut the tree was a fair suggestion; asking for it as firewood was reasonable. Yet urging its felling while requesting it raised suspicions of ulterior motives. Thus it is said: What people fear, one must fear. Do not think it harmless—its misfortune will grow. This is what it means.

There was a man who lost his axe. The note explains: "axe" refers to a hatchet. He suspected his neighbor’s son. Yang Bojun notes: There should be a "man" after "neighbor," as below it also says "neighbor’s son," and the *Taiping Yulan* (763) renders it as "neighbor’s son," though it omits "of," the character "man" is not missing. He observed the son’s gait—he had stolen the axe; his complexion—he had stolen the axe; his speech—he had stolen the axe; his movements and demeanor—nothing did not suggest he had stolen the axe. The *Sibu Congkan* edition omits "gait." Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (763) renders "movements and demeanor" as "demeanor and movements," which is correct. Below, it says, "Another day, he saw his neighbor’s son again, and his demeanor and movements no longer resembled those of an axe thief." Yang Bojun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Qu You* chapter) also uses "demeanor and movements." Wang’s observation is correct. Here, following Lu Chongxuan’s edition and the *Daozang Sijie* edition for emendation. The *Shiwen Leiju* (Bieji 18) and *He Bi Shilei* (Xuxi 33) also use "demeanor and movements." Soon after, he dug in his valley and found his axe. Another day, he saw his neighbor’s son again. Wang Shumin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (763), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (55, 59), *Shiwen Leiju* (Bieji 18), and *He Bi Shilei* (Xuxi 33) all omit the character "man." His demeanor and movements no longer resembled those of an axe thief.

His demeanor and movements no longer resembled those of an axe thief.

**Note:** When the mind is biased and deluded, it shifts and alters with one’s thoughts and intentions. In extreme cases, white and black become indistinguishable, square and round merge in form—how could this be a change in external things? Thus, the saying goes: the myriad affairs, tangled and confused, all arise from the mind.

**Exegesis:** Many misfortunes stem from doubts and resemblances. Even the fall of a kite or a mouse may breed suspicion and disaster. Only those who accumulate virtue, uphold the Dao, and remain impartial and selfless can avoid such calamities. The case of losing an axe and suspecting a neighbor is but one example.

**Note (variant):** The phrase *"how could this be a change in external things"* appears in the *Daozang Sijie* edition as *"how could external things have the power to change them?"*

**Phonetic Gloss:** *fù* (復), *fúyòu* (扶又) cut.

When Viscount Bai of Shen plotted rebellion,

**Note:** *Lǜ* (慮) means "to consider" or "to scheme," here referring to plotting rebellion.

**Phonetic Gloss:** *shèng* (勝), *shīzhèng* (詩證) cut.

he left court and stood, leaning on his staff upside down, its spike piercing his chin.

**Note:** *zhuì* (錣) refers to the pointed tip of a staff.

**Pei Jun’s Note:** The *Hanfeizi* (*Yu Lao* chapter) reads: *"He left court, inverted his staff, and its spike pierced his chin."*

**Phonetic Gloss:** *zhuì* (錣), *zhāngliè* (張劣) cut. Xu Shen’s commentary on the *Huainanzi* states: *"A horse whip has a sharp iron tip to prod a horse that refuses to advance."*

Blood flowed to the ground, yet he was unaware. A man of Zheng, hearing of this, said: *"If one can forget one’s chin, what else could one not forget?"*

**Note:** In the Northern Song edition and the *Shide Tang* edition, *"chin"* (頤) appears as *"head"* (頭).

When the mind is fixated, one’s steps may stumble over roots or pits,

**Phonetic Gloss:** *zhǔ* (屬), *zhú* (烛) sound. *zhuó* (著), *zhíluè* (直略) cut. *zhì* (踬), "to stumble." *kǎn* (埳), "pit."

one’s head may strike a wooden post, yet one remains oblivious.

**Pei Jun’s Note:** The passage *"When the mind is fixated..."* also appears in the *Huainanzi* (*Yuandao Xun*).

**Phonetic Gloss:** *dǐ* (抵), *dīnglǐ* (丁礼) cut.

Long ago, a man of Qi coveted gold. At dawn, he dressed and went to the market. Arriving at the gold vendor’s stall, he seized the gold and left.

**Phonetic Gloss:** *yìguān* (衣冠), both in departing tone. *yù* (鬻), *yù* (育) sound.

The authorities arrested him and asked: *"With people all around, why did you seize another’s gold?"*

**Wang Chongmin’s Note:** The *Leiju* (83), *Taiping Yulan* (810), and *Lüshi Chunqiu* all include the word *"reason"* (故) after *"why"* (何). The *Huainanzi* (*Fanlun Xun*) reads *"why"* (何故) as *"what"* (何也).

**Wang Shumin’s Note:** The *Liushitie* (8), *Shilei Fu* (9), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (1, 55), *Shiwen Leiju Xuxi* (25), and *Tianzhong Ji* (50) all include the word *"reason"* (故).

**Phonetic Gloss:** The text reads: *"Why did you seize another’s gold?"* (子攫人之金何故), with a variant omitting *"reason"* (故).

He replied: *"When I took the gold, I saw no one—only the gold."*

**Note:** The chaos wrought by craving and desire upon the human heart is this severe. Thus, the ancients said: *"One who examines the tip of an autumn hair cannot see the form of Mount Tai; one who tunes the harmony of the five notes cannot hear the sound of thunder. When the mind is ensnared by the myriad things and attached to externals, even great forms and sounds may be overlooked. How much more so for one whose heart strays from principle, who restrains emotions and gathers thoughts, abiding in tranquil stillness—how could the movements of the myriad things disturb them?"*

**Exegesis:** Zhang Zhan states: *"The chaos wrought by craving and desire upon the human heart is this severe. Thus, it is said: 'One who examines the tip of an autumn hair cannot see the form of Mount Tai; one who listens to the harmony of the five notes cannot hear the sound of thunder.' When the mind is fixed on something, the body may be forgotten—all such cases are like this."* This chapter speaks of the great harm in indulging desires, which can destroy the body and extinguish one’s nature. Now, one seeks to enrich the self with that which destroys it. If one could be without self, what need would there be for gold? To speak of being without self is not to destroy the self, but merely not to indulge it.

**Note:** In the *Daozang Sijie* edition, the word *"thus"* (因) appears after *"how"* (豈), likely in error.

**Lu Wenchang’s Note:** The word *"thing"* (物) in the note may be superfluous.

**Pei Jun’s Note:** Lu’s suggestion is uncertain. It is likely that *"the movements of the myriad things"* (萬物動之) should read *"the movements of the myriad things"* (萬物之動), with *"movements"* (動) and *"of"* (之) transposed.

**Phonetic Gloss:** *zhuó* (著), *zhíluè* (直略) cut. *bó* (泊), *hún* (魂) sound, meaning "tranquil and composed."

chunks.original_text: 列子集释　杨伯峻撰 列子集释卷第一 天瑞第一 〔注〕夫巨细舛错，修短殊性，虽天地之大，群品之众，涉于有生之分，关于动用之域者，存亡变化，自然之符。 夫唯寂然至虚凝一而不变者，非阴阳之所终始，四时之所迁革。 〔解〕夫群动之物，无不以生为主。 徒爱其生，不知生生之理。 生化者，有形也； 生生者，无象也。 有形谓之物，无象谓之神。 迹可用也，类乎阴阳。 论其真也，阴阳所不测。 故易曰：「阴阳不测之谓神。 」岂非天地之中大灵瑞也？ 故曰天瑞。 释文云：夫音符，是发语之端； 后更不音。 舛，昌兖切。 分，符问切； 下同。

*The Collected Annotations on the Liezi by Yang Bojun*
*Volume One: "Heavenly Portents" (Chapter One)*

[Annotation] Though vast and minute intermingle in disorder, though length of life and nature differ, even within the greatness of Heaven and Earth and the multitude of all beings—all that falls within the realm of living existence and enters the domain of activity and function—undergoes transformation between existence and decay as the natural tally of things. Only that which abides in absolute quiescence, ultimate emptiness, and undivided unity without change lies beyond the cycles of yin and yang or the revolutions of the four seasons.

[Exegesis] Among all moving things, none fails to take life as its master. Yet they cherish life without understanding the principle of life begetting life. That which undergoes generation and transformation possesses form; that which begets life is without image. What has form is called "thing"; what is without image is called "spirit." Its traces may be employed, akin to yin and yang. But when one discusses its true nature, it lies beyond the reckoning of yin and yang. Thus, the *Yijing* states: "That which yin and yang cannot fathom is called *shen*." Is this not the great numinous portent at the heart of Heaven and Earth? Hence, it is called "Heavenly Portents."

The *Explanations of the Text* note: *Fu* (夫) is pronounced *fú*, serving as the opening of a statement; this pronunciation is not repeated thereafter. *Chuǎn* (舛) is read as *chǎngyǎn*. *Fèn* (分) is read as *fúwèn*; the same applies below.

chunks.original_text: 子列子〔注〕载子于姓上者，首章或是弟子之所记故也。 释文云：冠子氏上者，着其为师也。 居郑圃，〔注〕郑有圃田。 释文云：圃音补。 圃田，郑之薮泽也，今在荥阳中牟县。 伯峻案：郑之圃田，一作甫田，见诗经、左传、尔雅诸书。 今河南中牟县西南之丈八沟及附近诸陂湖，皆其遗迹。 四十年人无识者。 〔注〕非形不与物接，言不与物交，不知其德之至，则同于不识者矣。 「无」，今从世德堂本、四解本作「无」，下同。 释文「无」或作亡。 国君卿大夫视之，犹众庶也。 〔注〕非自隔于物，直言无是非，行无轨迹，则物莫能知也。 行，下孟切。 国不足，〔注〕年饥。 将嫁于卫。 〔注〕自家而出谓之嫁。 〔解〕不足，年饥也。 嫁者，往也。 伯峻案：四库全书总目提要尔雅注疏云：「释诂云：『嫁，往也』，此取列子之文也。 」若如此，则列子在尔雅之前。 其实未必然，或今本列子有所因袭或列子袭尔雅也。 弟子曰：「先生往无反期，弟子敢有所谒； 〔解〕谒，请也。 释文云：谒，请也先生将何以教？ 先生不闻壶丘子林之言乎？ 」〔注〕壶丘子林，列子之师。 释文云：壶丘子林，司马彪注南华真经云，名林，郑人也。 子列子笑曰：「壶子何言哉？ 〔注〕四时行，百物生，岂假于言哉？ 仲父曰，论语，孔子曰：天何言哉？ 四时行焉，百物生焉，天何言哉？ 虽然，夫子尝语伯昏瞀人。 释文云：语，一本作诏； 诏，告也。 瞀，莫侯切； 后伯昏无人者亦音谋。 吾侧闻之，试以告女。 〔注〕伯昏，列子之友，同学于壶子。 不言自受教于壶子者，列子之谦者也。 卢文弨曰：张注「列子之谦者也」「者」字疑当作「言」。 释文云：女音汝。 其言曰：有生〔注〕今块然之形也。 释文云：块，口对切。 不生，〔注〕生物而不自生者也。 有化〔注〕今存亡变改也。 不化。 〔注〕化物而不自化者也。 〔解〕不因物生，不为物化，故能生于众生，化于群化者矣。 不生者能生生，〔注〕不生者，固生物之宗。 不化者能化化。 〔注〕不化者，固化物之主。 生者不能不生，化者不能不化。 〔注〕生者非能生而生，化者非能化而化也，直自不得不生、不得不化者也。 〔解〕凡有生则有死，为物化者常迁，安能无生无死、不化不迁哉？ 故常生常化。 〔注〕涉于有动之分者，不得暂无也。 常生常化者，无时不生，无时不化。 〔注〕生化相因，存亡复往，理无间也。 卢文弨曰：注「复往」二字当依后文乙正。 阴阳尔，四时尔，〔注〕阴阳四时，变化之物，而复属于有生之域者，皆随此陶运； 四时改而不停，万物化而不息者也。 〔解〕为阴阳所迁顺时转者，皆有形之物也。 念念迁化，生死无穷，故常生常化矣。 注「四时」下各本皆有「节」字，今依四解本删。 释文云：而复之复，扶又切。 不生者疑独，〔注〕不生之主，岂可实而验哉？ 疑其冥一而无始终也。 〔解〕神无方比，故称独也。 老子曰「独立而不改」也。 疑者不敢决言以明深妙者也。 注「不生之主」各本作「不生之生」。 不化者往复。 释文云：复依字音服。 后不音者，皆是入声。 往复，其际不可终； 〔注〕代谢无间，形气转续，其道不终。 世德堂本、藏本、北宋本皆不重「往复」两字。
chunks.translated_text:
Liezi—[Annotation:] Placing "Zi" before the surname indicates that the opening chapter may have been recorded by his disciples. *Shiwen* notes: Adding "Zi" to the surname signifies his status as a teacher.

He dwelt in the gardens of Zheng. [Annotation:] Zheng possessed the Pu Fields. *Shiwen* notes: *Pu* is pronounced *bǔ*. The Pu Fields were the marshes of Zheng, now located in Zhongmou County of Xingyang. Bo Jun observes: The Pu Fields of Zheng are also written as "Fu Fields" in the *Book of Songs*, *Zuozhuan*, and *Erya*. Today, the Zhangba Ditch and nearby lakes in southwest Zhongmou County, Henan, are their remnants.

For forty years, no one recognized him. [Annotation:] Without form, he did not engage with things; without speech, he did not interact with them. Those unaware of his utmost virtue were as if they did not know him at all. The character "無" (*wú*) here follows the *Shide Tang* edition and the *Four Explanations*; the same applies below. *Shiwen* notes: "無" is sometimes written as "亡."

The lord of the state, ministers, and grandees regarded him as one of the common people. [Annotation:] He did not isolate himself from things; rather, his words were free of right and wrong, his conduct left no trace, so things could not comprehend him. *Xíng* (行) is pronounced *xià* in the lower tone. The state suffered insufficiency. [Annotation:] A year of famine. He was to "marry out" to Wei. [Annotation:] To leave one’s home is called *jià* (嫁). [Explanation:] "Insufficiency" refers to a year of famine. *Jià* means "to go."

His disciples said: "Master, you depart without a set time for return. Your disciples dare to make a request—[Explanation:] *Yè* (谒) means "to request." *Shiwen* notes: *Yè* means "to request."—what teachings will you leave us? Have you not heard the words of Master Huqiu Zilin?" [Annotation:] Huqiu Zilin was Liezi’s teacher. *Shiwen* notes: Huqiu Zilin—*Sima Biao’s Commentary on the True Scripture of Southern Florescence* states his name was Lin, a native of Zheng.

Liezi laughed and said: "What words could Master Hu have? [Annotation:] The four seasons proceed, the myriad things are born—do these depend on words? As the *Lunyu* records Confucius saying: 'What does Heaven say? The four seasons proceed, the myriad things are born—what does Heaven say?' Yet the Master once spoke to Bohun Maoren. *Shiwen* notes: *Yǔ* (語) is also written as *zhào*; *zhào* means "to inform." *Mào* (瞀) is pronounced *mòhóu*; later, "Bohun Wu Ren" is also read as *móu*. I overheard it and shall try to tell you. [Annotation:] Bohun was Liezi’s friend, a fellow student under Master Hu. Not saying he received instruction directly from Master Hu reflects Liezi’s humility. Lu Wenchang notes: In Zhang’s annotation, "Liezi’s humility" may have an erroneous "者" (*zhě*) instead of "言" (*yán*). *Shiwen* notes: *Nǚ* (女) is pronounced *rǔ*.

His words were: There is *sheng* (生, arising)—[Annotation:] The present clod-like form. *Shiwen* notes: *Kuài* (块) is pronounced *kòuduì*.—yet not *sheng* (生, self-arising). [Annotation:] That which gives life to things yet does not arise itself. There is *hua* (化, transformation)—[Annotation:] The present state of existence, decay, change, and alteration.—yet not *hua* (化, self-transformation). [Annotation:] That which transforms things yet does not transform itself. [Explanation:] Not arising from things, not being transformed by things, it thus gives life to all living beings and transforms all transformations.

That which does not arise can give life to life. [Annotation:] That which does not arise is fundamentally the origin of living things. That which does not transform can transform transformation. [Annotation:] That which does not transform is fundamentally the master of transforming things. That which arises cannot but arise; that which transforms cannot but transform. [Annotation:] That which arises does not arise by its own power; that which transforms does not transform by its own power—it simply cannot but arise, cannot but transform. [Explanation:] All that has life must die; that which is transformed by things is ever-changing. How can it be without arising and perishing, without transformation and change? Thus, it is ever-arising, ever-transforming. [Annotation:] Those who enter the realm of movement and existence cannot be without it for a moment. That which is ever-arising and ever-transforming arises at all times and transforms at all times. [Annotation:] Arising and transformation follow one another; existence and decay alternate without cease—this principle is uninterrupted. Lu Wenchang notes: The characters "復往" (*fùwǎng*) in the annotation should be corrected according to later text.

It is yin and yang, it is the four seasons—[Annotation:] Yin and yang, the four seasons—things of change and transformation that yet belong to the realm of arising—all follow this shaping and movement. The four seasons change without ceasing; the myriad things transform without rest. [Explanation:] Those shifted by yin and yang and turning with the seasons are all things of form. Moment by moment they change; life and death are endless. Thus, they are ever-arising and ever-transforming. The character "節" (*jié*) after "四時" (*four seasons*) in all editions is deleted here following the *Four Explanations*.

That which does not arise is doubtfully solitary. [Annotation:] The master of non-arising—how can it be verified in reality? It is doubtfully darkly unified, without beginning or end. [Explanation:] The spirit has no direction or comparison; thus, it is called solitary. As Laozi says: "It stands alone and does not change." "Doubtfully" means not daring to speak decisively to clarify the profound and wondrous. The annotation "不生之主" (*master of non-arising*) in all editions is written as "不生之生" (*arising of non-arising*).

That which does not transform goes and returns. *Shiwen* notes: *Fù* (復) is pronounced *fú* in the standard reading; later instances not pronounced follow the entering tone. Going and returning—its bounds cannot be exhausted. [Annotation:] Alternation is uninterrupted; form and qi succeed one another—its Dao does not end. The *Shide Tang*, *Zang*, and *Northern Song* editions do not repeat the characters "往復" (*going and returning*).

chunks.original_text: 卢文弨曰：「往复」二字当迭。 陶鸿庆曰：张注云「代谢无间形气转续」正释往复之义，是其所见本未误。 王重民曰：卢陶二说是也。 吉府本正迭「往复」二字。 伯峻案：王说是也。 今从吉府本增。 疑独，其道不可穷。 〔注〕亦何以知其穷与不穷哉？ 直自疑其独立而不改，周行而不殆也。 〔解〕四时变易，不可终也； 神用变化，亦不可穷也。 陶鸿庆曰：疑者止也。 尔雅释言：疑，戾也。 郭注云：戾，止也。 疑者亦止。 诗桑柔，「靡所止疑」，孙卿解蔽篇「而无所疑止之」，皆与「止」连文，是疑与止同义。 此云疑独，亦谓止于独。 道德经所谓「天得一以清，地得一以宁」也。 张云「独立而不改」，正得其旨。 乃释「疑」为「疑惑」，望文生训，失之。 许维遹曰：疑读为拟，僭也，比也。 管子君臣篇云，「内有疑妻之妾，此宫乱也； 庶有疑适之子，此家乱也； 朝有疑相之臣，此国乱也」。 （吕氏春秋知度篇、慎子内篇文略同）韩非子说疑篇「疑」作「拟」。 又汉书食货志云「远方之能疑者」，颜师古注，「疑读为拟」。 并其证也。 此文「疑独」犹言「比独」，与下文「往复」相对为义。 仲父曰：终穷为韵，古音同在冬中部。 释文云：殆音待。 黄帝书曰：惠栋曰：此老子所述也。 老子之学盖本黄帝，故汉世称黄老。 释文云：黄帝姓公孙，名轩辕，得长生之道，在位一百年。 按汉书艺文志有黄帝书四篇，黄帝君臣一篇，黄帝铭六篇，与道家相类。 伯峻案：今本艺文志黄帝书作黄帝四经，黄帝君臣作十篇，班自注云，起六国时，与老相似也。 又有杂黄帝五十八篇，班自注云，六国时贤者所作。 谷神不死，〔注〕古有此书，今已不存。 夫谷虚而宅有，亦如庄子之称环中。 至虚无物，故谓谷神； 本自无生，故曰不死。 伯峻案：此老子第六章文。 是谓玄牝。 〔注〕老子有此一章，王弼注曰：「无形无影，无逆无违，处卑不动，守静不衰； 谷以之成而不见其形，此至物也。 处卑而不可得名，故谓之玄牝。 」俞正燮曰：牝者，古人以为溪谷； 所谓虚牝者，如今言空洞。 朱子语类云，「牝只是木孔受栒能受的物事。 元牝者，至妙之牝，不是那一样的牝。 」其言若即若离。 尝深思之，元者，白虎通五行篇云，元冥者，入冥也。 是元为入牝者。 唐律卫禁上释文云，有穴而可受入者为牝。 则元牝之为古语可知。 为表出之，儒者可勿复道矣。 伯峻案：张注所引老子王弼注曰「故谓之玄牝」，今本作「故谓之天地之根」。 释文「无影」作「无景」，云：牝，毗忍切。 景音影。 玄牝之门，是谓天地之根。 绵绵若存，用之不勤。 〔注〕王弼曰：「门，玄牝之所由也。 本其所由，与太极同体，故谓天地之根也。 欲言存邪？ 不见其形；
chunks.translated_text:
Lu Wenchao said: "The two characters 'going and returning' (*wangfu*) should be repeated." Tao Hongqing said: Zhang’s annotation—"Alternation is uninterrupted; form and qi succeed one another"—precisely explains the meaning of "going and returning," indicating that the version he saw was not in error. Wang Chongmin said: The arguments of Lu and Tao are both correct. The Jifu edition correctly repeats the two characters "going and returning." Bo Jun notes: Wang’s view is correct. Here, we follow the Jifu edition and add the repetition.

"Doubtfully solitary, its Dao cannot be exhausted." [Annotation:] How could one know whether it is exhaustible or not? One simply doubts its standing alone and not changing, its circling without peril. [Explanation:] The four seasons transform without end; the spirit’s function in change also cannot be exhausted.

Tao Hongqing said: "Doubt" means "to halt." The *Erya* explains: "Doubt (*yi*) means *li* (戾)." Guo’s annotation says: "*Li* means to halt. 'Doubt' also means to halt." The *Poem* "Sang Rou" says, "There is nowhere to halt in doubt," and Xunzi’s *Jiebi* chapter says, "with nothing to halt in doubt"—both pair "doubt" with "halt," showing they share the same meaning. Here, "doubtfully solitary" means halting in solitude. This aligns with the *Daodejing*’s "Heaven attains the One and becomes clear; Earth attains the One and becomes tranquil." Zhang’s "standing alone and not changing" precisely captures its essence. To gloss "doubt" as "doubtful hesitation" is to impose a meaning based on superficial resemblance, which is mistaken.

Xu Weiyu said: "Doubt" should be read as *ni* (拟), meaning "to usurp" or "to compare." The *Guanzi*’s "Junchen" chapter says: "Within the palace, if there are concubines who rival the wife, this is palace disorder; among the commoners, if there are sons who rival the heir, this is family disorder; in the court, if there are ministers who rival the prime minister, this is state disorder." (The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Zhidu" chapter and the *Shenzi*’s "Neipian" have similar passages.) The *Hanfeizi*’s "Shuoyi" chapter writes "doubt" as *ni*. The *Hanshu*’s "Shihuo Zhi" says, "Those from distant lands who can *ni*," and Yan Shigu’s annotation reads, "*Ni* is read as *ni*." These serve as evidence. Here, "doubtfully solitary" means "comparable to solitude," forming a paired meaning with the following "going and returning."

Zhongfu said: "End" (*qiong*) and "exhaust" (*qiong*) rhyme, both belonging to the *dong* rhyme group in ancient pronunciation.

*Shiwen* notes: "*Dai* (殆) is pronounced *dai*."

The *Book of the Yellow Emperor* says: Hui Dong said: This was recorded by Laozi. Laozi’s learning was likely based on the Yellow Emperor, hence the Han dynasty’s term "Huang-Lao." *Shiwen* notes: The Yellow Emperor’s surname was Gongsun, his given name Xuanyuan. He attained the Dao of longevity and reigned for a hundred years. According to the *Hanshu Yiwenzhi*, there were four chapters of the *Book of the Yellow Emperor*, one chapter of *The Yellow Emperor and His Ministers*, and six chapters of *Inscriptions of the Yellow Emperor*, all classified under Daoist works.

Bo Jun notes: In the current *Yiwenzhi*, *The Book of the Yellow Emperor* is titled *The Four Classics of the Yellow Emperor*, and *The Yellow Emperor and His Ministers* is ten chapters. Ban’s self-annotation says: "Originated during the Warring States period, similar to Laozi." There are also fifty-eight chapters of *Miscellaneous Writings of the Yellow Emperor*, with Ban’s self-annotation: "Composed by worthies of the Warring States period."

"The valley spirit does not die," [Annotation:] This book existed in ancient times but is now lost. The valley is empty yet contains a dwelling, much like Zhuangzi’s "ring center." Utterly empty and without substance, it is called the valley spirit; inherently without arising, it is said not to die.

Bo Jun notes: This is the sixth chapter of the *Laozi*.

"This is called the Mysterious Female." [Annotation:] The *Laozi* contains this chapter. Wang Bi’s commentary says: "Without form or shadow, without opposition or resistance, abiding in lowliness without movement, guarding stillness without decline—through this the valley is perfected yet its form is unseen. This is the supreme entity. Dwelling in lowliness and beyond naming, it is called the Mysterious Female."

Yu Zhengxie said: "Female" (*pin*) was understood by the ancients as a ravine or valley; the so-called "empty female" is akin to what we now call a hollow cavity. Zhu Xi’s *Yulei* says: "The female is merely the receptive aperture in wood, like a mortise. The Mysterious Female is the most wondrous female, not the same as that particular female." His words seem to approach yet depart from the meaning. Upon deep reflection, *yuan* (元) in the *Baihu Tong*’s "Wuxing" chapter means "to enter darkness." Thus, *yuan* signifies entering the female. The *Shiwen* of the Tang *Lü*’s "Weijin Shang" explains: "That which has an aperture and can receive entry is called the female." That *yuanpin* was an ancient expression is thus evident. To make this explicit is to spare Confucians further discussion.

Bo Jun notes: The *Laozi* passage Zhang’s annotation cites—"hence it is called the Mysterious Female"—in the current Wang Bi edition reads, "hence it is called the root of Heaven and Earth." *Shiwen* writes "without shadow" as "without *jing*" (景), and notes: "*Pin* is pronounced *piren*. *Jing* is read as *ying*."

"The gateway of the Mysterious Female is called the root of Heaven and Earth. Subtly continuous as if existing, its use is inexhaustible." [Annotation:] Wang Bi said: "The gateway is the means by which the Mysterious Female operates. Tracing its origin, it shares the same body as the Great Ultimate, hence it is called the root of Heaven and Earth. Does one wish to speak of its existence? Yet its form is not seen."

"Does one wish to speak of its absence? Yet the myriad things arise through it, hence it is said to be 'subtly continuous as if existing.' No thing is completed without it, yet it does not toil, hence it is said to be 'inexhaustible.'"

[Exegesis:] The valley is empty, and qi resides within it; the form is hollow, and spirit abides within. "Mysterious" denotes the wondrous without form; "female" denotes responsiveness without fixed direction. Emerging into life and entering death, nothing does not depend upon it, hence it is called the "gateway." It is the root of the formed, hence it is called the "root." Though unseen when sought, its use is boundless, hence it is said to be "as if existing."

The exegesis of "mysterious" appears as "primordial" in the Qin stele. During the Kangxi reign of the Qing, it was likely altered to avoid the emperor’s personal name, Xuanye. Here, the text follows the corrected version of the *Four Exegeses*.

Xu Weiyu notes: *Qin* should be glossed as "exhaust." The *Huainanzi*, "Yuan Dao Xun," states: "So subtle as to be inexhaustible," where Gao You comments: "*Qin* means exhaust." In the same chapter, "its use is inexhaustible," Gao again comments: "*Qin* means toil," mistakenly aligning with Zhang’s annotation.

Zhongfu observes: "Female," "gateway," "root," and "inexhaustible" form a rhyme, all sharing the same ancient sound in the *hun-gen* rhyme group.

*Shiwen* notes: *Mian* is pronounced *wuyan*. *Xie* is read as *yizhe*; the same applies below.

chunks.original_text: 故生物者不生，化物者不化。 〔注〕庄子亦有此言。 向秀注曰：吾之生也，非吾之所生，则生自生耳。 生生者岂有物哉？ 故不生也。 吾之化也，非物之所化，则化自化耳。 化化者岂有物哉？ 无物也，故不化焉。 若使生物者亦生，化物者亦化，则与物俱化，亦奚异于物？ 明夫不生不化者，然后能为生化之本也。 〔解〕此神为生之主，能生物化物，无物能生化之者。 王叔岷曰：注「故不生也。 」「故」上疑捝「无物也」三字。 「无物也，故不生也」与下文「无物也，故不化焉」相对而言。 释文云：向秀，向音饷，字子期，晋常侍，注南华真经二十八篇。 自生自化，自形自色，自智自力，自消自息。 〔注〕皆自尔耳，岂有尸而为之者哉？ 仲父曰：色力息为韵，古音同在职德部。 谓之生化形色智力消息者，非也。 」〔注〕若有心于生化形色，则岂能官天地而府万物，赡群生而不遗乎？ 〔解〕神之独运，非物能使； 若因情滞有同物生化，皆非道也。 俞樾曰：「谓」当作「为」，古书「谓」「为」通用，说详王氏引之经传释词。 上文云「自生自化，自形自色，自智自力。 自消自息」，故此云「为之生化形色智力消息者非也」。 张湛注上文云，「皆自尔耳，岂有尸而为之者哉」，正得其义。 陶鸿庆曰：俞氏平议读谓为为，非也。 谓读如道德经「同谓之元」之谓，此言万物根于无形，无形则无名，而强为之名者非矣。 下文子列子曰「非其名也」，注云，「事有实着，非假名而后得也」，正合此旨。 读谓为为，义反浅矣。 伯峻案：注「赡群生而不遗乎」，「赡」藏本、宋本、四解本皆作「瞻」，释文世德堂本皆作「赡」，作「赡」者是也。 说文「瞻，临视也」。 又新附，「赡，给也。 」孟子公孙丑篇注云：「赡，足也。 」此当训给训足。 又「遗」，释文及世德堂本作「匮」，作「遗」者是也。 其意谓若有心生化，则必有所偏； 今官天地府万物而无所遗失，则知是自生自化，非被生被化。 俞读谓为为，其义较顺。 陶驳疑未审。 释文「智」作「知」，「遗」作为「匮」，云：知音智，下同。 赡，时艳切。 匮音馈，竭也。 子列子曰：「昔者圣人因阴阳以统天地。 〔注〕天地者，举形而言； 阴阳者，明其度数统理。 〔解〕夫有形之物，皆有所生以运行之； 举其所大者，天地也。 运天地者，阴阳也。 阴阳，气之所变，无质无形； 天地因之以见生杀也。 阴阳易辩，神识难明，借此以喻彼，以为其例，然后知神以制形，无以有其生也。 夫有形者生于无形，〔注〕谓之生者，则不无； 无者，则不生。 故有无之不相生，理既然矣，则有何由而生？ 忽尔而自生。 忽尔而自生，而不知其所以生； 不知所以生，生则本同于无。 本同于无，而非无也。 此明有形之自形，无形以相形者也。 注「谓之生者则不无」，「无」世德堂本作「死」，盖因「无」「死」形近，又涉生字义而误。 则天地安从生？ 〔注〕天地无所从生，而自然生。 〔解〕天地，形之大者也。 阴阳者，非神识也。 有形若生于无形者，天地岂有神识心性乎？ 若其无者，从何而生耶？ 假设此问者，将明万物者有生也。 注「而自然生」御览一引作「自然而生」。 故曰：有太易，有太初，有太始，有太素。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, that which gives life does not itself live, and that which transforms does not itself transform.

**[Annotation]** *Zhuangzi* also contains this saying. Xiang Xiu’s commentary states: My life is not something I myself give life to—life simply arises of itself. How could that which gives life to life be a thing? Thus, it does not live. My transformation is not something things transform—transformation simply transforms of itself. How could that which transforms transformation be a thing? It is no-thing, and thus does not transform. If that which gives life were itself to live, and that which transforms were itself to transform, then it would transform along with things—how would it differ from them? Only by being neither born nor transformed can it serve as the root of life and transformation.

**[Exegesis]** This spirit is the master of life, able to give life to and transform things, while nothing can give life to or transform it.

Wang Shumin notes: In the annotation, "Thus, it does not live" likely omits three characters above *gu* 故 ("thus"), reading: "It is no-thing, and thus does not live," to parallel the following: "It is no-thing, and thus does not transform."

**[Pronunciation Notes]** Xiang Xiu: *Xiang* is pronounced *Xiang* (as in *xiang* 饷), courtesy name Ziqī, Jin dynasty Attendant-in-Ordinary, who annotated twenty-eight chapters of the *True Scripture of Southern Florescence*.

Life arises of itself, transformation occurs of itself, form takes shape of itself, color appears of itself, wisdom emerges of itself, strength manifests of itself, dissolution happens of itself, and cessation comes of itself.

**[Annotation]** All these occur spontaneously—how could there be an agent that enacts them?

Zhongfu observes: *Color* 色, *strength* 力, and *cessation* 息 rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *zhi-de* rhyme group.

To call it the giver of life, transformation, form, color, wisdom, strength, dissolution, and cessation would be mistaken.

**[Annotation]** If one were to harbor intent regarding life, transformation, form, or color, how could one govern heaven and earth, store the myriad things, and provide for all beings without omission?

**[Exegesis]** The spirit moves alone, unconstrained by things. If, bound by emotion, one were to equate it with the life and transformation of things, this would not be the Dao.

Yu Yue states: *Wei* 谓 ("to call") should be *wei* 為 ("to be"), as *wei* 谓 and *wei* 為 are interchangeable in ancient texts, as explained in Wang Yinzhi’s *Exegeses of Classical and Historical Words*. The preceding text reads: "Life arises of itself, transformation occurs of itself, form takes shape of itself, color appears of itself, wisdom emerges of itself, strength manifests of itself, dissolution happens of itself, and cessation comes of itself." Thus, this should read: "To *be* the giver of life, transformation, form, color, wisdom, strength, dissolution, and cessation would be mistaken." Zhang Zhan’s annotation to the preceding text—"All these occur spontaneously—how could there be an agent that enacts them?"—correctly captures its meaning.

Tao Hongqing states: Yu Yue’s *Pingyi* ("Level Discussions") reading of *wei* 谓 as *wei* 為 is incorrect. *Wei* 谓 here follows the usage in the *Daodejing*: "Those of the same *wei* 謂 are called obscure," meaning that the myriad things root in the formless, and the formless has no name—thus, to forcibly name it would be mistaken. The following passage, where Liezi states, "It is not their name," with the annotation, "Things have tangible reality, not merely names by which they are known," aligns precisely with this principle. Reading *wei* 謂 as *wei* 為 renders the meaning shallow.

Bo Jun notes: In the annotation, "provide for all beings without omission," the *Zang* 藏, *Song* 宋, and *Four Exegeses* editions all write *zhan* 瞻 ("to gaze"), while the *Shiwen* 世德堂 edition of the *Pronunciation Notes* writes *shan* 赡 ("to provide"). The latter is correct. The *Shuowen* defines *zhan* 瞻 as "to look down upon," while its later supplement defines *shan* 赡 as "to supply." The *Mengzi* *Gongsun Chou* chapter’s annotation glosses *shan* 赡 as "sufficiency." Here, it should mean "to supply" or "to suffice." The character *yi* 遗 ("omission") in the *Pronunciation Notes* and *Shiwen* edition is written as *kui* 匮 ("exhaustion"), but *yi* 遗 is correct. The meaning is: if one were to harbor intent regarding life and transformation, there would inevitably be bias. Now, governing heaven and earth and storing the myriad things without omission shows that these arise and transform of themselves, not through being given life or transformed. Yu Yue’s reading of *wei* 謂 as *wei* 為 yields a smoother meaning. Tao’s refutation is unfounded.

**[Pronunciation Notes]** *Zhi* 智 is written as *zhi* 知 ("wisdom"), and *yi* 遗 is written as *kui* 匮 ("exhaustion"). *Shan* 赡 is pronounced *shi yan* 時艷. *Kui* 匮 is pronounced *kui* 馈, meaning "exhaustion."

Master Liezi said: "In ancient times, the sages relied on yin and yang to govern heaven and earth."

**[Annotation]** Heaven and earth refer to form in general; yin and yang clarify their measures, order, and governance.

**[Exegesis]** All things with form have that which gives them life and moves them. The greatest of these are heaven and earth. That which moves heaven and earth is yin and yang. Yin and yang are transformations of qi, without substance or form. Heaven and earth manifest life and death through them. Yin and yang are easy to distinguish, but the spirit’s discernment is difficult to clarify. Using these as analogies for that establishes the pattern, revealing that the spirit governs form, and nothing gives life to it.

That which has form is born from that which has no form.

**[Annotation]** To call it "born" is not to say it is not without; to call it "without" is not to say it is not born. Thus, the mutual non-birth of being and non-being is a principle that is already so—how then could being arise? It suddenly arises of itself. Arising suddenly of itself, it does not know why it arises. Not knowing why it arises, its arising is fundamentally identical to non-being. Fundamentally identical to non-being, yet it is not non-being. This clarifies that the self-arising of form does not rely on the formless to give it form.

**[Annotation]** In "To call it 'born' is not to say it is not without," the *Shiwen* edition writes *wu* 無 ("without") as *si* 死 ("death"), likely due to the graphic similarity of *wu* 無 and *si* 死, compounded by the semantic association with *sheng* 生 ("life").

Then how could heaven and earth arise?

**[Annotation]** Heaven and earth have no source from which they arise—they arise naturally.

**[Exegesis]** Heaven and earth are the greatest of forms. Yin and yang are not spirit or discernment. If that which has form were born from that which has no form, would heaven and earth possess spirit, discernment, mind, or nature? If they are without these, from what could they arise? This hypothetical question aims to clarify that the myriad things have that which gives them life.

**[Annotation]** In "they arise naturally," the *Taiping Yulan* quotes this as "they arise of themselves."

chunks.original_text: 〔注〕此明物之自微至着，变化之相因袭也。 注文御览一引作「此明有物始之自微至着变化自相因袭也」。 释文「太」作「大」，云：大音太，下同。 太易者，未见气也； 〔注〕易者，不穷滞之称。 凝寂于太虚之域，将何所见耶？ 如易系之太极，老氏之浑成也。 注「何所见耶」，「耶」北宋本、四解本作「即」，属下句读； 世德堂本作「也」。 释文「浑」作「混」，云：见，贤遍切，注同。 称，尺证切，下同。 系，胡计切。 混，胡本切。 任大椿曰：山海经「浑敦无面目」，庄子「混沌为倏忽所凿」，浑敦即混沌。 汉书刘向传「贤不肖浑淆」，浑读为混，则混浑通。 太初者，气之始也； 〔注〕阴阳未判，即下句所谓浑沦也。 太始者，形之始也； 〔注〕阴阳既判，则品物流形也。 太素者，质之始也。 〔注〕质，性也。 既为物矣，则方员刚柔，静躁沈浮，各有其性。 气形质具而未相离，〔注〕此直论气形质，不复说太易； 太易为三者宗本，于后句别自明之也。 路史前纪一引「气」下有「与」字。 释文云：离，力智切，去也。 或作平声读。 近曰离，远曰别，后以意求之也。 别，彼列切。 故曰浑沦。 释文云：浑音魂，沦音论，下同。 浑沦者，言万物相浑沦而未相离也。 〔注〕虽浑然一气不相离散，而三才之道实潜兆乎其中。 沦，语之助也。 释文云：散，先汗切，卷内同。 视之不见，听之不闻，循之不得，故曰易也。 王重民曰：循当读如揗。 说文：揗，摩也。 汉书高帝纪，「因拊其背」。 颜注，「拊谓摩揗之也」。 后拊揗字皆作循。 史记晋世家「子反收余兵，拊循欲复战」，汉书赵充国传「拊循和辑」是也。 揗，正字； 循，假字。 释文云：循音旬。 易无形埒，〔注〕不知此下一字。 老子曰，「视之不见名曰希」，而此曰易，易亦希简之别称也。 太易之义如此而已，故能为万化宗主、冥一而不变者也。 「埒」，北宋本作「□」，汪本作「□」，今从四解本改正。 释文「埒」作「□」，云：淮南子作形埒，谓兆朕也； 干凿度作形□。 今从乎者转谓误也。 任大椿曰：淮南子本经训「合气化物，以成埒类」，高诱注「埒，形也。 」要略训「形埒之兆」，穆称训「道之有篇章形埒者」，兵略训「夫有形埒者，天下公见之」，凡形埒字皆作埒。 说文、玉篇、广韵有埒字，无□字； 类篇有□字，云，「耕田起土也」。 与「王耕一」之同意。 「埒」「□」异义，埒之作□，盖假借字。 又敬顺释文云，「今从乎者，转谓误也」，考淮南子要略训「嬴垀有无之情」，类篇「垀，埒也」，即敬顺所谓从乎者也。 垀之义同乎，埒则从乎，义自可通，而敬顺云转谓误也，未详其说。 易变而为一，〔注〕所谓易者，窈冥惚恍，不可变也； 一气恃之而化，故寄名变耳。 注「恃之」御览一引「恃」作「持」。 释文「恍」作「怳」，云，自一经九，大衍之数。 惚音忽。 怳，况往切。 一变而为七，七变而为九。 九变者，究也； 〔注〕究，穷也。 一变而为七九，不以次数者，全举阳数，领其都会。 胡怀琛曰：张注不甚明了。 中国数目系统，或曰，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 语见老子。 或曰，一而二，二生四，四生八。 所谓太极、两仪、四象、八卦是也。
chunks.translated_text:
Here the text clarifies how things evolve from the subtle to the manifest, with transformations following one another in succession. The *Taiping Yulan* quotes the annotation as: "This clarifies how things begin from the subtle to the manifest, with transformations naturally following one another in succession."

The *Shiwen* notes that "太" is written as "大," reading *dà* as *tài*, and the same applies below.

**Great Simplicity (太易)** is the state before qi is visible.
**[Annotation]** *Yi* (易) signifies that which is unbound and unobstructed. Congealed in the realm of the Great Void, what could be perceived there? It is like the *Taiji* in the *Yi Jing* or the "primordial unity" of Laozi.
**[Annotation]** In the phrase "what could be perceived," the character "耶" in the Northern Song edition and *Sijie* is written as "即," attaching to the following sentence; the *Shide Tang* edition writes "也."
**[Shiwen]** "浑" is written as "混," reading *hún* as *hùn*. *See* (见) is pronounced *xiàn* (贤遍切), and the same applies in the annotation. *Chēng* (称) is pronounced *chèng* (尺证切), and the same applies below. *Xì* (系) is pronounced *jì* (胡计切). *Hùn* (混) is pronounced *hún* (胡本切).
Ren Dachun notes: The *Shan Hai Jing* speaks of "Hundun without face or eyes," and *Zhuangzi* says, "Hundun was drilled by Shu and Hu," where *Hundun* (浑敦) is *Hundun* (混沌). In the *Han Shu*, Liu Xiang’s biography reads "the worthy and unworthy are mixed and confused," where *hùn* (浑) is read as *hún* (混), showing that *hùn* and *hún* are interchangeable.

**Great Beginning (太初)** is the inception of qi.
**[Annotation]** Before yin and yang separate, this is what the following sentence calls "primordial chaos" (*hunlun*).

**Great Inception (太始)** is the inception of form.
**[Annotation]** Once yin and yang have separated, the myriad things flow into form.

**Great Simplicity (太素)** is the inception of substance.
**[Annotation]** *Zhi* (质) means nature. Once things exist, they possess square or round, hard or soft, still or restless, sinking or floating qualities—each with its own nature.

When qi, form, and substance are all present but not yet separated—
**[Annotation]** This directly discusses qi, form, and substance, no longer mentioning the Great Simplicity. The Great Simplicity is the origin of these three, which will be clarified in the following sentence.
The *Lushi Qianji* includes the character "与" after "气."
**[Shiwen]** *Lí* (离) is pronounced *lì* (力智切), meaning "to separate." Some read it in the level tone. "Near" is called *lí* (离), "far" is called *bié* (别); the rest may be inferred by analogy. *Bié* (别) is pronounced *bǐngliè* (彼列切).

—it is called **primordial chaos (浑沦)**.
**[Shiwen]** *Hún* (浑) is pronounced *hún* (魂), *lún* (沦) is pronounced *lún* (论), and the same applies below.

**Primordial chaos (浑沦)** means the myriad things are intermingled yet not separated.
**[Annotation]** Though they form a single undifferentiated qi without dispersion, the Dao of the Three Powers is already latent within it. *Lún* (沦) is a grammatical particle.
**[Shiwen]** *Sàn* (散) is pronounced *sǎn* (先汗切), and the same applies throughout the volume.

It cannot be seen, heard, or grasped by tracing—hence it is called *yi* (易).
Wang Chongmin notes: *Xún* (循) should be read as *tún* (揗). The *Shuowen* defines *tún* as "to rub." The *Han Shu*’s *Annals of Emperor Gao* reads, "thereupon he patted his back," with Yan Shigu’s annotation: "*Fǔ* (拊) means to rub and stroke." Later, *fǔtún* (拊揗) was written as *xún* (循). Examples include the *Shiji*’s *Hereditary House of Jin*: "Zifan gathered the remaining troops, patting and encouraging them to fight again," and the *Han Shu*’s *Biography of Zhao Chongguo*: "patting and soothing to harmonize and unite." *Tún* is the original character; *xún* is the loan character.
**[Shiwen]** *Xún* (循) is pronounced *xún* (旬).

The *Yi* has no form or boundary—
**[Annotation]** The character following this is unknown. Laozi says, "That which cannot be seen is called *xi* (希)," while here it is called *yi* (易). *Yi* is another name for simplicity and subtlety.
The meaning of the Great Simplicity is thus: it serves as the origin of all transformations, remaining obscurely unified and unchanging.
**[Annotation]** In the Northern Song edition, "埒" is written as "□"; Wang’s edition also writes "□." Here, it is corrected following the *Sijie* edition.
**[Shiwen]** "埒" is written as "□," noting: The *Huainanzi* writes "form and boundary," meaning signs and omens. The *Qianzao Du* writes "form □." The current reading follows the character *hū* (乎), which is considered an error.
Ren Dachun notes: The *Huainanzi*’s *Benjing Xun* reads, "Qi coalesces to transform things, forming boundaries and categories," with Gao You’s annotation: "*Liè* (埒) means form." The *Yaolüe Xun* reads, "signs of form and boundary," the *Muzheng Xun* reads, "those with chapters, form, and boundary," and the *Binglüe Xun* reads, "those with form and boundary are publicly visible in the world." In all cases, *liè* (埒) is written as *liè* (埒). The *Shuowen*, *Yupian*, and *Guangyun* include *liè* but not *□*; the *Leipian* includes *□*, defining it as "to raise earth while plowing," sharing the same meaning as "the king plows once." *Liè* (埒) and *□* have different meanings; *liè* written as *□* is a loan character.
Jing Shun’s *Shiwen* states: "Now following *hū* (乎) is considered an error." Examining the *Huainanzi*’s *Yaolüe Xun*: "Yínghū (嬴垀) embodies the nature of being and non-being," where the *Leipian* defines *hū* (垀) as *liè* (埒)—this is what Jing Shun refers to as "following *hū*." The meaning of *hū* (垀) is the same as *hū* (乎), and *liè* (埒) derives from *hū* (乎), so the meaning is naturally coherent. Yet Jing Shun calls it an error—his reasoning is unclear.

The *Yi* transforms into the One—
**[Annotation]** The so-called *yi* is profound and indistinct, beyond transformation. Qi relies on it to transform, so it is provisionally named "transformation."
The *Taiping Yulan* quotes the annotation with "恃" written as "持."
**[Shiwen]** *Huǎng* (恍) is written as *huǎng* (怳), noting: From the One through the Nine, these are the numbers of the *Dayan*.
*Hū* (惚) is pronounced *hū* (忽). *Huǎng* (怳) is pronounced *kuàngwǎng* (况往切).

—one transforms into seven, seven transforms into nine. Nine transformations are the culmination.
**[Annotation]** *Jiū* (究) means "to exhaust." The transformation from one to seven and nine does not follow sequential numbers; rather, it fully presents the yang numbers to encompass their convergence.
Hu Huaichen notes: Zhang’s annotation is not entirely clear. The Chinese numerical system states either: "One generates two, two generates three, three generates the myriad things" (as in the *Laozi*), or "one becomes two, two generates four, four generates eight" (as in the *Taiji*, Two Modes, Four Images, and Eight Trigrams).

chunks.original_text: 说见易系辞。 一一变七，七变九，其说出周易干凿度。 （张注有「此章全是周易干凿度」云云。 ）然一变七，七变九，其理终不可解。 释文云：数，色主切乃复变而为一。 俞樾曰：上「变」字衍文，本作「九者究也，乃复变而为一」。 因涉上文「一变七变」而误为「九变」，则于词赘矣。 孙诒让曰：此章与易纬干凿度文同。 「九变者究也」纬作「九者气变之究也」，与下「一者形变之始也」文正相对，此书当亦与彼同。 今本变字误移着者字上，又脱气之二字耳。 王重民曰：孙说是也。 御览一引作「九变者之究也」，亦有舛误。 盖御览所据本已脱气字，又因「一变七变」而误移变字于者上，后人以之字为赘，遂以意削之也。 幸所引尚存之字，足证列子原文当同于易纬。 俞氏以变字为衍文，误矣。 王叔岷曰：孙说是也。 法苑珠林七引作「九者变之究也」，仅捝一气字。 释文「乃」作「乃」，云：乃古乃字。 一者，形变之始也。 〔注〕既涉于有形之域，理数相推，自一之九。 九数既终，乃复反而为一。 反而为一，归于形变之始。 此盖明变化往复无穷极。 清轻者上为天，释文云：上，时掌切。 浊重者下为地，〔注〕天地何耶，直虚实清浊之自分判者耳。 此一章全是周易干凿度也。 文选潘安仁西征赋注引「清轻」「浊重」作「轻清」「重浊」。 冲和气者为人； 文选西征赋注引作「冲和之气」。 陶鸿庆曰：冲读为中。 文子九守篇「故三皇、五帝有戒之器，命曰侑卮，其冲即正，其盈即覆」。 冲即中也。 又精诚篇「执冲含和」，淮南泰族训冲作中，皆冲中通用之证。 中与上文「上为天，下为地」相对成义。 中和气者，宅和气之中也。 文子上德篇云：「万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和，和居中央」，义与此同。 故天地含精，万物化生。 〔注〕推此言之，则阴阳气遍交会而气和，气和而为人生； 人生则有所倚而立也。 〔解〕一三五七九，阳之数也。 极则反一，运行无穷。 易曰，「本乎天者亲上，本乎地者亲下」。 亲下者，草本之类是也； 亲上者，含识之类是也。 故动物有神，植物无识。 无识者为气所变，有神者为识所迁，故云太易太初以至浑沦，言气之渐也。 其中精粹者，谓之为神。 神气精微者为贤为圣，神气杂浊者为凡为愚，乃至含生差别，则多品矣。 仲父曰：易系辞下云：「男女媾精，阴阳化生」。 伯峻案：解所引易，见干文言。 又精、生为韵，古音同在庚青部。

The explanation can be found in the *Appended Judgments* of the *Book of Changes*. The statement that "one transforms into seven, seven transforms into nine" originates from the *Qian Zaodu* of the *Weft of the Changes*.

*(Zhang’s annotation includes: "This entire chapter is from the *Qian Zaodu* of the *Weft of the Changes*.")*

However, the principle behind "one transforming into seven, seven transforming into nine" remains ultimately inexplicable. The *Shiwen* notes: "*Shu* (数) is pronounced *sèzhǔ* (色主切). It then transforms again into one."

Yu Yue states: The first "*bian* (变, transform)" is superfluous text. Originally, it read: "Nine is the culmination of *qi* transformation, which then reverts to one." Due to the influence of the preceding phrase "one transforms, seven transforms," it was mistakenly written as "nine transformations," rendering the wording redundant.

Sun Yirang says: This chapter aligns with the text of the *Qian Zaodu* in the *Weft of the Changes*. In the *Weft*, "Nine is the culmination of *qi* transformation" corresponds precisely with the subsequent phrase "One is the beginning of form transformation." In this text, the character *bian* (变) was erroneously transposed above *zhe* (者), and the two characters *qi zhi* (气之) were omitted.

Wang Chongmin says: Sun’s interpretation is correct. The *Taiping Imperial Encyclopedia* cites it as "Nine transformations are the culmination," which also contains errors. The edition consulted by the *Imperial Encyclopedia* had already omitted the character *qi* (气) and, influenced by "one transforms, seven transforms," mistakenly moved *bian* (变) above *zhe* (者). Later scholars, deeming *zhi* (之) redundant, arbitrarily deleted it. Fortunately, the preserved *zhi* (之) in the citation suffices to prove that the original text of the *Liezi* matched that of the *Weft of the Changes*. Yu Yue’s claim that *bian* (变) is superfluous is incorrect.

Wang Shumin says: Sun’s interpretation is correct. The *Dharma Garden Pearl Forest*, Volume 7, cites it as "Nine is the culmination of transformation," omitting only the character *qi* (气). The *Shiwen* writes *nai* (乃) as *nai* (乃), noting: *Nai* (乃) is an ancient form of *nai* (乃).

One is the beginning of form transformation.
**[Annotation]** Once entering the realm of form, principle and number mutually evolve, proceeding from one to nine. When the nine numbers reach their end, they revert to one. Reverting to one returns to the beginning of form transformation. This illustrates that transformations and changes recur endlessly without limit.

What is pure and light ascends to become Heaven.
*(The *Shiwen* notes: "Ascends" is pronounced *shízhǎng* (时掌切).)*

What is turbid and heavy descends to become Earth.
**[Annotation]** What are Heaven and Earth? They are simply the self-differentiation of emptiness and fullness, purity and turbidity.

*(The *Wen Xuan* commentary on Pan Anren’s "Western Expedition Rhapsody" cites "pure and light" and "turbid and heavy" as "light and pure" and "heavy and turbid.")*

What is harmonious *qi* becomes Human.
*(The *Wen Xuan* commentary on the "Western Expedition Rhapsody" cites this as "harmonious *qi*.")*

Tao Hongqing says: *Chong* (冲) should be read as *zhong* (中). The *Nine Safeguards* chapter of the *Wenzi* states: "Thus, the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors had vessels of admonition called *youzhi*, whose *chong* (冲) was upright; when full, they overturned." *Chong* (冲) here means *zhong* (中). Furthermore, the *Sincerity* chapter reads: "Grasping the *chong* (冲) and embracing harmony," while the *Tai Zu* chapter of the *Huainanzi* writes *chong* (冲) as *zhong* (中), both demonstrating the interchangeability of *chong* (冲) and *zhong* (中). This aligns with the preceding "ascends to become Heaven, descends to become Earth," forming a coherent meaning. *Zhonghe qi* (中和气) refers to dwelling in the center of harmonious *qi*. The *Superior Virtue* chapter of the *Wenzi* states: "The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang, with harmonious *qi* residing in the center," which conveys the same meaning.

Thus, Heaven and Earth contain essence, and the myriad things transform and come into being.
**[Annotation]** Extending this reasoning, when yin and yang *qi* universally intermingle and harmonize, harmonious *qi* gives rise to human life. Human life thus has a foundation upon which to stand.

**[Exegesis]** One, three, five, seven, and nine are the numbers of yang. When they reach their extreme, they revert to one, circulating endlessly. The *Book of Changes* states: "That which is rooted in Heaven inclines upward; that which is rooted in Earth inclines downward." What inclines downward comprises grasses and trees; what inclines upward comprises sentient beings. Thus, animals possess spirit, while plants lack consciousness. Those without consciousness are transformed by *qi*; those with spirit are shifted by consciousness. Hence, it is said: From *Taiyi* and *Taichu* to *Hunlun*, this describes the gradual progression of *qi*. Within it, the most refined and essential is called *shen* (spirit). Those with refined and subtle *shen* and *qi* become worthy or sagely; those with mixed and turbid *shen* and *qi* become ordinary or foolish. Even among living beings, distinctions abound, resulting in manifold classifications.

Zhongfu says: The *Appended Judgments* of the *Book of Changes* states: "When male and female unite their essence, yin and yang transform and give birth."

*(Bo Jun notes: The *Exegesis* cites the *Book of Changes* from the *Wenyan* commentary. Additionally, *jing* (精, essence) and *sheng* (生, birth) rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *geng-qing* rhyme group.)*

Hu Huaichen notes: Zhang’s annotation is not entirely clear. The Chinese numerical system states either: "One generates two, two generates three, three generates the myriad things" (as in the *Laozi*), or "one becomes two, two generates four, four generates eight" (as in the *Taiji*, Two Modes, Four Images, and Eight Trigrams).

chunks.original_text: 释文云：倚，于绮切。 子列子曰：「天地无全功，圣人无全能，万物无全用。 〔注〕全犹备也。 故天职生覆，地职形载，圣职教化，物职所宜。 〔注〕职，主也。 生各有性，性各有所宜者也。 然则天有所短，地有所长，圣有所否，释文作「天地所否」，云，否，蒲鄙切，塞也物有所通。 〔注〕夫体适于一方者，造余涂则阂矣。 王弼曰：「形必有所分，声必有所属； 若温也，则不能凉； 若宫也，则不能商。 」仲父曰：群书治要引「体」作「职」，「阂」作「罔」。 伯峻案：庄子天下篇述彭蒙、田骈、慎到之言曰：「天能覆之而不能载之，地能载之而不能覆之，大道能包之而不能辩之； 知万物皆有所可，有所不可」，亦即此意，而其所从言不同，故结论各异矣。 释文云：造，七到切。 阂音碍。 属音烛。 何则？ 生覆者不能形载，形载者不能教化，教化者不能违所宜，〔注〕顺之则通也。 宜定者不出所位。 〔注〕皆有素分，不可逆也。 伯峻案：「不出所位」不下疑脱「能」字。 「不能出所位」与「不能形载」等三句句法一律。 下句「不能出所位者也」，有能字，可证。 张注云云，似其所见本尚未误捝。 释文云：分，符问切，下「名分」「形分」同。 故天地之道，非阴则阳； 圣人之教，非仁则义； 万物之宜，非柔则刚：此皆随所宜而不能出所位者也。 〔注〕方员静躁，理不得兼； 然寻形即事，则名分不可相干； 任理之通，方员未必相乖。 故二仪之德，圣人之道，焘育群生，泽周万物，尽其清宁贞粹而已。 则殊涂融通，动静澄一，盖由圣人不逆万物之性，万物不犯圣人之化。 凡滞于一方者，形分之所阂耳。 道之所运，常冥通而无待。 〔解〕气运者能覆载，神运者能教化，然则天地生万物，圣人随状而用之。 仲父曰：注「静躁」治要引作「靖躁」。 释文云：焘音蹈，覆也。 粹音邃。 故有生者，有生生者； 有形者，有形形者； 有声者，有声声者； 有色者，有色色者； 有味者，有味味者。 〔注〕形、声、色、味皆忽尔而生，不能自生者也。 夫不能自生，则无为之本。 无为之本，则无当于一象，无系于一味； 故能为形气之主，动必由之者也。 〔解〕有形之始谓之生，能生此生者谓之形神。 能形其形，能声其声，能色其色，能味其味者，皆神之功，以无制有。 注「无当于一象」，「当」世德堂本作「留」。 汪莱曰：卢解「谓之形神」「形」字衍。 释文云：系音计。 生之所生者死矣，而生生者皆未尝终； 形之所形者实矣，而形形者未尝有； 声之所声者闻矣，而声声者未尝发； 色之所色者彰矣，而色色者未尝显； 味之所味者尝矣，而味味者未尝呈：〔注〕夫尽于一形者，皆随代谢而迁革矣； 故生者必终，而生生物者无变化也。 释文云：呈，示见也。 皆无为之职也。 〔注〕至无者，故能为万变之宗主也。 〔解〕神所运用，有始必终。 形声色味，皆非自辩者也； 所以潜运者，乃神之功高焉，无为而无不为也。 伯峻案：淮南精神训云，「化者复归于无形也，不化者与天地俱生也。 夫木之死也青，青去之也。 夫使木生者，岂木也？ 犹充形者之非形也。 故生生者未尝死也，其所生则死矣； 化物者未尝化也，其所化则化矣」，可为此文批注。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Exegesis* states: *Yǐ* is pronounced as *yú qǐ*.

Master Liezi says: "Heaven and Earth possess no complete efficacy, the sage possesses no complete ability, and the myriad things possess no complete utility.
*(Annotation: "Complete" means "perfectly equipped.")*
Thus, Heaven’s duty is to give life and provide cover, Earth’s duty is to shape and bear, the sage’s duty is to teach and transform, and things fulfill their proper roles.
*(Annotation: "Duty" means "to preside over." Each life has its nature, and each nature has its proper function.)*
Yet Heaven has its shortcomings, Earth has its strengths, the sage has his limitations—*(the *Exegesis* reads "what Heaven and Earth block," with *pǐ* pronounced *pú bǐ*, meaning "obstruction")*—and things have their penetrations.
*(Annotation: That which is suited to one direction becomes obstructed when applied elsewhere.)*
Wang Bi says: 'Form must have its divisions, sound must have its categories. If it is warm, it cannot be cool; if it is *gong*, it cannot be *shang*.'"

Zhongfu notes: The *Qunshu Zhiyao* cites this passage with *tǐ* ("duty") in place of *zhí* ("body") and *wǎng* ("nowhere") in place of *hé* ("obstruction").

*(Bo Jun notes: The *Zhuangzi*'s "Under Heaven" chapter records the words of Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao: "Heaven can cover but cannot bear, Earth can bear but cannot cover, the Great Dao can encompass but cannot discriminate. All things have what they can and cannot do." This conveys the same idea, though expressed differently, hence their conclusions diverge.)*

*(The *Exegesis* states: *Zào* is pronounced *qī dào*, *hé* sounds like *ài*, and *shǔ* sounds like *zhú*.)*

Why is this so? That which gives life and cover cannot shape and bear; that which shapes and bears cannot teach and transform; that which teaches and transforms cannot defy what is proper—*(Annotation: Following it brings penetration.)*—and what is fixed in propriety does not transgress its position.
*(Annotation: All have their inherent divisions, which cannot be reversed.)*
*(Bo Jun notes: There appears to be a missing "can" before "does not transgress its position," making "cannot transgress its position" parallel to the preceding three "cannot" clauses. The following sentence, "cannot transgress its position," includes "can," confirming this. Zhang’s annotation suggests his edition was not yet corrupted.)*

*(The *Exegesis* states: *Fèn* is pronounced *fú wèn*; the same applies to "name divisions" and "form divisions" below.)*

Thus, the Dao of Heaven and Earth is either yin or yang; the sage’s teachings are either benevolence or righteousness; the proper roles of the myriad things are either soft or hard. These all follow what is proper and cannot transgress their positions.
*(Annotation: Stillness and movement, square and round—principles cannot be combined. Yet when examining forms and affairs, their divisions cannot encroach upon one another. When following the penetration of principle, square and round need not conflict. Thus, the virtue of the Two Modes and the Dao of the sage nurture and sustain all life, pervading the myriad things, exhausting only their purity, tranquility, integrity, and essence. Then, divergent paths merge, movement and stillness become one—this arises from the sage not opposing the natures of the myriad things, and the myriad things not violating the sage’s transformative influence. All that is fixated on one direction is obstructed by its form’s divisions. The operation of the Dao is ever profoundly penetrating and without dependence.)*

*(Annotation: The movement of qi enables covering and bearing; the movement of spirit enables teaching and transformation. Thus, Heaven and Earth give life to the myriad things, and the sage employs them according to their forms.)*

Zhongfu notes: In the annotation, *jìng zào* ("stillness and movement") is cited in the *Qunshu Zhiyao* as *jìng zào* ("tranquility and movement").

*(The *Exegesis* states: *Dào* is pronounced *dǎo*, meaning "to cover"; *cuì* sounds like *suì*.)*

Thus, there are those that are born, and those that give birth; there are those that have form, and those that give form; there are those that have sound, and those that give sound; there are those that have color, and those that give color; there are those that have flavor, and those that give flavor.
*(Annotation: Form, sound, color, and flavor all arise in an instant yet cannot generate themselves. That which cannot generate itself is the root of non-action. The root of non-action has no attachment to a single image, no bond to a single flavor—thus it can be the master of form and qi, and all movement must proceed from it.)*

*(Annotation: The beginning of having form is called "birth"; that which can give birth to this birth is called "form and spirit." That which can form its form, sound its sound, color its color, and flavor its flavor—all are the work of spirit, using the insubstantial to govern the substantial. In the annotation, "no attachment to a single image," *dāng* ("attachment") is written as *liú* ("to remain") in the Shide Hall edition.)*

*(Wang Lai notes: In Lu’s annotation, "called 'form and spirit,'" the character *xíng* ("form") is superfluous.)*

*(The *Exegesis* states: *Xì* sounds like *jì*.)*

That which is born by the born dies, yet that which gives birth never ends; that which is formed by form is substantial, yet that which gives form never exists; that which is sounded by sound is heard, yet that which gives sound never emits; that which is colored by color is manifest, yet that which gives color never appears; that which is flavored by flavor is tasted, yet that which gives flavor never presents itself.
*(Annotation: That which is exhausted in one form all change and transform with the passing of time. Thus, the born must end, but that which gives birth to life knows no alteration.)*

*(The *Exegesis* states: *Chéng* means "to manifest.")*

All are the duties of non-action.
*(Annotation: The utterly insubstantial can thus be the master of all transformations.)*

*(Annotation: What spirit operates has a beginning and must have an end. Form, sound, color, and flavor—none can distinguish themselves. That which subtly operates is the sublime work of spirit, non-acting yet nothing left undone.)*

*(Bo Jun notes: The *Huainanzi*'s "Spirit and Essence" chapter states: "That which transforms returns to formlessness; that which does not transform is born together with Heaven and Earth. When wood dies, its greenness departs. That which causes wood to live—is it wood? It is like that which fills form yet is not form. Thus, that which gives life never dies, but what it gives life to dies; that which transforms never transforms, but what it transforms is transformed." This can serve as a commentary on this passage.)*
chunks.overlap_context:
bid *shen* and *qi* become ordinary or foolish. Even among living beings, distinctions abound, resulting in manifold classifications.

Zhongfu says: The *Appended Judgments* of the *Book of Changes* states: "When male and female unite their essence, yin and yang transform and give birth."

*(Bo Jun notes: The *Exegesis* cites the *Book of Changes* from the *Wenyan* commentary. Additionally, *jing* (精, essence) and *sheng* (生, birth) rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *geng-qing* rhyme group.)*

chunks.original_text: 能阴能阳，能柔能刚，能短能长，能员能方，能生能死，能暑能凉，能浮能沈，能宫能商，能出能没，能玄能黄，能甘能苦，能膻能香。 江有诰曰：阳刚方凉商黄香为韵，古音同在阳部。 释文云：膻，式连切。 无知也，无能也，而无不知也，而无不能也。 」〔注〕知尽则无知，能极则无能，故无所不知，无所不能。 何晏道论曰「有之为有，恃无以生； 事而为事，由无以成。 夫道之而无语，名之而无名，视之而无形，听之而无声，则道之全焉。 故能昭音向而出气物，包形神而章光影； 玄以之黑，素以之白，矩以之方，规以之员。 员方得形而此无形，白黑得名而此无名也。 」〔解〕老子曰：「吾不知谁之子，象帝之先」，言此神也。 先天先地，神鬼神帝，无能知者，无能证者。 若能体证兹道，则天地之内无不知，无不能矣。 注「恃无以生」北宋本、藏本同，而世德堂本作「待」，形近误也。 又卢解「则天地之内」秦刻本「天」误作「夫」，今从四解本正。 释文「向」作「响」，「影」作「景」，云：论，卢困切。 恃音市。 名，弥正切，与詺同。 响，许两切。 景音影。 子列子适卫，食于道，从者见百岁髑髅，陶鸿庆曰：列子因见髑髅，攓蓬而指，以示弟子百丰，不当言「从者」。 庄子秋水篇作「从见百岁髑髅」，无「者」字，当从之。 从见者，蒙上之辞，言从道上见之也。 （庄子释文以道从连文，引司马云，「从，道旁也。 」非是。 ）后人误读从去声，而臆增者字，则与下文意不相属。 伯峻案：陶以「从见」训「从道上见」，增字为训，似不确。 从当依释文作徒，字之误也。 诗王风中谷有蓷笺云：「徒用凶年深浅为厚薄」，释文引沈注云，「徒当作从」。 又齐风载驰笺云，「徒为淫乱之行」，释文，「徒，一本作从」，皆其例也。 徒与涂通，古同音也。 食于道徒，即食于道路。 （或训道旁，于古无征。 ）郭庆藩庄子集释至乐篇注云「列子天瑞篇正作食于道徒」，是郭所见列子有作徒者矣，当据改。 者字后人所加，陶说是。 惟陶误庄子至乐篇为秋水篇，偶疏。 释文作「食于道徒」，云，司马彪云，徒，道旁也； 一本或作从。 髑髅音独娄。 攓蓬而指，〔注〕攓，拔也。 类聚八二引作「搴蓬而指之」。 释文「蓬」作「逢」，云，攓音蹇。 逢音蓬，蒿也。 拔，皮八切。 任大椿云：九叹「登逄龙而下陨兮」注：「本作蓬」，「颿风蓬龙」注：「一作逢」，则逢蓬通。 顾谓弟子百丰曰：「唯予与彼知而未尝生未尝死也。 〔注〕俱涉变化之涂，则予生而彼死；
chunks.translated_text:
The Way can be yin and can be yang,
can be soft and can be hard,
can be short and can be long,
can be round and can be square,
can give life and can bring death,
can be hot and can be cool,
can float and can sink,
can be gong and can be shang,
can emerge and can submerge,
can be dark and can be yellow,
can be sweet and can be bitter,
can be rank and can be fragrant.

*(Jiang Yougao notes: "Yang, hard, square, cool, shang, yellow, and fragrant" all rhyme, as they belonged to the same yang rhyme group in ancient pronunciation.)*
*(The *Shiwen* states: "膻 is pronounced *shi lian*.")*

It is without knowledge, yet without inability,
and without knowing, yet without incapacity.
*(Annotation: When knowledge is exhausted, it becomes non-knowledge; when ability is perfected, it becomes non-ability. Thus, there is nothing it does not know, nothing it cannot do.)*

He Yan’s *Discourse on the Dao* states:
*"Being arises from non-being;
affairs are accomplished through non-affairs.
The Dao speaks not when it acts,
is nameless when named,
formless when seen,
soundless when heard—
such is the wholeness of the Dao.
Thus, it illumines sound and emits the qi of things,
embraces form and spirit, and manifests light and shadow.
Through the dark, blackness arises;
through the plain, whiteness arises;
through the carpenter’s square, squareness arises;
through the compass, roundness arises.
Round and square attain form, yet this remains formless;
black and white attain names, yet this remains nameless."*

*(Exegesis: Laozi said, "I know not whose child it is—it seems to precede the Lord of Heaven." This refers to this spirit. It precedes Heaven and Earth, spirits and gods, yet none can know it, none can verify it. If one can embody and verify this Dao, then within Heaven and Earth, there is nothing one does not know, nothing one cannot do.)*

*(The phrase "relies on non-being to arise" is identical in the Northern Song edition and the Zang edition; the Shide Hall edition mistakenly writes "awaits" due to graphic similarity.)*
*(In Lu’s exegesis, the Qin dynasty engraving erroneously writes "夫" for "天"; this follows the Four Exegeses edition in correction.)*
*(The *Shiwen* writes "响" for "向" and "景" for "影," and notes: "论 is pronounced *lu kun*. 恃 is pronounced *shi*. 名 is pronounced *mi zheng*, identical to 詺. 响 is pronounced *xu liang*. 景 is pronounced *ying*.")*

When Master Liezi traveled to Wei, he ate by the roadside. His followers saw a century-old skull. *(Tao Hongqing notes: When Liezi pointed to the skull amid the reeds to show his disciple Bai Feng, it should not say "his followers." The *Zhuangzi*’s "Autumn Waters" chapter writes "from [the road] saw a century-old skull," omitting the word "者." This should be followed. "From saw" is a phrase continuing the above, meaning "saw it by the roadside." (The *Zhuangzi* *Shiwen* mistakenly treats "道" and "从" as a compound, citing Sima Biao’s gloss: "从 means roadside." This is incorrect.) Later readers mispronounced "从" as *zòng* and arbitrarily added "者," disrupting the coherence of the passage.)*
*(Bo Jun notes: Tao’s interpretation of "从见" as "saw by the roadside" is an over-expansion. "从" should follow the *Shiwen* in being read as *tú*, a graphic error. The *Odes*’ "Wang Feng" chapter’s "Zhong Gu You Tui" commentary states: "徒 is used to express the severity of famine years," with the *Shiwen* citing Shen’s note: "徒 should be 作从." The "Zai Chi" commentary of the "Qi Feng" chapter states: "徒 refers to licentious conduct," with the *Shiwen* noting: "徒 appears as 从 in one edition." These are all examples. "徒" and "涂" are homophonous in antiquity. "食于道徒" means "ate by the roadside." (Interpreting it as "roadside" lacks ancient evidence.) Guo Qingfan’s *Zhuangzi Jishi* notes that the "Heaven’s Auspices" chapter of the *Liezi* originally writes "食于道徒," and Guo’s edition of the *Liezi* includes this variant. This should be adopted. The word "者" was added by later readers; Tao’s observation is correct. However, Tao mistakenly cites the "Perfect Joy" chapter of the *Zhuangzi* as "Autumn Waters," an oversight.)*
*(The *Shiwen* writes "食于道徒" and notes: "Sima Biao states: '徒 means roadside.' One edition writes 从.")*
*(髑髅 is pronounced *dú lóu*.)*

He plucked a reed and pointed, saying to his disciple Bai Feng:
*"Only you and it know that you have never been born and have never died.*
*(Annotation: Both traverse the path of transformation—thus, I am born while it dies.)"*

chunks.original_text: 推之至极之域，则理既无生，亦又无死也。 〔解〕形则有生有死，神也无死无生。 我如神在，彼如神去。 髑髅与我生死不同，若悟其神，未尝生死。 此过养乎？ 此过欢乎？ 〔注〕遭形则不能不养，遇生则不能不欢，此过误之徒，非理之实当也。 〔解〕既受其形，则欢养失理，以至于死耳。 洪颐曰：庄子至乐篇两「过」字皆作「果」。 国语晋语「知果」，汉书古今人表作「知过」。 过即果，假借字。 俞樾曰：养当读为恙。 尔雅释诂：恙，忧也。 恙与欢对，犹忧与乐对也。 恙与养古字通。 诗二子乘舟篇「中心养养」，传训养为忧，即本雅诂矣。 释文云：过，古卧切。 当，丁浪切。
chunks.translated_text:
At the ultimate extremity of this inquiry, principle admits neither birth nor death.

*(Exegesis: Form is subject to birth and death, but spirit knows neither death nor birth. As my spirit abides, so his spirit departs. Though the skull and I differ in birth and death, if one awakens to its spirit, there is no birth or death.)*

Is this beyond nurture? Is this beyond joy?

*(Annotation: Encountering form, one cannot but nurture; meeting life, one cannot but rejoice—these are the errors of the deluded, not the true reality of principle.)*

*(Exegesis: Once form is received, joy and nurture lose their proper measure, leading only to death.)*

Hong Yi remarks: In the *Zhuangzi*’s "Perfect Joy" chapter, both instances of "beyond" (*guo*) are written as "fruit" (*guo*). The *Guoyu*’s "Discourses of Jin" writes "Zhi Guo," while the *Hanshu*’s "Table of Ancient and Modern Persons" writes "Zhi Guo." *Guo* ("beyond") is here *guo* ("fruit"), a loan character.

Yu Yue states: *Yang* ("nurture") should be read as *yang* ("affliction"). The *Erya*’s "Explaining Words" glosses *yang* as "worry." *Yang* ("affliction") and *huan* ("joy") stand in opposition, just as worry and joy do. *Yang* ("affliction") and *yang* ("nurture") are anciently interchangeable. The *Book of Songs*’ "The Two Sons Board a Boat" reads *zhongxin yangyang* ("the heart’s affliction"), with the *Preface* glossing *yang* as "worry"—this follows the *Erya*’s definition.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Guo* is pronounced *gu wo*; *dang* is pronounced *ding lang*.

chunks.original_text: 种有几：〔注〕先问变化种数凡有几条，然后明之于下。 陶鸿庆曰几当读为机，黄帝篇之「杜德几」「善者几」「衡气几」诸几字，庄子皆作机，即其例也。 机即下文「万物皆出于机皆入于机」也。 张注殷释皆读几上声，而以为问辞，非。 释文云：种，居勇切。 几，居岂切。 若为鹑，〔注〕事见墨子。 王叔岷曰：尔雅翼十五、玉海急就篇四补注引「」并作「蛙」。 「蛙」下并有「化」字。 蛙即之俗。 释文云：鹑为鹑」也。 伯峻案音淳。 见，贤遍切。 墨子曰：「夫物或有久，或无久。 始当无久。 化，若：墨子经说上云：「始（句），时或有久，或无久。 始当无久」。 孙诒让闲诂云，列子释文引「始」作「夫物」，疑误。 得水为□，王先谦曰：释草：「藚，牛唇。 」郭注引毛诗传曰：「水舄也，如续断，寸寸有节，拔之可复。 」说文：「藚，水舄也。 」郝懿行云：「今验马生水中者，华如车前而大，拔之，节节复生。 」据此，即□也。 拔之寸节复生，故以□为名。 其或作断，又作续断者，□或误断，后人又妄加续字耳。 藚如续断，与生山谷之续断判然二物。 节节复生，无根着土，故名水舄，与本文「得水为□」合。 释文云：□音计，司马彪云：万物虽有兆眹，得水润之气，乃相继而生也。 得水土之际，则为蠙之衣。 〔注〕衣犹覆盖。 王先谦曰：释草：「蕍蕮。 」郭注，「今泽蕮」，案即泽泻也。 本草云：一名水泻。 （即水舄。 ）陶注，叶狭而长，丛生浅水中。 苏颂图经，叶似牛舌草，独叶而长，秋开白花作丛，似谷精草。 秋末采根暴干。 案此「得水土之交」，故有根可采也。 马叙伦曰：尔雅释草：「藫，石衣。 」郝懿行曰：「藫苔声相转。 说文曰，『，水衣。 』即苔也。 水衣即石衣，一曰鱼衣。 周礼醢人曰，『加笾之实有菹。 』郑众注曰：『，水中鱼衣也（据先郑解，字当作「」，后郑作「笞」，故解作箭萌。 今本周礼作「」者，后人误合笞为一字。 段玉裁说）』。 然蠙之衣即鱼衣。 蠙，说文作玭，尔雅释鱼作蜌，山海经西山经作□。 说文云，『螷，陛也则』。 陛借为蜌，蜌即蚌也。 」释文曰：蠙； 步田切。 司马彪云：物根在水土际，布在水中，就水上视之，不见，钞之，可得； 如张绵在水中矣。 楚人谓之蠙之衣。 伯峻案：今庄子释文「钞」作「按」。 生于陵屯，〔注〕陵屯，高洁处也。 释文洁作结，云，屯音豚，阜也。 处，昌据切，下同。 则为陵舄。 〔注〕此随所生之处而变者也。 王先谦曰：诗芣卫释文引陆机云，「牛舌又名当道。 」韩诗说云，「直曰车前，瞿曰芣卫」，乃就直道而生及生道两旁析言之。 直道即当道，皆与此生于陵屯合。 释文云：陵舄，舄音昔，一名泽舄，随燥湿之变也。 伯峻案：此亦引司马文。 陵舄得郁栖，则为乌足。 〔注〕此合而相生者也。 注中「者」字依藏本、四解本增。 释文云：郁栖，粪壤也。 乌足，草名也。 乌足之根为蛴螬，御览九四五引作「乌足以其根为蛴螬」。 王先谦曰：释虫「蟦，蛴螬」。 郭注：「在粪土中。 」蟦疑粪之音转字。 乌足系陵舄在粪壤所化，其根在粪土中，而出为蛴螬。 本草，「蟦蛴生河内泽及人家积粪草中，反行者良。

The kinds of transformation number several: [Note] First inquiring into the total number of transformative kinds, then clarifying them below.

Tao Hongqing states: *Ji* ("several") should be read as *ji* ("mechanism"). In the "Yellow Emperor" chapter, phrases like "the virtue/power of Du is *ji*," "the good is *ji*," and "the qi of the balance is *ji*"—all instances of *ji* in *Zhuangzi* are written as *ji* ("mechanism"), which serves as precedent. *Ji* ("mechanism") refers to the passage below: "All things emerge from the *ji* and enter into the *ji*." Zhang’s commentary and Yin’s exegesis both read *ji* in the third tone and treat it as an interrogative, which is incorrect.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhong* ("kind") is pronounced *ju yong*; *ji* is pronounced *ju qi*.

If it becomes a quail, [Note] The event is recorded in *Mozi*.

Wang Shumin states: The *Erya Yiyi* (15) and *Yuhai*’s supplementary notes to the *Jijiu Pian* (4) both write this as "frog" (*wa*), with the character "化" ("transform") added below. *Wa* ("frog") is a vulgar form of *zhi* ("quail").

The *Shiwen* notes: *Chun* ("quail") is pronounced *chun*.

Bo Jun’s note: The modern pronunciation is *chun*. *Jian* ("see") is pronounced *xian bian*.

*Mozi* states: "Of things, some endure long, some do not. The beginning is without duration." Transformation occurs thus: *Mozi*’s *Jingshuo Shang* reads: "The beginning (phrase). Time may endure long or not; the beginning is without duration." Sun Yirang’s *Xian Gu* notes that the *Liezi*’s *Shiwen* cites "beginning" as "of things," likely an error.

When it obtains water, it becomes *xu*. Wang Xianqian states: The *Erya*’s "Explaining Plants" reads: "*Xu*, ox-lips." Guo’s commentary cites the *Mao Shi Zhuan*: "Water *xi* (*xu*), resembling *xuduan* (teasel), jointed every inch; when pulled, it regrows." The *Shuowen* reads: "*Xu*, water *xi*." Hao Yixing states: "Now examining what grows in water, its flowers resemble plantain but are larger. When pulled, it regrows joint by joint, hence the name *xu*." Some write it as *duan* ("broken") or *xuduan* ("teasel"), but *xu* may have been mistaken for *duan*, and later generations erroneously added "continuing." *Xu* resembles *xuduan* but is distinct from the *xuduan* that grows in mountain valleys. As it regrows joint by joint without roots anchoring to soil, it is called water *xi*, aligning with the text’s "obtains water and becomes *xu*."

The *Shiwen* notes: *Xu* is pronounced *ji*. Sima Biao states: Though all things bear signs, only when they receive the moistening qi of water do they successively arise.

When it obtains the boundary of water and soil, it becomes the covering of *pin*. [Note] *Yi* ("covering") means to overlay.

Wang Xianqian states: The *Erya*’s "Explaining Plants" reads: "*Yu xie*." Guo’s commentary: "Now called marsh *xie*," which is *zexie* (water plantain). The *Bencao* reads: "Also called water discharge" (i.e., water *xi*). Tao’s commentary: "Leaves narrow and long, growing in clusters in shallow water." Su Song’s *Tu Jing*: "Leaves resemble *niushecao* (plantain), single and long; in autumn, it blooms white flowers in clusters, resembling *gujingcao* (pipewort). Roots are harvested in late autumn and dried." Here, "obtaining the intersection of water and soil," it develops roots that can be harvested.

Ma Xulun states: The *Erya*’s "Explaining Plants" reads: "*Tan*, stone covering." Hao Yixing states: "*Tan* and *tai* (moss) are phonetically interchangeable. The *Shuowen* reads: '*Pi*, water covering.' *Pi* is moss. Water covering is stone covering, also called fish covering." The *Zhouli*’s "Hairen" reads: "The additions to the *bian* vessels include *pi* pickles." Zheng Zhong’s commentary: "*Pi* is the fish covering in water" (based on the early Zheng’s explanation; the character should be *pi*; later Zheng wrote *chi*, thus interpreting it as arrow sprouts. Modern *Zhouli* editions write *pi*, likely a later conflation of *pi* and *chi* into one character. However, the covering of *pin* is fish covering). *Pin*—the *Shuowen* writes it as *pin*; the *Erya*’s "Explaining Fish" writes it as *bi*; the *Shanhai Jing*’s "Western Mountains" writes it as *□*. The *Shuowen* reads: "*Ping*, steps, then." *Bi* is borrowed for *bi* (*bivalve*); *bi* is clam.

The *Shiwen* reads: *Pin* is pronounced *bu tian*. Sima Biao states: The roots of things lie at the water-soil boundary, spreading in water; viewed from above the water, they are unseen, but when scooped, they can be obtained—like stretched silk in water. The people of Chu call this the covering of *pin*.

Bo Jun’s note: The modern *Zhuangzi Shiwen* writes "scooped" as "pressed."

When it grows on a mound, [Note] *Ling tun* ("mound") refers to a high and pure place.

The *Shiwen* writes *jie* ("pure") as *jie* ("knotted"), noting: *Tun* is pronounced *tun* (piglet), meaning mound. *Chu* ("place") is pronounced *chang ju*; the same below.

It becomes *ling xi*. [Note] This changes according to the place where it grows.

Wang Xianqian states: The *Shi Jing*’s *Fou Wei* *Shiwen* cites Lu Ji: "Ox-tongue is also called *dangdao*." The *Han Shi* commentary: "Growing straight is called *cheqian* (plantain); growing on the sides is called *fou wei*," distinguishing between those growing on straight paths and those on path edges. The straight path is *dangdao*, both aligning with "grows on a mound."

The *Shiwen* notes: *Ling xi* is pronounced *xi* (past); also called marsh *xi*, changing with dryness and moisture.

Bo Jun’s note: This also cites Sima’s text.

When *ling xi* obtains *yuqi* (fertile soil), it becomes crow’s foot. [Note] This arises from their combination.

The character "者" ("that which") in the note is added following the *Zangben* and *Sijieben*.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Yuqi* is manure soil. *Wuzu* is the name of a plant. The roots of *wuzu* become *qicao* (grubs). The *Yulin* (945) cites this as "the roots of *wuzu* become *qicao*."

Wang Xianqian states: The *Erya*’s "Explaining Insects" reads: "*Fei*, *qicao*." Guo’s commentary: "Found in dung soil." *Fei* may be a phonetic loan for *fen* (dung). *Wuzu* transforms from *ling xi* in dung soil; its roots lie in dung soil, emerging as *qicao*. The *Bencao*: "*Feiqi* grows in the marshes of Henan and in accumulated dung and grass among households; those that move backward are good."

chunks.original_text: 」陶注，「蛴亦作蠀」。 方言，「蠀螬谓之蟦」。 蛴蠀双声。 马叙伦曰：蛴螬非螬蛴。 韩保升、苏颂、陈藏器均辨之。 论衡无形篇曰，「蛴螬化而为复育，复育转而为蝉。 」陈藏器曰，「蛴螬居粪土中，身短足长，背有毛筋，但从夏入秋蜕而为蝉。 」李时珍曰：「蛴螬状如蚕而大，身短节促，足长有毛。 生树根及粪土中者外黄内黑，生旧茅屋上者外白内黯。 」释文云：郭注尔雅云，「在木中。 今虽通名为蝎，所在异。 」其叶为胡蝶。 〔注〕根，本也； 叶，散也。 言乌足为蛴螬之本，其末散化为胡蝶也。 注「其末」北宋本作「其未」，汪本从之，今依四解本正。 释文云：蝶音楪，即蛱蝶也。 蛱音颊。 胡蝶胥也〔注〕胥，皆也，言物皆化也。 化而为虫，俞樾曰：「胥也」当属下句读之，本云「胡蝶胥也化而为虫」，与下文「□掇千日为鸟」两文相对。 「千日为鸟」，言其久也； 「胥也化而为虫」，言其速也。 释文云：师说云，胥，少也； 谓少去时也。 生灶下，释文云：得热气生。 其状若脱，释文云：脱，他括切。 郭注尔雅云，脱谓剥皮也。 其名曰□掇。 〔注〕此一形之内变异者也。 释文云：□音衢。 掇，丁括切。 □掇，虫名。 □掇千日〔注〕千日而死。 化而为鸟，其名曰干余骨。 干余骨之沫为斯弥。 〔注〕沫犹精华生起。 释文「骨」作「胥」，云，沫音末。 胥，南华真经作骨。 李颐云，沫，口中汁也。 斯弥，虫名。 斯弥为食酰颐辂。 释文云：酰，许兮切，苦酒上蠛蠓也。 亦曰酰鸡，下同。 颐辂，上治下路。 食酰颐辂生乎食酰黄軦，释文云：軦音况。 颐辂黄軦，皆虫也。 食酰黄軦生乎九猷。 俞樾曰：「颐辂食酰黄軦食酰」八字皆衍文。 庄子至乐篇止作「颐辂生乎食酰，黄軦生乎九猷」，无此八字。 王叔岷曰：俞说非也。 此文以「斯弥为食酰颐辂」为句，「食酰颐辂生乎食酰黄軦」为句，「食酰黄軦生乎九猷」为句。 御览八八七引庄子「黄軦生乎九猷」上「黄軦食酰」四字尚未捝。 此当据列子以补庄子，不当据庄子捝误之文以删列子也。 释文云：李云，九当作久； 久，老也。 猷，虫名。 九猷生乎瞀芮，朱骏声曰：瞀芮即也。 瞀一声之转。 释文云：瞀，茂谋二音。 芮音蚋，小虫也，喜去乱飞。 瞀芮生乎腐蠸。 〔注〕此皆死而更生之一形者也。 释文云，腐音辅。 蠸音权，一音欢，谓瓜中黄甲虫也。 羊肝化为地皋，伯峻案：刘汝霖曾语我曰：「地皋」应作「地膏」，膏血连文，故地膏即地血。 说文及尔雅翼，茹藘，人血所生，故一名地血。 本草，茜根可以染绛，一名地血。 盖古人以茜根可染红色，遂以为动物膏血所化。 马血之为转邻也，胡怀琛曰：「转」字疑在「为」字上。 转为邻与上文化为地皋对文。 释文云：皋音高。 顾胤汉书集解云，如淤泥邻，说文作，又作磷，皆鬼火也。 淮南子云血为磷也。 音吝。 人血之为野火也。 〔注〕此皆一形之内自变化也。 鹞之为鹯，释文云：鹞音曜。 鹯音毡。 鹯之为布谷，释文作「布毂」，云，本又作谷。 陆机毛诗鸟兽疏云，鹯似鹞，黄毛、鹞头、苍身皆相似，其飞急疾，取鸠、鸽、燕、雀食之。 布毂，鴶鵴也，一名鸤鸠，一名击谷，一名乘鸠。 仲春雀、鹞、鹰、鹯之化为也，音掬。
