chunks.original_text: 列子曰：「汝何去来之频？ 」释文「汝」作「女」，云：女音汝。 尹生曰：「曩章戴有请于子，〔注〕章戴，尹生名。 卢文弨曰：注尹生下藏本有「之」字。 释文「戴」作「载」，云：曩，乃朗切。 章载字载则，一本作章戴。 子不我告，固有憾于子。 释文云：憾，胡绀切。 今复脱然，释文云：脱，土活切。 是以又来。 」列子曰：「曩吾以汝为达，〔注〕曩，昔也。 王叔岷曰：疑此注当在上文「曩章戴有请于子」下。 今汝之鄙至此乎？ 释文云：乎本又作于。 姬！ 将告汝〔注〕姬，居也。 释文云：姬音居。 所学于夫子者矣。 〔解〕昔汝去也，吾将谓汝达吾道； 今汝之息憾而来，知汝之鄙陋矣。 解「息憾」本作「怼憾」，今依四解本订正。 释文「汝」作「女」，云：女音汝。 自吾之事夫子友若人也，〔注〕夫子谓老商，若人谓伯高三年之后，心不敢念是非，口不敢言利害，始得夫子一眄而已。 〔注〕实怀利害而不敢言，此匿怨藏情者也，故眄之而已。 〔解〕专一而不离，恭敬以至，求顾吾之形，观吾之行者，斜。 也。 释文云：眄音五年之后，心庚念是非，口庚言利害，〔注〕庚当作更。 吉府本「庚」作「更」。 释文云：庚音更，居行切，益也，下同。 夫子始一解颜而笑。 〔注〕是非利害，世间之常理； 任心之所念，任口之所言，而无矜吝于胸怀，内外如一，不犹踰于匿而不显哉？ 欣其一致，聊寄笑焉。 〔解〕三年之后，专于定也，顾眄而已； 五年之后，越于专，其哂明矣。 北宋本「吝」作「忞」，「胸」作「鬯」，「犹」作「循」，皆非，今正。 「匿」世德堂本作「己」，亦非。 释文云：匿一本作巳。 七年之后，从心之所念，庚无是非； 释文云：从音纵，下同。 从口之所言，庚无利害，夫子始一引吾并席而坐。 〔注〕夫心者何？ 寂然而无意想也； 口者何？ 默然而自吐纳也。 若顺心之极，则无是非； 任口之理，则无利害。 道契师友，同位比肩，故其宜耳。 〔解〕审之而后言，欲是非利害无所误也。 释文云：契，苦计切。 九年之后，横心之所念，释文云：横去声，下同。 纵放也。 横口之所言，亦不知我之是非利害欤，亦不知彼之是非利害欤； 亦不知夫子之为我师，若人之为我友：内外进矣。 〔注〕心既无念，口既无违，故能恣其所念，纵其所言。 体道穷宗，为世津梁。 终日念而非我念，终日言而非我言。 若以无念为念，无言为言，未造于极也。 所谓无为而无不为者如斯，则彼此之异，于何而求？ 师资之义，将何所施？ 故曰内外尽矣。 〔解〕都无心，故是非利害不择之而后言，纵横者也。 纵心而言，皆合斯道。 释文云：造，七到切。 而后眼如耳，耳如鼻，鼻如口，无不同也。 〔解〕眼、耳、口、鼻不用其所能，各任之而无心，故云无不同也。 心凝形释，骨肉都融； 不觉形之所倚，释文云：倚，于绮切。 足之所履，随风东西，犹木叶干壳。 沈涛曰：戴侗六书故引唐本说文曰，干湿之干也。 徐本无干字。 涛案：干古干湿正字，通假作干。 列子黄帝篇木叶干壳，张湛注（伯峻案：当作释文）干音干，可证。 释文云：干音干。 壳，口角切。 竟不知风乘我邪？ 我乘风乎？ 〔注〕夫眼、耳、鼻、口，各有攸司。
chunks.translated_text:
Liezi said, "Why do you come and go so frequently?" The *Shiwen* notes: *rǔ* (汝) is written as *nǚ* (女), pronounced *rǔ*. Yin Sheng replied, "Formerly, Zhang Dai made requests of you." The annotation states: *Zhang Dai* is Yin Sheng’s name. Lu Wenchang notes: The annotation under Yin Sheng’s name in the Zang edition includes the character *zhī* (之). The *Shiwen* notes: *dài* (戴) is written as *zài* (载), and *nǎng* (曩) is pronounced *nǎng*. *Zhang Zai*’s courtesy name is *Zai Ze*; one edition writes *Zhang Dai*. "You did not instruct me, so I naturally harbored resentment toward you. Now, my mind is suddenly at ease, which is why I have returned." Liezi said, "Formerly, I took you for one who had attained understanding." The annotation states: *nǎng* means "formerly." Wang Shumin notes: This annotation likely belongs below the earlier phrase *"nǎng zhāng dài yǒu qǐng yú zǐ"* (曩章戴有请于子). "But has your vulgarity truly reached this point? Ji! I shall now tell you what I learned from the Master." The annotation states: *jī* (姬) means "to reside." The *Shiwen* notes: *jī* is pronounced *jū*. The explanation states: When you left before, I thought you had grasped my Way. Now that you return to dispel your resentment, I know your shallowness. The explanation notes: The original text read *"duì hàn"* (怼憾), but this has been corrected to *"xī hàn"* (息憾) according to the *Sijie* edition. The *Shiwen* notes: *rǔ* (汝) is written as *nǚ* (女), pronounced *rǔ*.

"Since I began studying under the Master and befriended such a person—after three years, my mind dared not entertain thoughts of right and wrong, nor my mouth speak of profit and harm—I only then received a single glance from the Master." The annotation states: Though inwardly harboring thoughts of profit and harm, one dared not speak of them, concealing resentment and hiding true feelings. Thus, he merely glanced at me. The explanation states: One who is single-minded and unwavering, reverent and devoted, seeking to observe my form and emulate my conduct, receives only a sidelong glance. The *Shiwen* notes: *miǎn* (眄) is pronounced *miàn*. "After five years, my mind *gēng* contemplated right and wrong, and my mouth *gēng* spoke of profit and harm." The annotation states: *Gēng* should be *gèng*. The *Jifu* edition writes *gèng* (更). The *Shiwen* notes: *gēng* is pronounced *gèng*, *jū xíng qiè*, meaning "to increase"; the same applies below. "Only then did the Master smile once, relaxing his countenance." The annotation states: Right and wrong, profit and harm are the common principles of the world. Following the mind’s thoughts and the mouth’s words without restraint or hesitation in the heart, aligning inner and outer as one—is this not surpassing concealment and revealing all? Delighted by this unity, he playfully bestowed a smile. The explanation states: After three years, one was devoted to stillness, receiving only glances. After five years, surpassing devotion, his smile became evident. The Northern Song edition writes *mín* (忞) for *lìn* (吝), *chàng* (鬯) for *xiōng* (胸), and *xún* (循) for *yóu* (犹), all of which are incorrect and have been corrected here. The *Shide Tang* edition writes *jǐ* (己) for *nì* (匿), which is also incorrect. The *Shiwen* notes: *nì* is written as *jǐ* in one edition.

"After seven years, following the mind’s thoughts, *gēng* there was no right or wrong; following the mouth’s words, *gēng* there was no profit or harm. Only then did the Master draw me to sit beside him on the same mat." The annotation states: What is the mind? It is stillness without thought. What is the mouth? It is silence, naturally inhaling and exhaling. If one follows the mind’s utmost, there is no right or wrong; if one follows the mouth’s principle, there is no profit or harm. When the Dao harmonizes with teacher and friend, sharing the same position side by side, it is fitting. The explanation states: One speaks only after careful consideration, ensuring no error in right or wrong, profit or harm. The *Shiwen* notes: *qì* (契) is pronounced *kǔ jì qiè*. "After nine years, freely following the mind’s thoughts, freely speaking the mouth’s words, I no longer knew whether my own right and wrong, profit and harm existed, nor whether the Master was my teacher or such a person my friend. Inner and outer had reached perfection." The annotation states: With the mind devoid of thought and the mouth free of contradiction, one can indulge the mind’s thoughts and give free rein to the mouth’s words. Having mastered the Dao and exhausted its essence, one becomes a bridge for the world. Though thoughts arise all day, they are not my thoughts; though words are spoken all day, they are not my words. If one takes non-thought as thought and non-speech as speech, one has not yet reached the ultimate. The so-called "non-action that leaves nothing undone" is like this. Then where can one seek the difference between self and other? Where can the relationship between teacher and student be applied? Thus, it is said that inner and outer are complete. The explanation states: With the mind utterly empty, right and wrong, profit and harm are spoken without distinction—this is freedom. Following the mind’s freedom in speech, all aligns with the Dao. The *Shiwen* notes: *zào* (造) is pronounced *qī dào qiè*.

"Afterward, eyes were like ears, ears like noses, noses like mouths—none were different." The explanation states: Eyes, ears, mouth, and nose did not use their respective functions but acted without intention, thus none were different. "The mind congealed, the form dissolved, bones and flesh fused entirely. Unaware of where the body leaned," the *Shiwen* notes: *yǐ* (倚) is pronounced *yú qǐ qiè*, "or where the feet trod, I drifted east and west with the wind like a withered leaf or a dried husk." Shen Tao notes: Dai Tong’s *Liu Shu Gu* cites the Tang edition of the *Shuowen*, saying *gān* (干) is the original character for dryness, interchangeable with *gān* (乾). The Xu edition omits *gān*. Tao’s note: *Gān* is the proper character for dryness, interchangeable with *gān*. The *Liezi Huangdi* chapter’s "withered leaf or dried husk," with Zhang Zhan’s annotation (note: should be *Shiwen*), *gān* pronounced *gān*, serves as evidence. The *Shiwen* notes: *gān* is pronounced *gān*, and *ké* (壳) is pronounced *kǒu jiǎo qiè*. "Did the wind ride me, or did I ride the wind?" The annotation states: Eyes, ears, nose, and mouth each have their respective functions.

chunks.original_text: 令神凝形废，无待于外，则视听不资眼、耳，味不赖鼻、口，故六藏七孔，四肢百节，块然尸居，同为一物，则形奚所倚？ 足奚所履？ 我之乘风，风之乘我，孰能辨也？ 〔解〕神凝者，不动也； 形释者，无碍也； 骨肉都融者，忘形骸也。 形骸忘于所之，神念离于所着，则与风气同之上下也。 卢文弨曰：注「令神凝形废」「令」当作「今」。 今女居先生之门，曾未浃时，释文云：曾音层。 浃，子协切。 而怼憾者再三。 女之片体将气所不受，汝之一节将地所不载。 〔注〕用其情，有其身，则肌骨不能相容，一体将无所寄？ 岂二仪之所能覆载。 伯峻案：将，且也。 履虚乘风，其可几乎？ 」释文云：几音冀。 尹生甚怍，释文云：怍音昨。 屏息良久，释文云：屏息，屏气似不息也。 不敢复言。 〔解〕列子所以乘风者，为能忘其身也。
chunks.translated_text:
Let the spirit congeal and the form dissolve, no longer dependent on externals—then sight and hearing do not rely on eyes and ears, nor do scent and taste depend on nose and mouth. Thus, the six viscera and seven orifices, the four limbs and hundred joints, lie inert as a corpse, all reduced to one thing. Where then does the form lean? Where do the feet tread? Whether I ride the wind or the wind rides me—who can distinguish?

**[Annotation]** *"Spirit congeals"* means immobility; *"form dissolves"* means no obstruction; *"flesh and bone wholly melt"* means forgetting the bodily frame. When the bodily frame is forgotten in its movements and the spirit’s thoughts detach from their attachments, one ascends and descends with the wind and qi as one.

Lu Wenchang notes: The annotation reads *"令神凝形废"* ("let the spirit congeal and the form dissolve"), but *"令"* should be *"今"* ("now"). *"Now you have entered the Master’s gate, yet before even a full cycle of time has passed"*—*Shiwen* notes: *"曾"* is pronounced *céng*; *"浃"* is pronounced *zié*. *"You have repeatedly expressed resentment and regret. Your entire body will not be borne by qi, nor will even a single part of you be supported by the earth."*

**[Annotation]** To employ one’s emotions and possess a self is to make flesh and bone incompatible—where then can the body reside? How could the two forces of heaven and earth sustain it? *"将"* means *"且"* ("about to"). To tread the void and ride the wind—how could this be possible?

*Shiwen* notes: *"几"* is pronounced *jī*. Yin Sheng was deeply ashamed. *Shiwen* notes: *"怍"* is pronounced *zuò*. He held his breath for a long while—*Shiwen* notes: *"屏息"* means to hold one’s breath as if not breathing—and dared not speak again.

**[Annotation]** The reason *Liezi* could ride the wind was that he was able to forget his body.

The *Shiwen* notes: *gān* is pronounced *gān*, and *ké* (壳) is pronounced *kǒu jiǎo qiè*. "Did the wind ride me, or did I ride the wind?" The annotation states: Eyes, ears, nose, and mouth each have their respective functions.

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：「吾所以有大患者，为吾有身； 及吾无身，吾有何患也？ 」若其形骸之不忘，则一节之重将地所不能载，何暇乘风而凌虚哉？ 伯峻案：解引老子「吾有何患也」，今本无「也」字。 释文云：复，扶又切。 列子问关尹曰：释文云：关尹，关令尹喜，字公度，着书九篇。 伯峻案：今本关尹子一卷，九篇，南宋陈振孙直斋书录解题疑为孙定（南宋人）依托，四库提要则云「或唐五代间方士解文章者所为也」。 「至人潜行不空，〔注〕不空者，实有也。 至人动止不以实有为阂者也。 郭象曰：其心虚，故能御群实也。 道藏江遹本、宋徽宗本「空」并作「窒」。 作「窒」者是也。 但张湛原本作「空」，故仍之。 俞樾曰：张注甚为迂曲。 释文曰，「空一本作窒」，当从之。 庄子达生篇正作「不窒」。 仲父曰：俞说是也。 潜行谓行于水也。 说文十一上水部：泳，潜行水中也。 哀十七年左传：越子以三军潜涉。 韩非子十过篇记智伯伐赵事云，「决晋阳之水以灌之，围晋阳三年。 城中巢居而处，悬釜而炊。 张孟谈谓赵襄子曰：臣请试潜行而出见韩魏之君」，皆其证也。 窒谓窒息，潜行入水与下入火正相对。 释文云：潜或作渐，亦音潜。 空一本作窒，塞也。 阂音碍。 秦恩复云：易「阒其无人」，陆释文：孟作窒。 虞翻注，空也。 空之为窒，犹乱之训治也。 蹈火不热，行乎万物之上而不栗。 〔注〕向秀曰：天下乐推而不厌，非吾之自高，故不栗者也。 释文云：栗音栗。 请问何以至于此？ 」关尹曰：「是纯气之守也，非智巧果敢之列。 〔注〕至纯至真，即我之性分，非求之于外。 慎而不失，则物所不能害，岂智计勇敢而得冒涉艰危哉？ 〔解〕言至人潜行积德，非本空虚者也，何如能蹈火不热，登高不栗乎？ 以明纯气出乎性，守神以合道，则能至于此，故曰至人也； 岂智巧果敢所能得耶？ 释文云：列音例。 姬！ 释文云：姬音居。 鱼语女。 〔注〕鱼当作吾。 吴闿生曰：钟鼎古文多以鱼为吴。 释文云：鱼音吾。 语，鱼据切。 女音汝。 凡有貌像声色者，皆物也。 〔注〕上至圣人，下及昆虫，皆形声之物。 以形声相观，则无殊绝者也。 物与物何以相远也？ 〔注〕向秀曰：唯无心者独远耳。 释文云：远，于万切。 夫奚足以至乎先？ 是色而已。 〔注〕向秀曰：同是形色之物耳，未足以相先也。 以相先者，唯自然也。 〔解〕凡有形者皆物也。 物皆是色，亦何后何先耶？ 而自贵贱物者，情惑之甚也。 会忘形守神习静以生慧者，然后能通神明者也。 伯峻案：「色」上脱「形」字，当作「是形色而已」。 「形色」承上文「貌像声色」而言。 注引向秀曰：「同是形色之物耳」，则向所注庄子本有「形」字。 江南古藏本庄子正作「是形色而已」，当据正。 说本奚侗庄子补注。 则物之造乎不形，而止乎无所化。 〔注〕有既无始，则所造者无形矣； 形既无终，则所止者无化矣。 造音作。 卢文弨曰：注「造音」下当有「造」字。 伯峻案：卢说可商。 据释文，张注只作「造音作」。 盖张湛与殷敬顺皆不晓音理，故其音有不可信者，不可以深求也。 释文云：造音作，臧祚切，注同。 夫得是而穷之者，焉释文云：焉，于虔切。 得而正焉？
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi said: *"My great affliction arises from having a body; if I were without a body, what affliction could I have?"* If one cannot forget the form and bones, then even the weight of a single joint would be more than the earth could bear—how then could one find leisure to ride the wind and tread the void?

**[Annotation]** The *Exegesis* cites Laozi’s *"what affliction could I have?"*—the present text omits the character *"也"*. *Shiwen* notes: *"复"* is pronounced *fù*. Liezi asked Guan Yin: *Shiwen* notes: Guan Yin was Guan Ling Yin Xi, styled Gongdu, who wrote nine chapters. **[Annotation]** The present *Guan Yinzi* consists of one scroll and nine chapters; Chen Zhensun of the Southern Song, in his *Zhizhai shulu jieti*, suspected it to be a forgery by Sun Ding (a Southern Song figure), while the *Siku quanshu* *tiyao* suggests it may have been composed by a Tang or Five Dynasties Daoist versed in literary arts.

*"The perfected person moves through water without obstruction—[Annotation] 'Without obstruction' means 'substantially present.' The perfected person’s movements and stillness are not hindered by substantial presence."* Guo Xiang said: *"Their mind is empty, thus they can master all that is substantial."* The *Daozang* Jiang Yu edition and the Song Huizong edition both write *"窒"* instead of *"空"*—*"窒"* is correct. However, Zhang Zhan’s original text reads *"空"*, so it is retained here. Yu Yue said: Zhang’s annotation is overly convoluted. *Shiwen* states: *"空, one version writes 窒"*—this should be followed. The *Zhuangzi* *"Da Sheng"* chapter indeed reads *"不窒"*. **[Annotation]** Master Zhongfu said: Yu Yue’s view is correct. *"潜行"* refers to moving through water. The *Shuowen*, in the water section of its eleventh chapter, states: *"泳 means to move submerged in water."* The *Zuozhuan* of the seventeenth year of Duke Ai records: *"The Viscount of Yue led his three armies to cross the river in secret."* The *Hanfeizi* *"Shi Guo"* chapter recounts the siege of Zhao by Zhi Bo: *"He breached the dikes of Jinyang to flood the city, besieging it for three years. Within the city, people nested in trees and cooked in suspended cauldrons. Zhang Mengtan said to Viscount Xiang of Zhao: 'I request to attempt a secret crossing to meet with the lords of Han and Wei.'"*—all these serve as evidence. *"窒"* means suffocation; moving through water and entering fire are directly opposed. *Shiwen* notes: *"潜"* is sometimes written *"渐"*, also pronounced *qián*. *"空"* is written as *"窒"* in one version, meaning blockage. *"阂"* is pronounced *ài*. Qin Enfu said: In the *Yi*, *"阒其无人"*, Lu’s *Shiwen* notes: Meng’s version writes *"窒"*. Yu Fan’s commentary: *"Empty."* *"空"* as *"窒"* is like *"乱"* glossed as *"治"*.

*"They tread fire without being burned, walk atop the myriad things without trembling. May I ask how one attains this?"* Guan Yin replied: *"This is the preservation of pure qi, not a matter of cunning, skill, or daring."* **[Annotation]** Utmost purity and truth are inherent in one’s nature, not sought externally. Guarding it without loss renders one invulnerable to harm—how could this be achieved through calculated bravery or reckless exposure to peril?

**[Exegesis]** The perfected person’s movement through water is the accumulation of virtue, not based on emptiness—how then can they tread fire without being burned or ascend heights without trembling? This clarifies that pure qi emerges from nature; preserving spirit to align with the Dao enables such attainment. Thus, they are called perfected persons—how could this be achieved through cunning, skill, or daring? *Shiwen* notes: *"列"* is pronounced *liè*. *"姬!"* *Shiwen* notes: *"姬"* is pronounced *jī*. *"Fish speaks to you."* **[Annotation]** *"鱼"* should be *"吾"*. Wu Kaisheng said: In ancient bronze inscriptions, *"鱼"* often stands for *"吾"*. *Shiwen* notes: *"鱼"* is pronounced *wú*. *"语"* is pronounced *yù*. *"女"* is pronounced *rǔ*.

*"All that possesses form, appearance, sound, or color is 'thing.'"* **[Annotation]** From sages above to insects below, all are beings of form and sound. Observing them through form and sound reveals no absolute distinction. How then can things be far removed from one another? **[Annotation]** Xiang Xiu said: Only the mindless are truly distant. *Shiwen* notes: *"远"* is pronounced *yuàn*.

*"Why should any be deemed prior? They are but form and color."* **[Annotation]** Xiang Xiu said: All are beings of form and color—none are inherently prior. That which precedes them is only spontaneity. **[Exegesis]** All that has form is "thing." All things are color—what comes after or before? Yet those who arbitrarily rank things in value are deeply deluded. Only by forgetting form, preserving spirit, cultivating stillness to generate wisdom, and thereby communing with the divine can one attain this. **[Annotation]** The character *"形"* is missing before *"色"*—it should read *"是形色而已"*. *"形色"* refers back to the earlier *"貌像声色"*. The annotation cites Xiang Xiu: *"All are beings of form and color"*—thus Xiang’s version of the *Zhuangzi* included *"形"*. The Jiangnan ancient *Zhuangzi* text indeed reads *"是形色而已"*, which should be adopted as correct. This follows Xi Tong’s *Zhuangzi Buzhu*.

*"Thus, things originate in the formless and rest where there is no transformation."* **[Annotation]** If existence has no beginning, then that which it creates is formless; if form has no end, then that which it rests in is unchanging. *"造"* is pronounced *zuò*. Lu Wenchang said: The annotation should include another *"造"* after *"造音"*. **[Annotation]** Lu’s suggestion is debatable. According to *Shiwen*, Zhang’s annotation only reads *"造音作"*. Zhang Zhan and Yin Jingshun both lacked understanding of phonetics, so their pronunciations are not always reliable and should not be over-scrutinized. *Shiwen* notes: *"造"* is pronounced *zuò*, *zàng zuò* cut, same as the annotation.

*"One who attains this and exhausts it—how could they be corrected?"* *Shiwen* notes: *"焉"* is pronounced *yán*. *"得而正焉?"*
chunks.overlap_context:
How could the two forces of heaven and earth sustain it? *"将"* means *"且"* ("about to"). To tread the void and ride the wind—how could this be possible?

*Shiwen* notes: *"几"* is pronounced *jī*. Yin Sheng was deeply ashamed. *Shiwen* notes: *"怍"* is pronounced *zuò*. He held his breath for a long while—*Shiwen* notes: *"屏息"* means to hold one’s breath as if not breathing—and dared not speak again.

**[Annotation]** The reason *Liezi* could ride the wind was that he was able to forget his body.

chunks.original_text: 〔注〕寻形声欲穷其终始者，亦焉得至极之所乎？ 〔解〕忘形守神，造乎不形也； 宝真合道者，止乎无所化也。 若得此道而穷理尽性者，何得不为正乎？ 「而正」本作「为正」。 俞樾曰：「为正」当作「而止」，字之误也。 止与正形相似。 为古文作□，与而亦相似。 襄十四年左传：「射为礼乎」，太平御览工菊部引作「射而礼乎」； 孟子滕文公篇「方里而井」，论语颜渊篇正义引作「方里为井」，并其证也。 庄子达生篇述此文曰，「夫得是而穷之者物焉得而止焉」，可据以订正。 王重民曰：吉府本「为」正作「而」。 伯峻案：俞、王两说是也。 「为」字今依吉府本正。 彼将处乎不深之度，〔注〕即形色而不求其终始者，不失自然之正矣。 深当作淫。 释文云：深音淫。 而藏乎无端之纪，〔注〕至理岂有隐藏哉？ 任而不执，故冥然无迹，端崖不见。 释文云：见，贤遍切。 游乎万物之所终始。 〔注〕乘理而无心者，则常与万物并游，岂得无终始之迹者乎？ 〔解〕至人者，言无失德也，故不淫其度矣； 行无失迹也，故藏乎无端矣； 常归其本也，故游万物之终始矣。 伯峻案：纪始为韵，古音同为之咍部之上声。 壹其性，养其气，释文云：养其气一本作真其气。 含其德，以通乎物之所造。 〔注〕气壹德纯者，岂但自通而已哉？ 物之所至，皆使无阂，然后通济群生焉。 造音操。 〔解〕性不杂乱，唯真与天地合其德而通于万物之性命。 卢文弨曰：张注末「音操」下藏本有「有」字。 释文云：造，七到切，至也。 夫若是者，其天守全，其神无郄，「郄」释文作「郄」，云，郄音绤，闲也。 俞樾曰：释文「闲也」，闲乃闲字之误，谓闲隙也。 郄与隙通。 庄子知北游篇「若白驹之过郄」，释文曰，「郄本作隙」，是也。 故郄有闲隙之义。 礼记曲礼篇「相见于隙地曰会」，郑注曰：「郄，间也」； 庄子养生主篇「批大郄」，德充符篇「使日夜无郄」，释文引崔李云，「郄，间也」，并可为证。 物奚自入焉？ 〔注〕自然之分不亏，则形神全一，忧患奚由而入也？ 〔解〕宝道则性全，去情则无郄无朕无迹也，外物何从而入焉？ 夫醉者之坠于车也，释文「坠」作「队」，云：队音坠。 虽疾不死。 骨节与人同，而犯害与人异，其神全也。 乘亦弗知也，坠亦弗知也。 〔注〕此借粗以明至理之必然也。 释文云：乘，食陵切。 死生惊惧不入乎其胸，是故物而不慑。 〔注〕向秀曰：遇而不恐也。 「」秦刻卢解本作「忤」。 秦恩复曰：「」「忤」古字通。 释文云：遌音忤，遇也。 一本作，心不欲见而见曰，于义颇迂。 庄子亦作。 慑，之涉切。 彼得全于酒而犹若是，〔注〕向秀曰：醉故失其所知耳，非自然无心也。 而况得全于天乎？ 〔注〕向秀曰：得全于天者，自然无心，委顺至理也。 圣人藏于天，故物莫之能伤也。 〔注〕郭象曰：不窥性分之外，故曰藏也。 〔解〕夫醉人者，神非合于道也，但为酒所全者，忧惧不入于天府，死生不伤其形神。 若得全于神者，故物不能伤也。 释文云：窥，去随切。 列御寇为伯昏无人射，释文无作无，云：为，于伪切。 无，莫侯切，下并同。 引之盈贯，〔注〕尽弦穷镝。 释文云：镝音的。
chunks.translated_text:
**[Annotation]** Those who seek to trace form and sound to exhaust their beginnings and ends—how could they ever reach the ultimate destination?

**[Exegesis]** Forgetting form and preserving spirit, one attains the formless; treasuring authenticity and uniting with the Dao, one rests where there is no transformation. If one attains this Dao and exhausts principle to fulfill one’s nature, how could they not be correct?

*"And be correct"* originally read *"become correct."* Yu Yue said: *"Become correct"* should be *"and rest,"* a scribal error. *"Rest"* and *"correct"* resemble each other in form, while *"become"* in ancient script (□) also resembles *"and."* The *Zuozhuan* (Year 14 of Duke Xiang) reads: *"Is archery ritual?"*—the *Taiping Yulan*’s *Jiju* section quotes it as *"Is archery and ritual?"* The *Mencius* (*Teng Wen Gong*) reads: *"A square li forms a well,"*—the *Lunyu* (*Yan Yuan*) *Zhengyi* quotes it as *"A square li becomes a well,"* both serving as evidence. The *Zhuangzi* (*Da Sheng*) cites this passage as: *"One who attains this and exhausts it—how could things restrain them?"*—this may be used to emend the text. Wang Chongmin said: The Jifu edition reads *"become"* as *"and."* Lu’s note: Yu and Wang’s arguments are sound. The *"become"* is here corrected to *"and"* following the Jifu edition.

They will abide in measure without excess,
**[Annotation]** Those who, upon encountering form and color, do not seek their beginnings and ends do not lose the correctness of nature.
*"Excess"* should be *"indulgence."* *Shiwen* notes: *"Excess"* is pronounced *yin.*

And conceal themselves in the traceless principle,
**[Annotation]** How could the ultimate principle be concealed? Acting without attachment, it is obscure and without trace, its boundaries unseen.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Seen"* is pronounced *xiàn.*

Wandering where the myriad things begin and end.
**[Annotation]** Those who ride principle without intention always wander alongside the myriad things—how could they lack traces of beginning and end?

**[Exegesis]** The perfected person speaks without losing virtue, thus not indulging their measure; acts without losing trace, thus concealing themselves in the traceless; constantly returns to their root, thus wandering the beginnings and ends of the myriad things.
Lu’s note: *"Principle"* and *"begin"* rhyme, both belonging to the *zhi* group’s rising tone in ancient phonology.

Unifying their nature, nurturing their *qi,*
*Shiwen* notes: *"Nurturing their qi"* in one version reads *"authenticating their qi."*

Embracing their virtue, to connect with that which things create.
**[Annotation]** Those whose *qi* is unified and virtue pure—how could they merely connect with themselves? Wherever things reach, they ensure no obstruction, thereby universally aiding all beings.
*"Create"* is pronounced *cāo.*

**[Exegesis]** When nature is not disordered, it is solely authentic, uniting virtue with heaven and earth to connect with the nature and destiny of the myriad things.
Lu Wenchang said: At the end of Zhang’s annotation, the Zang edition includes the character *"you"* after *"pronounced cāo."*
*Shiwen* notes: *"Create"* is pronounced *cāo* (seven *dào* cut), meaning *"to reach."*

One such as this preserves their heavenly endowment whole, their spirit without gap.
*"Gap"*—*Shiwen* writes *"郤,"* noting: *"郤"* is pronounced *xì,* meaning *"interval."*
Yu Yue said: *Shiwen*’s *"interval"* is an error for *"crevice,"* referring to a fissure. *"郤"* and *"隙"* are interchangeable. The *Zhuangzi* (*Zhi Bei You*) reads: *"Like a white colt passing through a gap,"*—*Shiwen* notes: *"Gap"* originally read *"隙,"* confirming this. Thus *"郤"* carries the meaning of *"crevice."* The *Liji* (*Qu Li*) reads: *"Meeting in a gap is called a gathering,"*—Zheng Xuan’s commentary: *"郤* means *interval."* The *Zhuangzi* (*Yang Sheng Zhu*) reads: *"Striking the great gap,"* and (*De Chong Fu*) *"causing day and night to have no gap,"*—*Shiwen* cites Cui and Li: *"郤* means *interval,"* all serving as evidence.

How could things enter them?
**[Annotation]** When one’s allotted nature remains unharmed, form and spirit are whole and unified—how could sorrow and disaster enter?
**[Exegesis]** Treasuring the Dao preserves one’s nature; eliminating emotion leaves no gap, no sign, no trace—how could external things enter?

When a drunkard falls from a carriage,
*Shiwen* writes *"falls"* as *"队,"* noting: *"队"* is pronounced *zhuì.*

Though swift, they do not die. Their bones and joints are the same as others’, yet the harm they suffer differs—because their spirit is whole. They neither know they are riding nor know they have fallen.
**[Annotation]** This borrows the coarse to clarify the inevitable truth of the ultimate principle.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Riding"* is pronounced *shèng.*

Death and life, alarm and fear do not enter their breast, thus they encounter things without trembling.
**[Annotation]** Xiang Xiu said: They meet without terror.
*"Encounter"*—the Qin engraving’s Lu exegesis reads *"忤."*
Qin Enfu said: *""* and *"忤"* are interchangeable characters.
*Shiwen* notes: *"遌"* is pronounced *wǔ,* meaning *"encounter."* One version reads *","* glossed as *"seeing what one does not wish to see,"* which is rather forced. The *Zhuangzi* also writes *"."*
*"Trembling"* is pronounced *zhé.*

If one can be whole through wine and yet be thus,
**[Annotation]** Xiang Xiu said: Drunkenness causes them to lose what they know—this is not the natural absence of intention.

How much more so for one whole through heaven?
**[Annotation]** Xiang Xiu said: One whole through heaven naturally lacks intention, submitting to the ultimate principle.

The sage conceals themselves in heaven, thus nothing can harm them.
**[Annotation]** Guo Xiang said: Not peering beyond the bounds of one’s nature is called *"concealing."*
*Shiwen* notes: *"Peering"* is pronounced *kuī.*

**[Exegesis]** The drunkard’s spirit is not united with the Dao—they are merely preserved by wine, so alarm and fear do not enter their heavenly storehouse, and death and life do not harm their form and spirit. If one is whole through spirit, then things cannot harm them.

Lie Yukou shot for Bo Hun Wuren,
*Shiwen* writes *"Wuren"* as *"Wu,"* noting: *"For"* is pronounced *wèi;* *"Wu"* is pronounced *móu,* and so on below.

Drawing the bow to its fullest,
**[Annotation]** Exhausting the string and piercing the arrowhead.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Arrowhead"* is pronounced *dí.*

Zhang Zhan and Yin Jingshun both lacked understanding of phonetics, so their pronunciations are not always reliable and should not be over-scrutinized. *Shiwen* notes: *"造"* is pronounced *zuò*, *zàng zuò* cut, same as the annotation.

*"One who attains this and exhausts it—how could they be corrected?"* *Shiwen* notes: *"焉"* is pronounced *yán*. *"得而正焉?"*

chunks.original_text: 措杯水其肘上，〔注〕手停审故，杯水不倾。 注「故」四解本作「固」，误。 释文云：杯，必回切。 肘，竹九切。 发之，镝矢复沓，〔注〕郭象曰：矢去也。 箭镝去复往沓。 释文「镝」作「摘」，云：摘音的，本作镝。 复，扶又切。 沓音踏。 方矢复寓。 〔注〕郭象曰：箭方去，未至的，以复寄杯于肘，言敏捷之妙也。 奚侗曰：说文：镝，矢锋也。 小尔雅：沓，合也。 楚辞天问「天何所沓」，王逸注：「沓，合也。 」诗秦风：「方何为期。 」郑笺，「方今以何时为还期乎」，是方有今义。 发之镝矢复沓，言已发者，镝与矢复相连合。 方矢犹今矢，是引而未发之矢。 对已发者言，则未发者为今矢； 若以先后言，则今矢又为后矢。 方矢复寓，言后矢又寓于弦也。 仲尼篇「善射能令后镞中前括，发发相及，矢矢相属。 前矢造准而无绝落，后矢之括犹衔弦，视之若一焉」，正可移释此文。 释文云：寓音遇。 捷，疾叶切。 当是时也，犹象人也。 〔解〕引满而置水于其肘上，发一箭复沓一箭，犹如泥木象人也。 志审神定，形不动，以致于此也。 释文云：木偶人形曰象人。 伯昏无人曰：「是射之射，〔注〕虽尽射之理，而不能不以矜物也。 非不射之射也。 〔注〕忘其能否，虽不射而同乎射也。 当与汝登高山，履危石，临百仞之渊，若能射乎？ 」〔注〕内有所畏惧，则失其射矣。 〔解〕恃其能而安其形审其当耳，非谓忘形遗物而以神运者也。 伯峻案：当即傥，若也，如也。 韩非子人主篇，「当使虎豹失其爪牙，则人必制之矣」，当即傥也，可证。 于是无人遂登高山，履危石，临百仞之渊，背逡巡，足二分垂在外，释文云：逡，七旬切。 二分垂谓足二分悬垂在外。 揖御寇而进之。 御寇伏地，汗流至踵。 〔解〕登高履危而惧若此者，忧其身，惜其生也。 曾不知有其形者，适足以伤其生； 忘其形者，适所以成其生。 御寇但善于射者，非合于道也。 若忘形全神无累于天下者，乃不射之射也。 释文云：踵音肿。 伯昏无人曰：「夫至人者，上窥青天，下潜黄泉，挥斥八极，释文云：斥音尺。 郭象云：挥斥犹放纵也。 又曰：挥斥，奋迅也。 神气不变。 〔注〕郭象曰：挥斥犹纵放也。 夫德充于内，则神满于外，无远近幽深，所在皆明，故审安危之机而泊然自得也。 注「曰」字汪本作为「云」，今从北宋本、藏本订正。 今汝怵然有恂目之志，秦恩复曰：恂当作。 释文云：怵，丑律切。 恂音荀。 何承天纂要云：吴人呼瞬目为恂目。 尔于中也殆矣夫！ 」〔注〕郭象曰：不能明至分，故有惧而所丧者多矣，岂唯射乎？ 〔解〕夫至道之人自得于天地之间，神气独主，忧乐不能入也。 今汝尚恐惧之若此，岂近乎道者耶？ 汝于是终始初习耳，未能得其妙也。
chunks.translated_text:
He placed a cup of water on his elbow—
**[Annotation]** The hand remained steady, so the cup of water did not spill.
**[Note]** The character *"gu"* (故) in four *jie* editions appears as *"gu"* (固), which is incorrect.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Cup"* is pronounced *bēi;* *"elbow"* is pronounced *zhǒu.*

He loosed the arrow, and the arrowhead returned in succession—
**[Annotation]** Guo Xiang said: The arrow had departed.
The arrowhead, once loosed, returned in sequence.
*Shiwen* writes *"dí"* (镝) as *"zhāi"* (摘), noting: *"Zhāi"* is pronounced *dí,* originally written as *"dí"* (镝). *"Returned"* is pronounced *fù;* *"succession"* is pronounced *tà.*

The arrow just loosed still lingered—
**[Annotation]** Guo Xiang said: As the arrow had just departed and not yet reached the target, it again rested upon the cup on the elbow—this speaks to the marvel of swiftness.
Xi Xiong said: The *Shuowen* states: *"Dí"* (镝) is the tip of an arrow. The *Xiao Erya* says: *"Tà"* (沓) means *"to join."* The *Chu Ci*’s *"Tian Wen"* asks, *"Where does Heaven join?"* Wang Yi’s commentary: *"Tà"* means *"to join."* The *Book of Songs*’ *"Qin Feng"* reads: *"When shall we meet again?"* Zheng Xuan’s commentary: *"Now, at what time shall we set the date of return?"*—thus *"fāng"* (方) carries the sense of *"now."* *"Fā zhi dí shǐ fù tà"* (发之镝矢复沓) means that the loosed arrowhead and shaft join in sequence. *"Fāng shǐ"* (方矢) refers to the arrow of the present moment, one drawn but not yet loosed. In contrast to the loosed arrow, the unloosed one is the *"now-arrow"*; yet in terms of sequence, the *"now-arrow"* becomes the later arrow. *"Fāng shǐ fù yù"* (方矢复寓) means the later arrow again rests upon the string. The *"Zhongni"* chapter states: *"A skilled archer can make the rear arrow’s head strike the front arrow’s nock, each shot following the last, each arrow linking to the next. The front arrow reaches the mark without falling, while the nock of the rear arrow still holds the string—seen from afar, they appear as one."* This passage may be applied to explain the present text.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Yù"* (寓) is pronounced *yù;* *"swiftness"* is pronounced *jié.*

At that moment, he resembled a wooden figure—
**[Exegesis]** Drawing the bow to full tension and placing water upon his elbow, he loosed one arrow after another in succession, like a clay or wooden effigy. His will was focused, his spirit settled, his form unmoving—thus he achieved this feat.
*Shiwen* notes: A wooden puppet is called a *"xiàngrén"* (象人).

Bo Hun Wuren said: "This is the shooting of one who shoots—
**[Annotation]** Though he has mastered the principles of shooting, he cannot help but take pride in his skill.
It is not the shooting of one who does not shoot—
**[Annotation]** Forgetting success or failure, though not shooting, he is one with shooting.

Let us ascend a high mountain, tread upon perilous rocks, and stand at the edge of an abyss a hundred *ren* deep—could you still shoot then?"
**[Annotation]** If one harbors fear within, one loses their skill in shooting.
**[Exegesis]** Relying on one’s ability and feeling secure in form and aim is not the same as forgetting form, relinquishing things, and moving with spirit.

**[Bo Jun’s Note]** *"Dāng"* (当) should be *"tǎng"* (傥), meaning *"if"* or *"as."* The *Han Feizi*’s *"Ren Zhu"* chapter states: *"If tigers and leopards were to lose their claws and fangs, men would surely subdue them"*—here, *"dāng"* is likewise *"tǎng,"* providing evidence.

Thereupon, Wuren ascended the high mountain, trod upon perilous rocks, and stood at the edge of an abyss a hundred *ren* deep. Turning his back, he retreated hesitantly, with two parts of his feet dangling over the edge.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Qūn"* (逡) is pronounced *qūn;* *"two parts dangling"* means two parts of the feet hung suspended over the void.

He beckoned Lie Yukou forward. Yukou prostrated himself on the ground, sweat streaming down to his heels.
**[Exegesis]** Ascending heights and treading peril, he feared thus because he cherished his body and clung to life. Little did he know that attachment to form is precisely what harms life, while forgetting form is what fulfills it. Yukou was merely skilled in shooting, not one with the Dao. Only one who forgets form, preserves spirit, and bears no burden in the world embodies the shooting of one who does not shoot.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Heel"* is pronounced *zhǒng.*

Bo Hun Wuren said: "The perfected person—
gazes upward into the blue sky, plunges downward into the Yellow Springs, roams to the eight limits,
*Shiwen* notes: *"Chì"* (斥) is pronounced *chǐ.*
Guo Xiang said: *"Huīchì"* (挥斥) means *"to roam freely."*
He also said: *"Huīchì"* means *"vigorous and swift."*
Their spirit and qi remain unaltered—
**[Annotation]** Guo Xiang said: *"Huīchì"* means *"to roam freely."* When virtue fills the inner self, spirit overflows externally. No matter how distant, deep, or obscure, all is illuminated—thus one discerns the mechanisms of safety and danger yet rests in serene self-possession.
**[Note]** The character *"yuē"* (曰) in Wang’s edition appears as *"yún"* (云); here, it is corrected according to the Northern Song and *Zang* editions.

Now you startle with fear, your eyes darting—
**[Qin Enfu’s Note]** *"Xún"* (恂) should be *"shùn"* ().
*Shiwen* notes: *"Chù"* (怵) is pronounced *chù;* *"xún"* (恂) is pronounced *xún.*
The *Zuan Yao* by He Chengtian states: The people of Wu call blinking *"xúnmù"* (恂目).

How perilous your inner state has become!"
**[Annotation]** Guo Xiang said: Failing to grasp the ultimate principle, one is beset by fear and loses much—how could this apply only to shooting?
**[Exegesis]** The person of the utmost Dao is self-possessed between Heaven and Earth, their spirit and qi sovereign. Joy and sorrow cannot enter. Now you tremble with such fear—how could this be near the Dao? You have merely begun to learn, yet have not attained its marvel."
chunks.overlap_context:
rely preserved by wine, so alarm and fear do not enter their heavenly storehouse, and death and life do not harm their form and spirit. If one is whole through spirit, then things cannot harm them.

Lie Yukou shot for Bo Hun Wuren,
*Shiwen* writes *"Wuren"* as *"Wu,"* noting: *"For"* is pronounced *wèi;* *"Wu"* is pronounced *móu,* and so on below.

Drawing the bow to its fullest,
**[Annotation]** Exhausting the string and piercing the arrowhead.
*Shiwen* notes: *"Arrowhead"* is pronounced *dí.*

chunks.original_text: 奚侗曰：志即识字，谓标识也。 犹言表着于外。 中读如字，谓心中也。 礼文王世子礼乐交错于中，郑注：中，心中也。 王叔岷曰：张注引郭象文，庄子田子方篇注迭「有惧」二字，当从之。 此文捝「有惧」二字，文意不完。 释文云：中，丁仲切。 殆矣夫一本作始矣夫。 范氏有子曰子华，善养私名，〔注〕游侠之徒也。 文选陆士衡拟古诗注引「范氏」上有一「晋」字。 许维遹曰：名疑为客之坏字。 注「游侠之徒也」，则原文本作客明矣。 又下文「子华使其侠客」，正承此而言。 举国服之； 有宠于晋君，不仕而居三卿之右。 目所偏视，晋国爵之； 口所偏肥，〔注〕音鄙。 晋国黜之。 〔注〕肥，薄也。 卢文弨曰：注「音鄙，肥，薄也。 」疑本是「音鄙薄」，肥字乃衍文。 段玉裁曰：古肥与非通。 口所偏肥，犹云口所偏非耳。 洪颐曰：汉书叙传「安滔滔而不萉兮」，邓展曰：「萉，避也。 」肥又通作腓字。 诗采薇「小人所腓」，毛传：「腓，避也。 」口所偏避，谓不齿之人。 释文云：肥，皮美切。 按说文字林并作□，又作圮，皆毁也。 字从其省。
chunks.translated_text:
Xu Diao said: *Zhi* (志) is the character *shi* (识), meaning "mark" or "sign"—as in being outwardly manifest. *Zhong* (中) is read as written, meaning "within the heart." As in the *Li Wen Wang Shi Zi* under the *Li Ji*, where Zheng Xuan’s note states: "Zhong means within the heart."

Wang Shumin said: Zhang’s commentary cites Guo Xiang’s text, where the *Zhuangzi* "Tian Zifang" chapter’s note repeats the phrase *"you ju"* (有惧, "with fear"). This should be followed. The present text omits *"you ju"*, leaving the meaning incomplete.

*Shiwen* notes: *Zhong* is pronounced *ding zhong* (丁仲切).

*"Dai yi fu"* (殆矣夫) in one version reads *"shi yi fu"* (始矣夫).

Fan had a son named Zihua, who was skilled at cultivating a private reputation.
**[Annotation]** A knight-errant.

The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on Lu Ji’s *"Nigu Shi"* includes a *"Jin"* (晋) before *"Fan shi"* (范氏).

Xu Weiyu said: *"Ming"* (名, "name") is likely a corruption of *"ke"* (客, "guest"). The annotation—"a knight-errant"—makes it clear the original text read *"ke."*

Furthermore, the following line—*"Zihua sent his knight-errant"*—directly continues this idea.

The whole state submitted to him. Favored by the Lord of Jin, he held no office yet ranked above the Three Ministers. Whatever he glanced at sidelong, the state of Jin ennobled; whatever he spoke of with partiality,
**[Annotation]** *Fei* (肥) is pronounced *bi* (鄙).
the state of Jin demoted.
**[Annotation]** *Fei* means "to slight."

Lu Wenchang said: The annotation—*"pronounced bi; fei means bo"* (薄)—likely originally read *"pronounced bi bo"* (鄙薄), with *"fei"* being a superfluous character.

Duan Yucai said: In antiquity, *fei* (肥) and *fei* (非) were interchangeable. *"Kou suo pian fei"* (口所偏肥) thus means *"kou suo pian fei"* (口所偏非, "what the mouth slights").

Hong Yi said: The *Hanshu* "Xu Zhuan" reads *"an taotao er bu fei xi"* (安滔滔而不萉兮), where Deng Zhan notes: *"Fei* means 'to avoid.'" *Fei* also corresponds to *fei* (腓). The *Shijing* "Cai Wei" states: *"xiaoren suo fei"* (小人所腓), with the *Mao Zhuan* glossing *"fei"* as "to avoid." *"Kou suo pian fei"* (口所偏避) thus refers to those one disdains.

*Shiwen* notes: *Fei* is pronounced *pi mei* (皮美切).

According to the *Shuo Wen* and *Zi Lin*, the character is also written as *□* or *pi* (圮), both meaning "to ruin." The character is an abbreviated form of *qi* (其).

chunks.original_text: 秦恩复曰：说文无□字，当作，俗作脆。 圮当作肥，故释文云字从其省。 多肉之肥字古作□，从□，不从色。 俞樾曰：说文无□字。 □部：□，□也。 □与毁义近是。 □为□之误。 张注曰「音鄙，肥，薄也」，疑本作「肥音鄙，薄也。 」盖谓读如鄙薄之鄙耳。 □字孙愐音符鄙切，与张读正合。 □省作肥，故释文曰字从其省也。 秦氏恩复校刻卢重玄本以□为字之误。 夫何得训毁，于义难通。 盖误读张注作肥薄也，故为此说。 今正其字为□，其义为毁，其音为鄙，则皆得之矣。 秦说非也。 游其庭者侔于朝。 释文云：侔音谋，齐也。 朝音潮。 子华使其侠客以智鄙相攻，强弱相凌。 释文云：相凌一本作相击。 虽伤破于前，不用介意。 释文云：介音界，副也，称也。 终日夜以此为戏乐，国殆成俗。 〔解〕偏视者，顾眄之深也； 偏肥者，毁谤之厚也。 士因其谈以为荣辱，故游其门者比于晋朝。 而子华使令门客恣其言辩，无所回避； 人相毁辱，殆成风俗。
chunks.translated_text:
Qin Enfu said: The *Shuo Wen* lacks the character *□*; it should be written as *脆* in common usage. *圮* should be written as *肥*. Thus, the *Shiwen* states that the character is an abbreviated form of *其*. The ancient form of *肥* ("fleshy") was written as *□*, from *□*, not from *色*.

Yu Yue said: The *Shuo Wen* lacks the character *□*. Under the *□* section: *□* means *毁* ("to ruin"). *□* and *毁* have similar meanings, so *□* is an error for *□*. Zhang’s annotation reads: *"yin bi, fei, bo ye"* ("pronounced *bi*, *fei* means 'slight'"), but it likely originally read: *"fei yin bi, bo ye"* ("*fei*, pronounced *bi*, means 'slight'"). This suggests it is read like *鄙薄* ("slight"). The character *□* is pronounced *符鄙切* (*fu bi qie*) in Sun Mian’s work, which matches Zhang’s reading. *□* is abbreviated as *肥*, hence the *Shiwen* states that the character is an abbreviated form of *其*. Qin Enfu, in his collated edition of Lu Chongxuan’s text, took *□* to be an error for *字*. How could it be glossed as *毁* ("to ruin")? The meaning would be difficult to reconcile. He likely misread Zhang’s annotation as *"fei bo ye"* ("*fei* means 'slight'") and thus proposed this explanation. If we correct the character to *□*, take its meaning as *毁* ("to ruin"), and its pronunciation as *鄙*, then all aspects align. Qin’s argument is incorrect.

*"You qi ting zhe mou yu chao"* ("Those who frequented his court were comparable to the court of Jin"). The *Shiwen* notes: *"mou yin mou, qi ye"* ("*mou* is pronounced *mou* and means 'equal'"); *"chao yin chao"* ("*chao* is pronounced *chao*").

*"Zihua shi qi xia ke yi zhi bi xiang gong, qiang ruo xiang ling"* ("Zihua sent his retainers to attack one another with cunning and vulgarity, to overpower the weak with strength"). The *Shiwen* notes: *"xiang ling yi zuo xiang ji"* ("*xiang ling* ('to bully') has an alternate reading of *xiang ji* ('to strike')").

*"Sui shang po yu qian, bu yong jie yi"* ("Though they were wounded or broken before him, he paid no heed"). The *Shiwen* notes: *"jie yin jie, fu ye, cheng ye"* ("*jie* is pronounced *jie* and means 'secondary' or 'to match'").

All day and night, they made this their amusement, and the state nearly became a custom.

**[Explanation]**
*"Pian shi"* ("partial regard") refers to deep glances; *"pian fei"* ("partial *fei*") refers to thick slander. Scholars took their conversations as the basis of honor and disgrace, so those who frequented his gate were comparable to the court of Jin. Zihua allowed his retainers to indulge in their verbal disputes without restraint, and people mutually slandered and humiliated one another until it nearly became a custom.

chunks.original_text: 禾生、子伯，范氏之上客，出行，经垧外，〔注〕垧，郊野之外也。 释文云：垧，古萤切。 宿于田更商丘开之舍。 〔注〕更当作叟。 释文「更」作「叟」，云：叟，西口切。 秦恩复曰：三老五更，老人之通称，作更于义亦通。 任大椿曰：考文王世子「三老五更」，注，「更当为叟」。 文王世子释文「更，工衡反，注同。 蔡作叟，音素口反。 」田更之作田叟，与五更之作五叟同。 王重民曰：蔡说见独断，且谓俗书嫂作，证更与叟互通。 蔡氏五更之说姑俱不论，而张湛所见已作更，则释文作叟者乃后人所改。 御览三百四十引亦作叟。 中夜，禾生、子伯二人相与言子华之名势，能使存者亡，亡者存； 富者贫，贫者富。 〔解〕存者亡，毁之也； 亡者存，誉之也。 富者贫，夺之也； 贫者富，施之也。 而商丘开下里不达，将谓圣力所成之也。 商丘开先窘于饥寒，释文云：先，悉荐切。 窘，奇陨切，困也。 潜于牖北听之。
chunks.translated_text:
Hesheng and Zibo, eminent retainers of the Fan clan, went on a journey and passed beyond the fields. **[Annotation]** *Shǎng* refers to the outer countryside. The *Shiwen* notes: "*Shǎng*, pronounced *gǔ yíng*." They lodged at the dwelling of the field elder Shangqiu Kai. **[Annotation]** *Gēng* should be written as *sǒu*. The *Shiwen* reads "*gēng* as *sǒu*," noting: "*sǒu*, pronounced *xī kǒu*." Qin Enfu said: "The *Three Elders and Five Gēng* are general terms for the elderly; writing it as *gēng* is also semantically valid." Ren Dachun said: "In the *Wenwang Shizi*, the note to *Three Elders and Five Gēng* states, '*Gēng* should be *sǒu*.' The *Shiwen* of the *Wenwang Shizi* reads: '*Gēng*, *gōng héng* rhyme, the note being the same. Cai writes it as *sǒu*, pronounced *sù kǒu*.' Thus, *field gēng* as *field sǒu* aligns with *Five Gēng* as *Five Sǒu*." Wang Chongmin said: "Cai’s view appears in the *Duduan*, where he argues that in vulgar script, *sǎo* (sister-in-law) is written as [a character resembling *gēng*], proving *gēng* and *sǒu* are interchangeable. Setting aside Cai’s theory on *Five Gēng*, Zhang Zhan’s text already writes it as *gēng*, so the *Shiwen*’s *sǒu* must be a later alteration. The *Taiping Yulan* (340) also cites it as *sǒu*."

In the dead of night, Hesheng and Zibo conversed about Zihua’s fame and influence, how he could make the living perish and the dead live, the rich poor and the poor rich. **[Explanation]** "The living perish" means to slander them; "the dead live" means to praise them. "The rich poor" means to seize from them; "the poor rich" means to bestow upon them. Shangqiu Kai, a man of humble origins, failed to comprehend this, believing it to be the work of some sagely power. Shangqiu Kai had long suffered from hunger and cold—the *Shiwen* notes: "*xiān*, pronounced *xī jiàn*; *jiǒng*, pronounced *qí yǔn*, meaning 'distressed'"—and secretly listened from behind the north window.

Yu Yue remarked: "The north of the window is the very center of the chamber. Hesheng and Zibo lodged in the field watchman’s hut where Shangqiu Kai resided—surely they were within the room itself. How could Shangqiu Kai have listened from behind the north window? *Yǒu běi* likely ought to read *běi yǒu*, meaning 'facing north.' The *Mao Commentary* to the *Ode* 'Seventh Month' states: '*Xiàng* means a north-facing window'—this is correct. The two were inside the room, while Shangqiu Kai listened from outside the north window, which accords perfectly with reason. In antiquity, the chambers of both scholars and commoners all had north-facing windows, as explained in detail in *Qunjing Pingyi*.

Thereupon, he presented himself at Zihua’s gate, offering his labor in exchange for provisions, bearing a basket. The *Shiwen* notes: *Hè* is pronounced *hú kě*; *běn* is read as *běn*, meaning a wicker basket. Zihua’s disciples were all of noble lineage, clad in white silk, riding in carriages, pacing slowly with distant gazes. Upon seeing Shangqiu Kai—aged, frail, dark of face, his robes and cap in disarray—they could not but stare in astonishment. **[Annotation]** *Nè* is pronounced *nú gé*. Bo Jun notes: Wu Kaiseng suggests that *nè* likely means "to gawk in surprise," deriving its sense from the combination of "eye" and "ear." The *Zhonghua Da Zidian* defines it as "to slight," interpreting it according to context. The *Shiwen* reads: *nè*, *nú gé*. The *Fangyan* states: "In the regions of Yang and Yue, when people belittle one another as ignorant, they call it *nè*. *Nè* means disbelief in what one sees and hears."

Soon after, they grew familiar and began to mock and deceive him. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (430) writes *dài* as *gài*. The *Shuowen* states: "*Dài* means to deceive with words"; "*gài* means silk labor." *Dài* is the original character, though later generations often substituted *gài*. The *Zhongni* chapter reads: "I laugh at Long’s deception of Kong Chuan"—these are among the few surviving instances of the ancient character. The *Shiwen* reads: *dài* is pronounced *dài*. The *Fangyan* states: "To deceive one another. Originally written as *gài*."

They shoved, jostled, struck, **[Annotation]** *Dǎng* is pronounced *huǎng*; *āi* is pronounced *wū dài*; *dǎn* is read *dū gǎn*. The *Shiwen* reads: *bèi*, *pú jiè*, meaning fatigued.

Then they ascended a high terrace together. The *Shiwen* writes *jù chéng* as *jù shēng*, noting: *jù shēng* has an alternate version, *jù chéng*. *Chéng* means to ascend. The *Shiwen* writes *shǎng* as *cháng*, reading: *cháng* is pronounced *shǎng*. All clamored to accept the challenge. **[Explanation]** To mock him as a fool, the crowd feigned eagerness to obey. Scholars note: "委曲" means winding or bending. The *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the "Biography of Sima Xiangru," writes *cuī cuò* (崔错) as *bó* (癹), an ancient form of *wěi* (委). The *Wen Xuan*, in the "Rhapsody on Dance," states: "Amid the decadence of the latter age, they return," where Yan Shigu glosses it as *wěi* (委). The *Book of Han*, in the "Biography of Yang Xiong," reads: "The followers were indistinct and could not...," with differing pronunciations and meanings, lacking a *□* sound. The *Yupian* states: *□*, pronounced *qúliú*, refers to well-cooked meat sauce. As for *qū* (曲), Li Shan’s commentary equates it with *wěiqū* (委曲). The pronunciations and meanings differ. The character *fú* (□) is pronounced *fúlóng*. All these relate to *wěi* (委). The *Yupian* also includes the character *□*, pronounced *huán*, citing the *Shuowen* as "scratching a fresh wound." There is also a character *jī* (肌) written as *□*, where the *□* of *yīn* (音) is also written as *jī* (肌). Thus, the *□* in the *Shiwen*’s pronunciation may be an error for another character. Even modern editions remain uncertain about the transmission error in the *Shiwen*. Fan’s faction deemed it coincidental and saw no cause for suspicion. The *Shiwen* writes *jù* (讵) as *jù* (巨), noting: *ǒu* (偶) is pronounced *wǔkǒu*. *Jù* (巨) means "great," with an alternate version as *jù* (讵). Ren Dachun states: In the *Book of Han*, "Annals of Emperor Gao," it reads: "If the Duke of Pei had not first broken through Guanzhong, could you have entered?" where Yan Shigu glosses *jù* (巨) as *jù* (讵). The *Shiwen* on the *Zhuangzi*’s "On the Equality of Things" notes: "Yōngjù (庸讵), where Xu’s edition writes *jù* (讵) as *jù* (巨)," showing that *jù* (讵) and *jù* (巨) are interchangeable. This corroborates Jing Shun’s *Shiwen*, where *jù* (讵) is written as *jù* (巨).

He then pointed to the deep bends of the river’s curve and said: The *Shiwen* notes: *fù* (复) is pronounced *fúyòu*. *Yín* (淫) sounds *shēn*. *Wēi* (隈), pronounced *wūhuī*, means "water’s bend," with an alternate version as *yú* (隅). "Within lies a precious pearl; if you dive, you may retrieve it." The *Shiwen* notes: *yǒng* (泳) sounds *yǒng*, meaning "to swim submerged." Shangqiu Kai then dove in. **[Annotation]** Swimming submerged at the water’s bottom is called *yǒng*. The *Shiwen* notes: *dǐ* (底) is pronounced *dūlǐ*. Upon emerging, he indeed obtained the pearl. The crowd was struck with doubt. **[Annotation]** *Fǎng* (昉) means "to begin." The *Shiwen* notes: *fǎng* (昉) is pronounced *fēnliǎng*, or written as *fàng* (放). Yu Yue states: The ancient character *fàng* (放) is interchangeable with *fāng* (方). The *Book of Documents*, in the "Canon of Yao," reads: "Rejecting commands and disrupting clans," while the *Book of Han*, in the "Biographies of Fu Xi" and "Wang Shang," both write it as "放命圮族," serving as evidence. The *Guangya*, in its "Explanation of Terms," states: *Fāng* (方) means "to begin." Thus, *fǎng* (昉) is a vulgar character, *fàng* (放) is the standard character, and both derive from *fāng* (方), meaning "beginning."

Zihua then began to provide him with meat, grain, clothing, and silk. Soon after, a great fire broke out in Fan’s treasury. chunks.original_text: 范氏之党以为有道，乃共谢之曰：「吾不知子之有道而诞子，〔注〕诞，欺也。 吾不知子之神人而辱子。 御览四三０引作「吾不知子之有道而绐子，吾不知子之有神而辱子」。 子其愚我也，子其聋我也，子其盲我也。 敢问其道。 」〔解〕从台而下若飞焉，入水取珠若陆焉，入火往来无所伤焉，子华门人咸以为神而有道。 此见欺怒而不愠者，必以我等聋盲之辈。 敢问其道。 商丘开曰：「吾亡道。 释文云：亡音无。 虽吾之心，亦不知所以。 御览四三０引「不知」下有「其」字。 虽然，有一于此，试与子言之。 曩子二客之宿吾舍也，闻誉范氏之势，释文云：誉音余。 能使存者亡，亡者存； 富者贫，贫者富。 吾诚之无二心，卢文弨曰：「诚之」太平御览四百三十作「诚信」。 俞樾曰：尔雅释诂：「诚，信也。 」吾诚之即吾信之也。 下文「唯恐诚之之不至」，即唯恐信之之不至也。 故不远而来。 及来，以子党之言皆实也，唯恐诚之之不至，卢文弨曰：御览引不重之字，下同。 伯峻案：引见御览四百三十卷。 行之之不及，释文作「唯恐诚之之不至，至之之不行，行之之不及」； 云：一本无至之之不行一句。 不知形体之所措，利害之所存也。 心一而已。 物亡迕者，如斯而已。 王重民曰：吉府本无上「已」字。 御览四百三十引「而已」作「已矣」。 今昉知子党之诞我，我内藏猜虑，外矜观听，追幸昔日之不焦溺也，怛然内热，惕然震悸矣。 释文云：怛，丁达切，惊也。 水火岂复可近哉？ 」〔解〕老子曰「大智若愚」者，似之而非也。 但一志无他虑，能顿忘其形骸者，则死生忧惧不能入，况泯然与道合，宝神以会真，智周于宇宙，功备群有者，复何得一二论之耶？ 及是非生于心，则水火不可近之也。 释文云：近去声。 自此之后，范氏门徒路遇乞儿马医，弗敢辱也，必下车而揖之。 宰我闻之，以告仲尼。 仲尼曰：「汝弗知乎？

The faction of Fan’s clan, believing him to possess the Dao, collectively apologized to him, saying: “We did not know you possessed the Dao and thus deceived you. The *Taiping Yulan*, fascicle 430, cites this as: *‘We did not know you possessed the Dao and thus misled you; we did not know you were a divine being and thus humiliated you.’* You must think us fools, deaf, or blind. We dare ask: what is your Dao?”

The commentary explains: Descending from the terrace as if in flight, retrieving pearls from water as if on land, and entering and exiting fire unharmed—all of Zihua’s disciples regarded him as divine and in possession of the Dao. Yet here he endures deception and anger without resentment, as if we were deaf and blind. We dare ask: what is your Dao?

Shangqiu Kai replied: “I possess no Dao. The *Shiwen* notes: *wáng* is pronounced *wú*. Even in my own heart, I do not know the reason. The *Taiping Yulan*, fascicle 430, adds a *qí* (其) after *bùzhī* (不知). Nevertheless, there is one thing I can tell you. When those two guests lodged at my dwelling, I heard them praise the power of the Fan clan—they claimed it could make the living perish and the dead live, the rich poor and the poor rich. I believed them wholeheartedly, without doubt. Yu Yue notes: The *Er Ya*’s *Shi Gu* states: *‘Chéng* (诚) means *xìn* (信).’ Thus, *wú chéng zhī* (吾诚之) is *wú xìn zhī* (吾信之). I believed them so completely that I came without hesitation. Upon arrival, I took your faction’s words as truth, fearing only that my belief was not sincere enough. Lu Wenchang notes: The *Taiping Yulan* omits the repeated *zhī* (之) below. Bo Jun observes: This passage appears in *Taiping Yulan*, fascicle 430. I feared my actions fell short, not knowing where to place my body or where harm and benefit lay. My heart was unified, nothing more. When nothing in the external world conflicts with the mind, it is like this. Wang Chongmin notes: The Jifu edition omits the first *yǐ* (已). The *Taiping Yulan*, fascicle 430, cites *éryǐ* (而已) as *yǐyǐ* (已矣). Now that I know your faction deceived me, inwardly I harbor suspicion and doubt, while outwardly I feign composure and vigilance. I cling to the fortune of not having been scorched or drowned in the past, yet my heart burns with distress and trembles with fear. The *Shiwen* notes: *Dá* (怛) is pronounced *dīngdá* and means ‘startled.’ How could I dare approach water or fire again?”

The commentary explains: Laozi’s saying, *“Great wisdom appears foolish,”* resembles this but is not the same. One whose will is single-minded and free of other concerns, who can suddenly forget their bodily form, will find that life and death, joy and fear cannot penetrate. How much more so for one who merges with the Dao, treasures their spirit to unite with the real, whose wisdom encompasses the cosmos, and whose merit suffices for all things—how could such matters be discussed in mere fragments? But once right and wrong arise in the heart, even water and fire become unapproachable. The *Shiwen* notes: *jìn* (近) is read in the falling tone.

The person of utmost sincerity can move all things. They stir heaven and earth, move ghosts and spirits, traverse the six directions without resistance—how could this be limited to treading perilous paths or entering water and fire? The *Shiwen* notes: *xiǎn* (险) is read with the falling tone. If even Shang Qiu Kai’s belief in false things was not rebuffed, how much more so when both self and other are sincere? Young ones, take heed!

The beggars and horse-doctors are all lowly people, yet one does not dare slight them. The Master’s words fully express the principle of utmost sincerity’s power to move. The *Shiwen* notes: *zhì* (识) is read as *zhì*.

During the reign of King Xuan of Zhou, there was a herdsman named Liang Yang in charge of livestock. The *Shiwen* notes: King Xuan was named Jing, son of King Li. *Mùzhèng* refers to the overseer of animals. *Yāng* (鸯) is read as *yāng*. He could raise wild birds and beasts, feeding them within the palace gardens. The *Shiwen* notes: *wěi* (委) is read as *wěi*. *Shí* (食) is read as *sì*; the same applies to *shí hǔ* (食虎) below. Even tigers, wolves, eagles, and osprey—none were not gentle and docile. The original text omits *xùn* (驯) after *róu* (柔); the *Zang* edition and *Shi De Tang* edition include it, and it is now restored. The *Yùlǎn* (926) omits *xùn*. The *Shiwen* notes: *diāo è* (雕鹗) is read as *diāo è*. *Xùn* (驯) is read as *sūn lún*, meaning "obedient." One edition omits *xùn*. Males and females stood before him, breeding in groups. The *Shiwen* notes: *zī* (孳) is read as *zī* or *zì*. *Zīwěi* (孳尾) refers to the reproduction of male and female. Birth and transformation are called *zī*; mating is called *wěi*. Different species lived together without attacking or biting one another. The *Shiwen* notes: *bó shì* (搏噬) is read as *bó shì*. The king, fearing that the skill would die with him, ordered Mao Qiu Yuan to transmit it. chunks.original_text: 梁鸯曰：「鸯，贱役也，何术以告尔？ 惧王之谓隐于尔也，且一言我养虎之法。 凡顺之则喜，逆之则怒，此有血气者之性也。 然喜怒岂妄发哉？ 皆逆之所犯也。 夫食虎者，不敢以生物与之，为其杀之之怒也； 〔注〕恐因杀以致怒。 王叔岷曰：北山录异学篇引「之怒」作「而怒」，下同。 御览八九一、记纂渊海九八引并作「恐怒」，下同。 释文云：为，于伪切，下同。 不敢以全物与之，为其碎之之怒也。 〔注〕恐因其用力致怒。 释文云：碎之一本作决之。 王叔岷曰：事类赋二十兽部一、记纂渊海九八、天中记六十引并作「决之」。 庄子人间世篇同。 时其饥饱，达其怒心。 〔注〕向秀曰：达其心之所以怒而顺之也。 王叔岷曰：淮南主术篇「怒心」作「怒恚」。 「怒恚」与「饥饱」对言，当从之。 「心」盖「恚」之坯字。 虎之与人异类，而媚养己者，顺也； 〔注〕殊性而爱媚我，顺之故也。 故其杀之，逆也。 〔注〕所以害物，逆其心故。 卢文弨曰：藏本注「害物」下有「而」字，疑当作「由」。 注末有「也」字。 王重民曰：庄子人间世杀之作杀者，当从之。 故犹则也，说见经传释词。 此谓虎虽与人异类，其媚养己者，由于能顺其性； 则其所以嗜杀者，由于逆其性也。 王叔岷曰：疑此文本作「故其杀之者逆也」。 今本此文捝「者」字，庄子捝「之」字，文意并不完。 伯峻案：王说是也，张注即是此意，则张所见本尚未误。 然则吾岂敢逆之使怒哉？ 亦不顺之使喜也。 夫喜之复也必怒，怒之复也常喜，皆不中也。 〔注〕不处中和，势极则反，必然之数。 王叔岷曰：埤雅三引「夫」作「何则」。 疑「夫」上原有「何则」二字。 埤雅或略引夫字也。 今吾心无逆顺者也，则鸟兽之视吾，犹其侪也。 释文云：侪，助皆切。 故游吾园者，不思高林旷泽； 释文「旷泽」作「广泽」，云：广本又作旷。 任大椿曰：左传庄二十八年传「广莫」，注云：「旷莫之地。 」荀子解蔽篇，「则广焉能克之」，杨倞注：「广读为旷。 」王霸篇「胡不广焉」，杨倞注云：「或曰读为旷。 」汉书武五子传「横术何广广兮」，苏林曰：「广音旷。 」则广旷通。 寝吾庭者，不愿深山幽谷，理使然也。 〔注〕圣人所以陶运群生，使各得其性，亦犹役人之能将养禽兽，使不相残害也。 〔解〕夫形质各有殊，神气则不异也。 故庄子云，视其异也，则肝胆楚越； 视其同也，则万物一体矣。 至人以神会之也，入鸟不乱行，入兽不乱群者，逆顺同志而不迕； 故猛兽可养，海鸥可狎也。 夫禽兽之入深山幽谷者，欲全其身，远人害也。 苟无其虞，则园庭之与山林，夫何异哉？ 颜回问乎仲尼曰：「吾尝济乎觞深之渊矣，津人操舟若神。 孙诒让曰：说文水部云：「津，水渡也。 」津人盖掌渡之吏士。 左传昭二十四年：「王子朝用成周之宝珪于河，甲戌，津人得诸河上。 」刘向列女传辩通篇「赵津女娟者，赵河津吏之女。 」释文云：操，七刀切，下同。 吾问焉，曰：『操舟可学邪？ 』曰：『可； 能游者可教也，释文云：浮水曰游。 善游者数能。 〔注〕向秀曰：其数自能也，言其道数必能不惧舟也。 释文「不惧舟」作「擢舟」，云：数，色据切，术也，注同。
chunks.translated_text:
Liang Yang said: "I am but a lowly servant—what art could I possibly teach you? Yet I fear the king may suspect I am withholding something from you, so let me speak briefly of my method for raising tigers.

All creatures with blood and qi are by nature pleased when obeyed and enraged when opposed. But are their joy and anger ever wantonly expressed? No—both arise only when their will is thwarted.

When feeding a tiger, one must never offer it living prey, for it will grow furious at having to kill. As the commentary notes: *This is to avoid provoking its killing rage.* Wang Shu-min observes that the *Beishan Lu*’s *Yixue* chapter renders *‘its rage’* as *‘and grow enraged’*; the *Taiping Yulan* (891) and *Jizuan Yuanhai* (98) both read *‘fear its rage’*, with the same variation below.

Nor should one offer it whole prey, for it will grow furious at having to tear it apart. As the commentary notes: *This is to avoid provoking its exertion-induced rage.* The *Shiwen* records an alternate reading of *‘tear it apart’* as *‘rend it’*. Wang Shu-min notes that the *Shilei Fu* (20), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (98), and *Tianzhong Ji* (60) all read *‘rend it’*, as does the *Zhuangzi*’s *Renjian Shi* chapter.

One must time its hunger and satiety, and comprehend the source of its anger. As Xiang Xiu comments: *This means discerning the cause of its anger and aligning with it.* Wang Shu-min notes that the *Huainanzi*’s *Zhushu* chapter reads *‘anger’* as *‘wrath’*—*‘wrath’* pairs better with *‘hunger and satiety’*, so this reading should be followed. *‘Heart’* here is likely a corrupted form of *‘wrath’*.

Though tigers and humans are of different kinds, they fawn upon those who raise them—this is obedience. Thus, when they kill, it is defiance. As the commentary notes: *They harm other beings because their will is opposed.* Lu Wenchang observes that in the Zang edition, the commentary includes an *‘and’* after *‘harm other beings’*, which may originally have been *‘due to’*. The note also ends with *‘also’*. Wang Chongmin notes that the *Zhuangzi*’s *Renjian Shi* chapter reads *‘kill’* as *‘killers’*—this should be followed. *Thus* here functions as *therefore* (see *Jingzhuan Shici*). This means that though tigers differ from humans, their fawning upon their keepers stems from having their nature obeyed, while their bloodlust arises from having it defied. Wang Shu-min suggests the original text may have read *‘Thus those who kill them do so through defiance.’* The current version omits *‘those’*, while the *Zhuangzi* omits *‘them’*—neither is complete. However, Guo Pu’s commentary already reflects this meaning, so his edition must have been uncorrupted.

Then how could I dare oppose them and provoke their anger? Yet neither do I obey them to elicit their joy. For joy inevitably gives way to anger, and anger to joy—both miss the mark. As the commentary notes: *Deviating from the mean, extremes inevitably reverse—this is the natural order.*

Now, my heart harbors neither opposition nor compliance, so birds and beasts regard me as one of their own. Thus, those that roam my garden do not long for lofty forests or vast marshes. As the *Shiwen* records, *‘vast marshes’* is also written *‘expansive marshes’*. Ren Dachun notes: The *Zuozhuan*’s twenty-eighth year of Duke Zhuang reads *‘guangmo’* (广莫), with the commentary glossing it as *‘a desolate expanse’*. The *Xunzi*’s *Jiebi* chapter reads *‘then how could it be vast enough to overcome it?’*, with Yang Liang noting *‘vast’* may be read as *‘desolate’*. The *Wangba* chapter reads *‘why not make it vast?’*, with Yang Liang again noting *‘vast’* may be read as *‘desolate’*. The *Hanshu*’s *Wu Wuzhi Zhuan* reads *‘how boundless is the art of deception!’*, with Su Lin glossing *‘boundless’* as *‘desolate’*. Thus, *vast* and *desolate* are interchangeable.

Those that rest in my courtyard do not yearn for deep mountains or secluded valleys—this is the principle at work. As the commentary notes: *The sage’s way of nurturing all beings, allowing each to fulfill its nature, is like a trainer’s skill in raising animals without letting them harm one another.*

The *Exegesis* states: *Though forms and substances differ, their spirit and qi are not distinct. Thus, the Zhuangzi says: ‘Viewed in their differences, liver and gallbladder are as distant as Chu and Yue; viewed in their sameness, the myriad things are one body.’ The perfected person unites with them in spirit, so that birds do not scatter in flight and beasts do not disperse in herds—opposition and compliance share the same intent without conflict. Hence, fierce beasts can be tamed, and gulls can be befriended. Birds and beasts retreat to deep mountains and secluded valleys to preserve themselves, far from human harm. But if no threat exists, then what difference is there between gardens and forests?*

Yan Hui asked Confucius: *"I once crossed the Goblet Depths, where the ferryman handled the boat as if by magic."* Sun Yirang notes: The *Shuowen*’s *Water* section defines *jin* (津) as *‘a river crossing’*; *jinren* likely refers to the officials or soldiers in charge of ferries. The *Zuozhuan*’s twenty-fourth year of Duke Zhao records: *"Prince Chao used the treasured jades of Chengzhou to sacrifice to the Yellow River. On the jiayin day, a ferryman retrieved them from the river."* Liu Xiang’s *Lienü Zhuan*’s *Biantong* chapter mentions *"Zhao Jinjuan, the daughter of a ferry official of Zhao."* The *Shiwen* reads *cao* (操) as *qī dāo*; the same below.

*"I asked him, ‘Can one learn to handle a boat?’ He replied, ‘Yes. Those who can swim can be taught. Those skilled in swimming often succeed.’"* As Xiang Xiu comments: *Their skill comes naturally—this means their method ensures they are unafraid of boats.* The *Shiwen* records *‘unafraid of boats’* as *‘seizing boats’*, noting *shu* (数) is read *sè jù*, meaning *‘method’*; the commentary concurs.

chunks.original_text: 」〔解〕善操舟者，能学之也； 善游浮者，串习之也； 至乎没人未尝见舟而得者，斯乃神会，彼不能达。 仲尼曰：「□！ 释文云：□音衣，与□同，叹声也。 胡怀琛曰：□即噫字。 吾与若玩其文也久矣，释文云：玩，五贯切，习也。 而未达其实，而固且道与。 〔注〕见操舟之可学，则是玩其文； 未悟没者之自能，则是未至其实； 今且为汝说之也。 陶鸿庆曰：张注「操舟之可学」云云殊谬。 仲尼之意，言吾与汝但玩习道理之文，而未尝取验于事实，固不足以知道也。 下文「壶子曰，吾与汝无（俞氏以无为毌字之误毌即贯习字）其文未既其实而固得道与」注引向秀曰，「夫实由文显，道以事彰」云云，正得其旨。 疑此文且亦当作得，古文字坏其下半，遂误为且矣。 释文云：与音余。 为，于伪切。 能游者可教也，轻水也； 善游者之数能也，忘水也。 〔注〕忘水则无矜畏之心。 卢文弨曰：注藏本作「忘水者则无矜畏之心也。 」陶鸿庆曰：「能游者」下亦当有「之」字。 乃若夫没人之未尝见舟也而谡操之也，彼视渊若陵，视舟之覆犹其车却也。 覆却万物方陈乎前而不得入其舍。 〔注〕神明所居故谓之舍。 卢文弨曰：注藏本作神明所居者故谓之舍也。 俞樾曰：方，并也。 方之本义为两舟相并，故方有并义。 荀子致仕篇：「莫不明通方起以尚尽矣」，杨注曰：「方起，并起。 」汉书扬雄传「虽方征侨与偓佺兮」，师古注曰：「方谓并行也。 」皆其证也。 方陈乎前谓万物并陈乎前也。 奚侗曰：俞说非是。 易恒卦「君子以立不易方。 」王注：「方犹道也。 」覆却承上舟车言，覆却万方谓舟车覆却之道甚多也。 列子黄帝篇衍「物」字，庄子不衍。 恶往而不暇？ 〔注〕所遇皆间暇也。 释文云：恶音乌。 间音闲。

[Solution]
One who skillfully steers a boat can learn it; one who skillfully swims and floats has practiced it in sequence. As for the diver who has never seen a boat yet masters it, this is a matter of spiritual communion—others cannot comprehend it.

Confucius said: “Ah! *Yi*!” [Shiwen] *Yi* (□) is pronounced *yī*, identical to *yī* (□), an exclamatory sound. Hu Huaichen says: *Yi* (□) is the same as *yī* (噫). “You and I have long studied its text,” [Shiwen] *Wan* (玩) is pronounced *wǔ guàn*, meaning “to practice.” “yet have not grasped its reality, and thus merely discourse on the Dao.”

[Annotation]
Observing that boat-handling can be learned is merely studying its text; failing to realize that divers inherently possess the ability is not yet attaining its reality. Now I shall explain it to you. Tao Hongqing says: Zhang’s annotation, “boat-handling can be learned,” is entirely mistaken. Confucius’s meaning is that you and I have only practiced the text of principles without ever verifying them in reality, and thus fundamentally cannot comprehend the Dao. The following passage—“Master Huzi said, ‘You and I have not yet exhausted its text and reality, yet fundamentally grasp the Dao’”—with Xiang Xiu’s annotation, “Reality is revealed through text, and the Dao is manifested through affairs,” precisely captures its intent. It is suspected that *qie* (且) here should also be *de* (得); the lower half of the ancient character was damaged, leading to its misreading as *qie*. [Shiwen] *Yu* (与) is pronounced *yú*. *Wei* (为) is pronounced *yú wěi*.

One who can swim may be taught—this is due to their lightness in water. One who excels at swimming does so through technique, for they have forgotten the water. [Annotation] To forget the water is to be free of pride or fear. Lu Wenchang says: The *Zang* edition of the annotation reads, “One who forgets the water is then free of pride or fear.” Tao Hongqing says: After “one who can swim,” there should also be a *zhi* (之).

As for the diver who has never seen a boat yet acts thus in steering it, to him the abyss appears as a mound, and a capsized boat seems no different from a cart rolling backward. The overturning and retreat of the myriad things lie arrayed before him, yet none can enter his dwelling. [Annotation] This is called the dwelling of spirit. Lu Wenchang says: The *Zang* edition of the annotation reads, “This is the dwelling of spirit, thus it is called *she* (舍).” Yu Yue says: *Fang* (方) means “together.” The original meaning of *fang* is two boats side by side, hence it carries the sense of “together.” In the *Xunzi*’s “Zhi Shi” chapter, “None fail to clearly understand and rise together in pursuit of utmost perfection,” Yang’s annotation says: “Fangqi (方起) means to rise together.” In the *Han Shu*’s “Yang Xiong Zhuan,” “Though together they journey with Qiao and Woquan,” Yan Shigu’s annotation says: “Fang means to travel side by side.” Both serve as evidence. *Fang chen hu qian* (方陈乎前) means the myriad things lie arrayed together before him. Xi Diao says: Yu’s interpretation is incorrect. In the *Yi Jing*’s *Heng* hexagram, “The noble person establishes without changing *fang*.” Wang Bi’s annotation says: “*Fang* means the Dao.” *Fuque* (覆却) follows the above analogy of boats and carts; *fuque wan fang* (覆却万方) refers to the many ways in which boats and carts overturn and retreat. The *Liezi*’s “Huangdi” chapter adds the character *wu* (物), but the *Zhuangzi* does not.

Where could he not find leisure? [Annotation] All he encounters is leisure. [Shiwen] *Wu* (恶) is pronounced *wū*. *Jian* (间) is pronounced *xián*.

is called *sōng tóu sōng nǎo* (倯头倯脑), akin to the Northern term *tóu nǎo* (头脑). In Chu, *sōng* (倯) is also called *sù* (谡). *Liezi* states that one who has never seen a boat yet *sù* (谡) operates it—*sù* here means *to act thus*.

*Sù* (谡) is pronounced *suǒ liù*; *Zhuangzi* writes it as *biàn* (便). *Wù* (鹜) is pronounced *mù*, meaning *duck*. In one version, it is written as *jīn* (矜), an erroneous character.

chunks.original_text: 以瓦抠者巧，释文云：抠，探也，以手藏物探而取之曰抠，亦曰藏彄。 风土记云：腊日饮祭之后，叟妪儿童为彄之戏。 辛氏三秦记：汉钩弋夫人手拳，时人效之，因名为藏钩也。 彄，口侯切，庄子作抠。 秦恩复曰：今本庄子抠作注。 以钩抠者惮，释文云：钩，银铜为之。 惮，待汗切。 以黄金抠者惛。 〔注〕互有所投曰抠。 郭象曰：所要愈重，则其心愈矜也。 注「曰」世德堂本作「者」，非，今从藏本。 沈赤然曰：庄子达生篇袭用此语，而改「抠」为「注」。 按投曰抠，射而赌物曰注。 伯峻案：吾师吴检斋先生云：庄子作「注」，吕氏作「殶」，淮南作「鉒」，声大同，盖博戏胜算之名。 淮南注云：鉒者提马，即投壶为胜者立马之马。 今方俗谓博进之算为注马，其遗语也。 列子作抠，则以为藏彄字，别有意义。 释文「惛」作「殙」，云：殙音昏。 方言曰：迷，殙也。 要，于遥切。 愈音庾，益也。 巧一也，许维遹曰：巧上疑捝其字。 庄子达生篇作「其巧一也」，吕氏春秋去尤篇作「其祥一也」，并有「其」字可证。 而有所矜，则重外也。 凡重外者拙内。 」〔注〕唯忘内外，遗轻重，则无巧拙矣。 〔解〕见操舟者可学者，玩其文也。 若会其真者，彼则视水如陵，覆溺不入其灵府矣，何往而不闲暇哉？ 以瓦投物者，但见其巧中而不惮于失瓦也； 若以钩投物，则不专于巧中，更恐失钩之拙也； 若以黄金为投者，不敢祈中，惟惧失金之损矣。 是知向时之妙忘于外物，今时之惧惜于外物也。 代人知矜外之两失，而贪物以丧其生。 「拙」北宋本作「撰」，汪本从之； 他本作「拱」。 卢文弨曰：「拱」藏本作「拙」，是也。 今从之。 庄子亦作「拙」。 「拱」「拙」形近，故致误。 释文「拙」作「拱」，云：拱本作拙。 孔子观于吕梁，庄逵吉曰：吕梁有有两说，一说在西河。 司马彪曰：吕梁在离石县西是也。 水经注云：河水左合一水，出善无县故城西南八十里，其水西流，历于吕梁之山，而为吕梁洪。 昔吕梁未辟，河出孟门之上。 盖大禹所辟以通河也。 今离石县西历山寻河，并无过峘，至是乃为巨险，即吕梁矣。 在离石北以东百有余里。 （伯峻注：水经注原文止此，因系节引，故不加引号。 以东百有余里，原文作以东可二百有余里，当系偶误。 ）道元虽驳正郡国志，然亦主西河之说矣。 一说在彭城。 俞正燮曰：说符篇云：「孔子自卫反鲁，息驾河梁而观焉」，实是一事。 庄子达生篇河梁即孔子所观。 释文引司马彪云：「河水有石绝处也，今西河离石西有此悬绝，世谓之黄梁。 」吕氏春秋爱类篇：「吕梁未发」，高诱云：「在彭城吕县，大石在水中，禹发而通之。 」淮南本经训「吕梁未发」，注亦云：「在彭城」，按四书所说是两吕梁，庄列之文合在彭城，吕氏淮南吕梁确在离石，古注乃互错。 水经注于泗水引孔子事，河水引吕文及司马说，真为通矣。 庄子释文云，「北人名水皆曰河」，则泗得有河名。 汉书沟洫志云：禹酾二渠，后三代时自荥阳下引河东南为鸿沟，以通宋、卫、陈、蔡、曹、郑，与济、汝、淮、泗会于楚。 泗梁正得名河梁。 宋刘奉世校汉书以为误，妄矣。 或谓泗吕梁始于唐，读史方舆纪要言晋宋已有之，语俱不审。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who play with clay tiles are skillful—*Shiwen* notes: "*Kou* (抠) means to probe; using the hand to conceal an object and probe to retrieve it is called *kou*, also termed *cangkou* (藏彄)." *Fengtu Ji* states: "After the sacrificial drinking on the La day, elders and children play the game of *kou*." Xin’s *San Qin Ji* records: "Lady Gouyi of Han had clenched fists, and people of the time imitated her, thus naming it *canggou* (藏钩)." *Kou* (彄) is pronounced *kou* (口侯切), and *Zhuangzi* writes it as *kou* (抠). Qin Enfu says: "In the current edition of *Zhuangzi*, *kou* is written as *zhu* (注)."

Those who play with hooks are cautious—*Shiwen* notes: "Hooks are made of silver or bronze." *Dan* (惮) is pronounced *dàn* (待汗切).

Those who play with gold are confused. [Annotation] The act of mutual concealment is called *kou*. Guo Xiang says: "The heavier the stake, the more the mind clings." The annotation’s "曰" in the *Shide Tang* edition is written as "者," which is incorrect; the present version follows the *Zang* edition. Shen Chiran says: "*Zhuangzi*’s *Das Sheng* chapter borrows this passage but changes *kou* to *zhu* (注)." Note: *Tou* (投) means *kou*; shooting to wager is called *zhu* (注). Bo Jun notes: "My teacher, Master Wu Jianzai, says: *Zhuangzi* writes *zhu* (注), *Lüshi Chunqiu* writes *zhu* (殶), and *Huainanzi* writes *zhu* (鉒), all phonetically similar, likely referring to the name of a winning tally in gambling." *Huainanzi*’s annotation states: "*Zhu* (鉒) means *tima* (提马), the 'horse' set up for the victor in *touhu* (投壶)." Today, local customs call the gambling tally *zhuma* (注马), a vestige of this term. *Liezi* writes *kou* (抠), treating it as the character for *cangkou* (藏彄), with a distinct meaning. *Shiwen* writes *hun* (惛) as *hun* (殙), noting: "*Hun* is pronounced *hūn*." *Fangyan* says: "Confusion is *hun*." *Yao* (要) is pronounced *yáo* (于遥切). *Yu* (愈) is pronounced *yǔ* (庾), meaning "to increase."

Skill is one—Xu Weiyu says: "The character *qi* (其) is likely missing before *qiao* (巧)." *Zhuangzi*’s *Das Sheng* chapter writes, "Their skill is one," and *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Qu You* chapter writes, "Their auspice is one," both including the character *qi* (其) as evidence.

Yet when one clings, it is an attachment to externals. All who cling to externals are clumsy within. [Annotation] Only by forgetting both internal and external, relinquishing light and heavy, can one transcend skill and clumsiness.

[Exegesis] Observing the boatman reveals what may be learned, for one savors the text. But if one grasps its truth, then he regards water as land, and capsizing or drowning does not enter his mind—where could he not find leisure? Those who wager with tiles see only their skill in hitting the mark and do not fear losing the tile; if they wager with hooks, they are no longer solely focused on skill but also dread the clumsiness of losing the hook; if they wager with gold, they dare not hope to hit the mark, only fearing the loss of gold. Thus, one sees that the former marvel forgot external things, while the latter fears and clings to them. People of this age know the dual loss of clinging to externals yet covet things to the point of forfeiting their lives.

"Clumsy" (*zhuo*, 拙) in the Northern Song edition is written as *quan* (撰), which Wang’s edition follows; other editions write *gong* (拱). Lu Wenchang says: "*Gong* (拱) in the *Zang* edition is *zhuo* (拙), which is correct." The present version follows it. *Zhuangzi* also writes *zhuo* (拙). *Gong* (拱) and *zhuo* (拙) are graphically similar, hence the error. *Shiwen* writes *zhuo* (拙) as *gong* (拱), noting: "*Gong* is originally *zhuo*."

Confucius observed at Lüliang—Zhuang Kuiji says: There are two accounts of Lüliang. One places it in the West River. Sima Biao says: "Lüliang is west of Lishi County." *Shui Jing Zhu* states: "The river converges with a stream emerging eighty *li* southwest of the old city of Shanwu County. The water flows west, passing through the Lüliang Mountains, forming the Lüliang Rapids. Before Lüliang was opened, the river emerged above Mengmen. This was likely the passage Yu the Great opened to channel the river. Today, following the river west from Lishi County, there are no passes until reaching this point, where it becomes a great peril—this is Lüliang. It lies over a hundred *li* northeast of Lishi." (Bo Jun’s note: The original text of *Shui Jing Zhu* ends here; as this is an abridged citation, no quotation marks are added. The phrase "over a hundred *li* northeast" originally reads "over two hundred *li* northeast," likely a minor error.)

Another account places it in Pengcheng. Yu Zhengxie says: The *Shuo Fu* chapter states, "Confucius returned from Wei to Lu, rested his carriage at the river bridge, and observed it," which is the same event. *Zhuangzi*’s *Das Sheng* chapter refers to the river bridge as the place Confucius observed. *Shiwen* cites Sima Biao: "Where the river is cut by rocks, now in the west of Lishi in the West River, there is such a precipitous place, commonly called Huangliang." *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Ai Lei* chapter says, "Lüliang was not yet opened," and Gao You’s annotation states: "In Lü County of Pengcheng, a great stone lies in the water, which Yu opened to clear the way." *Huainanzi*’s *Ben Jing* chapter says, "Lüliang was not yet opened," and its annotation also states: "In Pengcheng." Note: The four texts describe two different Lüliangs. The *Zhuangzi* and *Liezi* passages refer to Pengcheng, while *Lüshi Chunqiu* and *Huainanzi* place Lüliang in Lishi. The ancient annotations are thus confused.

*Shui Jing Zhu* cites Confucius’s observation in its account of the Si River and Lü’s text and Sima’s account in its account of the Yellow River, which is truly comprehensive. *Zhuangzi*’s *Shiwen* states: "Northerners call all waters *he* (河)." Thus, the Si River may also be called *he*. *Han Shu*’s *Gou Xu Zhi* states: "Yu split two channels; later, during the Three Dynasties, a canal was dug from the river southeast of Xingyang to form the Honggou, connecting Song, Wei, Chen, Cai, Cao, and Zheng, and meeting the Ji, Ru, Huai, and Si in Chu." The Si River’s bridge is thus rightly called a river bridge. Liu Fengshi of Song, in his collation of *Han Shu*, mistakenly deemed this an error. Some claim the Si River’s Lüliang originated in the Tang. *Dushi Fangyu Jiyao* states it existed in the Jin and Song dynasties, but such claims are imprecise.
