"If brave men always preserved it, then Duke Zhuang and Duke Ling would still possess it. Bo Jun notes: 'And always preserve it' means 'could always preserve it.' *Néng* (能) and *ér* (而) share an ancient pronunciation, hence they may be used interchangeably. If these several lords were to preserve it, our lord would now be donning a straw raincoat and bamboo hat, standing amidst the furrows of the fields. Would he have leisure to grieve over affairs or contemplate death in vain?

[Annotation] *Xíng jiǎ* (行假) should read *hé xiá* (何暇).
[Exegesis] That the dead may return to life is a notion common to Buddhist scriptures, Daoist texts, and Confucian teachings, though none state it plainly. Here, however, it is said that 'our lord would now be donning a straw raincoat and bamboo hat, standing amidst the furrows of the fields'—thus the principle of life and death is made clear. We know that power brings about destiny, and destiny brings forth life; hence the workings of life’s renewal are evident. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Han Shi Waizhuan* reads *hé xiá* (何暇). The *Shiwen* glosses: *Xíng jiǎ* is pronounced *hé xiá*. Then how could our lord have attained this position and stand here? Because it is by turns occupied and relinquished. As for the lord alone weeping over it—this is unkind. Seeing an unkind lord and flattering ministers, I saw these two things, and this is why I alone secretly laughed."

Bo Jun notes: *Wéi* (为) means *yǐ* (以). "The reason for laughing alone" means "the reason why I alone laughed." For further discussion, see Wang’s *Shici*.

Duke Jing felt ashamed, raised his cup, and punished himself. He then penalized the two ministers, each with two cups. There was a man of Wei named Dongmen Wu whose son died, yet he did not grieve. Wang Shumin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (518), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (48, 51), *Shiwen Leiju* (Later Collection 7), and *Hebi Shilei* (Former Collection 32) all include "aged forty" after "there was a man." The phrase "his son died, yet he did not grieve" is rendered as "he had a son whom he lost, yet he did not grieve."

His steward said: Bo Jun notes: The *Liji*’s "Qu Li" (Part II) states: "A scholar does not refer to his steward or eldest concubine by name." *Xiàngshì* (相室) likely means *jiāxiàng* (家相), the one who assists in household affairs. The *Shiwen* glosses: *Xiàng* is pronounced *sì liàng*. "Your lordship’s love for your son was unmatched in the world. Now that your son has died, why do you not grieve?" Dongmen Wu replied: "I once had no son. When I had no son, I did not grieve. Now that my son has died, it is the same as when I had no son before. Why should I grieve?" Wang Chongmin notes: The *Jifu* edition reads *jù* (讵) instead of *chén* (臣), likely the original read *xī jù yōu yān* (奚巨忧焉). *Xī jù* is a compound, but readers, not grasping its meaning, altered it to place the emphasis on *xī* (奚). Bo Jun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (518) reads: "Then why should I grieve?"

The farmer hurries to the season, the merchant hastens for profit, the artisan pursues his craft, and the official chases power—such is the force of circumstance. Yet the farmer faces drought and flood, the merchant meets gain and loss, the artisan encounters success and failure, and the official meets favor or rejection—such is the force of destiny.

[Annotation] The workings of nature’s hidden course.
[Exegesis] That scholars, farmers, artisans, and merchants each pursue profit and chase power is what their strength can achieve. Drought and flood, success and failure, favor and rejection—these lie beyond their power, so they entrust themselves to destiny and find peace. This is like gathering the mulberry and elm without harming their protection. The world attributes what cannot be helped to destiny, yet those who do not strive are deluded by the semblance of attainment. Dongmen Wu was skilled at accepting destiny, not at understanding it. If the living have one who gives life, then one grasps that which creates one’s destiny; how then could one entrust destiny to the living? This is to grasp the principle of alternating presence and absence. One who understands destiny should entrust it to fate while applying one’s strength.

Qin Enfu notes: Lu’s annotation on the "mulberry and elm" sentence is unclear. Sun Yirang notes: The exegesis likely reads *sāng* (桑) for *sōu* (橾) and *yǔn huò* (陨获) for *sǔn hù* (损护), as seen in the *Liji*’s "Ruxing" chapter. Bo Jun notes: Based on Lu’s exegesis, it seems the *Chongxuan* edition connects "the farmer hurries to the season" to the preceding passage. However, judging by the meaning, "the farmer hurries to the season" and what follows form a separate section, summarizing the chapter’s theme, and thus remains set apart.

chunks.original_text: 〔注〕夫生者，一气之暂聚，一物之暂灵。 暂聚者终散，暂灵者归虚。 而好逸恶劳，物之常性。 故当生之所乐者，厚味、美服、好色、音声而已耳。 而复不能肆性情之所安，耳目之所娱，以仁义为关键，用礼教为衿带，自枯槁于当年，求余名于后世者，是不达乎生生之趣也。 〔解〕夫君子殉名，小人殉利。 唯名与利，皆情之所溺，俗人所争焉。 故体道之人也，为善不近名，不趋俗人之所竞； 为恶不近刑，不行俗人之所非。 违道以求名，溺情以从欲，俱失其中也。 故有道者不居焉。 此言似反，学者多疑。 然则杨朱之篇亦何殊于盗跖也？ 释文云：杨朱，或云字子居，战国时人，后于墨子。 杨朱与禽滑厘辩论，其说也爱己，不拔一毛以利天下，与墨子相反。 陆德明云，「杨戎字子居」，恐子居非杨朱也。 好，呼报切。 恶，乌路切。 复，扶又切。 键音件。 衿音今。 槁，口老切。 梁玉绳曰：庄子应帝王，阳子居，释文，「李云，居，名也。 子，男子通称。 」又寓言篇释文，「姓杨，名朱，字子居」，与老子相问答，何以指为杨朱？ 伯峻案：杨朱与杨子居是否一人，古今颇有争论文字。 汪中述学老子考异之附注以为两人，衍而至于近人唐钺，作杨朱考，载于东方杂志二十二卷五期中，力言杨朱非杨子居。 以为两人者近是。 杨朱游于鲁，舍于孟氏。 孟氏问曰：「人而已矣，奚以名为？ 」曰：「以名者为富。 」「既富矣，奚不已焉？ 」曰：「为贵。 」「既贵矣，奚不已焉？ 」曰：「为死。 」「既死矣，奚为焉？ 」曰：「为子孙。 」〔注〕夫事为无己，故情无厌足。 释文云：为富、为贵、为死、奚为焉、为子孙之为，并于伪切。 厌，一盐切。 「名奚益于子孙？ 」曰：「名乃苦其身，燋其心。 〔注〕夫名者，因伪以求真，假虚以招实，矫性而行之，有为而为之者，岂得无勤忧之弊邪？ 释文云：燋音椒。 乘其名者，泽及宗族，利兼乡党； 况子孙乎？

[Annotation] Life is but a momentary gathering of qi, a fleeting spark of sentience in a single being. What is momentarily gathered must ultimately scatter; what is fleetingly sentient must return to emptiness. Yet to favor ease and detest labor is the constant nature of all things. Thus, what delights one in life amounts to nothing more than rich flavors, fine garments, beautiful forms, and enchanting sounds. Yet one cannot freely follow the inclinations of one’s nature or the pleasures of the senses, instead using benevolence and righteousness as bolts and ritual propriety as sashes, withering away in one’s prime while seeking a lingering reputation in posterity—this is to fail to grasp the joy of the ceaseless arising of life.

[Exegesis] The noble person dies for fame, the petty person for profit. Fame and profit alike are what emotions drown in and the common crowd contends for. Thus, one who embodies the Dao does good without nearing fame, does not rush toward what the crowd competes for; does evil without nearing punishment, does not act in ways the crowd condemns. To violate the Dao in pursuit of fame or to drown in emotion in pursuit of desire is equally to lose the mean. Therefore, one who possesses the Dao does not dwell in such extremes. This passage seems contradictory, and scholars have often doubted it. Yet how does the chapter of Yang Zhu differ from that of Robber Zhi?

The *Shiwen* notes: Yang Zhu, some say his courtesy name was Ziju, was a man of the Warring States period, later than Mozi. Yang Zhu debated with Qin Guli, advocating self-love and refusing to pluck a single hair for the benefit of the world, opposing Mozi’s teachings. Lu Deming states, “Yang Rong’s courtesy name was Ziju,” suggesting Ziju was not Yang Zhu.

*Hao* is pronounced *hūbào*; *wù* as *wūlù*; *fù* as *fúyòu*; *jiàn* sounds like *jiàn*; *jīn* as *jīn*; *gǎo* as *kǒulǎo*.

Liang Yusheng remarks: In the *Zhuangzi*’s “Emperor of the North Sea,” Yang Ziju appears, and the *Shiwen* notes, “Li [Yi] says: *Ju* is his given name; *zi* is a general term for men.” Elsewhere, in the *Zhuangzi*’s “Words for All Occasions,” the *Shiwen* states, “His surname was Yang, given name Zhu, courtesy name Ziju,” where he engages in dialogue with Laozi. How then could he be identified as Yang Zhu?

Yang Jun notes: Whether Yang Zhu and Yang Ziju were the same person has long been debated. Wang Zhong, in his *Shuxue Laozi Kaoyi* appendix, argued they were two distinct figures, and later scholars like Tang Yue, in his *Yang Zhu Kao* (published in *Dongfang Zazhi*, vol. 22, no. 5), insisted Yang Zhu was not Yang Ziju. The view that they were two people is likely correct.

Yang Zhu traveled to Lu and lodged with the Meng family. Meng asked him, “One is merely human—why the need for fame?” Yang Zhu replied, “Fame is for wealth.” “Once wealthy, why not stop?” “For honor.” “Once honored, why not stop?” “For death.” “Once dead, what then?” “For descendants.”

[Annotation] Since one’s affairs never cease, one’s desires are never sated.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Wéi fù*, *wéi guì*, *wéi sǐ*, *xī wéi yān*, and *wéi zǐsūn* are all pronounced with the *wěi* tone. *Yàn* is pronounced *yīyán*.

“What benefit does fame bring to one’s descendants?” Yang Zhu replied, “Fame torments the body and scorches the heart.

[Annotation] Fame is to seek the real through the false, to summon the substantial through the insubstantial, to act against one’s nature and force one’s conduct—how could it not entail the toil of anxiety?

The *Shiwen* notes: *Jiāo* is pronounced *jiāo*.

Yet those who ride upon fame bring blessings to their clans and benefits to their villages—how much more so to their descendants?”

Tao Hongqing said: “The eight characters ‘Fame torments the body and scorches the heart’ should follow the passage above, ‘Master Meng asked: "Man is but man—why seek fame?"’—to reveal the harm of fame and the folly of those who pursue it. Furthermore, the lines ‘Once wealthy, why not cease? Once noble, why not cease?’ precisely describe those who, despite tormenting body and scorching heart, do not desist. Now, mistakenly omitted here, the preceding passage lacks full meaning, while this passage, discussing the benefits of fame, first presents its harms, disrupting the coherence of the argument.”

“Those who pursue fame must be incorruptible; incorruptibility leads to poverty. Those who pursue fame must be yielding; yielding leads to lowliness.”

[Annotation] This is the objection of a disputant. Now, those who possess the fame of incorruptibility and yielding yet cannot escape poverty and lowliness do so because they practice goodness without seeking profit.

[Explication] In this worldly life, man is concerned only with fame and profit. The sage uses fame and profit as a hook: petty men die for profit, gentlemen die for fame—none fail to be ensnared. Though good and evil differ, both involve seeking. Yet those who seek fame and succeed not only attain wealth and nobility but bring glory to their descendants and benefit their villages. Though they torment the body, scorch the heart, and labor in incorruptibility and yielding, their aspirations have an object, and their passions forget themselves—both lose the mean.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Nàn* is pronounced *nǎidàn*.

the lord was licentious, and so was he; the lord was extravagant, and so was he.”

“Their aspirations aligned, their words followed one another, and their Dao was enacted, making the state hegemonic. Yet after death, Guan Zhong was nothing more.”

[Explication] The benefit of true fame is meager.

chunks.translated_text:
[Explication] The benefit of false fame runs deep.

“If true fame leads to poverty, false fame brings wealth.”

[Annotation] To do good without seeking fame, yet fame arises naturally—this is true fame. To pursue fame in order to gain profit while the world remains unaware—this is false fame. False fame is what secures profit.

The annotation “fame arises naturally” reads in the *Zang* edition as “yet arises naturally.”

Yu Yue remarks: After “If true fame leads to poverty, false fame brings wealth,” two sentences should follow: “true fame leads to lowliness, false fame brings nobility.” The preceding text states, “All who seek fame must be incorruptible, and incorruptibility leads to poverty; all who seek fame must be yielding, and yielding leads to lowliness.” Thus, the examples of Guan Zhong and the Tian clan are cited to prove that true fame results in poverty and lowliness, while false fame yields wealth and nobility.

Tao Hongqing states: Yu’s suggestion that two sentences—“true fame leads to lowliness, false fame brings nobility”—should be added is correct. However, his claim that this and the preceding discussion of Guan Zhong and the Tian clan form a single argument is mistaken. The earlier passage reads, “All who seek fame must be incorruptible, and incorruptibility leads to poverty; all who seek fame must be yielding, and yielding leads to lowliness.” Zhang’s annotation rightly treats this as the objection of a disputant. Here, the statement “If true fame leads to poverty, false fame brings wealth; true fame leads to lowliness, false fame brings nobility” likewise represents the objection of a disputant. *Ruo* (“if”) here means “in this manner”; for further discussion, see Wang’s *Jingzhuan Shici* (“*Ruo* may be followed by *ran* [‘thus’]; the phrase ‘Meng Sunyang said, *ruoran* [if thus], swift death is preferable to prolonged life’ in the *Shuofu* and ‘*Ruoran*, why could the dead not speak of the art of living?’ in the *Shuo Fu* provide examples”).

chunks.translated_text:
The claim that Guan Zhong’s descendants were poor and lowly due to their true fame, while the descendants of the Tian clan were wealthy and noble due to their false fame, would imply that fame indeed leads to poverty and lowliness. The disputant’s intent here is that "true" refers to genuine fame, while "false" refers to something other than fame. The subsequent response states, “Truth has no fame, fame has no truth; fame is but falsity.” This means that truth and fame cannot coexist—once something is called fame, it is all falsity with no truth, which would imply that fame indeed leads to wealth and nobility. The respondent’s intent is that "false" constitutes fame, while "true" is not fame. The following response explicitly marks its beginning with *yue* (“it is said”) to distinguish it, leaving no doubt that this is the disputant’s objection. If one were to attribute this and the preceding and following passages to a single speaker, then the lines “Truth has no fame, fame has no truth” and so on would become redundant and superfluous, their purpose unclear.

From “Now that they are wealthy, why not pursue it?” onward, all belong to the disputant’s objections, where the *yue* (“it is said”) is omitted. Readers must discern the meaning for themselves.

It is said: “Truth has no fame, fame has no truth. Fame is but falsity.”
[Annotation] Without falsity, one cannot attract profit.
[Exegesis] Those with true conduct have no fame; those who seek fame have no truth. Thus, without falsity, profit cannot be made manifest.

Formerly—Emending note: The *Taiping Yulan* (424) and *Yiwen Leiju* (21) omit the character *zhe* (“one who”)—Yao and Shun falsely offered the world to Xu You and Shan Juan, yet did not lose the world, enjoying a reign of a hundred years.
[Annotation] The traces of truth and falsity arise from circumstances. Those who achieve falsity follow the traces of Yao and Shun, but the sage is without falsity.
Emending note: Yao’s offer of the world to Xu You is also recorded in the *Zhuangzi*’s “Free and Easy Wandering” chapter; Shun’s offer of the world to Shan Juan is likewise found in the *Zhuangzi*’s “Giving Away a Throne” and “Robber Zhi” chapters.

Boyi and Shuqi truly ceded the rulership of Guzhu—Emending note: The *Taiping Yulan* (424) and *Yiwen Leiju* (21) omit the character *jun* (“lord”), which is correct—and ultimately lost their state, starving to death on Mount Shouyang.

The distinction between truth and falsity is thus made clear.

[Annotation] *Shěng* means "to examine."

If worldly people do not lose their authenticity in pursuit of fame and profit, they will drown in passions and desires, forgetting the Dao.

The good are few in the world, while the unvirtuous are many; thus, those who chase reputation are rare, while those who follow desire are legion. Even the wise can do nothing about this, for all have lost the mean.

The pleasures of this life are not to be forsaken—Yu Yue notes: *"Dāng shēn"* ("this life") is an error for *"dāng shēng"* ("present life"). Below, it states, *"The reputation after death is not to be sought,"* and *"dāng shēng"* directly opposes *"sǐ hòu"* ("after death"). Further on, it says, *"Moreover, hasten to the present life—why rush to consider the afterlife?"*—this serves as proof. *Shiwen* notes: *"Qù"* is pronounced *qiū lǚ*. Thus, one is not swayed by the lure of reputation. The annotation reads: *"Those who do good without drawing near to fame."*

The Northern Song edition, Wang’s edition, and the *Four Explications* edition write *"guān"* ("observe") for *"quàn"* ("exhort"), but here we follow the Jifu edition, the *Daoist Canon* unannotated edition, and the Shidetang edition in correcting it. *Shiwen* notes: *"Quàn"* has a variant reading as *"guān."*

Following one’s nature in wandering, one does not oppose the desires of the myriad things. The reputation after death is not to be sought, so one does not incur punishment. The annotation reads: *"Those who do evil without drawing near to punishment."* Bo Jun notes: Not opposing the desires of the myriad things means not offending others; not offending others means not doing evil, hence one does not incur punishment. Zhang’s annotation touches on this but does not elaborate. *Shiwen* notes: *"Jìn"* is read in the falling tone, and so below. *"Xíng"* means harm.

Fame and reputation, whether early or late, and the length of one’s lifespan are not matters to be measured. The exegesis states: To cite the people of the great antiquity is to suit the mean. That which is born and dies is form; that which emerges into life and enters death is spirit. Knowing that life and death are but fleeting arrivals and departures, one does not urgently seek fame; knowing that spirit is neither born nor dies, one does not anxiously strive for the Dao. Thus, one acts from the heart without resisting what nature favors. One delights in the body alone—what use is there for fame? Thus, one wanders in accord with one’s nature without opposing the desires of the myriad things. One is content in the moment alone—what fear is there of punishment? Therefore, fame, reputation, and lifespan are not matters to be calculated.

Those who delight in the body and are content in the moment move in harmony with the Dao, not drowning in emotion. Yang Zhu said: "What differs among the myriad things is life; what is the same is death. In life, there are the worthy and the foolish, the noble and the base—this is what differs. In death, there is putrefaction and dissolution—this is what is the same. Though this be so, worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness are not within one’s power; putrefaction and dissolution are also not within one’s power. Thus, life is not what one lives, death is not what one dies; worthiness is not what one makes worthy, foolishness is not what one makes foolish, nobility is not what one makes noble, baseness is not what one makes base." The annotation reads: All these are natural, not what one’s power can effect.

Bo Jun notes: After *"gù shēng fēi suǒ shēng"* ("thus, life is not what one lives"), the character *"néng"* ("power") is likely omitted below each *"suǒ"* ("what"). These phrases closely follow *"xián yú guì jiàn fēi suǒ néng yě, chòu fǔ xiāo miè yì fēi suǒ néng yě"* ("worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness are not within one’s power; putrefaction and dissolution are also not within one’s power"). A careful reading of Zhang’s annotation and Lu’s exegesis below suggests that the editions they consulted all included *"néng."*

Yet the myriad things are equal in life and equal in death, equal in worthiness and equal in foolishness, equal in nobility and equal in baseness. The annotation reads: All return equally to nature. Whether ten years or a hundred years, all die. The benevolent and sagely die, the cruel and foolish die. In life, they may be Yao and Shun; in death, they are but rotting bones. In life, they may be Jie and Zhou; in death, they are but rotting bones. The bones rot the same—who knows the difference? Moreover, hasten to the present life—why rush to consider the afterlife? The annotation reads: This mocks those who calculate the afterlife in their delusion.

One who does not scheme for the past, does not worry for the future, and has no attachment to the present—this is the perfection of virtue. The exegesis states: Life is the retribution of this body; death is the exhaustion of this retribution. Worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness are the distinctions of living things—hence they differ. Putrefaction and dissolution are the constants of dead things—hence they are the same. The world points to form as life and death, unaware of the spirit beyond form. When the spirit departs, it is as if all knowledge ceases. Thus, worthiness and foolishness, nobility and baseness, putrefaction and dissolution are not what form itself can effect. If not self-effected, then the substance of all living things has never not been equal. People know what is equal but not why they differ. Moreover, they compete in the present life and have no leisure to nurture what gives them life—thus those who possess the Dao do not conform to this.

Yang Zhu said: "Bo Yi did not lack desire—his error lay in his pride in purity, leading him to starve to death." The annotation reads: He clung to starvation until death. *Shiwen* notes: The *Gongyang Commentary* states: *"Fàng sǐ bù lì"* ("He starved to death without establishing himself"). Liu Zhao’s annotation reads: *"Fàng"* means "to the utmost." Zhan Ji did not lack emotion—his error lay in his pride in integrity, leading him to diminish his lineage. *Shiwen* notes: *"Guǎ zōng"* means "few in lineage." How mistaken is this error of purity and integrity! The annotation reads: These are words that slander the worthy and betray reality, yet to convey praise or blame, one cannot but place responsibility on those of lofty virtue.

The exegesis states: The excess of pursuing fame truly reaches this point—this is not how one embodies the truth, perfects the Dao, forgets fame, and attains reality. Yang Zhu said: "Yuan Xian was impoverished in Lu." Bo Jun notes: *"Jù"* should be *"jù."* The *Shuowen*, *Yupian*, *Guangyun*, *Jiyun*, and *Yunhui* all write *"jù,"* not *"jǔ."* The *Leipian* writes *"jǔ."* The *Jiyun* also includes *"jǔ,"* glossing it as *"ōu jù."* It is suspected that those writing *"jǔ"* were all later scholars from the Tang onward, for before the Tang, there was no character *"jǔ."*

The ear desires to hear sounds, yet if denied, this is called *obstructing hearing*; the eye desires to see beauty, yet if denied, this is called *obstructing sight*; the nose desires to turn toward pepper and orchid, yet if denied scent, this is called *obstructing breath*. All these obstructions are the ways of tyrannical rulers. The annotation explains: *Tyrannical* means excessive. The *Exegesis on Texts* notes: *Tyrannical* means ruinous and cruel. The annotation explains: To cherish reputation and be bound by ritual, inwardly harboring self-importance, fear, worry, and suffering until death, is to value long life and distant years—this is not what I esteem.

The commentary states: Yifu’s talent was sufficient to assist a hegemonic lord and revive decaying order, yet his indulgence in extravagance and excess was enough to offend future generations and corrupt customs. Thus, when the Master praised his talent, he said, “Were it not for Guan Zhong, we would still be wearing our hair loose and folding our robes to the left.” Yet when he condemned his lack of ritual, he said, “Guan Zhong’s vessel was small indeed! If even Guan Zhong knew ritual, who would not know it?” Liezi used a man of great talent to push his desires to the extreme, so that those on the Dao might recognize his errors.

Guan Yiwu asked, “I have already told you of nurturing life—what of sending off the dead?” Yan Pingzhong replied, “Sending off the dead is a trivial matter—what is there to say?” Guan Yiwu said, “I still wish to hear of it.” Pingzhong said, “Once dead, how does it concern me? Burn the body—it is acceptable. Sink it in water—it is acceptable. Bury it in earth—it is acceptable. Leave it exposed—it is acceptable. Clothe it in firewood and cast it into a ravine—it is acceptable. Array it in embroidered robes and place it in a stone outer coffin—it is acceptable. Let it be as circumstances allow.”

[Annotation] Yan Ying was a Mohist. He governed himself with frugality and moderation, moving always in accord with standards and measures, yet he did not grasp the distinction between life and death. Thus, these two worthies are cited to illustrate the proper cultivation of the person, taking only their divergence in extravagance and frugality.

[Exegesis] Worldly people cling deeply to the pursuit of desire but treat the rites of sending off the dead with thin regard. Thin regard makes restraint easy, while deep attachment makes sentiment difficult to govern. Thus, to enrich life is what the multitude delights in; to treat death lightly is what the common heart readily follows. Liezi, then, used the extravagant to give free rein to passion and the frugal to restrain ritual. Hence, the likes of Wangsun were reproved by good officials for losing the middle Way.

Guan Yiwu turned to Bao Shu Huangzi and said, “As for the Way of life and death, we two have advanced in it.”

[Annotation] When one possesses awareness, one’s control is not dictated by external things; when one lacks awareness, it is not what I have heard of.

[Exegesis] Since it is no longer governed by me, one should let things take their course—this is what worldly people mean when they say death is a state of unawareness. When passion is forgotten, cravings no longer exist—how then could one be ensnared by sounds and sights? chunks.original_text: 子纳侨之言，则朝自悔而夕食禄矣。 」朝穆曰：「吾知之久矣，择之亦久矣，〔注〕觉事行多端，选所好而为之耳。 释文云：行，下孟切。 好，呼报切。 岂待若言而后识之哉？ 凡生之难遇而死之易及。 释文云：易，以豉切，下同。 以难遇之生，俟易及之死，释文云：俟一本作傒。 可孰念哉？ 而欲尊礼义以夸人，释文「夸」作「跨」，云：口花切，下同； 一本作夸。 矫情性以招名，吾以此为弗若死矣。 〔注〕达哉此言！ 若夫刻意从俗，违性顺物，失当身之暂乐，怀长愁于一世； 虽支体具存，实邻于死者。 释文云：乐音洛，下同。 为欲尽一生之欢，「欢」元本、世德堂本作「观」，误。 穷当年之乐。 唯患腹溢而不得恣口之饮，力惫而不得肆情于色； 释文云：惫，皮界切。 不遑忧名声之丑，性命之危也。 且若以治国之能夸物，欲以说辞乱我之心，释文云：说辞一本作伪辞。 荣禄喜我之意，不亦鄙而可怜哉？ 我又欲与若别之。 〔注〕别之犹辨也。 释文云：别，彼列切，注同。 夫善治外者，物未必治，而身交苦； 善治内者，物未必乱，而性交逸。 以若之治外，其法可暂行于一国，未合于人心； 以我之治内，可推之于天下，君臣之道息矣。 吾常欲以此术而喻之，若反以彼术而教我哉？ 」伯峻案：「喻之」当作「喻若」。 本作「吾常欲以此术而喻若，若反以彼术而教我哉」？ 「若」字重迭。 古人于重迭处辄省其下文，而画二笔以识之。 钞者不察，以二笔误作之，「若若」遂讹作「若之」。 浅人又谓「若之」不可通，乃乙转成为「之若」，遂铸成此错矣。 子产忙然无以应之。 〔解〕殉情耽欲之人，诡辞邪辩足以塞圣贤之口，乱天下法。 故桀纣之智足以饰非，少卯之辞足以惑众。 虽不屈于一时，亦鼓倡于当代。 故夫子屈盗跖之说，子产困于朝穆之言，不足多悔也。 而惑者以为列子叙之以畅其情，张湛注之以为达其理，斯乃鄙俗之常好，岂道流之雅术乎？ 胡怀琛曰：「忙然」今通作「茫然」。 伯峻案：解「夫子屈盗跖之说」当作为「夫子屈于盗跖之说」，事见庄子盗跖篇。 释文「忙」作「」，云：音忙。 他日以告邓析。
chunks.translated_text:
Zichan heeded Jiao’s words, and by morning he would repent, by evening he would enjoy emolument.”

Zhaomu said: “I have long known this, and long chosen it. The paths of action are manifold—one selects what one prefers and acts accordingly. How could I await your words to recognize it? Life is hard to encounter, death is easy to reach. With life so hard to encounter, to wait for death so easy to reach—how could one not ponder this deeply? Yet you would exalt ritual and righteousness to impress others, feign temperament and nature to seek fame. To me, this is no better than death.

How penetrating are these words! As for those who painstakingly follow convention, violate their nature to comply with things, forfeit the fleeting joy of the present, and harbor lifelong sorrow—though their limbs remain intact, they are already near death. To desire the full enjoyment of life’s delights, to exhaust the year’s pleasures, one need only fear a bloated belly that prevents unrestrained drinking, or weariness that bars indulgence in sensuality. One has no leisure to fret over the disgrace of reputation or the peril of life and fate.

Moreover, do you intend to flaunt your governance skills to impress others, to use specious words to disturb my heart, to delight my mind with rank and emolument? Is this not base and pitiable? I would further distinguish this from your way.

One who excels at governing the external may not bring order to things but will exhaust himself; one who excels at governing the internal may not bring chaos to things but will harmonize his nature. Your way of governing the external may be briefly enforced in one state, yet it does not accord with human hearts. My way of governing the internal may be extended to all under heaven, and the Way of ruler and minister will cease.

I have long wished to explain this method to you, yet you instead instruct me in that method?”

*Note: The text originally read, “I have long wished to explain this method to you, yet you instead instruct me in that method?” The repetition of “you” was indicated by a mark in the original, later miscopied as “之若,” resulting in the present error.*

Zichan was left speechless, unable to respond.

[Exegesis] Those who pursue passion and indulge desire wield cunning words and perverse arguments sufficient to silence the mouths of sages and disrupt the laws of all under heaven. Thus, Jie and Zhou’s intelligence could adorn their wrongdoing, and Shaowu’s rhetoric could bewilder the masses. Though they may not have prevailed in their time, they stirred up their era. Thus, the Master was confounded by the words of Robber Zhi, and Zichan was stymied by Zhaomu’s speech—no great regret. Yet the deluded believe *Liezi* recounts this to express its sentiment, and Zhang Zhan annotates it to elucidate its principle. Such is the common taste of the vulgar—how could it be the refined art of the Dao’s lineage?

Hu Huaichen notes: “忙然” is now commonly written as “茫然.”

*Note: The exegesis originally read, “the Master was confounded by the words of Robber Zhi,” referring to the episode in the *Zhuangzi*, “Robber Zhi.”*

Later, Zichan reported this to Deng Xi.

Zichan followed Deng Xi’s advice. Taking advantage of an opportunity, he visited his brothers and addressed them, the *Shiwen* notes: *Jian* (opportunity) is pronounced *jian*. Saying: “What makes humans noble above beasts is wisdom and foresight. What wisdom and foresight guide is ritual and righteousness. When ritual and righteousness are perfected, fame and position follow. If you act on impulse, indulging in desires, your life and fate will be imperiled.”

chunks.original_text: 邓析曰：「子与真人居而不知也，孰谓子智者乎？ 郑国之治偶耳，非子之功也。 」〔注〕不知真人则不能治国，治国者偶尔。 此一篇辞义太径挺抑抗，不似君子之音气。 然其旨欲去自拘束者之累，故有过逸之言者耳。 〔解〕夫当才而赏之，择德而任之，则贤者日进而不肖者退矣。 任必以才，善人之道亨通矣； 退必不肖，小人之道不怨矣。 使贤不肖各安其分，适其志，则郑国之治当矣。 彼二子酣酒而爱色，礼义所不修，不因父兄之势以干时，纵心嗜欲而不悔，此诚真人也。 而乃欲矫其迹，为其心，取禄位以私之，是国偶然有以理，非子之至公也，岂得为智乎？ 此言真人者，非真圣之人，乃真不才之人。 注「太」世德堂本作「大」。 卢文弨曰：注「径挺」庄子作「径庭」，又作「俓侹」。 秦恩复曰：解「为其心」，「为」「伪」古字通。 荀子性恶篇杨倞注：「伪，为也，矫也。 凡非天性而人作为之者谓之伪，故伪字人傍为，亦会意字也。 」释文「径挺」作「径廷」，云：廷音听。 抗，苦浪切。 去，丘吕切。 累去声。 卫端木叔者，子贡之世也。 伯峻案：秦策：「泽可以遗世。 」注云：「世，后世也。 」晋语：「非德不及世。 」注云：「世，嗣也。 」「子贡之世」谓子贡之后。 下云「藉其先赀」，谓藉子贡之赀，以子贡善货殖故也。 浅人不达世字之义，妄加父字。 御览四七七又四九三引皆作「世父」，其实非也。 但八三０引无「父」字，未误。 亦有妄加「子」字者，如白孔六帖十九所引。 藉其先赀，伯峻案：管子内业篇：「彼自来可藉与谋。 」注云：「藉，因也。 」释文云：赀音髭。

Deng Xi said: “You lived alongside a true person yet did not recognize him—how can you be called wise? The governance of Zheng was merely coincidental, not your achievement.”

*[Annotation:]*
Not knowing a true person, one cannot govern a state; governance is but a matter of chance.

This entire passage is too blunt and confrontational in its rhetoric, lacking the tone of a gentleman. Yet its intent is to relieve the burdens of those who constrain themselves, hence its excessively unrestrained words.

*[Exegesis:]*
When rewards are given according to ability and appointments made by virtue, the worthy advance day by day while the unworthy retreat. If appointments are made solely by talent, the Way of the good prospers; if the unworthy are inevitably dismissed, the Way of the petty incurs no resentment. Let the worthy and unworthy each settle into their proper place and fulfill their aspirations, and the governance of Zheng will be fitting.

Those two men indulged in wine and sensual pleasures, neglecting ritual and righteousness. They did not rely on the influence of fathers and elder brothers to seize opportunities, but followed their desires without remorse—these were truly true persons. Yet you sought to correct their conduct and feign their intentions, seizing emoluments and rank for private gain. That the state happened to be well-ordered was no credit to your impartiality—how could this be called wisdom?

Here, “true person” does not refer to a truly sagely individual, but to one who is genuinely without talent.

*[Annotation:]*
The character *tai* (太) in the *Shidetang* edition appears as *da* (大).

Lu Wenchang notes: In the *Zhuangzi*, the phrase “jingting” (径挺) appears as “jingting” (径庭) or “jingtin” (俓侹).

Qin Enfu observes: In the exegesis, “wei qi xin” (为其心), *wei* (为) and *wei* (伪) were interchangeable in ancient script. Yang Liang’s commentary on the *Xunzi*’s “Xing’e” chapter states: “‘Wei’ means ‘to do’ or ‘to feign.’ Anything not of innate nature but contrived by humans is called *wei*. Thus, the character *wei* (伪) combines *ren* (人) and *wei* (为), forming a compound ideograph.”

The *Shiwen* renders “jingting” (径挺) as “jingtin” (径廷), with *ting* (廷) pronounced *ting* (听). *Kang* (抗) is pronounced *kang* (苦浪切). *Qu* (去) is pronounced *qǔ* (丘吕切). *Lei* (累) is read in the falling tone.

Wei’s Duanmu Shu was a descendant of Zigong. *[Exegesis by Bo Jun:]* The *Strategies of Qin* states: “Marshlands can be bequeathed to posterity,” with the annotation: “‘Posterity’ refers to later generations.” The *Discourses of Jin* reads: “Without virtue, one does not reach the age,” with the annotation: “‘Age’ means succession.” Thus, “descendant of Zigong” refers to Zigong’s posterity. Below, it says “relying on his ancestral wealth,” meaning he relied on Zigong’s wealth, for Zigong was skilled in commerce. Shallow-minded people, not grasping the meaning of *shi* (世, “posterity”), arbitrarily added the character *fu* (父, “father”). The *Taiping Yulan* (477 and 493) both cite it as “Shifu” (世父), but this is incorrect. However, the citation in volume 830 omits *fu* (父), avoiding the error. Others have mistakenly added *zi* (子), as in the *Bai-Kong Liutie* (19).

“Relying on his ancestral wealth.” *[Exegesis by Bo Jun:]* The *Guanzi*’s “Neiye” chapter states: “That which comes of itself may be relied upon for counsel,” with the annotation: “‘Rely’ means ‘to depend upon.’” The *Shiwen* glosses *zi* (赀) as *zi* (髭).

chunks.original_text: 家累万金。 不治世故，放意所好。 释文云：好，呼报切，下同。 其生民之所欲为，人意之所欲玩者，无不为也，无不玩也。 墙屋台榭，园囿池沼，饮食车服，声乐嫔御，拟齐楚之君焉。 至其情所欲好，耳所欲听，目所欲视，口所欲尝，虽殊方偏国，〔注〕偏，边。 非齐土之所产育者，无不必致之； 俞樾曰：下文云：「虽山川阻险，涂径修远，无不必之」。 则此文当云「无不必致」，误衍「之」字。 犹藩墙之物也。 释文「藩」作「蕃」，云：甫袁切。 任大椿曰：周礼大司徒注云：「杜子春读蕃乐为藩乐。 」诗「折柳樊圃」，释文，「樊，藩也，本又作蕃」。 韩奕释文同。 左传昭二十八年释文，「藩亦作蕃」。 楚语，「为之关钥蕃篱」，韦昭注，「蕃篱，壁落也。 蕃篱即藩篱也」，则藩蕃通。 及其游也，虽山川阻险，释文「阻险」作「岨崄」，云：岨与阻同，崄与险同。 任大椿曰：水经注「阻险」多作「岨崄」，与释文同。 涂径修远，无不必之，犹人之行咫步也。 释文云：咫音纸。 宾客在庭者日百住，俞樾曰：「住」当为「数」，声之误也。 黄帝篇：「沤鸟之至者百住而不止。 」张注曰：「住当作数。 」是其证矣。 此篇卢重玄本作「往」，则是误字。 释文云：住，色主切，或作往。 庖厨之下不绝烟火，释文「庖」作「胞」，云：胞，蒲交切，本又作庖。 任大椿曰：考祭统，「胞者，肉吏之贱者也。 」注：「胞者庖。 」庄子庚桑楚篇：「是故汤以胞厨笼伊尹。 」汉书东方朔传：「胞人臣偃。 」师古曰，「胞与庖同义」，故庖胞通也。 堂庑之上不绝声乐。 释文云：庑音武。 奉养之余，先散之宗族； 宗族之余，次散之邑里； 邑里之余，乃散之一国。 行年六十，气干将衰，弃其家事，都散其库藏、珍宝、车服、妾媵。 释文云：藏，沮浪切。 媵，以证切。 一年之中尽焉，不为子孙留财。 释文云：为，于伪切。 及其病也，无药石之储； 及其死也，无瘗埋之资。 〔注〕达于理者，知万物之无常，财货之暂聚。 聚之，非我之功也，且尽奉养之宜； 散之，非我之施也，且明物不常聚。 若斯人者，岂名誉所劝，礼法所拘哉？ 释文云：施，始豉切，下同。 一国之人受其施者，王重民曰：御览四百九十三引「之」下无「人」字。 相与赋而藏之，俞樾曰：赋者，计口出钱也。 周官大宰职郑注曰：「赋，口率出泉也。 」汉书食货志师古注曰，「赋谓计口发财」，是其义矣。 藏犹言葬也，礼记檀弓篇，「葬也者，藏也」，故葬与藏得相通。 周易系辞传，「葬之中野」，汉书刘向传引作「臧之中野」，臧即藏字也。 端木叔死无瘗埋之资，故受其施者相与赋钱而葬之也。 反其子孙之财焉。 禽骨〔注〕又屈。 厘闻之，曰：释文「禽骨厘」作「禽屈厘」，云：屈厘音骨狸，墨子弟子也。 「端木叔，狂人也，辱其祖矣。 」段干生闻之，曰：「端木叔，达人也，德过其祖矣。 王重民曰：御览四百九十三引「段干生」作「段干木」，当从之。 释文云：过音戈。 其所行也，其所为也，众意所惊，而诚理所取。 卫之君子多以礼教自持，固未足以得此人之心也。 」 孟孙阳问杨朱曰：「有人于此，贵生爱身，以蕲不死，可乎？ 」释文云：蕲音祈曰：「理无不死。
chunks.translated_text:
The household amassed wealth of ten thousand gold. He paid no heed to worldly affairs, indulging whatever he fancied. As the *Shiwen* notes: *hao* (好, “fancy”) is pronounced *hu bao*, and the same applies below. Whatever the people desired to do, whatever the human heart longed to enjoy—nothing was left undone, nothing left unindulged. Walls and houses, terraces and pavilions, gardens and parks, ponds and pools, food and drink, carriages and robes, music and concubines—he rivaled the lords of Qi and Chu. As for what his nature craved, what his ears longed to hear, his eyes to see, his mouth to taste—even if it came from distant lands or remote regions (the commentary notes: *pian*, 偏, means “remote”), or was not native to Qi, he spared no effort to obtain it. Yu Yue observes: The passage below reads, “Though mountains and rivers barred the way, though paths stretched long and far, nothing was left unvisited,” so this passage should read “nothing was left unobtained,” with the extra *zhi* (之) being an erroneous interpolation. Yet to him, such things were as readily at hand as objects within a garden fence. The *Shiwen* writes *fan* (藩) as *fan* (蕃), glossing it *fu yuan*. Ren Dachun notes: The *Zhouli*’s *Da Situ* commentary states, “Du Zichun reads *fan yue* (蕃樂) as *fan yue* (藩樂).” The *Shi*’s “Breaking willows for the garden fence” has the *Shiwen* gloss: “*Fan* (樊) means *fan* (藩), and is also written *fan* (蕃).” The *Han Yi*’s *Shiwen* concurs. The *Zuozhuan*’s twenty-eighth year *Shiwen* reads, “*Fan* (藩) is also written *fan* (蕃).” The *Chu Yu* states, “They made for it gates and bolts, *fan li* (蕃籬),” with Wei Zhao’s commentary: “*Fan li* (蕃籬) means walls and enclosures; *fan li* (蕃籬) is the same as *fan li* (藩籬),” showing that *fan* (藩) and *fan* (蕃) are interchangeable.

When he traveled, though mountains and rivers barred the way (the *Shiwen* writes *zu xian* (阻險) as *ju yan* (岨崄), noting that *ju* (岨) is the same as *zu* (阻), and *yan* (崄) the same as *xian* (險)), though paths stretched long and far, nothing was left unvisited—it was as effortless as taking a single step. The *Shiwen* glosses *zhi* (咫) as *zhi* (紙). Guests filled his courtyard daily by the hundreds. Yu Yue states: *Zhu* (住) should be *shu* (數), a phonetic error. The *Huangdi* chapter reads: “The flocking birds arrived by the hundreds without cease,” with Zhang’s commentary: “*Zhu* (住) should be *shu* (數),” confirming this. This passage in Lu Chongxuan’s edition reads *wang* (往), which is a mistaken character. The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhu* (住) is pronounced *se zhu*, and is also written *wang* (往). Smoke never ceased rising from his kitchens (the *Shiwen* writes *pao* (庖) as *bao* (胞), glossing it *pu jiao*, and noting it is also written *pao* (庖)). Ren Dachun observes: The *Kao Ji Tong* states, “*Bao* (胞) refers to the lowliest of meat-officials,” with the commentary: “*Bao* (胞) means *pao* (庖).” The *Zhuangzi*’s “Gengsang Chu” chapter reads: “Thus Tang used *bao* (胞) and *chu* (厨) to ensnare Yi Yin.” The *Hanshu*’s *Dongfang Shuo Zhuan* reads: “*Bao* (胞) official Yin Yan,” with Yan Shigu’s commentary: “*Bao* (胞) and *pao* (庖) share the same meaning,” showing that *pao* (庖) and *bao* (胞) are interchangeable. Music never ceased playing in his halls and corridors. The *Shiwen* glosses *wu* (庑) as *wu* (武).

What remained after his own provision was first distributed to his clan; what remained after the clan was next distributed to his village; what remained after the village was then distributed throughout the state. At sixty years of age, his *qi* and vigor waning, he abandoned his household affairs, dispersing all his storehouses, treasures, carriages, robes, concubines, and attendants. Within a year, he exhausted it all, leaving no wealth for his descendants. The *Shiwen* glosses *wei* (為) as *yu wei* (于偽). When he fell ill, he had no store of medicines or stones; when he died, he had no resources for burial. The commentary notes: One who grasps the Dao understands the impermanence of all things and the fleeting nature of wealth. Its accumulation is not one’s own achievement, so one fulfills the proper measure of provision; its dispersal is not one’s own gift, so one clarifies that things do not permanently gather. Such a person—how could mere fame or ritual and law restrain him? The *Shiwen* glosses *shi* (施) as *shi chi* (始豉), and the same applies below.

Those in the state who received his gifts—Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (493) omits *ren* (人) after *zhi* (之)—joined together to contribute and bury him. Yu Yue states: *Fu* (賦) means calculating by household to raise funds. The *Zhouli*’s *Da Zai* commentary by Zheng Xuan reads: “*Fu* (賦) means a per-person levy of coin.” The *Hanshu*’s *Shi Huo Zhi*, in Yan Shigu’s commentary, reads: “*Fu* (賦) means calculating by household to raise wealth,” which clarifies its meaning. *Zang* (藏) here means burial, as in the *Liji*’s “Tan Gong” chapter: “Burial is *zang* (藏),” so *zang* (葬) and *zang* (藏) are interchangeable. The *Yi Jing*’s *Xi Ci Zhuan* reads: “Buried in the wilds,” while the *Hanshu*’s *Liu Xiang Zhuan* quotes it as “*Zang* (臧) in the wilds,” with *zang* (臧) being the same as *zang* (藏). Since Duanmu Shu had no resources for burial, those who received his gifts pooled their contributions to bury him, returning his descendants’ wealth to them.

“If one sought long life, would that be possible?”
Yang Zhu replied: “In principle, there is no long life. Life is not preserved by valuing it, nor is the body enriched by cherishing it. Moreover, what would be the purpose of long life?

[Note] Even if long life were granted, it would not be what one truly desires. The five passions—love and hate—remain the same in ancient times as now; the safety or peril of the four limbs, the same; the bitterness or joy of worldly affairs, the same; the alternations of order and chaos, the same. We have heard of these things, seen them, and experienced them.

[Lu's note] *Geng* (更) means to undergo or experience. The *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the "Biographies of Dayuan," states: "The Han, then intent on destroying the Hu, upon hearing these words, wished to establish communication. The route would necessarily pass through the Xiongnu." The *Suoyin* commentary explains: "*Geng* means to traverse." The word applies equally to the traversal of a journey and the experience of life.

[Shiwen] *Geng* is pronounced *geng* (庚).

A hundred years would still feel too long—how much more the suffering of long life?”

[Note] The experiences of a single lifetime are thus: now love, now hate; now safety, now peril, like an endless cycle. If one were to consider this joy? Then the return of what has already come would bring no renewed delight. If one were to consider this suffering? Then the afflictions of the self cannot be endured again. Thus, the longer one lives, the more sorrows accumulate.

[Shiwen] *Chong* (重) is pronounced *zhong* (柱用切); *fu* (复) is pronounced *fu* (扶又切).

Meng Sunyang said: “If that is so, then swift death is preferable to long life. In that case, to tread upon blades or plunge into boiling water would achieve one’s aim.”

Those two tyrants, in life, enjoyed the pleasures of indulging their desires; in death, bore the name of folly and violence. In truth, such men are fundamentally untouched by reputation. Though slandered, they knew it not; though praised, they knew it not. Yu Yue notes: The preceding text speaks of Shun, Yu, the Zhou, and Confucius, saying, "Though praised, they knew it not; though rewarded, they knew it not." Thus, in discussing Jie and Zhou, it should read, "Though slandered, they knew it not; though punished, they knew it not." "Slandered" pairs with "praised," and "punished" with "rewarded," aligning with the later passage: "Those four sages, though the destination of all praise; those two tyrants, though the destination of all blame." "Praised and rewarded" are the destination of praise; "slandered and punished" are the destination of blame. Here, following the earlier text by also using "praised" renders the meaning incoherent. How do they differ from clods of earth?

**[Annotation]** They exhausted the extremes of arrogance and extravagance, indulging their insatiable natures. Though nourished by all under Heaven, they never found contentment in their hearts. Those four sages, though the destination of all praise, toiled to the end of their days, and all alike met death. Those two tyrants, though the destination of all blame, reveled to the end of their days—*Shiwen* notes: *lè* (乐) is read as *luò*—and likewise all met death.

Yang Zhu met with the King of Liang. Speaking of governing the realm, he said it was as easy as turning one’s palm. Wang Chongmin notes: *Leiju* 94 cites this as "King Hui of Liang," and the following "the King said" omits the word "Liang." The King said: "Sir, you cannot even govern one wife and one concubine, nor tend three *mu* of garden; yet you claim governing the realm is as easy as turning your palm. Why is this?" Yang Zhu replied: "Have you seen those who herd sheep? Wang Chongmin notes: The words "见其" are reversed in error. *Leiju* 94 writes "其" as "夫," which also works (*Shuo Yuan*’s *Zhengli* chapter reads: "Have you not seen the sheep?"). The use of *qi* to mean *bi* is explained in Zhongfu’s *Advanced Chinese Grammar* and *Word Explications*. A hundred sheep in a flock, led by a five-*chi* boy carrying a switch and following behind—Wang Chongmin notes: *Leiju* 94 writes the first "而" as "为," which is likely correct. The ancient character for *wei* (为) was written as □, easily confused with *er* (而). This book’s *Yellow Emperor* chapter reads: "Those who attain this and exhaust it—how could they be upright?" *Zhuangzi*’s *Dasheng* chapter reads: "How could things restrain them?" If they wish to go east, they go east; if west, they go west. But if Yao were to lead a single sheep, with Shun carrying the switch and following behind, they could not move forward.

Moreover, I have heard: fish that can swallow a boat do not swim in shallow streams; the great swan soars high and does not alight in filthy ponds. Why? Their aspirations are lofty."

Wang Shumin states: The *Shuo Yuan*’s *Zhengli* chapter and the *Jinlouzi*’s *Liyan Xia* chapter both include the character *zhi* (志) after "其," and this should be followed. The subsequent text reads: "Why? Their tones are sparse." Here, *zhi* (志) and *yin* (音) stand in parallel. The grand harmonies of *huangzhong* and *dalü* cannot accompany frantic, clamorous dances. Why? Their tones are sparse.

The character *zhong* (钟) appears as *zhong* (锺) in Wang’s edition and is identical in the *Jifu* edition; here, it follows the standard versions. Tao Hongqing notes: "奏" should be "凑." *Cou* means convergence. Those who govern the great do not govern the petty; those who achieve great deeds do not fuss over trifles—this is what it means.

Yang Zhu said: "The affairs of the distant past have vanished—who records them? The deeds of the Three Sovereigns exist as if they exist not, the affairs of the Five Emperors seem like waking dreams (as the *Shiwen* notes: *jue* is read as *jiao*). The undertakings of the Three Kings appear now hidden, now manifest—of a hundred million, one is not known. (As the *Shiwen* notes: *shi* is read as in the standard pronunciation, or as *zhi* below, and similarly hereafter.) The events of one’s own lifetime are sometimes heard, sometimes seen—of ten thousand, one is not known. The matters before one’s eyes now exist, now cease—of a thousand, one is not known. From the distant past to the present, the years are indeed beyond counting. Yet since Fuxi’s time, over three hundred thousand years have passed, and all—wisdom and folly, beauty and ugliness, success and failure, right and wrong—have dissolved into nothingness, differing only in the swiftness or slowness of their passing.

[Annotation:] To be bewildered by such swiftness or slowness, to race endlessly in pursuit—is this not contemptible? To pride oneself on fleeting praise or blame, to wear body and spirit raw for it, and to seek a lingering name for a few hundred years after death (as the *Shiwen* notes: *yao* is read as in *yī yáo qiè*)—can this moisten dry bones? Where is the joy in life?"

Yang Zhu said: "Humans resemble the classes of Heaven and Earth, bearing the nature of the Five Constants. [Annotation:] *Xiao* means 'to resemble.' Alike in yin and yang, their nature follows the Five Phases. The *Shiwen* notes: *Xiao* is written as *qiao*, pronounced like *xiao*; some versions use *xiao*. Ren Dachun said: In the *Huainanzi*, 'to immerse in thoughts of *xiao* types,' Gao You annotates: '*Xiao* means things that resemble.' The *Hanshu: Xingfa Zhi* states: 'All people resemble the forms of Heaven and Earth.' Yan Shigu takes *xiao* as *xiao*, thus *xiao*, *qiao*, and *xiao* are interchangeable."

Of all living beings, humans are the most spiritually endowed. Yet their claws and teeth are insufficient for defense, their skin and flesh inadequate for self-protection. The *Shiwen* notes: *Han* is written as *han*, pronounced like *han*. *Yu* is pronounced *yǔ*. Their swift movement is not enough to pursue benefit or flee harm—originally 'flee benefit and harm,' now corrected according to the Dunhuang manuscript S.7776. Bo Jun notes: The *Shuowen* states: '□ means to hasten.' The *Shiming* says: 'Slow walking is called *bu*, swift walking *qu*, and hasty movement *zou*.' The *Lüshi Chunqiu: Quanxun* reads: 'The King of Qi fled to Ju,' with the annotation: '*Zou* means to flee.' The *Shiwen* writes *qu* as *qu*, pronounced *qū*.

Devoid of fur or feathers to shield against cold and heat, humans must rely on external things for sustenance. All versions include 'nature' after 'sustenance,' now deleted following the Dunhuang manuscript S.7776. They employ wisdom rather than brute force. Thus, what wisdom values is preserving the self; what force disdains is encroaching upon others. Yet the body does not belong to oneself—once born, one cannot but preserve it. Things do not belong to oneself—once possessed, one cannot discard them. 'Cannot discard them'—the Northern Song, Wang, Qin block-printed Lu, and Shidetang editions all read 'cannot but discard them.' Yu Yue said: It should read 'cannot discard them,' as the following text states: 'Though one does not discard things, one cannot claim ownership of them.' The version 'cannot but discard' contradicts the subsequent passage, likely influenced by the earlier 'once born, one cannot but preserve it,' mistakenly changing *er* to *bu*. Bo Jun notes: Yu Yue's argument is sound; the Daoist Canon's unannotated text, Lin Xiyi's edition, and the Jifu edition correctly use *er*. Here, the text is amended accordingly. The *Shiwen* writes 'er qu' as 'bu qu,' with *qu* pronounced *qù*.

The body is indeed the master of life, just as things are the master of sustenance. Though one preserves life, all versions include 'body' after 'life,' now deleted following the Dunhuang manuscript S.7776—one cannot claim ownership of the body. Though one does not discard things, one cannot claim ownership of them. To claim ownership of things or the body is to wrongfully appropriate the bodies and things of the world. The *Shiwen* notes: *Heng* is pronounced with the falling tone, as below. Those who neither wrongfully appropriate the bodies nor the things of the world—all versions omit these fourteen characters, now restored from the Dunhuang manuscript—are none other than the sages! [Annotation:] Only the sage understands that the body cannot be privately owned, nor things possessed.

Tao Hongqing said: Zhang's annotation misplaces the punctuation. 'Are none other than the sages' should be read with the following, forming an inverted sentence: 'Are none other than the sages—those who share the bodies of the world, share the things of the world—are none other than the perfected!' This both praises their sagacity and acknowledges their perfection. The *Yi Jing: Qian Gua Wenyan* states: 'Are none other than the sages! Those who know advance and retreat, life and death, yet do not lose their correctness—are none other than the sages!' The syntax is identical. Bo Jun notes: Tao's edition omits the fourteen characters 'neither wrongfully appropriate,' hence his argument. With these characters restored, Tao's interpretation is no longer tenable. The *Shiwen* connects the following passage as a single segment: 'Those who share the bodies of the world, share the things of the world—are none other than the perfected!' This is called the utmost of the utmost. [Annotation:] To regard the bodies of the world as one's own body, the things of the world as one's own things—who but the perfected can achieve this? Having realized the error of selfishness and the rightness of impartiality, this is called the utmost of the utmost.

chunks.original_text: 不要势，释文云：要，一遥切。 何羡位？ 不贪富，何羡货？ 此之谓顺民也。 〔注〕得其生理。 天下无对，制命在内。 〔注〕外物所不能制。 伯峻案：对内为韵，古音同在脂部。 故语有之曰：人不宦，情欲失半； 人不衣食，君臣道息。 江有诰曰：宦半为韵，古音同在元部。 食息为韵，古音同在之部。 周谚曰：释文云：谚音彦。 田父可坐杀，释文云：父音甫，下同。 晨出夜入，自以性之恒； 啜菽茹藿，王叔岷曰：记纂渊海五七引「菽」作「水」。 释文云：啜，川劣切。 茹去声。 藿音霍。 自以味之极； 肌肉粗厚，释文云：粗，仓胡切。 筋节□急，〔注〕□音区位切。 释文「□」作「腃」，云：筋音斤。 音喟，筋节急也。 或作□□，上音权，下区位切。 □丑，筋急貌。 秦恩复曰：释文「音喟」者，□字音喟也。 「□」当作「□」。 □，癸声，故音区位反。 若「□」字则当音之春反矣。 玉篇：「□□，丑貌。 」□从月，雚声； □从月，卷声。 雚卷声之转也。 淮南子修务训作「□」，高诱注：「读权衡之权，急气言之。 □读夔。 」读夔是区位反之明证。 尔雅：「其萌虇」，郭音缱绻，是腃即误字之明证。 「□」张湛本作「□」，淮南子作「」。 从山从口皆非，当从月。 任大椿曰：「□」无区位之音，当为「腃」之误。 又「筋急貌」三字下世德堂本又有「曰腃音区位切」六字，道藏本脱去此六字非也。 盖列子别本或作「□腃」，释文因分释「□腃」二字。 其云「□丑」，释「□」字之义。 玉篇、广雅、广韵皆云「□□丑貌」，故以□丑释□字之义。 其云「筋急貌曰腃音区位切」，欲明「腃」之与「□」音义之不同也。 今道藏本脱去「曰腃」以下六字，则竟似以筋急貌释□丑矣。 □丑无筋急之训也。 伯峻案：任说非也。 「腃音区位切」五字本张注，世德堂本溷与释文为一，任据世德堂本补释文，不可信。 又玉篇广韵之「□□丑貌」（广雅释诂作「□□丑也」），当以「□□」连读。 王氏广雅疏证引淮南子修务训「睽哆咴」，即广雅之「□咴□」，即此「□□」也。 任氏以「□丑」为读，非也。 然释文亦有错脱。 一朝处以柔毛绨幕，释文云：绨幕音啼莫。 荐以梁肉兰橘，心□体烦，内热生病矣。 释文云：□，一铅切。 商鲁之君与田父侔地，释文云：侔，莫侯切。 则亦不盈一时而惫矣。 〔注〕言有所安习者，皆不可卒改易，况自然乎？ 释文云：卒，村入声。 故野人之所安，野人之所美，谓天下无过者。 昔者宋国有田夫，常衣缊黂，〔注〕乱麻。 「黂」世德堂本作「黂」，误。 释文云：衣，于既切。 缊，一问切。 黂，房未切。 缊黂，谓分弊麻絮衣也。 韩诗外传云，异色之衣也。 又音汾。 仅以过冬。

Do not crave power—[Annotation:] *Yào* is pronounced *yáo*. Why covet rank? Do not covet wealth, why covet goods? These are called the "compliant people." [Annotation:] They attain the principle of life.

The world has no equal, for control over fate lies within. [Annotation:] It cannot be controlled by external things. [Annotation:] *Duì* ("equal") and *nèi* ("within") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *zhi* rhyme group.

Thus, the saying goes: "When a man does not seek office, half his desires are lost; when a man does not depend on clothing and food, the Way of ruler and minister ceases." Jiang Yougao notes: *Huàn* ("office") and *bàn* ("half") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *yuan* rhyme group. *Shí* ("food") and *xī* ("cease") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *zhi* rhyme group.

A Zhou proverb says—[Annotation:] *Yàn* is pronounced *yàn*—"A field laborer may be killed by sitting still." [Annotation:] *Fù* is pronounced *fǔ*, the same below. Rising at dawn and retiring at dusk, he takes this as the constant of his nature; sipping bean broth and chewing coarse greens—[Annotation:] The *Jizuan Yuanhai*, chapter 57, cites *shuǐ* ("water") for *shū* ("bean"). [Annotation:] *Chuò* is pronounced *chuǎi*. *Rú* is read in the falling tone. *Huò* is pronounced *huò*.—he takes this as the height of flavor. His flesh is coarse and thick, [Annotation:] *Cū* is pronounced *cāng*, his sinews and joints taut and tense—[Annotation:] *□* is pronounced *qūwèi*. [Annotation:] The *Shiwen* writes *□* as *kuì*, noting: *Jīn* is pronounced *jīn*. It is read *kuì*, meaning "sinews and joints tense." Alternatively written as *□□*, the first character is pronounced *quán*, the second *qūwèi*. *□chǒu* describes the appearance of tense sinews. Qin Enfu notes: The *Shiwen*’s "read *kuì*" refers to the pronunciation of *□*. *□* should be written as *□*. *□* belongs to the *guǐ* phonetic series, hence it is read *qūwèi*. If it were *□*, it would be read *zhīchūn*. The *Yupian* states: "*□□*, an ugly appearance." *□* is written with the *yuè* radical and the *guàn* phonetic; *□* with the *yuè* radical and the *juǎn* phonetic. *Guàn* and *juǎn* are phonetic transformations. The *Huainanzi*’s *Xiumu Xun* writes it as *□*, with Gao You’s commentary: "Read as *quánhéng*’s *quán*, pronounced with a tense tone. *□* is read *kuí*." That *kuí* is a reversal of *qūwèi* is clear proof. The *Erya*’s "*qǔn* is its sprout" is glossed by Guo as *qiǎnquǎn*, which is clear evidence that *kuì* is a corrupted character. [Annotation:] Zhang Zhan’s edition writes *□* as *□*; the *Huainanzi* writes it as *□*. Neither the "mountain" nor the "mouth" radical is correct—it should be the "moon" radical. Ren Dachun states: *□* has no *qūwèi* pronunciation and should be an error for *kuì*. Furthermore, the Shide Tang edition adds after "sinews tense in appearance" the six characters "*yuē kuì yīn qūwèi qiè*," which the Daoist Canon edition omits in error. This is because alternate versions of the *Liezi* may write *□kuì*, and the *Shiwen* thus explains the two characters separately. Where it says "*□* ugly," it glosses the meaning of *□*. The *Yupian*, *Guangya*, and *Guangyun* all state "*□□* ugly in appearance," hence *□* ugly is used to explain the meaning of *□*. Where it says "sinews tense in appearance is called *kuì*, pronounced *qūwèi*," it clarifies the difference in pronunciation and meaning between *kuì* and *□*. The Daoist Canon edition’s omission of the six characters from "*yuē kuì*" onward makes it seem as if *□* ugly is glossed as "sinews tense in appearance," but *□* ugly has no such definition. [Annotation:] Bo Jun notes: Ren’s argument is incorrect. The five characters "*kuì yīn qūwèi qiè*" originally belong to Zhang’s commentary; the Shide Tang edition conflates them with the *Shiwen*, and Ren’s supplementation of the *Shiwen* based on the Shide Tang edition is unreliable. Furthermore, the *Yupian* and *Guangyun*’s "*□□* ugly in appearance" (the *Guangya*’s *Shigu* writes "*□□* ugly") should be read as *□□* together. Wang’s *Guangya Shuzheng* cites the *Huainanzi*’s *Xiumu Xun*: "*kuīduō huī*," which is the *Guangya*’s "*□huī□*," the same as this *□□*. Ren’s reading of *□* ugly is incorrect. However, the *Shiwen* also contains errors and omissions.

If one morning he is placed amidst soft furs and fine silk curtains—[Annotation:] *Tímò* is pronounced *tímò*—and offered fine grains, meats, orchids, and citrus, his heart will be vexed and his body restless, and internal heat will breed illness. [Annotation:] *□* is pronounced *yǎn*. The lords of Shang and Lu, equal in status to the field laborer—[Annotation:] *Móu* is pronounced *móu*—would likewise not endure even a single day before exhaustion. [Annotation:] To speak of what one is accustomed to: none of it can be abruptly changed, let alone what is natural. [Annotation:] *Zú* is pronounced in the falling tone.

Thus, what the rustic finds at ease, what the rustic finds beautiful, is deemed without peer in the world. Long ago, in the state of Song, there was a field laborer who always wore a garment of matted hemp—[Annotation:] Tangled flax. [Annotation:] The Shide Tang edition writes *fén* as *fén*, which is incorrect. [Annotation:] *Yì* is pronounced *yì*. *Yùn* is pronounced *yùn*. *Fén* is pronounced *fén*. *Yùnfén* refers to a garment made from torn hemp fibers. The *Han Shi Waizhuan* calls it "a garment of mixed colors." Alternatively pronounced *fén*.—just enough to survive the winter.

Their lives may be taken or spared, for control over their fate lies beyond themselves. [Annotation:] When whole, they are not bound to their own will. Bo Jun notes: *Huó* ("live") and *wài* ("beyond") rhyme, sharing the same ancient sound in the *zhi* rhyme group.

If they do not resist fate, why crave longevity? If they do not prize nobility, why crave reputation?

chunks.original_text: 暨春东作，伯峻案：尧典云：「寅宾出日，平秩东作。 」伪孔传云：「岁起于东而始就耕，谓之东作。 」赵岐孟子注云：「书曰平秩东作，谓治农事也。 」汉书王莽传云：「每县则耕以劝东作。 」后汉质帝记、续汉书礼仪志皆云：「方春东作」，更其明证。 释文云：暨音洎。 自曝于日，王叔岷曰：事类赋一、御览三、天中记一引「自曝于日」并作「曝日于野」，「野」下更有「美之」二字。 释文云：曝，蒲木切。 不知天下之有广厦隩室，绵纩狐貉。 释文云：隩音奥。 貉音鹤。
chunks.translated_text: When spring arrived for the eastern labors—[Annotation:] The *Canon of Yao* states: *"Yin welcomes the rising sun, and the eastern labors are arranged in order."* The apocryphal Kong commentary says: *"The year begins in the east, and the commencement of plowing is called 'eastern labors.'"* Zhao Qi’s annotation to the *Mencius* reads: *"The Book says, 'The eastern labors are arranged in order,' referring to the management of agricultural affairs."* The *Book of Han*’s *Biography of Wang Mang* states: *"In every county, plowing was practiced to encourage the eastern labors."* The *Records of Emperor Zhi of the Later Han* and the *Continuation of the Han’s Treatise on Ritual and Ceremonies* both say: *"When spring arrives for the eastern labors,"* providing further clear evidence. [Annotation:] *Jì* is pronounced *jì*.—he would bask in the sun himself—[Annotation:] Wang Shumin notes: *The Anthology of Categorized Matters*, *Imperial Digest*, and *Tianzhong Record* all quote *"basking in the sun"* as *"basking in the sun in the fields,"* with the addition of *"admiring it"* after *"fields."* [Annotation:] *Pù* is pronounced *pù*.—unaware that the world contained spacious halls and secluded chambers, silk floss and fox-fur robes. [Annotation:] *Ào* is pronounced *ào*. [Annotation:] *Hé* is pronounced *hè*.

chunks.original_text: 顾谓其妻曰：『负日之暄，伯峻案：暄，暖或字。 释文云：暄音萱。 人莫知者； 王叔岷曰：文选与山巨源绝交书注、记纂渊海二、事文类聚别集二二合璧事类前集一引「者」并作为「之」。 以献吾君，将有重赏。 』里之富室告之曰：『昔人有美戎菽，甘枲茎芹萍子者，对乡豪称之。 〔注〕乡豪，里之贵者。 释文「萍」作「」，云：戎菽已解力命篇。 枲，胥里切。 枲，胡枲也。 苍颉篇云：□耳也。 一名苍耳。 枲俗音此。 □，思上声。 尔雅云：萍，也。 又苹，籁萧也。 郭注，今籁蒿也，初生亦可食也。 乡豪取而尝之，蜇于口，释文云：蜇音哲。 惨于腹，释文云：惨，千感切。 惨、蜇，痛也。 众哂而怨之，释文云：哂，式忍切。 其人大惭。 子，此类也。
chunks.translated_text: He turned to his wife and said: *"The warmth of the sun on my back—[Annotation:] *Xuān* may be written as *nuǎn* (warm). [Annotation:] *Xuān* is pronounced *xuān*—no one else knows of it. If I present it to our lord, I shall receive a great reward."* A wealthy man of the village informed him: *"In the past, there was a man who praised fine large beans, sweet *xǐ*-stemmed celery, water-pepper seeds, and *píng* to the village magnate. [Annotation:] The village magnate was the most honored man of the locality. [Annotation:] *Píng* is written as *pín* here. [Annotation:] *Róngshū* (large beans) was explained in the *Lì Mìng* chapter. *Xǐ* is pronounced *xǐlǐ*. *Xǐ* refers to *húxǐ* (cocklebur). The *Cāng Jié Piān* states: *□* is an ear [of grain]. It is also called *cāng’ěr* (cocklebur). *Xǐ* is colloquially pronounced *cǐ*. *□* is pronounced with the rising tone. The *Ěryǎ* states: *Píng* is *fúróng* (water-pepper). Also, *píng* is *lài xiāo* (reed). Guo’s commentary notes: This is today’s *lài hāo* (wormwood), which is edible when young. The magnate took some and tasted it, but it stung his mouth [Annotation:] *Zhé* is pronounced *zhé*—and pained his stomach. [Annotation:] *Cǎn* is pronounced *qiān gǎn*. *Cǎn* and *zhé* both mean *pain*. The crowd laughed at him and resented him. [Annotation:] *Shěn* is pronounced *shì rěn*. The man was deeply ashamed. You, sir, are of this same sort."*

chunks.original_text: 』」伯峻案：文选嵇康与山巨源绝交书「野人有快炙背而美芹子者，欲献之至尊」，可见本有此传说，作列子者用以入此章。 杨朱曰：「丰屋美服，厚味姣色。 蒋超伯曰：说文，「□，大屋也」。 引易曰，「□其屋」。 则作□亦可。 释文云：姣音绞。 有此四者，何求于外？ 有此而求外者，无厌之性。 「厌」北宋本、世德堂本作「厌」。 释文「厌」作「餍」，云：餍，一盐切。 无厌之性，阴阳之蠹也。 〔注〕非但累其身，乃侵损正气。 注「其」世德堂本作「正」，误。 释文云：蠹音妒。 累去声。 忠不足以安君，适足以危身； 义不足以利物，适足以害生。 安上不由于忠，而忠名灭焉； 利物不由于义，而义名绝焉。 君臣皆安，物我兼利，古之道也。 鬻子曰：『去名者无忧：』释文云：去，丘吕切，下同。 老子曰：『名者实之宾。 』伯峻案：今老子无此语，而见于庄子逍遥游篇。 而悠悠者趋名不已。 名固不可去，名固不可宾邪？ 今有名则尊荣，亡名则卑辱。 释文作为「者亡」，云：亡音无，下同。 尊荣则逸乐，释文云：乐音洛，下同。 卑辱则忧苦。 忧苦，犯性者也； 逸乐，顺性者也。 斯实之所系矣。 名胡可去？ 名胡可宾？ 但恶夫守名而累实。 释文云：恶，乌路切。 夫音符。 累去声。

Liu Xiaobiao notes: In the *Wen Xuan*, Ji Kang’s *"Letter Breaking Off Relations with Shan Juyuan"* states, "There was a rustic who, delighted by roasting his back in the sun and finding water-cress delicious, wished to present them to the emperor." This shows the legend already existed, and the compiler of the *Liezi* incorporated it into this chapter.

Yang Zhu said: "Grand mansions, fine robes, rich flavors, and beautiful women—with these four, what more could one seek externally? Yet those who possess them and still seek beyond are of insatiable nature. Such insatiable nature is the moth that gnaws at yin and yang. [Annotation:] It not only burdens the self but also erodes the upright qi."

[Annotation:] The character *其* in the note appears as *正* in the *Shidetang* edition, which is incorrect.

[Annotation:] *Dù* is pronounced *dù*. *Lěi* is read in the falling tone.

"Loyalty is insufficient to secure the ruler’s peace and only endangers the self; righteousness is insufficient to benefit others and only harms one’s life. Peace for superior and subject does not arise from loyalty, yet the name of loyalty is extinguished; benefit to others does not arise from righteousness, yet the name of righteousness is lost. When ruler and subject are at peace and self and others both profit—this was the Way of antiquity. The *Yuzi* states: *'He who abandons fame knows no sorrow.'* Laozi said: *'Fame is but the guest of reality.'* [Liu Xiaobiao notes:] This line does not appear in the current *Laozi* but is found in the *Zhuangzi*’s *Free and Easy Wandering* chapter. Yet the careless multitude ceaselessly pursue fame. If fame cannot be abandoned, can it truly be treated as a mere guest?

Now, to have fame is to gain honor and glory; to lack fame is to suffer lowliness and disgrace. Honor and glory bring ease and joy; lowliness and disgrace bring sorrow and suffering. Sorrow and suffering violate one’s nature; ease and joy accord with it. These are the ties that bind reality. How can fame be abandoned? How can it be treated as a guest? The true evil lies in clinging to fame and thereby burdening reality."

[Annotation:] *Wù* is pronounced *wùlù*. *Fú* is read as *fú*. *Lěi* is in the falling tone.

chunks.original_text: 守名而累实，将恤危亡之不救，岂徒逸乐忧苦之间哉？ 」秦恩复曰：自「卫端木叔者」以下卢解缺佚，无从补正。 列子集释卷第八 说符第八 〔注〕夫事故无方，倚伏相推，言而验之者，摄乎变通之会。 〔解〕本篇去末明本，约形辩神。 立事以显真，因名以求实； 然后知徇情之失道，从欲以丧真。 故知道者不失其自时，任能者不必远害。 秦恩复曰：解中「自」字疑衍。 子列子学于壶丘子林。 壶丘子林曰：「子知持后，则可言持身矣。 」〔注〕老子曰「后其身而身先。 」列子曰：「顾闻持后。 」曰：「顾若影，则知之。 」列子顾而观影：形枉则影曲，形直则影正。 然则枉直随形而不在影，屈申任物而不在我。 此之谓持后而处先。 〔注〕物莫能与争，故常处先。 此语以壶子答而不条显，列子一得持后之义因而自释之，壶子即以为解，故不复答列子也。 〔解〕夫影由形立，曲直在于形生； 形由神存，直伪在于神用。 若见影而形辩，知形而神彰； 不责影以正身，不执身以明道，观其末而知其本，因其着而识其微，然后能常处先矣。 注「以壶子答」道藏本、元本并作「似壶子答」。 伯峻案：淮南子缪称训云：「列子学壶子，观景柱而知持后矣。 」释文云：争音诤。 解音蟹。 复，扶又切。 关尹谓子列子曰：「言美则响美，言恶则响恶； 身长则影长，身短则影短。 名也者，响也； 身也者，影也。 〔注〕夫美恶报应譬之影响，理无差焉。 陶鸿庆曰：上句云「名也者响也」，承上「言美则响美，言恶则响恶」而言； 是响出于言，而言非响也。 此句承上「身长则影长，身短则影短」而言； 是影出于身，而身非影也。 今云「身也者影也」，义颇难通。 此「身」字乃指受报之身言之，与上文「身长身短」意义迥别。 下文云，「度在身，稽在人。 人爱我，我必爱之； 人恶我，我必恶之」，意谓观人之爱我恶我，则知我之爱人恶人。 爱人恶人者，身也； 人爱人恶之身则影也。 故曰：身也者，影也。 王叔岷曰：「身」当作「行」，下文「慎尔行，将有随之」，即承此言。 今本作「身」，涉上文「身长则影长，身短则影短」而误。 御览四百三十引尸子作「行者影也」，可为旁证。 伯峻案：王说可取，陶氏曲为之说，颇嫌迂僻。 故曰：慎尔言，将有和之； 「和」北宋本作「知」，汪本从之，今从吉府本、世德堂本订正。 释文云：和，胡卧切，一作知。 慎尔行，释文云：行，下孟切，注同。 将有随之。 〔注〕所谓出其言，善，千里应之； 行乎迩，见乎远。 江有诰曰：和随为韵，古音同在歌部。 释文云：见，贤遍切。 是故圣人见出以知入，观往以知来，此其所以先知之理也。 〔注〕见言出则响入，形往则影来，明报应之理不异于此也。 而物所未悟，故曰先知之耳。 〔解〕响之因声，声善则响美； 名之因实，实善则名真。 故名者声之响，身者神之影也。 声出而响和，行习而神随； 故圣人闻响以知声，见行而知道也。 度在身，释文云：度依字读。 稽在人。 人爱我，我必爱之； 人恶我，释文云：恶，乌路切。 我必恶之。 〔注〕礼度在身，考验由人。 爱恶从之，物不负己。 汤武爱天下，故王； 「故王」北宋本作「兹王」，汪本从之，今从各本正。

"Clinging to fame and thereby burdening reality will lead to concerns over peril and ruin that cannot be saved—how could it be merely a matter between ease and joy or sorrow and suffering?"

Qin Enfu notes: From the passage beginning *"Wei, the Viscount Duanmu Shu,"* onward, Lu’s commentary is missing, and there is no way to supplement or correct it.

*Liezi Jishi*, Volume Eight: *Shuofu* (Explaining Symbols)

[Annotation:] Affairs are boundless, with fortune and misfortune mutually propelling one another. When words are spoken and verified, they are grasped within the convergence of change and adaptation.

[Exegesis:] This chapter, departing from the *Mo Ming* edition, approximates form to discern spirit. Establishing affairs reveals the real; pursuing names seeks reality. Only then does one recognize the loss of the Dao in following emotions and the forfeiture of truth in indulging desires. Thus, those who know the Dao do not lose their timely self, and those who employ ability need not distance themselves from harm.

Qin Enfu notes: The character *"zi"* (自) in the exegesis is likely superfluous.

Master Liezi studied under Master Huqiu Zilin.
Master Huqiu Zilin said: "If you understand *holding back*, then we may speak of *holding the self*."
[Annotation:] Laozi said, *"Hold back the self, and the self will advance."*
Liezi said: "I have heard of *holding back*."
Master Huqiu replied: "Look at your shadow, and you will understand."
Liezi turned and observed his shadow: when the body was bent, the shadow was crooked; when the body was straight, the shadow was upright. Thus, crookedness and straightness follow the body and do not reside in the shadow; bending and extending depend on the object and not on the self. This is called *holding back to occupy the forefront*."
[Annotation:] No thing can contend with it, so it always occupies the forefront. These words, though Huzi’s answer, are not clearly expounded. Liezi grasped the meaning of *holding back* and thereby explained it himself, so Huzi did not further respond.
[Exegesis:] The shadow arises from the form, and crookedness or straightness originates in the form’s movement. The form exists through the spirit, and authenticity or falsity lies in the spirit’s function. If one discerns the form by observing the shadow and knows the spirit by understanding the form—without demanding the shadow to rectify the body or clinging to the body to illuminate the Dao—then by observing the branch, one knows the root, and by examining the manifest, one perceives the subtle. Only then can one always occupy the forefront.

The *Daozang* edition and Yuan edition both read *"seems Huzi’s answer"* instead of *"with Huzi’s answer."*
Bo Jun notes: The *Huainanzi*’s *Miu Cheng Xun* states: *"Liezi studied under Huzi and, observing the reflection in a pillar, understood *holding back*."*

[Phonetic Annotations:] *Zheng* (争) is pronounced *zhèng*. *Xie* (解) is pronounced *xiè*. *Fu* (复) is read *fú*.

Guan Yin said to Master Liezi: "Beautiful words produce a beautiful echo; foul words produce a foul echo. A long body casts a long shadow; a short body casts a short shadow. The name is the echo; the self is the shadow."
[Annotation:] The retribution of good and evil is like echoes and shadows—there is no discrepancy in principle.
Tao Hongqing notes: The preceding line, *"The name is the echo,"* follows from *"Beautiful words produce a beautiful echo; foul words produce a foul echo"*—an echo arises from words, but words are not the echo. This line follows from *"A long body casts a long shadow; a short body casts a short shadow"*—a shadow arises from the body, but the body is not the shadow. Now, saying *"the self is the shadow"* is somewhat difficult to reconcile. Here, *"self"* refers to the body that receives retribution, entirely distinct in meaning from *"long body"* or *"short body"* above. The subsequent text—*"Measure lies in the self; verification lies in others. If others love me, I must love them; if others hate me, I must hate them"*—means that by observing others’ love or hatred toward me, one knows my own love or hatred toward others. Loving or hating others is the self; others loving or hating that self is the shadow. Thus, *"the self is the shadow."*
Wang Shumin notes: *"Self"* (身) should be *"conduct"* (行). The following line, *"Be cautious in your conduct, for it will be followed,"* directly continues this idea. The current text’s *"self"* is an error, arising from the preceding *"long body"* and *"short body."* The *Shizi*, as cited in the *Taiping Yulan* (430), reads *"conduct is the shadow,"* providing collateral evidence.
Bo Jun notes: Wang’s proposal is tenable; Tao’s interpretation, though ingenious, is overly circuitous.

Thus it is said: Be cautious in your words, for they will be harmonized; be cautious in your conduct, for it will be followed.
[Annotation:] As the saying goes: *"Speak good words, and a thousand *li* away they will respond; act nearby, and it will be seen afar."*
Jiang Yougao notes: *"He"* (和) and *"sui"* (随) rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *ge* rhyme group.
[Phonetic Annotations:] *Jian* (见) is pronounced *xiàn*.

Therefore, the sage observes the outgoing to know the incoming, examines the past to know the future—this is the principle by which they possess foreknowledge.
[Annotation:] Seeing words go out and echoes return, forms depart and shadows arrive, one understands that the principle of retribution is no different. Yet things have not yet awakened to this, so it is called *"foreknowledge."*
[Exegesis:] The echo follows the sound; if the sound is good, the echo is beautiful. The name follows reality; if reality is good, the name is true. Thus, the name is the echo of the sound, and the self is the shadow of the spirit. Sounds emit and echoes harmonize; conduct is practiced and the spirit follows. Therefore, the sage hears the echo to know the sound and sees conduct to know the Dao.

The measure lies in the self; verification lies in others. If others love me, I must love them; if others hate me, I must hate them.
[Annotation:] Ritual measure lies in the self; verification lies with others. Love and hatred follow accordingly—things do not betray the self.
Tang and Wu loved the world, thus they reigned.
