chunks.original_text: 释文云：王，于放切。 桀纣恶天下，故亡，〔注〕此则成验。 此所稽也。 〔解〕礼度在于身，稽考在于人，若影之应乎形，响之应乎声。 汤武、桀纣其迹可稽也，其度可明也。 爱恶之心不可不慎也。 稽度皆明而不道也，譬之出不由门，行不从径也。 〔注〕稽度之理既明，而复道不行者，则出可不由户，行不从径也。 释文云：径一本作衢，一本作术。 复，扶又切。 以是求利，不亦难乎？ 〔注〕违理而得利未之有。 〔解〕稽度之事可明而不为道者，譬行不由门户与街衢耳。 欲以求利身于天下者，不亦难乎？ 秦恩复曰：据解则卢本「径」作「衢」。 尝观之神农有炎之德，稽之虞、夏、商、周之书，度诸法士贤人之言，释文云：度，徒洛切，量也。 所以存亡废兴而非由此道者，未之有也。 」〔注〕自古迄今无不符验。 〔解〕考其行，稽其迹，自古帝王贤圣之言犹人，存亡废兴粲然可明。 若不由此道而为理者，未之有也。 严恢曰：「所为问道者为富。 〔注〕问犹学也。 释文云：为，于伪切。 今得珠亦富矣，安用道？ 」〔注〕道，富之本也； 珠，富之末也。 有本故末存，存末则失本也。 注「富之末也」北宋本无「也」字，汪本从之，今依四解本增。 子列子曰：「桀纣唯重利而轻道，是以亡。 〔注〕非不富，失本则亡身。 幸哉余未汝语也。 释文云：语，鱼据切。 人而无义，唯食而已，〔注〕义者，宜也。 得理之宜者，物不能夺也。 是鸡狗也。 强食靡角，俞樾曰：「靡」读为「摩」。 庄子马蹄篇：「喜则交颈相靡。 」释文引李云，「摩也」，是靡与摩义通也。 「靡角」之「靡」即「交颈相靡」之「靡」，谓以角相靡也。 王叔岷曰：俞说是也。 御览四二一引作「磨」。 磨、摩、靡古并通用。 释文云：靡，文彼切。 韩诗外传云：「靡，共也。 」吕氏春秋云：角，试力也。 此言人重利而轻道，唯食而已，亦犹禽兽饱食而相共角力以求胜也。 胜者为制，是禽兽也。 〔注〕以力求胜，非人道也。 王重民曰：「制」字义不可通，盖当作「利」，字之误也。 御览四百二十一引作「胜者为利」，可证。 为鸡狗禽兽矣，而欲人之尊己，不可得也。 〔注〕岂欲人之尊己，道在则自尊耳。 人不尊己，则危辱及之矣。 」〔注〕乐推而不厌，尊己之谓。 苟违斯义，亡将至。 〔解〕无乏少者谓之富，非谓求利之富也。 若重利轻道，桀纣所以亡也。 鸡犬禽兽不知仁义，争食恃力，不知其它。 行此则危辱及身，欲人之尊己，岂可得矣？ 此谓因名求实。 列子学射中矣，〔注〕率尔自中，非能期中者也。 释文云：中，丁仲切，下同。 请于关尹子。 尹子曰：王重民曰：御览七百四十五引迭一「关」字，是也。 古书或称「关尹」，无称为「尹子」者，下同。 王叔岷曰：王说是也。 吕氏春秋审己篇亦作「关尹子曰」。 下同。 「子知子之所以中者乎？ 」对曰：「弗知也。 」关尹子曰：「未可。 」〔注〕虽中而未知所以中，故曰未可也。 退而习之。 三年，又以报关尹子。 尹子曰：「子知子之所以中乎？ 」列子曰：「知之矣。 」关尹子曰：「可矣； 守而勿失也。 〔注〕心平体正，内求诸己，得所以中之道，则前期命矢，发无遗矣。 非独射也，为国与身亦皆如之。
chunks.translated_text:
"Wang" is pronounced *yù* (于放切). Jie and Zhou hated the world, thus they perished.
[Annotation:] This is the verification of the principle. This is what is meant by *"verification."*

[Exegesis:] Ritual measure lies in the self; verification lies in others—like the shadow responding to the form, the echo answering the sound. The traces of Tang, Wu, Jie, and Zhou may be examined; their measures may be made clear. One must be cautious in matters of love and hatred. If both verification and measure are clear yet the Dao is not followed, it is like going out without using the door or walking without following the path.
[Annotation:] When the principles of verification and measure are already clear, yet the Dao is still not practiced, it is like exiting without passing through the gate or walking without following the path. (The character *jìng* [径] appears in one version as *qú* [衢], and in another as *shù* [术]. *Fù* [复] is pronounced *fú* [扶又切].) To seek profit by such means—is it not difficult?
[Annotation:] There has never been profit gained by violating principle.

[Exegesis:] If the matters of verification and measure are clear yet the Dao is not followed, it is like walking without using the gate or the thoroughfare. To seek profit for oneself in the world by such means—is it not difficult? (Qin Enfu notes: According to the exegesis, the Lu edition reads *qú* [衢] instead of *jìng* [径].)

I have observed the virtue of Shennong and Yan, examined the books of Yu, Xia, Shang, and Zhou, and measured them against the words of learned scholars and worthies. There has never been a case of survival or ruin, rise or fall that did not proceed from this Dao.
[Annotation:] From ancient times to the present, there has been no instance without verification.

[Exegesis:] By examining their conduct and verifying their traces, the words of ancient sage-kings and worthies remain consistent with those of others. Survival and ruin, rise and fall are all clearly evident. There has never been a case of governance not proceeding from this Dao.

Yan Hui said: "Those who ask about the Dao do so to become wealthy.
[Annotation:] *Ask* here means *to learn.* (*Wèi* [为] is pronounced *wéi* [于伪切].) Now that I have obtained a pearl, I am wealthy—what need is there for the Dao?"
[Annotation:] The Dao is the root of wealth; the pearl is its branch. When the root exists, the branch remains; to preserve the branch is to lose the root. (The Northern Song edition omits the character *yě* [也] after *"wealth’s branch,"* and Wang’s edition follows this. Here, it is restored according to the *Four Exegeses* edition.)

Master Liezi said: "Jie and Zhou valued profit and slighted the Dao, thus they perished.
[Annotation:] They were not without wealth, but by losing the root, they lost themselves. How fortunate that I have not yet spoken to you of this! A person without righteousness eats and nothing more—
[Annotation:] *Righteousness* means *what is fitting.* One who attains the fitting principle of reason cannot be deprived by external things. Such a person is no better than a chicken or a dog. Forcibly seizing food and butting heads—
(Yu Yue says: *Mǐ* [靡] should be read as *mó* [摩]. In the *Mati* chapter of the *Zhuangzi*, it says, *"When pleased, they rub necks together."* The exegesis by Li cites *mó* [摩], showing that *mǐ* [靡] and *mó* [摩] share the same meaning. Thus, *mǐ jiǎo* [靡角] means *rubbing horns together.* Wang Shumin says: Yu’s interpretation is correct. The *Taiping Yulan* [421] quotes it as *mó* [磨]. *Mó* [磨], *mó* [摩], and *mǐ* [靡] were interchangeable in ancient usage. *Mǐ* [靡] is pronounced *wén bǐ* [文彼切]. The *Han Shi Waizhuan* says: *Mǐ* [靡] means *together.* The *Lüshi Chunqiu* says: *Jiǎo* [角] means *to test strength.* This passage describes those who value profit and slight the Dao, eating and nothing more—like birds and beasts that eat their fill and then butt heads together to compete for dominance.) The victor gains control—such are birds and beasts.
[Annotation:] To seek victory by force is not the human Dao. (Wang Chongmin says: The character *zhì* [制] is semantically incoherent here and should be *lì* [利], a scribal error. The *Taiping Yulan* [421] quotes it as *"the victor gains profit,"* which confirms this.) To be no better than chickens, dogs, birds, or beasts yet desire others’ respect—this cannot be attained.
[Annotation:] How could one desire others’ respect? When the Dao is present, one is naturally respected. If others do not respect you, danger and disgrace will befall you.
[Annotation:] To be willingly esteemed without resentment is what it means to be respected. If one violates this principle, ruin will follow.

[Exegesis:] *Wealth* means *without lack*—it does not refer to the wealth of profit-seeking. To value profit and slight the Dao is how Jie and Zhou perished. Chickens, dogs, birds, and beasts know nothing of benevolence and righteousness; they fight over food and rely on strength, unaware of anything else. To act thus is to invite danger and disgrace upon oneself. How could one then expect others’ respect? This is what is meant by *seeking reality through names.*

Liezi had hit the target in archery.
[Annotation:] He had hit it by chance, not through deliberate aim. (*Zhòng* [中] is pronounced *dīng zhòng* [丁仲切] below.)
He asked Master Guan Yin about it. Master Yin said:
(Wang Chongmin says: The *Taiping Yulan* [745] includes an additional *guān* [关] here, which is correct. Ancient texts sometimes refer to him as *Guan Yin* but never as *Yinzi* below. Wang Shumin says: Wang’s interpretation is correct. The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Shen Ji* chapter also reads *"Master Guan Yin said"* below.)
"Do you know why you hit the target?"
He replied: "I do not."
Master Guan Yin said: "Not yet."
[Annotation:] Though he had hit the target, he did not know how, so it was said to be "not yet."
He withdrew and practiced. After three years, he returned to report to Master Guan Yin. The Master said: "Do you know why you hit the target?"
Liezi said: "I know now."
Master Guan Yin said: "It is acceptable. Hold to this and do not lose it.
[Annotation:] With a calm mind and upright body, seeking within oneself, one attains the Dao of hitting the target. Then, one may aim at the target in advance, and every shot will strike without fail. This is not only true of archery—governing a state and cultivating the self are the same."

Thus, the sage does not examine whether something endures or perishes but examines the reason it is so.

Though one may hit the target without knowing how, this is not the Dao of hitting the target; though one may endure without knowing why, this is not the principle of endurance. Therefore, in archery, the unskilled and the skilled may both hit the mark, yet those who know *why* they hit it differ. The worthy and the foolish may both endure, yet those who know *why* they endure are distinct.

One who does not know *why* they hit the target is not the most excellent of the excellent. To grasp it with the hand and respond with the heart, to command the shot and strike the mark—this is attainment. To attain and hold to it is called the Dao. One who knows this Dao may apply it not only to archery but also to governing a state and cultivating the self.

The master of archery does not value merely hitting the target but values the reason it *must* be hit. Likewise, the master of ordering a state or cultivating the self does not value mere endurance but values the reason it *must* endure. Thus, whether the worthy or the foolish, order or chaos, may be known—this is the presence of the Dao.

Liezi said: "Those whose appearance is flourishing are arrogant; those whose strength is flourishing are aggressive—they cannot yet be spoken to of the Dao. Only when their hair is streaked with white may one speak to them of it, lest they lose it. How much less can they practice it?

Those who are arrogant and aggressive allow no one to instruct them. With no one to instruct them, they become isolated and lack support. The worthy, however, employ others, and so even in old age they do not decline; even when their wisdom is exhausted, they do not fall into chaos.

Thus, the difficulty in governing a state lies not in being worthy oneself but in recognizing worth in others. One who deems themselves worthy is, as stated above, isolated and without support. But one who recognizes worth allows the wise to counsel them and the capable to serve them. With no talent wasted, the state is easily ordered."

The common people rely on appearance and strength. Those who rely on appearance foster arrogance and indolence; those who rely on strength harbor aggressive and combative intentions—they cannot be spoken to of the Dao. Only when their appearance and strength have faded, when their hair is streaked with white, may one speak to them of it. Yet even then, though they may hear the Dao in old age, they cannot attain it—how much less can they practice it? Thus, those who abide in humility and weakness are embraced by the Dao, while those who are self-assertive and aggressive find no one willing to instruct them. With no one willing to instruct them, how can they have support?

The worthy entrust themselves to others, and so their spirit does not wane with age, nor does their mind fall into chaos when their wisdom is spent. One who governs a state in this way, recognizing worth and employing it, allows worthy talent to serve them. But one who deems themselves worthy and lacks support loses others.

There was once a man of Song who, for his lord, crafted mulberry leaves from jade.

After three years, it was completed. Its edges and stems, whether full or slender, its fine veins and lush sheen—when mixed among real mulberry leaves, none could distinguish them. Thus, this man came to feed himself by his skill throughout the state of Song.

Master Liezi heard of this and said: "If heaven and earth took three years to produce a single leaf, then things with leaves would be few indeed. Therefore, the sage relies on the transformative power of the Dao and not on clever skill."

[Annotation] This shows that relying on skill is insufficient to sustain things; following the Dao in transformation leaves nothing unfulfilled.

[Exegesis] Carving and polishing to return to simplicity is the Way of restoring purity. Thus it is said: the master binder needs no glue or lacquer; the master locker needs no bolt or key. Therefore, great eloquence seems inarticulate, and great skill seems clumsy. If three years’ labor produces a single leaf indistinguishable from a real one, how can this be the skill of governing a state or preserving the Dao? Thus, the sage relies on the transformative power of the Dao—just as harmonious qi spreads and all things come to life—rather than on clever skill. To defy the principles of heaven and produce artificial craft is to fail to understand root and branch.

[Note] "Skill" in some editions reads "merit" or "ability." "Sustain things" in the Northern Song edition appears as "marry things," where "marry" is likely a scribal error.

Master Liezi was poor, his face bearing the pallor of hunger. A guest spoke of this to Zi Yang of Zheng, saying: "Lie Yukou is surely a man of the Dao, yet he dwells in your state and suffers poverty—does this not suggest the lord does not love men of worth?" Zi Yang of Zheng immediately ordered an official to send him grain. Master Liezi went out to meet the messenger, bowed twice, and declined. The messenger departed. When Master Liezi returned inside, his wife struck her breast and said: "I have heard that the wife and children of a man of the Dao all enjoy ease and happiness. Now you bear the look of hunger, and the lord, passing by, sent you food. You refused it—is this not fate?" Master Liezi laughed and said to her: "The lord does not know me himself."

Master Liezi said: "He sent me grain on the words of another; should he blame me, it would likewise be on the words of another—this is why I did not accept it."

Bo Jun notes: The *Xin Xu*’s "Jie Shi" chapter contains the lines: "Moreover, to accept another’s sustenance and not die for their peril is unrighteous; to die for their peril is to die for an unprincipled man—how can that be righteous?"

In the end, the people indeed rose in revolt and killed Zi Yang.

[Commentary] To eat another’s provisions is to share their concerns. The lord did not know me himself but bestowed grain upon me based on another’s words; if he were to blame me, it would likewise be based on another’s words. What I value is the one who truly knows me—a man who has awakened to the Dao. When Zi Yang’s calamity arose, I was not harmed—this is what it truly means not to be burdened or harmed by external things.

The Lu family of the Shi clan had two sons: one fond of learning, the other fond of military arts. The one fond of learning offered his arts to the Marquis of Qi; the Marquis accepted him and made him tutor to the various princes. The one fond of military arts went to Chu and offered his methods to the King of Chu; the King was pleased and made him military commander. Their salaries enriched their household, and their ranks honored their kin.

The neighboring Meng family had two sons as well, who pursued the same studies, yet they were distressed by poverty. Envying the Shi family’s prosperity, they asked for the path to advancement. The two sons told the Meng family the truth. One of the Meng sons went to Qin and offered his arts to the King of Qin. The King of Qin said: "Now the feudal lords contend with force, and what they pursue is nothing but arms and provisions. If I were to govern my state with benevolence and righteousness, it would be the way to ruin."

Thus, the King of Qin imprisoned and exiled the Meng son. The other son went to Wei and offered his methods to the Marquis of Wei. The Marquis said: "My state is weak, hemmed in between great powers. I serve the great states and soothe the small ones—this is the Way to seek security. Were I to rely on military power, destruction would soon follow. If I were to let you return intact and you went to another state, the harm you could bring me would be no small matter." He then had the Meng son’s feet cut off and sent him back to Lu.

Upon their return, the father and son of the Meng family beat their chests and reproached the Shi family. The Shi family said: "In all things, those who seize the moment prosper, while those who miss it perish. Your Way was the same as ours, yet your success differed—this was a matter of missing the moment, not of flawed conduct. Moreover, in the world, principles have no constant right, and affairs no constant wrong. What was used before may now be discarded; what is discarded today may later be employed. In this, use and disuse have no fixed right or wrong. Seizing opportunities and meeting the moment, responding to affairs without fixed method—this depends on wisdom. Though one may possess the arts of benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and law, without wisdom suited to the time, one acts and misses the moment. If wisdom is insufficient, even were one as learned as Confucius or as skilled as Lü Shang, where could one go and not meet with failure?" The Meng father and son, their resentment dissolved, said: "We understand. Say no more!"

To study the Dao of benevolence and righteousness, to master the arts of strategy and planning—though civil and martial differ, both converge in the application of talent and conduct, which must rely on wisdom suited to the moment. Wisdom is the application of the Dao; to rely solely on wisdom is to depart from the Dao.

To strike is to hit the gap; to act is to meet the moment. Responding to change without fixed method—all this is wisdom. The Meng father and son, having awakened, said only, “Say no more.”

When Duke Wen of Jin went forth to meet the lords, intending to attack Wei, Prince Chu looked up to the sky and laughed. The Prime Minister asked, “Why do you laugh?” He replied, “I laugh at my neighbor, who was escorting his wife back to her family when, on the road, he saw a woman gathering mulberry leaves. Enamored, he spoke to her, yet when he turned to look at his wife, another was beckoning to her as well. I laugh at this.”

The Duke grasped his meaning and called off the attack.

chunks.original_text: 王重民曰：类聚八十八、御览三百零五又四百五十七引「寤」并作「悟」。 释文云：寤音悟。 引师而还，未至，而有伐其北鄙者矣。 〔注〕夫我之所行，人亦行之。 而欲骋己之志，谓物不生心，惑于彼此之情也。 〔解〕夫贪于得而不知得有所守者，俗人之常情也。 故嗜欲无穷而真道日丧矣。 所以贵夫知道者，内守其道而不失，外用于物而不遗。 世人则不然矣，外贪欲色，他妇是悦也； 内失于道者，而已妻见招矣。 秦恩复曰：解中「得有所守」「得」字疑是衍文。 晋国苦盗。 有郄雍者，伯峻案：「郄」当作「郄」。 说文，「郄，晋大夫叔虎之邑也。 」段注云：「叔虎之子曰郄芮，以邑为氏。 」治要引正作「郄」，下同，当从之。 邵瑛群经正字云：「俗又讹作郄者，亦郄之变。 汉学师宋恩等题名，师□□」，偏旁从，与相似，俗遂变作郄。 玉篇云：「郄俗从。 」释文云：郄，去逆切。 雍音邕。 能视盗之貌，「貌」本作「眼」，今从吉府本、世德堂本正。 御览四百九十九引亦作「貌」。 释文云：貌一本作眼。 察其眉睫之间，而得其情。 释文云：睫音接。 晋侯使视盗，千百无遗一焉。 晋侯大喜，告赵文子曰：「吾得一人，而一国盗为尽矣，伯峻案：御览四九九引「为」下有「之」字。 释文云：为，于伪切。 奚用多为？ 」文子曰：「吾君恃伺察而得盗，盗不尽矣，且郄雍必不得其死焉。 」俄而群盗谋曰：「吾所穷者郄雍也。 」王重民曰：御览四百九十九引「所」下有「以」字，是也。 遂共盗而残之。 〔注〕残贼杀之。 王重民曰：治要、御览四百九十九引「残」并作「戕」，疑作「戕」者近是。 说文，「它国臣来弒君曰戕」，故张注曰「贼杀之」。 释文「残」作为「戕」，云：音墙，注同； 一本作残。 晋侯闻而大骇，释文「骇」作「駴」，云：与骇同。 立召文子而告之曰：「果如子言，郄雍死矣！ 然取盗何方？ 」秦刻卢解本无「盗」字。 文子曰：「周谚有言：察见渊鱼者不祥，智料隐匿者有殃。 〔注〕此答所以致死。 江有诰曰：祥殃为韵，古音同在阳部。 伯峻案：韩非子说林上云：「古者有谚曰，知渊中之鱼者不祥。 」释文云：料去声。 且君欲无盗，若莫举贤而任之； 使教明于上，化行于下，民有耻心，则何盗之为？ 」〔注〕此答所以止盗之方。 于是用随会知政，而群盗奔秦焉。 〔注〕用聪明以察是非者，群诈之所逃； 用先识以擿奸伏者，众恶之所疾。 智之为患，岂虚言哉？ 〔解〕教者，迹也，众人所以履而行焉。 化者，道也，众人所以日用而心伏。 心伏则有耻，迹明则教成。 举贤任才，盗斯奔矣。 或问曰：庄子云：「圣人生而大盗起。 」此云举贤任才而群盗去，何谓邪？ 答曰：求虚名而丧其实者，大盗斯起矣； 得其实而去为名者，群盗斯去矣。 故举贤而任才者，求名也； 用随会者，得实也。 理不相违，何疑之有耶？ 注「用先识」治要引「先」作「少」，近是。 释文云：擿，陟革切。 孔子自卫反鲁，息驾乎河梁而观焉。

Wang Chongmin notes: In the *Leiju* (ch. 88) and *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 305 and 457), the character "寤" is uniformly written as "悟." The *Shiwen* glosses: "寤 is pronounced as 悟." The army was withdrawn, yet before it returned, raiders had already struck its northern border.

**[Annotation]** What I have done, others may also do. To indulge one’s own ambitions while assuming others will not harbor the same intentions is to be deluded by the distinction between self and other.

**[Exegesis]** To covet gain without understanding that gain must be guarded is the common folly of the vulgar. Thus, desires know no bounds, and the true Dao daily wanes. The value of one who knows the Dao lies in inwardly preserving the Dao without loss and outwardly applying it to things without omission. The worldly, however, are not so: outwardly, they lust after other women, enamored of another’s wife; inwardly, they lose the Dao, and their own wife is beckoned by another.

Qin Enfu remarks: In the exegesis, the character "得" in "得有所守" is likely a superfluous interpolation.

The state of Jin suffered from rampant banditry. There was a man named Xi Yong—Lu Jun notes: "郄" should be written as "郤." The *Shuowen* states, "郤 was the fief of Shu Hu, a grandee of Jin." Duan Yucai’s commentary adds: "Shu Hu’s son was named Xi Rui, who took his fief as his surname." The *Qunshu Zhiyao* correctly writes it as "郤," and the same should apply below. Shao Ying’s *Qunjing Zhengzi* observes: "The vulgar further corrupt it to '郄,' a variant of '郤.' In the *Hanxue Shichao* by Song En et al., the character '师' appears as '□□,' with a component resembling '卩,' leading the vulgar to alter it to '郄.' The * Yupian* notes: '郄 is a vulgar form of 卩.'" The *Shiwen* glosses: "郄 is pronounced *qì* (去逆切). 雍 is pronounced *yōng* (邕)." Xi Yong could discern a bandit’s appearance—"貌" originally read "眼," but the present version follows the *Jifu* and *Shidetang* editions, which correct it to "貌." The *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) also writes it as "貌." The *Shiwen* notes: "貌 appears in one edition as 眼."—and examine the space between their brows and lashes to uncover their true nature. The *Shiwen* glosses: "睫 is pronounced *jié* (接)." The Marquis of Jin sent him to identify bandits, and among thousands, not one escaped his detection.

The Marquis of Jin rejoiced greatly and told Zhao Wenzi: "I have found one man, and the bandits of the entire state are as good as eradicated. Lu Jun notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) includes a "之" after "为." The *Shiwen* glosses: "为 is pronounced *wěi* (于伪切). Why should I employ many?" Wenzi replied: "My lord relies on surveillance to catch bandits, yet bandits will not be eradicated. Moreover, Xi Yong will surely not meet a natural death." Soon after, the bandits plotted among themselves: "The one who has cornered us is Xi Yong." Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) includes a "以" after "所," which is correct. They then joined forces to murder him.

**[Annotation]** "残" means to kill or destroy. Wang Chongmin notes: The *Qunshu Zhiyao* and *Taiping Yulan* (ch. 499) write "残" as "戕," and the latter may be closer to the original. The *Shuowen* defines "戕" as "a minister from another state who assassinates a ruler," hence Zhang’s annotation reads "to kill treacherously." The *Shiwen* writes "残" as "戕," glossing: "戕 is pronounced *qiāng* (墙), as in the annotation; one edition writes it as 残."

The Marquis of Jin, upon hearing this, was greatly alarmed. The *Shiwen* writes "骇" as "駴," noting: "It is the same as 骇." He immediately summoned Wenzi and said: "As you predicted, Xi Yong is dead! But what method should we use to capture the bandits?" The *Qinke Lu* edition omits the character "盗." Wenzi replied: "There is a Zhou proverb that says: 'One who sees the fish in the depths is inauspicious; one who predicts hidden things brings calamity.' Jiang Yougao notes: "祥 and 殃 form a rhyme, both belonging to the ancient *yang* rhyme group." Lu Jun notes: The *Hanfeizi* (*Shuo Lin Shang*) states: "An ancient proverb says, 'One who knows the fish in the depths is inauspicious.'" The *Shiwen* glosses: "料 is pronounced in the falling tone (去声). Moreover, if my lord wishes to eliminate banditry, you must elevate the worthy and employ them. Let instruction be clear above, and transformation flow below; if the people have a sense of shame, what banditry will there be?"

**[Annotation]** This answers the method to stop banditry.

Thereupon, they appointed Sui Hui to oversee governance, and the bandits fled to Qin.

**[Annotation]** To employ keen discernment in judging right and wrong is to invite the flight of the deceitful; to use foresight in exposing hidden evils is to incur the hatred of the wicked. Is the peril of wisdom mere empty talk?

**[Exegesis]** Instruction is the outward form, the path by which the multitude walks. Transformation is the Dao, the principle by which the multitude daily lives and inwardly submits. When the heart submits, shame arises; when the outward form is clear, instruction is achieved. Elevate the worthy and employ the capable, and bandits will flee. Someone asked: Zhuangzi said, "When the sage is born, great bandits arise." Yet here it says that elevating the worthy and employing the capable causes bandits to depart. How can this be? The answer: To seek empty fame while losing substance is to give rise to great bandits; to attain substance while forsaking fame is to cause bandits to depart. Thus, elevating the worthy and employing the capable is the pursuit of fame; employing Sui Hui is the attainment of substance. The principles do not contradict each other—what doubt can there be? The *Qunshu Zhiyao* writes "先" as "少" in the annotation "用先识," which is closer to the original. The *Shiwen* glosses: "擿 is pronounced *zhí* (陟革切)."

Confucius, returning from Wei to Lu, halted his carriage at the bridge over the Yellow River and gazed upon it.

When Duke Wen of Jin went forth to meet the lords, intending to attack Wei, Prince Chu looked up to the sky and laughed. The Prime Minister asked, “Why do you laugh?” He replied, “I laugh at my neighbor, who was escorting his wife back to her family when, on the road, he saw a woman gathering mulberry leaves. Enamored, he spoke to her, yet when he turned to look at his wife, another was beckoning to her as well. I laugh at this.”

The Duke grasped his meaning and called off the attack.

chunks.original_text: 有悬水三十仞，「十」世德堂本作「千」，误。 圜流九十里，释文云：圜与圆同。 鱼鳖弗能游，鼋鼍弗能居，有一丈夫方将厉之。 治要引无「一」字。 释文云：厉，涉水也。 孔子使人并涯止之，曰：治要引无「并涯」二字。 释文云：并，蒲浪切。 涯音崖。 「此悬水三十仞，圜流九十里，鱼鳖弗能游，鼋鼍弗能居也。 治要引无「弗能游」三字。 意者难可以济乎？ 」丈夫不以错意，治要引「错」作「措」。 释文云：错，七故切。 遂度而出。 孔子问之曰：「巧乎？ 有道术乎？ 王叔岷曰：家语致思篇、说苑杂言篇「巧乎」上并有「子」字，文意较完，当从之。 本书黄帝篇「子巧乎！ 有道耶？ 」庄子知北游篇：「子巧与？ 有道与？ 」并与此文例同。 所以能入而出者，何也？ 」丈夫对曰：「始吾之入也，先以忠信； 及吾之出也，又从以忠信。 忠信错吾躯于波流，而吾不敢用私，治要引「错」作「措」。 俞樾曰：「忠信错吾躯于波流」，「忠信」字涉上句衍。 王叔岷曰：俞说是也。 治要引正无「忠信」二字。 所以能入而复出者，以此也。 」孔子谓弟子曰：「二三子识之！ 释文云：识音志。 水且犹可以忠信诚身亲之，而况人乎？ 」〔注〕黄帝篇中已有此章而小不同，所明亦无以异，故不复释其义也。 〔解〕夫忠者同于物，信者无所疑。 同而不疑，不私其己，故能入而复出也。 然则同而不疑，不私其己，知道矣夫！ 黄帝篇中已有此章。 伯峻案：此章专以忠信二字为主，「诚身」二字疑衍。 治要引正无「诚身」二字可证也。 释文云：复，扶又切。 白公问孔子曰：「人可与微言乎？ 」王重民曰：吕览精谕篇、淮南道应篇「问」下并有「于」字，御览五十八引「问」下亦有「于」字，今本脱误。 孔子不应。 〔注〕白公，楚平王之孙，太子建之子也。 其父为费无极所谮，出奔郑，郑人杀之。 胜欲令尹子西司马子期伐郑，许而未行。 晋伐郑，子西子期将救郑。 胜怒曰：郑人在此，雠不远矣。 欲杀子西子期，故问孔子。 孔子知之，故不应。 微言犹密谋也。 〔解〕微言者，密言也，令人不能知也。 白公，楚平王之孙，太子建之子。 建出奔郑，白公欲乱，故孔子不应耳。

A cataract plunges three hundred feet—*Shide Hall*’s edition mistakenly writes "thirty." Its whirling currents span ninety *li*. Fish and soft-shelled turtles cannot swim there; *yuan*-turtles and alligators cannot dwell there. Yet a man was just about to ford it. The *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the word "a." *Shiwen* notes: *厉* means "to wade through water." Confucius sent someone along the bank to stop him—the *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the words "along the bank." *Shiwen* notes: *并* is pronounced *páng*; *涯* sounds like *yá*. "This cataract plunges three hundred feet; its whirling currents span ninety *li*. Fish and soft-shelled turtles cannot swim there; *yuan*-turtles and alligators cannot dwell there. Do you think it can be crossed?" The *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the words "cannot swim." The man did not alter his resolve—the *Qunshu Zhiyao* writes *措* for *错*. *Shiwen* notes: *错* is pronounced *cù*. He then crossed and emerged.

Confucius asked him, "Are you skillful? Do you possess a Daoist technique?" Wang Shumin notes: The *Jia Yu*’s *Zhisi* chapter and the *Shuo Yuan*’s *Zayan* chapter both add the word "you" before "skillful," making the phrasing more complete; this should be followed. This text’s *Huangdi* chapter reads, "Are you skillful? Do you possess the Way?" The *Zhuangzi*’s *Zhi Beiyou* chapter reads, "Are you skillful? Do you possess the Dao?" Both follow the same pattern. "How is it that you were able to enter and emerge?" The man replied, "When I first entered, I relied on loyalty and trust. When I emerged, I again followed loyalty and trust. Loyalty and trust placed my body amidst the waves, and I dared not act on private motives—the *Qunshu Zhiyao* writes *措* for *错*. Yu Yue notes: The phrase "loyalty and trust placed my body amidst the waves" contains a superfluous "loyalty and trust," likely borrowed from the preceding sentence. Wang Shumin notes: Yu Yue’s observation is correct. The *Qunshu Zhiyao* indeed omits the words "loyalty and trust." "Thus I was able to enter and emerge—this is how."

Confucius said to his disciples, "Remember this, all of you!" *Shiwen* notes: *识* is pronounced *zhì*. "If even water can be approached with loyalty, trust, and sincerity, how much more so can people?" The annotation notes: This passage appears in the *Huangdi* chapter with minor differences, but its meaning is not distinct, so its meaning is not re-explained here. The explanation states: Loyalty harmonizes with all things; trust leaves no room for doubt. Harmonizing without doubt and refraining from private motives—this is how one enters and emerges. Thus, to harmonize without doubt and refrain from private motives is to grasp the Dao! This passage also appears in the *Huangdi* chapter. Bo Jun notes: This passage centers on the two words "loyalty" and "trust"; the words "and sincerity" may be superfluous. The *Qunshu Zhiyao* omits the words "and sincerity," confirming this. *Shiwen* notes: *复* is pronounced *fù*.

Lord Bai asked Confucius, "Can one speak with you in secret?" Wang Chongmin notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Jingyu* chapter, the *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter, and the *Taiping Yulan* (chapter 58) all include the word "to" after "asked"—the current text is missing it due to a scribal error. Confucius did not respond. The annotation notes: Lord Bai was the grandson of King Ping of Chu and the son of Crown Prince Jian. His father was slandered by Fei Wuji and fled to Zheng, where the Zheng people killed him. Bai wished to have ministers Zixi and Ziqing attack Zheng, but though they agreed, they did not act. When Jin attacked Zheng, Zixi and Ziqing prepared to aid Zheng. Bai grew angry, saying, "The Zheng people are here—our enemies are not far off!" He wished to kill Zixi and Ziqing, so he questioned Confucius. Confucius, knowing his intent, did not respond. *微言* means "secret plans." The explanation states: *微言* refers to secret speech, which others cannot know. Lord Bai was the grandson of King Ping of Chu and the son of Crown Prince Jian. When Jian fled to Zheng, Lord Bai sought to cause chaos, so Confucius did not respond.

chunks.original_text: 卢文弨曰：注「胜欲令尹子西司马子期伐郑」，「欲」藏本作「报」。 伯峻案：作「报」者误。 史记楚世家云：「白公故以此怨郑，欲伐之」，可证欲字之不误。 吕览精谕篇高诱注作「胜与庶父令尹子西司马子期伐郑，许而未行」。 「与」亦当作「欲」。 张注多用高注，此注亦节略高注之文也。 释文「欲令」作「报令」，云：费，房未切。 胜，诗证切，白公名。 令，郎定切。 白公问曰：「若以石投水，何如？ 」王叔岷曰：「问」字涉上文「白公问孔子曰」而衍。 事类赋七、御览五八、记纂渊海一、天中记九引皆无「问」字。 吕氏春秋精谕篇、淮南道应篇并同。 孔子曰：「吴之善没者能取之。 」〔注〕石之投水则没，喻其微言不可觉； 故孔子答以善没者能得之，明物不可隐者也。 卢文弨曰：注藏本「言」下有「人」字，「不可觉」作「不能觉」。 曰：「若以水投水何如？ 」孔子曰：「淄渑之合，易牙尝而知之。 」〔注〕复为善味者所别也。 〔解〕以石投水，喻迹不可见； 以水投水，喻合不可隐也。 味者分淄渑，不可合也，唯神契理会然后得也。 释文云：淄，侧其切。 渑音乘。 复，扶又切。 别，彼列切。 白公曰：「人固不可与微言乎？ 」「固」北宋本、汪本、四解本作「故」。 王重民曰：道藏白文本、吉府本、淮南道应篇、御览五十八引「故」并作为「固」。 伯峻案：作「固」者是，今正。 孔子曰：「何为不可？ 唯知言之谓者乎！ 〔注〕谓者所以发言之旨趣。 发言之旨趣，则是言之微者。 形之于事，则无所隐。 释文云：趣音趋。 夫知言之谓者：不以言言也。 〔注〕言言则无微隐。 〔解〕夫情生而事彰，味殊而可尝，唯神之无方。 知言之谓者，神会也。 争鱼者濡，逐兽者趋，非乐之也。 〔注〕自然之势自应濡走。 伯峻案：吕览举难篇云：「救溺者濡，追逃者趋。 」释文云：乐音洛。 故至言去言，〔注〕理自明，化自行。 释文云：去，丘吕切。 至为无为。 〔注〕理自成，物自从。 夫浅知之所争者末矣。 」〔注〕失本存末，事着而后争解，鲜不及也。 〔解〕鱼在于水，争之者濡； 兽走于野，逐之者趋，非乐之也，其势使然也。 故至言者不在言，至为者无所为也。 浅智逐末，常失其理。 道之所行，物无不当者矣。 释文云：知音智。 鲜，息浅切白公不得已，遂死于浴室。 〔注〕不知言之所谓，遂便作乱，故及于难。 〔解〕忿而非理，死以快意，下愚之所以乱常也。 俞樾曰：「已」字乃「也」字之误。 淮南子道应篇作「白公不得也」，吕氏春秋精谕篇作「白公弗得也」，并其证也。 张注曰，「不知言之所谓，遂便作乱，故及于难」，正解「不得」之义。 释文云：难，乃旦切。 赵襄子使新稚穆子攻翟，〔注〕穆子，襄子家臣新稚狗也。 翟，鲜虞也。 伯峻案：此事又见晋语九、吕览慎大篇、淮南道应训。 释文云：穆子，晋大夫新稚狗也。 翟音狄。 胜之，释文为句。 取左人中人； 〔注〕左人中人，鲜虞二邑名。 使遽人来谒之。 〔注〕遽，传也。 谒，告也。 〔解〕急来告捷也。 世德堂本无「来」字。 释文云：遽音巨。 传去声。

Lu Wenchao states: The annotation reads "Bai wished to have ministers Zixi and Ziqing attack Zheng," but the *Zangben* edition has "報" (*revenge*) instead of "欲" (*wish*). Bo Jun notes: The version with "報" is incorrect. The *Records of the Grand Historian: House of Chu* states, "Lord Bai harbored this resentment toward Zheng and wished to attack it," which proves that "欲" is not in error. Lüshi Chunqiu’s *Jingyu* chapter, in Gao You’s annotation, reads: "Bai, together with his uncle the Prime Minister Zixi and the Marshal Ziqing, attacked Zheng, agreeing but not acting." Here, "與" (*together with*) should also be "欲" (*wished to*). Zhang’s annotation frequently cites Gao’s, and this note is also an abridgment of Gao’s text.

The *Shiwen* reads "報令" instead of "欲令," and notes: *Fei* is pronounced *fangwei*; *Sheng* (Bai’s given name) is pronounced *shizheng*; *ling* is pronounced *langding*.

Lord Bai asked, "If one casts a stone into water, what then?" Wang Shumin states: The character "問" (*asked*) is superfluous, having been carried over from the earlier passage "Lord Bai asked Confucius." The *Shilei Fu* (Chapter 7), *Taiping Yulan* (Chapter 58), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (Chapter 1), and *Tianzhong Ji* (Chapter 9) all omit the character "問." The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Jingyu* chapter and the *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter likewise omit it.

Confucius said, "A skilled diver from Wu could retrieve it." The annotation explains: A stone cast into water sinks, just as subtle speech cannot be perceived. Thus, Confucius answered that only a skilled diver could retrieve it, illustrating that nothing can remain hidden.

Lu Wenchao states: In the *Zangben* annotation, the character "人" (*person*) appears after "言" (*speech*), and "不可覺" (*cannot be perceived*) is written as "不能覺" (*unable to perceive*).

Lord Bai asked, "If one pours water into water, what then?" Confucius said, "When the waters of the Zi and the Meng rivers mingle, Yi Ya could distinguish them by taste." The annotation explains: Even a master of flavors could tell them apart. The *Jie* states: Casting a stone into water is like traces that cannot be seen; pouring water into water is like blending that cannot be concealed. Flavors, once distinct like the Zi and Meng rivers, cannot be merged—only through profound resonance with principle can one grasp them.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Zi* is pronounced *ceqi*; *Meng* is pronounced *cheng*; *fu* is pronounced *fuyou*; *bie* is pronounced *bili*.

Lord Bai said, "Is it truly impossible to share subtle speech with others?" The Northern Song edition, Wang’s edition, and the *Sijie* edition read "故" (*therefore*) instead of "固" (*truly*). Wang Chongmin states: The *Daozang* unannotated edition, *Jifu* edition, *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter, and *Taiping Yulan* (Chapter 58) all have "固" instead of "故." Bo Jun notes: "固" is correct; the text has been emended accordingly.

Confucius said, "Why would it be impossible? Only one who knows the meaning of speech can do so." The annotation explains: *Wei* (*meaning*) refers to the intent behind speech. The intent behind speech is precisely its subtlety. When manifested in action, nothing remains hidden. The *Shiwen* notes: *Qu* is pronounced *qu*.

"One who knows the meaning of speech does not speak through words." The annotation explains: To speak through words is to lack subtlety or concealment. The *Jie* states: Emotions arise and affairs become evident; flavors differ yet can be tasted—only the boundless spirit can grasp them. One who knows the meaning of speech achieves spiritual resonance. Those who fight over fish get wet; those who chase beasts run—not because they delight in it. The annotation explains: It is the natural course of events that they get wet or run. Bo Jun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Junan* chapter states, "Those who rescue the drowning get wet; those who pursue fugitives run." The *Shiwen* notes: *Le* is pronounced *luo*.

"Thus, the highest speech transcends words." The annotation explains: Principles become clear of themselves; transformation proceeds on its own. The *Shiwen* notes: *Qu* is pronounced *qulv*.

"The highest action is non-action." The annotation explains: Principles fulfill themselves; things follow of their own accord. "What shallow minds contend over is trivial." The annotation explains: Clinging to the superficial while losing the root, they only resolve disputes after matters become evident—rarely do they avoid failure. The *Jie* states: Fish belong in water; those who fight over them get wet. Beasts run in the wild; those who chase them run—not because they delight in it, but because circumstances compel them. Thus, the highest speech does not reside in words, and the highest action requires no doing. Shallow minds pursue trivialities and constantly lose sight of principle. Where the Dao is enacted, all things find their proper place. The *Shiwen* notes: *Zhi* is pronounced *zhi*; *xian* is pronounced *xianqian*.

Lord Bai, unable to restrain himself, died in the bathhouse. The annotation explains: Not understanding the meaning of speech, he proceeded to create chaos and thus met with disaster. The *Jie* states: Acting in blind fury without regard for principle, he died to satisfy his impulses—this is how the foolish disrupt order. Yu Yue states: The character "已" (*already*) is an error for "也" (*indeed*). The *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter reads "白公不得也" (*Lord Bai did not attain it*), and the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Jingyu* chapter reads "白公弗得也" (*Lord Bai could not attain it*), both serving as evidence. Zhang’s annotation, "Not understanding the meaning of speech, he proceeded to create chaos and thus met with disaster," precisely explains the meaning of "不得" (*did not attain*). The *Shiwen* notes: *Nan* is pronounced *nandan*.

Viscount Xiang of Zhao sent Xin Zhi Muzi to attack the Di. The annotation explains: Muzi was Xin Zhi Gou, a household minister of Viscount Xiang. The Di were the Xianyu. Bo Jun notes: This event is also recorded in the *Guoyu* (Chapter 9), the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Shenda* chapter, and the *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter. The *Shiwen* notes: Muzi was Xin Zhi Gou, a grandee of Jin. *Di* is pronounced *di*.

He was victorious, and the *Shiwen* treats this as a complete sentence. He captured the people of Zuoren and Zhongren. The annotation explains: Zuoren and Zhongren were two towns of the Xianyu. He sent a courier to announce the victory. The annotation explains: *Ju* means *transmit*; *ye* means *announce*. The *Jie* states: He hurried to announce the triumph. The *Shide Tang* edition omits the character "來" (*come*). The *Shiwen* notes: *Ju* is pronounced *ju*; *chuan* is the departing tone.
chunks.overlap_context: and Ziqing prepared to aid Zheng. Bai grew angry, saying, "The Zheng people are here—our enemies are not far off!" He wished to kill Zixi and Ziqing, so he questioned Confucius. Confucius, knowing his intent, did not respond. *微言* means "secret plans." The explanation states: *微言* refers to secret speech, which others cannot know. Lord Bai was the grandson of King Ping of Chu and the son of Crown Prince Jian. When Jian fled to Zheng, Lord Bai sought to cause chaos, so Confucius did not respond.

chunks.original_text: 襄子方食而有忧色。 左右曰：「一朝而两城下，此人之所喜也； 今君有忧色。 何也？ 」襄子曰：「夫江河之大也，不过三日； 〔注〕谓潮水有大小。 飘风暴雨不终朝，释文云：飘，符宵切。 日中不须臾。 〔注〕势盛者必退也。 伯峻案：吕览淮南子俱无「不终朝」三字。 梁履绳曰：老子曰，「飘风不终朝，骤雨不终日」，此襄子语义所本。 今赵氏之德行无所施于积，〔注〕无积德而有重功，不可不戒惧也。 俞樾曰：「施」衍字，盖即「于」字之误而复者。 吕氏春秋慎大篇亦有此文，正无「施」字。 王重民曰：俞说是也。 淮南道应篇亦有此文，亦无「施」字。 释文云：行，下孟切。 一朝而两城下，亡其及我哉！ 」〔注〕不忘亡则不亡之也。 〔解〕不能积德累行而以强力下二城。 夫物盛必衰，不亡何待耶？ 故贪不以忻，贤者所以惧。 知苟得之所以惧也，然后能积其德矣。 孔子闻之曰：「赵氏其昌乎！ 夫忧者所以为昌也，〔注〕戒之深也。 喜者所以为亡也。 〔注〕将致矜伐。 胜非其难者也； 持之，其难者也。 伯峻案：吕览高注云：「持犹守」。 贤主以此持胜，故其福及后世。 齐、楚、吴、越皆尝胜矣，然卒取亡焉，梁启超曰：观此语，可见此书必有后人附益。 列子与郑驷阳同时，时吴越虽亡，齐楚固在也。 记楚之亡，虽非秦始皇二十四年以后，亦当在乐毅入临淄、白起入郢后矣。 释文「卒」作「卒然」，云：卒，子律切。 不达乎持胜也。 唯有道之主为能持胜。 」〔注〕胜敌者皆比国，而有以不能持胜，故危亡及之。 〔解〕矜功伐能，所以亡也； 忧得诫强，所以昌也。 贤者以此福及后代，道者以此泽被含生，此之谓持胜。 持胜者，持此诫慎胜彼强梁，唯有道者所能行也。 孔子之劲能拓国门之关，而不肯以力闻。 〔注〕劲，力也。 拓，举也。 孔子能举门关而力名不闻者，不用其力也。 孙诒让曰：左传襄十年：「偪阳人启门，诸侯之士门焉。 县门发，聊人纥抉之以出门者。 」疑流俗传以鄹大夫事为孔子也。 胡怀琛曰：诸子中引此事亦多作孔子。 吕氏春秋慎大览、淮南子道应篇、颜氏家训诫兵篇皆作孔子。 史通雅说上亦然。 校书者多未置辩，惟毕沅校吕氏春秋尝言及焉。 是在当时仲尼父亦通称孔子欤？ 抑相因袭讹误也？ 王重民曰：释文曰，「拓一本作招」，案：作招者是也。 淮南主术篇：「孔子之通智过于苌弘，勇服于孟贲，足蹑郊搜，力招城关，能亦多矣。 」高注曰：「招，举也。 」吕氏春秋慎大篇：「孔子之劲能举国门之关。 」高注曰「以一手捉城门关显而举之。 」「捉」字当是「招」字之误。 此又以「招」释「举」也。 张注：「拓，举也。 」盖「拓」亦「招」字之误，则列子本作「招」明矣。 文选吴都赋注引正作「招」。 意林引作「举」，虽得其义，殆非列子之旧矣。 释文云：劲，居盛切，力也。 拓一本作招。 李善注文选吴都赋曰：「招与翘同。 」淮南子作「杓」。 许慎云：杓，引也。 古者县门下从上杓引之者难也。 墨子为守攻，公输般服，而不肯以兵知。 〔注〕公输般善为攻器，墨子设守能却之，为般所服。 而不称知兵者，不有其能也。 释文云：般音班。 故善持胜者以强为弱。 〔注〕得为攻之母也。
chunks.translated_text:
Viscount Xiang was eating when his countenance turned anxious. His attendants said, "In a single morning, two cities have fallen—this is cause for joy among men. Yet why does my lord wear such a troubled expression?"

Viscount Xiang replied, "The greatness of the Yangtze and Yellow River lasts no more than three days,"—referring to the ebb and flow of their tides. "A whirlwind or torrential rain does not endure the whole morning. The *Shiwen* notes: *piao* is pronounced *fuxiao*. The sun at its zenith does not tarry for even a moment,"—for that which waxes to its fullest must wane. Bo Jun notes: The *Lüshi Chunqiu* and *Huainanzi* both omit the phrase "does not endure the whole morning." Liang Lvsheng said: The *Daodejing* states, "A whirlwind does not last the morning; a sudden rain does not last the day"—this is the source of Viscount Xiang’s meaning.

"Now, the virtue and conduct of the Zhao clan have not been cultivated through accumulation. Without accumulated virtue yet achieving such weighty success, one cannot but be wary. Yu Yue said: The character *shi* (*施*) is superfluous, likely a duplication of the character *yu* (*于*). The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Shenda* chapter also contains this passage, and it indeed lacks the character *shi*. Wang Chongmin said: Yu Yue’s observation is correct. The *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter likewise omits *shi*. The *Shiwen* notes: *xing* is pronounced *xiameng*.

"In a single morning, two cities have fallen—how can ruin not overtake us?"—for he who does not forget ruin will not perish. The annotation explains: Unable to accumulate virtue and deeds, yet by sheer force seizing two cities—when things reach their zenith, they must decline. What awaits but ruin? Thus, the wise do not rejoice in greed, for they know the peril of fleeting gain. Only then can one truly cultivate virtue.

Confucius, hearing of this, said, "The Zhao clan shall flourish! For anxiety is the very means by which they shall prosper"—such deep caution. "Joy is the very means by which they shall perish"—for it leads to arrogance and boasting. Victory is not the difficult part; preserving it is the true challenge. Bo Jun notes: Gao You’s commentary on the *Lüshi Chunqiu* states: *chi* (*持*) means *to preserve*.

"The worthy ruler preserves victory by this means, and thus his blessings extend to later generations. The states of Qi, Chu, Wu, and Yue all once achieved victory, yet in the end met their ruin. Liang Qichao said: From this passage, it is evident that this text must contain later interpolations. *Liezi* and Zheng Siyang were contemporaries, yet though Wu and Yue had already fallen, Qi and Chu still existed. The record of Chu’s fall, even if not after the twenty-fourth year of Qin Shi Huang, must have occurred after Yue Yi entered Linzi and Bai Qi entered Ying.

"They failed to grasp how to preserve victory. Only a ruler who embodies the Way can truly preserve it."—for all who conquer their rivals are but peer states, and those who cannot preserve victory bring peril and ruin upon themselves.

The annotation explains: Pride in merit and boasting of ability lead to ruin; anxiety over gain and caution against strength lead to prosperity. The worthy ensure blessings for later generations by this means, and those who follow the Way extend their beneficence to all living beings—this is what it means to preserve victory. To preserve victory is to uphold this caution and vigilance against the arrogance of strength, a path only the man of the Way can tread.

Confucius possessed such strength that he could lift the crossbar of a city gate, yet he refused to be known for his power. The annotation explains: *Jin* means *strength*; *tuo* means *to lift*. Though Confucius could raise the gate’s crossbar, he did not allow his strength to be renowned, for he did not employ it. Sun Yirang said: The *Zuozhuan* (Duke Xiang, Year 10) records: "The people of Biyang opened the gate, and the officers of the feudal lords entered. The gate’s counterweight was released, but Liao Ren of Ju wrenched it open to let them out." It is likely that later traditions conflated the deeds of a Zou grandee with those of Confucius. Hu Huaichen said: Many texts, including the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Shenda* chapter, the *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying* chapter, the *Yanshi Jiaxun*’s *Jiebing* chapter, and the *Shitong*’s *Yashuo* section, all attribute this feat to Confucius. Most collators have not disputed this, though Bi Yuan, in his commentary on the *Lüshi Chunqiu*, once questioned it. Was this because in those times, Confucius the Younger was also commonly called Confucius? Or was it due to repeated transmission errors?

Wang Chongmin said: The *Shiwen* notes, "*Tuo* is also written as *zhao*." The *Huainanzi*’s *Zhushu* chapter states: "Confucius’ intelligence surpassed that of Chang Hong, his courage rivaled Meng Ben’s, his feet could tread the wilds of Jiao and Sou, and his strength could *zhao* the crossbar of a city gate—his abilities were indeed many." Gao You’s commentary says: "*Zhao* means *to lift*." The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Shenda* chapter reads: "Confucius’ strength could lift the crossbar of a city gate." Gao You’s commentary says: "With one hand, he grasped the city gate’s crossbar and lifted it." The character *zhuo* (*grasp*) is likely a corruption of *zhao*. Here, *zhao* is used to gloss *ju* (*lift*). Zhang’s commentary states: "*Tuo* means *to lift*," but *tuo* is probably also a corruption of *zhao*. Thus, the *Liezi* originally must have read *zhao*. The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on the *Wu Du Fu* directly cites it as *zhao*. The *Yilin* quotes it as *ju* (*lift*), which, while capturing the meaning, likely does not preserve the original text of the *Liezi*.

The *Shiwen* notes: *Jin* is pronounced *jusheng* and means *strength*. *Tuo* is also written as *zhao*. Li Shan’s commentary on the *Wen Xuan*’s *Wu Du Fu* states: "*Zhao* is the same as *qiao*." The *Huainanzi* writes it as *biao*. Xu Shen explains: *Biao* means *to pull*. In ancient times, lifting a city gate’s crossbar from below was difficult.

Mozi, though skilled in defense, caused Gongshu Ban to yield, yet he refused to be known for his military knowledge. The annotation explains: Gongshu Ban excelled in crafting siege engines, but Mozi devised defenses that repelled him, earning Ban’s admiration. Yet Mozi did not claim expertise in warfare, for he did not flaunt his ability. The *Shiwen* notes: *Ban* is pronounced *ban*.

Thus, the one who truly preserves victory turns strength into weakness—for humility is the mother of triumph.

chunks.original_text: 〔解〕夫子之力能举关，墨子之善能制敌，不以力谋显而以道德闻者，善此持胜以强为弱也。 夫艺成者必为人所役，好胜者必遇于强敌； 唯道德仁义者可以役物而兴化者也。 宋人有好行仁义者，释文云：好，呼报切。 三世不懈。 王叔岷曰：记纂渊海五六、事文类聚别集三十、合璧事类续集五五引「三世」并作「三年」释文云：懈，古卖切。 家无故黑牛生白犊，以问孔子。 伯峻案：孔子，淮南子人间训作「先生」，论衡福虚篇作「孔子」。 孔子曰：「此吉祥也，以荐上帝。 」居一年，其父无故而盲。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master’s strength could lift a gate’s crossbar, and Mozi’s skill could subdue enemies, yet neither sought renown through force or strategy but became known for their virtue and power—this is the art of preserving victory by turning strength into weakness.

Those who master skills will inevitably be employed by others, and those who crave triumph will surely encounter stronger foes. Only those who embody virtue, benevolence, and righteousness can command things and inspire transformation.

In Song there was a man who delighted in practicing benevolence and righteousness. Three generations of his family never wavered in this. His household’s black ox unexpectedly bore a white calf, and he inquired of Confucius. Confucius said: “This is an auspicious omen; offer it to the Supreme Lord.” A year later, the man’s father inexplicably went blind.

chunks.original_text: 其牛又复生白犊，释文云：复，扶又切。 其父又复令其子问孔子。 其子曰：「前问之而失明，又何问乎？ 」父曰：「圣人之言先迕后合。 释文云：迕音误。 其事未究，姑复问之。 」其子又复问孔子。 孔子曰：「吉祥也。 」复教以祭。 其子归致命。 其父曰：「行孔子之言也。 」居一年，其子又无故而盲。 其后楚攻宋，围其城； 「围」北宋本作「国」，汪本从之，今从藏本、吉府本、世德堂本订正。 释文云：许慎注淮南子云：楚庄王时围宋九月。 一本作国，非是。 民易子而食之，析骸而炊之； 伯峻案：左传宣公十四年云：「敝邑易子而食，析骸以爨。 」释文云：析音锡。 丁壮者皆乘城而战，死者太半。 秦刻卢解本、世德堂本「太」作「大」。 释文「太」作「大」，云：音泰。 此人以父子有疾皆免。 及围解而疾俱复。 〔注〕此所谓祸福相倚也。 〔解〕夫仁者爱人，义者济物。 三世不息，其于积善深矣。 若有其才则招禄，无其才则致福，此余庆之所锺也。 吉祥之应，为善之征，克全其生而获其利。 积行之报，岂虚言也哉？

The ox once more bore a white calf. His father again instructed his son to inquire of Confucius. The son said: “Last time we asked, you lost your sight—why ask again?” The father replied: “The words of a sage first oppose, then align. The matter remains unresolved; let us ask once more.” The son again questioned Confucius. Confucius said: “It is an auspicious omen.” He again instructed them to make an offering. The son returned and reported this. His father said: “Follow Confucius’s words.”

A year later, the son inexplicably went blind. Later, Chu attacked Song and besieged its city. The people resorted to exchanging children to eat and breaking bones for fuel. The able-bodied all mounted the walls to fight, and more than half perished. This man, with both father and son afflicted by illness, was spared. When the siege lifted, their ailments both recovered.

**[Annotation]** This is what is meant by fortune and misfortune depending on each other.

**[Exegesis]** The benevolent love others; the righteous aid all things. Three generations without ceasing—such accumulation of goodness runs deep. If one possesses the capacity, it draws forth reward; if not, it brings blessing. This is where lingering fortune gathers. The response of auspicious omens is the sign of goodness, preserving life and securing its benefits. Is the recompense of accumulated conduct mere empty words?

chunks.original_text: 王重民曰：御览七百四十引「疾」上有「盲」字。 宋有兰子者〔注〕凡人物不知生出主谓之兰也。 注「主」世德堂本作「者」。 任大桩曰：注「凡人物不知生出者谓之兰也」，「生」字疑「妄」字之讹。 俞樾曰：说文门部：「□，妄入宫掖也，读若阑。 」是兰子之兰即□之引申义。 苏时学曰：兰子义未详，旧注释兰为妄，亦未了了。 今世俗谓无赖子为烂仔，其义疑本于此。 释文云：史记注云：无符传出入为阑。 应劭曰：阑，妄也。 此所谓阑子者，是以技妄游者也。 疑兰字与阑同。 任大桩曰：兰阑古多通用。 汉书息夫躬传：「涕泣流兮萑兰。 」臣瓒曰：「莞兰，泣涕阑干也。 」则兰与阑同。 王莽传：「与牛马同兰。 」师古云：「兰谓遮兰，即牛马兰圈。 」玉篇、广韵阑下训云，「遮也，牢也」，即王莽传注遮兰兰圈之谓也。 后汉书公孙述传：「又造十层赤楼帛兰船。 」注云：「以帛饰其阑槛。 」则阑即兰也。 管子中匡篇：「兰盾鞈革。 」注：「兰即所谓兰锜，兵架也。 」水经注：「县有蜀王兵阑。 」华阳国志：「蜀有兵阑。 」兰盾兰锜即兵阑也。 盖阑多借兰。 列子此文阑之作兰，与诸书训义虽异，而通假则同。 以技干宋元。 王重民曰：类聚六十、御览三百四十四、又四百八十三引「宋元」下并有「君」字。 王叔岷曰：书钞一二二、六帖三三、六一，御览五六九引亦并有「君」字。 事类赋十三引列子传同。 伯峻案：「宋元」当从书钞、御览、类聚诸书所引补「君」字，宋元君疑即褚少孙补史记龟策列传之宋元王。 司马贞索隐称宋元王为宋元君，是其例也。 宋至偃始称王，即为齐所灭，无谥，私谥为康王（国策及吕览淫辞），或献王（荀子），即元君欤？ 钱穆先秦诸子系年考辨宋元王考则谓宋元王为王偃太子，亦是县揣之词。 吕览君守篇，「鲁鄙人遗宋元王闭」，宋元王当与此同。 又宋有元公，平公之子也，非此元君。 释文「技」作「妓」，云：渠绮切。 宋元召而使见。 伯峻案：「元」下疑捝「君」字。 下文皆作「元君」可证。 释文云：见，贤遍切。 其技以双枝，长倍其身，属其，伯峻案：「枝」世德堂本作「技」，御览三百四十四又四百八十三引作「杖」，又五百六十九引作「枝」。 释文云：倍依字。 属音烛。 音胫。 并趋并驰，弄七剑迭而跃之，五剑常在空中。 元君大惊，立赐金帛。 又有兰子又能燕戏者，〔注〕如今之绝倒投狭者。 王重民曰：下「又」字当衍，御览四百八十三引无。 王叔岷曰：六帖三三，御览五六九引亦并无下「又」字。 闻之，复以干元君。 释文云：复，扶又切，下同。 元君大怒曰：「昔有异技干寡人者，〔注〕谓先侨人。 卢文弨曰：郭璞注山海经长股国云，「今伎家乔人盖象此」，侨乔通用。 释文云：侨，音乔，寄也。 技无庸，释文云：为句。 适值寡人有欢心，故赐金帛。 彼必闻此而进复望吾赏。 」拘而拟戮之，北宋本脱「拟」字，汪本从之，今从各本增。 六帖六一引「拘」上有「将」字，御览五六九引「拘」上有「乃」字。 释文云：一本漏拟字。 经月乃放。 〔注〕此技同而时异，则功赏不可预要也。 〔解〕夫积仁义以守道者，福可全也； 恃力技以侥幸，不常禄也。

Wang Chongmin notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (740) includes the character "blind" (盲) before "ailments" (疾).

There was a *lanzi* in Song—
**[Annotation]** Generally, any person or thing whose origin is unknown is called *lan*.

**[Emendation]** The *Shide Tang* edition reads "者" instead of "主" in the annotation.

Ren Dazhuang remarks: In the annotation "凡人物不知生出者谓之兰也," the character "生" is likely a corruption of "妄."

Yu Yue observes: The *Shuowen Jiezi* (Gate Radical) states: "□ means to recklessly enter palace chambers, pronounced like *lan* (阑)." Thus, the *lan* in *lanzi* is an extended sense of □.

Su Shixue says: The meaning of *lanzi* is unclear; the old annotation glosses *lan* as "reckless," but this is also obscure. In modern vernacular, worthless rogues are called *lan zai* (烂仔), and its meaning may derive from this.

The *Shiwen* states: The *Shiji* commentary says: "To enter or exit without a tally is *lan* (阑)." Ying Shao says: "*Lan* means reckless." This so-called *lanzi* refers to those who wander recklessly by means of their skills. It is suspected that *lan* is interchangeable with *lan* (阑).

Ren Dazhuang says: *Lan* (兰) and *lan* (阑) were often used interchangeably in ancient texts. The *Hanshu* (*Biography of Xifu Gong*) states: "Tears flow like *huanlan* (萑兰)."臣瓒 comments: "*Huanlan* means tears streaming down." Thus, *lan* is the same as *lan* (阑). The *Biography of Wang Mang* states: "[They] share the same *lan* (兰) as cattle and horses." Yan Shigu explains: "*Lan* refers to barriers, like the *lan* enclosures for cattle and horses." The * Yupian* and *Guangyun* define *lan* (阑) as "to block" or "to confine," which aligns with Yan Shigu’s note on "barrier enclosures." The *Hou Hanshu* (*Biography of Gongsun Shu*) states: "[He] also built ten-tiered red towers and *bolan* (帛兰) boats." The commentary explains: "[They were] adorned with silk on their railings (*lan* 槛)." Thus, *lan* (阑) is the same as *lan* (兰). The *Guanzi* (*Zhong Kuang*) states: "*Lan* shields and leather armor." The commentary says: "*Lan* refers to what is called *lanqi* (兰锜), a weapon rack." The *Shui Jing Zhu* states: "The county has the *binglan* (兵阑) of the King of Shu." The *Huayang Guozhi* states: "Shu has *binglan* (兵阑)." *Lan* shields and *lanqi* are thus *binglan*. Generally, *lan* (阑) is often borrowed as *lan* (兰).

In this passage of the *Liezi*, *lan* (阑) is written as *lan* (兰). Though the meanings in various texts differ, the interchangeable usage is the same.

He used his skills to seek favor with the Lord of Song Yuan.

Wang Chongmin notes: The *Yiwen Leiju* (60), *Taiping Yulan* (344 and 483) all include the character "Lord" (君) after "Song Yuan."

Wang Shumin says: The *Beitang Shuchao* (122), *Yiwen Leiju* (33 and 61), and *Taiping Yulan* (569) also include "Lord" (君). The *Shilei Fu* (13) cites the *Liezi* biography in the same way.

Bo Jun notes: "Song Yuan" should follow the *Beitang Shuchao*, *Taiping Yulan*, and *Yiwen Leiju* in adding "Lord" (君). The Lord of Song Yuan may be the same as the King of Song Yuan mentioned in the *Shiji* (*Biographies of Divination and Strategies*), supplemented by Chu Shaosun. Sima Zhen’s *Suoyin* refers to the King of Song Yuan as the Lord of Song Yuan, which serves as a precedent. Song Zhi Yan was the first to declare himself king, but he was soon destroyed by Qi, leaving no posthumous title. His private posthumous title was King Kang (*Zhan Guo Ce* and *Lüshi Chunlan* *Yinci*), or King Xian (*Xunzi*). Could this be the Lord Yuan?

Qian Mu’s *Xian Qin Zhuzixi Nian Kaobian* (*Examination of the King of Song Yuan*) suggests that the King of Song Yuan was the crown prince of King Yan, but this is mere conjecture.

The *Lüshi Chunqiu* (*Jun Shou*) states: "A rustic from Lu sent a *bi* (闭) to the King of Song Yuan," who should be the same as this Lord Yuan. There was also a Lord Yuan of Song, son of Lord Ping, but he is not this Lord Yuan.

The *Shiwen* states: "技" is written as "妓," pronounced *qiyi*.

The Lord of Song Yuan summoned him and had him perform.

Bo Jun notes: The character "Lord" (君) is likely missing after "Yuan." The following text consistently uses "Lord Yuan," which serves as evidence.

The *Shiwen* states: "见" is pronounced *xiàn*.

His skill involved using a pair of staffs, twice the length of his body, attached to his shins.

Bo Jun notes: "枝" in the *Shide Tang* edition is written as "技"; the *Taiping Yulan* (344 and 483) writes it as "杖," and (569) as "枝."

The *Shiwen* states: "倍" follows the standard pronunciation. "属" is pronounced *zhú*. "" is pronounced *jìng*.

He ran and galloped in tandem, juggling seven swords by tossing them in succession, with five swords always in the air. The Lord of Song Yuan was greatly astonished and immediately bestowed gold and silk upon him.

There was another *lanzi* skilled in *yanxi*—
**[Annotation]** Like today’s acrobats who perform daring feats in narrow spaces.

Wang Chongmin notes: The second "又" is likely a superfluous character; the *Taiping Yulan* (483) omits it.

Wang Shumin says: The *Yiwen Leiju* (33) and *Taiping Yulan* (569) also omit the second "又."

Upon hearing of this, he also sought favor with the Lord of Song Yuan.

The *Shiwen* states: "复" is pronounced *fù*, the same below.

The Lord of Song Yuan grew furious and said: "In the past, there was one with extraordinary skills who sought my favor—
**[Annotation]** Referring to the earlier performer.

Lu Wenchang notes: Guo Pu’s commentary on the *Shan Hai Jing* (*Land of Long-Legged People*) states: "Today’s acrobats who perform as *qiaoren* (乔人) likely imitate this." *Qiao* (侨) and *qiao* (乔) are interchangeable.

The *Shiwen* states: "侨" is pronounced *qiáo*, meaning "to lodge."

—whose skills were of no use. **[Annotation]** End of sentence. It just so happened that I was in high spirits, so I bestowed gold and silk upon him. He must have heard of this and come again, hoping for my reward."

He was detained and nearly executed. The Northern Song edition omits the character "拟," and Wang’s edition follows it; this character is now restored from other editions.

The *Yiwen Leiju* (61) includes "将" before "拘," and the *Taiping Yulan* (569) includes "乃" before "拘."

The *Shiwen* states: One edition omits the character "拟."

After a month, he was released.

**[Annotation]** Though the skills were the same, the timing differed, so rewards and merits cannot be demanded in advance.

**[Exegesis]** Those who accumulate benevolence and righteousness to uphold the Dao may preserve their fortune; those who rely on strength and skill for luck will not enjoy lasting prosperity.

**[Exegesis]** The benevolent love others; the righteous aid all things. Three generations without ceasing—such accumulation of goodness runs deep. If one possesses the capacity, it draws forth reward; if not, it brings blessing. This is where lingering fortune gathers. The response of auspicious omens is the sign of goodness, preserving life and securing its benefits. Is the recompense of accumulated conduct mere empty words?

chunks.original_text: 列子两举其事，以彰德行之为益耳。 释文「预要」作「豫要」，云：要，一遥切。 秦穆公谓伯乐曰：「子之年长矣，〔注〕伯乐，善相马者。 释文云：长，张丈切。 相，息亮切，下同。 子姓有可使求马者乎？ 」〔注〕问伯乐之种姓有能相马继乐者不。 孙诒让曰：特牲馈食礼云：「子姓兄弟如主人之服。 」郑注云：「所祭者之子孙。 言子姓者，子之所生。 」丧大记云：「卿大夫父兄子姓立于东方。 」注云：「子姓谓众子孙也。 」姓之言生也。 国语楚语：「帅其子姓。 」韦注云：「众子姓，同姓也。 」伯乐对曰：「良马可形容筋骨相也。 〔注〕马之良者可以形骨取也。 王重民曰； 类聚九十三引「可」下有「以」字，是也。 淮南道应篇同。 释文云：筋音斤。 天下之马者，若灭若没，若亡若失。 〔注〕天下之绝伦者，不于形骨毛色中求，故仿佛恍惚，若存若亡，难得知也。 释文云：仿佛上音昉，下芳味切。 慌惚音怳忽。 若此者绝尘弭□。 〔注〕言迅速之极。 释文云：弭，亡尔切。 □，迹也，一本作彻。 臣之子皆下才也，汪莱曰：据下卢解「子姓者子弟之同姓者也」，则「臣之子」下脱「姓」字。 伯峻案：淮南子道应训「臣之子」下亦无「姓」字，汪说未谛。 可告以良马，不可告以天下之马也。 臣有所与共担纆薪菜者，〔注〕负索薪菜，盖贱役者。 「纆」各本皆作「缠」。 王念孙曰：「缠」字之义诸书或训为绕（说文），或训为束（广雅），无训为索者，「缠」当为「纆」字之误也。 说文作□，云：索也。 字或作纆，坎上六：「系用徽纆。 」马融曰：「徽纆，索也。 」刘表曰：「三股曰徽，两股曰纆。 」盖世人多见缠，少见纆，故传写多误耳。 唯道藏本列子释文作纆，音墨，足证今本之误。 朱珔曰：哀十四年公羊传，「然则孰狩之，薪采者之。 」大雅毛传「刍荛，薪采者。 」「薪采」即「采薪」，采或作菜。 列子「担缠薪菜」。 俞樾曰：「共」乃「供」之字。 释文一作供，是也。 盖担缠薪菜皆此人供之耳。 「担缠薪菜」是两事，担缠者，负荷什物； 薪菜者，以给炊也。 缠乃纆字之误。 菜当作采，古字通用。 释文云：共，同也，一本作供。 担，丁甘切。 纆音墨。 有九方皋，淮南子及吕览观表篇作「九方堙」。 胡怀琛曰：九方，姓； 皋，名。 庄子有九方歅。 通志谓九方皋、九方歅是一个人。 余窃谓九与鬼声近通用。 史记殷本纪：「以西伯、九侯、鄂侯三公」，徐广注：「一作鬼侯」，是其证。 然则九方即殷时鬼方，以地为姓也。 皋、歅是否一人，尚待考。 伯峻案：文选张协七命「方堙不能睹其若灭」，李善注引吕氏春秋，谓景阳用吕览也。 王叔岷曰：淮南道应篇「九」上无「有」字。 此文「有」字疑涉上「有」字而衍。 艺文类聚九三、事类赋二一、御览八九六、记纂渊海九八、事文类聚后集三八引「九」上皆无「有」字。 释文云：皋音高。 此其于马非臣之下也。 「此」各本作「比」，道藏白文本、林希逸本、元本、世德堂本作「此」，淮南子亦作「此」。 卢文弨曰：比，发语辞。 孟子，「比天之所以与我者」，贾谊，「比物此志也」，皆同。 伯峻案：卢说不可信。 孟子之比训皆，贾谊传之比物，犹比类也（从王先谦汉书补注说）。

Liezi recounts these two episodes to illustrate the benefits of virtue and conduct.

**[Annotation]** The *Shiwen* renders "预要" as "豫要," noting: "要, read as *yāo* (遥切)."

Duke Mu of Qin said to Bo Le, "You are advanced in years.
**[Annotation]** Bo Le was skilled in evaluating horses.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: "长, read as *zhǎng* (张丈切)." "相, read as *xiàng* (息亮切), same below."

Is there anyone among your kinsmen who can be sent to seek horses?"
**[Annotation]** The question asks whether any of Bo Le’s lineage possesses the ability to evaluate horses and succeed him.
**[Annotation]** Sun Yirang notes: The *Te Sheng Kui Shi Li* states, "The sons and grandsons of the deceased wear the same mourning attire as the host." Zheng Xuan’s commentary explains: "The term *zi xing* refers to the descendants of the one being sacrificed. The phrase means 'those born of the son.'" The *Sang Da Ji* records, "Ministers, great officers, uncles, brothers, and *zi xing* stand to the east." The commentary explains: "*Zi xing* refers to all descendants." *Xing* means "born." The *Guoyu: Chu Yu* states, "Leading their *zi xing*," with Wei Zhao’s commentary: "*Zi xing* refers to those of the same lineage."

Bo Le replied, "A fine horse can be discerned by its form, appearance, sinews, and bones.
**[Annotation]** A superior horse can be identified by its physical structure.
**[Annotation]** Wang Chongmin notes: The *Yiwen Leiju* (93) includes the character "以" after "可," which is correct. The *Huainanzi: Daoying* chapter concurs.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: "筋, pronounced *jīn* (斤)."

As for the horse of all under heaven, it is as if vanished, as if concealed, as if lost, as if gone.
**[Annotation]** The peerless horse of the world cannot be sought in form, bones, or coat; thus, it appears indistinct, as if present yet absent, difficult to recognize.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: "仿佛, *fǎng fú* (昉芳味切)." "恍惚, *huǎng hū* (怳忽)."

Such a horse leaves no dust nor track.
**[Annotation]** This describes its extreme swiftness.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: "弭, pronounced *mǐ* (亡尔切)." "□, meaning 'track,' also written as 彻 in one edition."

My sons are all of inferior talent. Wang Lai notes: Based on Lu’s explanation below—"*zi xing* refers to those of the same lineage among younger generations"—the character "姓" is missing after "臣之子." Yang Bojun counters: The *Huainanzi: Daoying* chapter also omits "姓" after "臣之子," so Wang’s claim is unfounded.

I can instruct them in identifying fine horses, but not in recognizing the horse of all under heaven. I have one with whom I share the task of carrying ropes and gathering firewood and greens.
**[Annotation]** This refers to one who carries ropes and collects firewood and greens, likely a menial laborer. All editions write "缠," but Wang Niansun argues: The character "缠" is glossed in various texts as "winding" (*Shuowen*) or "binding" (*Guangya*), but never as "rope." It should be "纆," a character for "rope" in the *Shuowen* (written as □), sometimes appearing as "纆." The *Yijing*, *Kan* hexagram, line six, states: "系用徽纆." Ma Rong explains: "徽纆 means rope." Liu Biao adds: "Three strands make a *hui*; two strands make a *mo*." Most people are familiar with "缠" but not "纆," leading to frequent transcription errors. Only the *Daozang* edition of the *Liezi Shiwen* writes "纆," pronounced *mò* (墨), confirming the error in current editions.
**[Annotation]** Zhu Huan notes: The *Gongyang Zhuan* (Year 14 of Duke Ai) states, "Then who hunts? The gatherers of firewood." The *Mao Commentary* on the *Odes* (*Daya*) explains: "*Chu rao* refers to gatherers of firewood." "*Chu rao*" is synonymous with "*cai xin*" (gathering firewood); "*cai*" may also be written as "*cài*."
**[Annotation]** Yu Yue argues: "共" is a miswriting of "供." The *Shiwen* includes an alternate reading as "供," which is correct. The phrase likely means this person supplies both carrying ropes and gathering firewood. "担缠薪菜" describes two tasks: "担缠" refers to carrying goods, while "薪菜" refers to gathering fuel for cooking. "缠" is a miswriting of "纆," and "菜" should be "采," as the characters were interchangeable in ancient times.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: "共, meaning 'together,' also written as 供." "担, pronounced *dān* (丁甘切)." "纆, pronounced *mò* (墨)."

There is one named Jiu Fang Gao." The *Huainanzi* and *Lüshi Chunqiu: Guan Biao* chapter write this as "Jiu Fang Yin."
**[Annotation]** Hu Huaichen notes: "Jiu Fang" is the surname; "Gao" is the given name. The *Zhuangzi* mentions Jiu Fang Yin. The *Tongzhi* claims Jiu Fang Gao and Jiu Fang Yin are the same person. I humbly suggest that "jiu" and "gui" are phonetically close and interchangeable. The *Records of the Grand Historian: Yin Benji* states: "With the Three Dukes—Xibo, Jiuhou, and Ehou," where Xu Guang’s commentary notes: "One version writes 'Guihou,'" providing evidence. Thus, "Jiu Fang" may derive from the Shang-era Guifang, taking the region as their surname. Whether Gao and Yin are the same person requires further investigation.
**[Annotation]** Yang Bojun notes: The *Wen Xuan: Zhang Xie’s Seven Commands* cites the *Lüshi Chunqiu*, referring to Jing Yang’s use of the *Lüshi Chunqiu*.
**[Annotation]** Wang Shumin notes: The *Huainanzi: Daoying* chapter omits the character "有" before "九." This "有" may be a superfluous interpolation from the preceding "有." The *Yiwen Leiju* (93), *Shilei Fu* (21), *Taiping Yulan* (896), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (98), and *Shiwen Leiju: Houji* (38) all omit "有" before "九."
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: "皋, pronounced *gāo* (高)."

In evaluating horses, he is not beneath me."
**[Annotation]** All editions write "比," but the *Daozang* unannotated edition, Lin Xiyi’s edition, Yuan edition, and Shide Hall edition write "此," as does the *Huainanzi*. Lu Wenchang argues: "比" is a particle introducing speech. The *Mencius* states, "比 the gifts bestowed by Heaven upon me," and Jia Yi writes, "比物此志," both examples of this usage.
**[Annotation]** Yang Bojun counters: Lu’s argument is unconvincing. In the *Mencius*, "比" means "all," while in Jia Yi’s *Biography*, "比物" means "to categorize" (following Wang Xianqian’s *Hanshu Buzhu*).

After a month, he was released.

**[Annotation]** Though the skills were the same, the timing differed, so rewards and merits cannot be demanded in advance.

**[Exegesis]** Those who accumulate benevolence and righteousness to uphold the Dao may preserve their fortune; those who rely on strength and skill for luck will not enjoy lasting prosperity.

chunks.original_text: 比字不能用为发语辞。 且孟子之「比」今本多作「此」，贾谊传之「比」，新书作「此」，可见古书「比」「此」二字常以形近致混。 此处当作「此」，不当作「比」，今依道藏白文本订正。 释文云：一本作比。 请见之。 」〔注〕非臣之下言有过于己。 〔解〕担缠薪菜者，贱役者也。 子姓者，子弟之同姓者也。 释文云：过，古卧切。 见，贤遍切，下同。 穆公见之，使行求马。 三月而反报曰：「已得之矣，在沙丘。 」〔注〕地名。 穆公曰：「何马也？ 」对曰：「牝而黄。 」释文云：牝，频忍切。 使人往取之，牡而骊。 释文云：牡，牟后切。 骊，力移切。 穆公不说，释文云：说音悦。 召伯乐而谓之曰：「败矣，子所使求马者！ 〔注〕谓九方皋。 王叔岷曰：艺文类聚九三、事类赋二一、御览八九六、记纂渊海九八、事文类聚后集三八引「子」下并有「之」字，淮南道应篇同，当从之。 色物、牝牡尚弗能知，卢文弨云：「色物」御览八百九十六引作「物色」。 伯峻案：「色」，淮南子道应训作「毛」，当从之。 毛，纯色； 物，杂色，详杨树达积微居小学述林释物。 又何马之能知也？ 」伯乐喟然太息曰：「一至于此乎？
chunks.translated_text:
The character *bi* (比) cannot serve as an introductory particle. Moreover, in the *Mencius*, the character *bi* (比) is often written as *ci* (此) in modern editions, and in Jia Yi’s *Biography*, the *bi* (比) in "比物" appears as *ci* (此) in the *Xinshu*. This shows that in ancient texts, *bi* (比) and *ci* (此) were frequently confused due to their graphic similarity. Here, it should read *ci* (此), not *bi* (比), and we follow the *Daozang* unannotated edition in emending it.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: "One edition writes *bi* (比)."

"[He is] not beneath me" means [the horse] surpasses oneself.
**[Annotation]** Those who carry firewood and gather vegetables are menial laborers. *Zixing* refers to those of the same clan as one’s descendants.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: *guo* (过), pronounced *gǔ* (古卧切); *jian* (见), pronounced *xiàn* (贤遍切), same below.

Duke Mu saw him and sent him to seek a horse. After three months, he returned and reported: "I have found it; it is in Shaqiu."
**[Annotation]** A place name.

Duke Mu asked: "What kind of horse is it?"
He replied: "A yellow mare."
When someone was sent to retrieve it, it proved to be a black stallion. Duke Mu was displeased.
**[Annotation]** *Shiwen* notes: *shuō* (说), pronounced *yuè* (悦).

He summoned Bo Le and said to him: "You have failed, the one you sent to seek a horse!
**[Annotation]** Referring to Jiu Fang Gao.
**[Annotation]** Wang Shu-min notes: The *Yiwen Leiju* (93), *Shilei Fu* (21), *Taiping Yulan* (896), *Jizuan Yuanhai* (98), and *Shiwen Leiju: Houji* (38) all include "之" after "子." The *Huainanzi: Daoying Xun* does as well; this should be followed.

He cannot even discern color and sex—
**[Annotation]** Lu Wenchang notes: The *Taiping Yulan* (896) writes "物色" for "色物."
**[Annotation]** Yang Bojun notes: In the *Huainanzi: Daoying Xun*, "色" appears as "毛." This should be followed. *Mao* refers to pure color; *wu* (物), to mixed color. See Yang Shuda’s *Jiwei Ju Xiaoxue Shulin: Shiwu* for details.

—how could he know anything of horses?"
Bo Le sighed deeply and said: "Has it truly come to this?"

g* unannotated edition, Lin Xiyi’s edition, Yuan edition, and Shide Hall edition write "此," as does the *Huainanzi*. Lu Wenchang argues: "比" is a particle introducing speech. The *Mencius* states, "比 the gifts bestowed by Heaven upon me," and Jia Yi writes, "比物此志," both examples of this usage.
**[Annotation]** Yang Bojun counters: Lu’s argument is unconvincing. In the *Mencius*, "比" means "all," while in Jia Yi’s *Biography*, "比物" means "to categorize" (following Wang Xianqian’s *Hanshu Buzhu*).

chunks.original_text: 是乃其所以千万臣而无数者也。 〔注〕言其相马之妙乃如此也，是以胜臣千万而不可量。 〔解〕皋之相马，相其神，不相其形也。 形者，常人之所辩也。 伯乐叹其忘形而得神，用心一至于此，自以为不及皋之无数倍也。 故穆公以为败，伯乐以为能也。 若皋之所观天机也，〔注〕天机，形骨之表所以使蹄足者； 得之于心，不显其见。 得其精而忘其粗，北宋本、汪本、四解本无「而」字，御览八百九十六、类聚九十三引同，今从道藏白文本、林希逸本、吉府本、世德堂本增。 艺文类聚九三、埤雅十五、事文类聚后集三八、韵府群玉三、天中记五五、经济类篇九八引并有「而」字。 释文云：粗与鹿同。 在其内而忘其外； 〔注〕精内谓天机，粗外谓牝牡毛色。 许维遹曰：在犹察也。 见其所见，〔注〕所见者，唯天机也。 不见其所不见； 〔注〕所不见，毛色牝牡也视其所视，〔注〕视所宜视者，不忘其所视。 注藏本「所」上有「其」字。 而遗其所不视。 〔注〕所不应视者，不以经意也。 若皋之相者，乃有贵乎马者也。 」〔注〕言皋之此术岂止于相马而已，神明所得，必有贵于相马者，言其妙也。 「相者」四解本作「相马」。 王重民曰：北宋本、道藏本、吉府本并作「者」，疑作「者」是也。 因上下文诸马字而误。 淮南道应篇作「若彼之所相者乃有贵乎马者」。 马至，果天下之马也。 〔解〕夫形质者，万物之着也； 神气者，无象之微也。 运有形者，无象也； 用无象者，形物也。 终日用之而不知其功，终年运之而不以为劳，知而养之者，道之主也。 皋之见乎所见者以神也。 契其神者而贵于马也，代人皆不知所贵矣。 楚庄王问詹何曰：释文云：詹音占也。 「治国柰何！ 」〔注〕詹何，盖隐者也。 詹何对曰：「臣明于治身而不明于治国也。 」治要引「臣」作「何」，吕览执一篇亦作「何闻为身不闻为国」，淮南道应训「臣」亦作「何」。 楚庄王曰：王叔岷曰：「庄」字衍文。 上文已言楚庄王，此不必更出「庄」字。 治要引正无「庄」字。 淮南道应篇同。 「寡人得奉宗庙社稷，愿学所以守之。 」詹何对曰：「臣未尝闻身治而国乱者也，伯峻案：此两语又见淮南诠言训。 释文云：治，直吏切，国治同。 又未尝闻身乱而国治者也。 故本在身，不敢对以末。 」楚王曰：「善。 」〔解〕损物以厚生，小人之常情也； 损生以利物，好名之诡行也。 安社稷者，后其身也。 善理身者。 国自理之矣。 君者国之主，神者形之主。 理国在乎安君，理身在乎安神。 神安则道崇，道崇则国理。 神者身之本，道者神之功，故不敢以末对。 狐丘丈人谓孙叔敖〔注〕楚大夫也。 伯峻案：说苑敬慎篇载此事，与此异。 释文云：敖，五劳切。 孙叔敖，楚大夫也。 曰：「人有三怨，子之知乎？ 」〔注〕狐丘，邑名。 丈人，长老者。 释文云：长，张丈切。 孙叔敖曰：「何谓也？ 」对曰：「爵高者，人妒之； 官大者，主恶之； 释文云：恶，乌路切。 禄厚者，怨逮之。 」俞樾曰：淮南子道应篇作「禄厚者怨处之」，是也。 「怨处之」谓怨雠之所处也，犹曰为怨府也。 处与妒恶为韵。 若作「逮」，则失其韵矣。 盖由浅人不达处字之义而臆改。 王重民曰：俞说是也，御览四百五十九引「逮」正作「处」。
chunks.translated_text:
This is why his skill surpasses mine by a thousand or ten thousandfold, beyond measure.
**[Annotation]** His art of judging horses is so extraordinary that he surpasses me by an incalculable degree.

**[Exegesis]** Gao observes the horse’s spirit, not its form. Form is what ordinary people discern. Bo Le sighed in admiration at how he forgot form to grasp the spirit, how his focus had reached such a point—realizing he himself fell short of Gao by an immeasurable margin. Thus, while Duke Mu saw failure, Bo Le saw ability.

What Gao perceived was the *heavenly mechanism*—
**[Annotation]** The *heavenly mechanism* refers to what governs the outward form and bones, enabling movement of hooves and limbs. It is grasped in the mind yet leaves no visible trace.

—capturing its essence while forgetting its coarse aspects.
**[Annotation]** The *Yiwen Leiju* (93), *Peiwen Yunfu* (3), *Tianzhong Ji* (55), *Jingji Leipian* (98), and *Shiwen Leiju: Houji* (38) all include "而" here, as do the *Daozang* unannotated edition, Lin Xiyi’s edition, Jifu edition, and Shidetang edition. The *Shiwen Yuelu* notes: *Cu* (coarse) is pronounced like *lu* (deer).

He saw what lay within while forgetting what lay without—
**[Annotation]** The *inner essence* refers to the *heavenly mechanism*; the *outer coarse* refers to sex and coat color.

Xu Weiyu notes: *Zai* (在) here means "to examine."

—seeing what should be seen,
**[Annotation]** What should be seen is only the *heavenly mechanism.*

—and not seeing what should not be seen.
**[Annotation]** What should not be seen includes coat color and sex.

He fixed his gaze on what ought to be gazed upon—
**[Annotation]** The *Zang* edition includes "其" before "所."

—and disregarded what should not be regarded.
**[Annotation]** What should not be regarded is not given deliberate attention.

Such was Gao’s judgment—one that valued what truly mattered in a horse.
**[Annotation]** Gao’s method was not merely about judging horses; what he attained through spiritual insight must hold a value beyond mere horse-judging, for his art was sublime.

**[Annotation]** The *Sijie* edition reads "相马" (judging horses) instead of "相者" (judgment). Wang Chongmin notes: The Northern Song edition, *Daozang* edition, and Jifu edition all read "者," which is likely correct. The error may stem from the repeated use of "马" (horse) in the surrounding text. The *Huainanzi: Daoying Xun* reads: "What he judged held a value beyond mere horses."

The horse arrived and proved to be a steed of the world.
**[Exegesis]** Form and substance are the manifest aspects of the myriad things; spirit and *qi* are the subtle, formless essence. That which operates through form is itself formless; that which employs the formless gives shape to things. Though used all day, its workings go unnoticed; though set in motion year after year, it is not deemed laborious. To know and nurture it is to master the Dao.

What Gao saw in what he saw was the spirit. To align with the spirit is to value what truly matters in a horse—something no one else of his time understood.

King Zhuang of Chu asked Zhan He:
**[Annotation]** The *Shiwen Yuelu* notes: *Zhan* is pronounced like *zhan* (占).

"How should one govern the state?"
**[Annotation]** Zhan He was likely a recluse.

Zhan He replied: "I am skilled in governing the self but unskilled in governing the state."
**[Annotation]** The *Zhiyi* reads "何" (He) instead of "臣" (I). The *Lüshi Chunqiu: Zhiyi* also reads "何闻为身不闻为国" (He has heard of governing the self but not of governing the state), as does the *Huainanzi: Daoying Xun*.

King Zhuang of Chu said:
**[Annotation]** Wang Shumin notes: The character "庄" (Zhuang) is superfluous. Since "King Zhuang of Chu" was already mentioned above, it need not be repeated here. The *Zhiyi* omits it, as does the *Huainanzi: Daoying Xun*.

"I have been entrusted with the ancestral temples and the altars of soil and grain. I wish to learn how to preserve them."

Zhan He replied: "I have never heard of a case where one’s self was well-governed yet the state fell into chaos.
**[Annotation]** These two lines also appear in the *Huainanzi: Quan Yan Xun*. The *Shiwen Yuelu* notes: *Zhi* (治, govern) is pronounced like *zhi* (直吏切); the same applies to *guo zhi* (国治, state governance).

Nor have I ever heard of a case where one’s self was in disorder yet the state was well-governed. Thus, the root lies in the self; I dare not respond with mere branches."

The king said: "Well said."

**[Exegesis]** To diminish things for the sake of enriching life is the common inclination of petty men; to diminish life for the sake of benefiting things is the deceptive conduct of those who crave fame. To secure the altars of the state, one must place the self after. He who governs the self well finds the state governs itself. The ruler is the master of the state; the spirit is the master of the body. Governing the state lies in pacifying the ruler; governing the self lies in pacifying the spirit. When the spirit is at peace, the Dao is exalted; when the Dao is exalted, the state is well-governed. The spirit is the root of the self; the Dao is the function of the spirit. Thus, he dared not respond with mere branches.

The Elder of Huqiu said to Sunshu Ao:
**[Annotation]** A minister of Chu. Yang Bojun notes: The *Shuo Yuan: Jing Shen* records this event differently. The *Shiwen Yuelu* notes: *Ao* (敖) is pronounced like *lao* (五劳切). Sunshu Ao was a minister of Chu.

"Do you know the three things that incur resentment?"
**[Annotation]** Huqiu was a town name. *Zhangren* (丈人) refers to an elder. The *Shiwen Yuelu* notes: *Zhang* (长) is pronounced like *zhang* (张丈切).

Sunshu Ao asked: "What are they?"

The elder replied: "Those with high rank are envied by others; those with great office are resented by their lord;
**[Annotation]** The *Shiwen Yuelu* notes: *Wu* (恶) is pronounced like *wu* (乌路切).

those with generous emoluments are targeted by grievances."
**[Annotation]** Yu Yue notes: The *Huainanzi: Daoying Xun* reads "禄厚者怨处之" (those with generous emoluments are the dwelling place of resentment), which is correct. *Chu* (处) means the dwelling place of enmity, akin to saying "a storehouse of resentment." *Chu* rhymes with *du* (妒, envy) and *wu* (恶, resentment). If written as *dai* (逮), the rhyme is lost—likely a later alteration by someone who misunderstood *chu*. Wang Chongmin notes: Yu Yue’s argument is sound; the *Taiping Yulan* (459) reads "处" instead of "逮."
